site_title: Corporate gifting grows during Covid-19, businesses expect higher sales this Chinese New Year
summary: Corporate gifting has seen a surge in demand during the COVID-19 pandemic, with local gift companies experiencing steady or increased sales since the start of the pandemic. Companies like Noel Gifts, Simply Hamper, and PrintnGift reported higher sales, with Noel Gifts expecting a 5-8% year-on-year increase and Simply Hamper seeing a 10% increase. Consumers are opting for higher-quality and more practical products, such as health-related items and utility-focused gifts. Despite supply chain disruptions and rising costs, businesses are managing to keep prices affordable and are focusing on promoting their festive care packs instead of traditional red packets.

site_title: Legendary Entertainment to get US$760 million infusion from Apollo
summary: Legendary Entertainment, behind films like Dune and Godzilla vs Kong, has received a $760 million investment from Apollo private equity fund. The studio, acquired by China's Dalian Wanda Group in 2016, had explored going public and was attracted by its track record and relationships with top studios and streaming services. Apollo will acquire a significant minority stake, with partners joining the board of directors. This investment is part of recent deals in Hollywood, where backers are betting on content demand as streaming services compete for subscribers.

site_title: US: Stocks end dismal January on positive note
summary: US stocks ended January on a positive note, with the Nasdaq leading the way, up 3.4% for the day and down 9% for the month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.2% and the S&P 500 jumped 1.9%. Despite a dismal start to the month, investors appeared to have returned to the equity market in apparent bargain-hunting. This week's calendar includes key earnings reports and economic data, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Marcel Breuer house demolished on Long Island, angering preservationists
summary: The Marcel Breuer-designed house, "Geller I," was demolished on Long Island in January after preservationists attempted to save it. The 1945 binuclear house, featuring furniture designed by Breuer and a site-specific Jackson Pollock painting, was considered a modernist architectural masterpiece. Despite being eligible for landmark designation, the owners, Shimon and Judy Eckstein, demolished the house within three weeks after being contacted by preservationists. Historians say the loss highlights the vulnerability of modernist architecture due to changing housing market dynamics and lax landmarking rules.

site_title: Indonesia's Bali to open for all international travellers
summary: Indonesia's Bali will open to all international travelers starting February 4, with a reduced 5-day quarantine period for fully vaccinated travelers. This follows a previous 7-day quarantine requirement.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.07% to 27,001.98, and the Topix index rising 1.01% to 1,895.93. Investors are focused on upcoming corporate earnings reports.

site_title: Wheat slides on US weather, reduced fears over Ukraine
summary: US wheat futures fell 3% to their lowest in nearly 2 weeks on forecasts of moisture in the US Plains wheat belt and reduced fears of conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Corn futures retreated, while soybeans reached a 7-month high on expectations of drought-stressed South American harvests shifting demand to the US. Chicago Board of Trade March wheat settled at $7.61-1/4 per bushel, down 25 US cents, while March corn ended at $6.26 a bushel, down 10 cents.

site_title: Chinese New Year looks lucrative for Singapore restaurants
summary: Singapore's restaurants are expecting a lucrative Chinese New Year, despite pandemic restrictions. Sales are projected to increase by 30% from 2021, with some businesses seeing a 10% rise in sales compared to pre-pandemic levels. Online orders and virtual celebrations are driving growth, with food-delivery platform Oddle seeing double the delivery sales in Singapore this Chinese New Year. High-end hotels are also experiencing strong demand for in-person bookings.

site_title: Labour MP Desmond Choo to join EDB's board
summary: Labour MP Desmond Choo has been appointed to the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) board, effective Feb 1. He replaces Patrick Tay Teck Guan and Tan Hooi Ling, who are stepping down. Choo, also the assistant secretary-general of the National Trades Union Congress, brings experience from various labour unions and companies. The changes take effect on Jan 31.

site_title: Cautious optimism about Singapore's economy in 2022 despite uncertainty over Omicron and China: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 3-5% in 2022, despite uncertainty from the Omicron variant and China's zero-Covid-19 policy, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. He expressed cautious optimism, citing the strong American and European economies, as well as progress in reopening borders in Southeast Asia. However, he acknowledged that certain sectors, such as food and beverage, tourism, and entertainment, still face difficulties.

site_title: Business lobby expects uptick in India consumption by next quarter
summary: India's consumption demand is expected to pick up by the first quarter of the financial year, driven by measures to boost economic growth in the upcoming federal budget. The Confederation of Indian Industry predicts a 14% year-on-year increase in public expenditure, which could ignite the sector where demand is weak. With supply-chain disruptions expected to ease, manufacturing is expected to receive a further push. The industry lobby group is anticipating relief measures in the budget, which will likely boost spending and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Inflation and deficits don't dim the appeal of US bonds
summary: US government bond yields remain near two-year highs despite inflation concerns, with the 10-year Treasury note yield at 1.8%. Low yields persist due to long-term inflation expectations, a large surge in global wealth, and the desire of retiring baby boomers to protect their nest eggs. The growing demand for government debt securities has kept borrowing costs low, with the US national debt reaching 120% of GDP. Analysts believe that the low yields provide a "perfect time" for governments to issue bonds and engage in long-term investment plans.

site_title: Top oil producers to meet amid record crude prices
summary: The world's top oil-producing countries, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, will meet to discuss output increases amid record crude prices. Crude prices have reached seven-year highs due to geopolitical tensions, with Brent oil surpassing $90 per barrel. Analysts expect the group to continue boosting output by 400,000 barrels per day in March, but fears of an imminent Russian invasion of Ukraine could lead to further price increases. The meeting comes as Opec nations struggle to meet production targets, adding to upward pressure on prices.

site_title: China faces Olympic-sized sporting challenge
summary: China is facing significant challenges ahead of the Beijing Winter Olympics, which begin on February 4, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and diplomatic boycott by Western countries. The country has reported a surge in infections, with 34 new cases detected among Olympics-related personnel, and has enforced stringent measures to curb the spread. The event also raises concerns about human rights in Xinjiang, prompting a diplomatic boycott by multiple countries. The challenges facing the Beijing Games are not unique, as previous events such as the 2016 Rio Olympics and 2008 Beijing Summer Olympics have also been plagued by similar issues.

site_title: Fed unwind will impact Asia differently this time
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates eight times over the next two years and reduce its bond holdings by $1.5 trillion, potentially impacting emerging markets differently than in the 2013 "taper tantrum." Unlike previous periods, emerging market assets have seen little inflow of capital, with the exception of China, driven by increased market access and global indices inclusion. Instead, Fed liquidity has flowed into emerging markets through international trade flows, particularly in Asia, where exports have been strongly correlated with the Fed's balance sheet growth.

site_title: China bans Australian meatworks at centre of Covid outbreak
summary: China has temporarily banned meat from a South Australian meatworks, Teys Australia's Naracoorte facility, following a Covid-19 outbreak at the facility. The suspension, effective January 29, comes as China increases scrutiny of overseas processing plants. The decision was made without citing a specific reason, but follows a controversy where workers were told to come to work even if infected with the virus. The company plans to work with regulatory bodies to achieve reinstatement of the facility's access to China. This is the latest in a string of import halts from Australia in two years.

site_title: Oil climbs on lower supply and post-pandemic recovery
summary: Oil prices climbed on Tuesday, hovering near seven-year highs, due to a limited production increase by major oil producers and a solid post-pandemic recovery in fuel demand. Brent crude rose 0.4% to $89.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.4% to $88.47 a barrel. Market analysts expect Opec+ to keep to its policy of gradual production increases, with some predicting a potential increase in Saudi output outside the Opec framework. The current price rally is driven by concerns over supply shortages and geopolitical tensions, particularly between Russia and the West.

site_title: Business confidence for Singapore manufacturing, services firms ease for next 6 months
summary: Singapore business optimism remains positive, with manufacturers' and services firms showing decreased confidence for the next 6 months. Manufacturers have a net weighted balance of 8% optimism, down from 16% in the previous poll, while services firms have 14%, down from 19%. This indicates a slight easing of business confidence into the new year.

site_title: Asia: China, South Korea, Taiwan markets closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in China, South Korea, and Taiwan are closed on Monday for public holidays. In other news, Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US despite tariff uncertainty. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty. A Dutch firm is set to privatise Grand Venture Technology at $0.94 per share.

site_title: CDC warns against travel to Mexico, Brazil, Singapore over Covid-19
summary: The US CDC advises against travel to 12 countries, including Mexico, Brazil, and Singapore, due to high coronavirus infection rates. The CDC now lists nearly 130 countries as "Level Four: Very High" and 53 as "Level Three: High." The US State Department also raised travel warnings for some of these countries to "Level 4: Do Not Travel." This decision comes as the US government has added over 60 countries to its list of places to avoid since mid-December.

site_title: STI flattish with 0.1% rise on muted trading on Chinese New Year eve
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,249.59 points on the eve of Chinese New Year, with 13 gainers and 12 decliners. The US Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike possibility was shrugged off by Asian markets. Meanwhile, local bank OCBC closed up 0.4% after announcing goodwill payouts to phishing victims, and N2IU hit its 52-week low despite a 5.6% year-on-year rise in net property income.

site_title: Ryanair posts Q3 loss of 96m euros, expects Q4 to be 'hugely uncertain'
summary: Ryanair reported a Q3 loss of 96 million euros, in line with analyst estimates, and expects Q4 to be "hugely uncertain" due to late and close-in bookings. The airline reiterated its forecast loss for the full year, ranging from 250-450 million euros, and expects to fly under 100 million passengers. CEO Michael O'Leary cited ongoing Covid disruptions as a major concern, despite recent improvements in bookings.

site_title: Macau Legend plunges 30% after CEO arrested in junket clampdown
summary: Shares of Macau Legend Development plummeted 30% after CEO Weng Lin Chan was arrested on money laundering charges. The arrest is part of a clampdown in Macau's gaming market. Galaxy Entertainment Group and Wynn Macau also fell, with Galaxy Entertainment Group dropping 2% and Wynn Macau 2.5%. The arrest has raised concerns about the future of the gaming industry in Macau, the world's largest gaming market.

site_title: NextEnergy Capital raises record US$896m for solar infrastructure fund
summary: NextEnergy Capital has raised a record US$896 million for its NextPower III ESG fund, focused on solar infrastructure investments in OECD countries. The fund's hard close surpasses its target of US$750 million, driven by growing demand for sustainable energy investments. With an installed capacity of 742 megawatts across 23 projects, the fund aims to replace the annual fossil fuel-based energy needs of 1.3 million homes. Investors include pension schemes, insurance companies, and family offices from nine countries, supporting the global transition to renewable energy.

site_title: Land & Buildings hedge fund willing to offer US$4.5b for LXP Reit
summary: Land & Buildings Investment Management has expressed interest in acquiring LXP Industrial Trust for US$4.5 billion, offering US$16 per share in cash. The proposal, valued at US$6 billion, includes LXP's debt, and Land & Buildings is confident in securing necessary funds from financial institutions. LXP plans to review the proposal with its advisers before deciding next steps. This acquisition would be the latest among leveraged buyouts by activist hedge funds, following a US$13 billion deal for Citrix Systems by Elliott Management's private equity unit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MLT, ComfortDelGro, CLCT, OCBC, GHY, LHN, IHH Healthcare
summary: Key developments in the stock market include: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q3 DPU rose 5.8% year-over-year, while CapitaLand China Trust posted a 35.1% increase in DPU. ComfortDelGro announced a stake sale and delayed its UK acquisition, while OCBC made full goodwill payouts to phishing scam victims. GHY Culture and Media appointed three new directors, LHN submitted a pre-admission notification for an initial public offering, and IHH Healthcare dismissed a US$6.5 billion lawsuit.

site_title: Indonesia's not-so-capital idea
summary: Indonesia is set to become the first 21st-century country to relocate its capital, with the Indonesian House of National Representatives passing legislation to move the nation's capital to Nusantara in East Kalimantan. The move aims to alleviate Jakarta's overcrowding and transform it into a more livable city. However, critics argue that getting the location wrong could spell failure, citing examples of failed capital relocations such as Brasilia, Brazil, and the potential for Nusantara to become a hub for Chinese influence. The $32 billion project has raised concerns about its wisdom, particularly given the ongoing pandemic-induced economic downturn.

site_title: Boeing seals deals with Qatar Airways, launches new cargo plane
summary: Boeing has sealed deals with Qatar Airways worth $27 billion, including the sale of 34 777X freighters and 25 737 MAX planes, marking the largest freighter commitment in Boeing's history. The agreements follow a public feud with Airbus and come as Boeing faces quality control issues and a mixed recovery in commercial aviation. The deals are expected to sustain 35,000 US jobs and bolster suppliers across 38 states, with deliveries starting in 2027.

site_title: Australia: Miners drive shares lower ahead of RBA policy meeting
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Monday, driven down by mining heavyweights Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group, despite rising iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 41.1 points, with BHP Group's unification of its dual listing stricture contributing to the losses. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to end its bond-buying program on Tuesday, but is expected to wait until November before raising interest rates for the first time in over a decade.

site_title: Thailand ready for rush of tourists with quarantine-free visas
summary: Thailand is set to welcome hundreds of thousands of tourists with the launch of a quarantine-free visa program, starting February 2, allowing fully vaccinated visitors of any nationality to enter the country. The program, part of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's "living with the Covid strategy," aims to boost the pandemic-battered economy, with 5 million foreign visitors expected this year, mainly from Europe and the US. The program is expected to attract 200,000-300,000 travelers in February, with potential numbers reaching 9 million if Chinese and Indian tourists return.

site_title: In food world, debate rages about recipe plagiarism
summary: A debate rages in the food world over recipe plagiarism, with pastry chef Nick Malgieri accusing a food blogger of copying his recipe for panettone, a traditional Italian sweet bread. Malgieri discovered the similarities while browsing the blog and immediately recognized the recipe as his own. This incident has sparked a wider conversation about intellectual property in the culinary world, with many chefs and food bloggers sharing their own experiences of recipe plagiarism and the importance of protecting original recipes.

site_title: 759 Covid-19 patients hospitalised in Singapore; 4,241 community cases
summary: Singapore reported 759 Covid-19 hospitalizations, with 64 requiring oxygen support and 10 in the ICU, as of Jan 31. One person died from the virus. Community cases increased by 12, with 4,241 reported, mostly detected by antigen rapid tests. The weekly infection growth rate stands at 1.94. Singapore has detected 352,811 Covid-19 cases with 855 deaths, and 92% of its eligible population has completed the full vaccination regimen.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Asian markets, including China, South Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Malaysia, and Singapore, are closed on February 1 for a public holiday. On July 10, 2025, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the remaining shares of PSC at S$0.40 per share. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging past their previous highs.

site_title: Facebook is not ready for the 2022 election wave
summary: Facebook is not adequately prepared for the 2022 and 2024 election wave, with numerous elections set to take place globally. The company must scale up its efforts to combat misinformation, hate speech, and other issues, requiring significant investments and partnerships. Facebook has made progress in recent years, but its focus on the US has left other countries with inadequate protections. The company must prioritize transparency and hire more staff to handle the increasing number of elections, with estimates suggesting it needs at least 1,000 more full-time employees.

site_title: Wall Street split on number of Fed hikes
summary: Wall Street's major banks disagree on the number and pace of Federal Reserve interest rate hikes after Chair Jerome Powell signaled potential aggressiveness in tackling inflation. Economists and investors are making differing judgments, with some predicting 4-7 quarter-point hikes in 2022. Forecasts vary on the timing and magnitude of the Fed's balance sheet reduction, with some predicting as few as 1 hike in 2022 and others expecting up to 7. Disagreements persist over the future path of monetary policy, with some banks forecasting higher rates and others anticipating more gradual increases.

site_title: Citi whistle blower wants share of US$400 million penalty
summary: A Citigroup employee, Tamika Miller, claims she provided US regulators with information that led to the bank's $400 million fine for risk-management failures. Miller, a former auditor, is seeking a 30% share of the penalty, which could amount to $120 million. The fine was issued by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency in 2020, after the Justice Department declined to pursue the case. Miller sued Citigroup in 2019, alleging fraud and seeking a portion of the settlement under the False Claims Act.

site_title: An army of faceless suits is taking over the US$4 trillion hedge fund world
summary: The US$4 trillion hedge fund industry is shifting towards a new model, with multi-strat funds drawing most of the new money. These funds pool investor money into various trading strategies, executed by an army of traders, and have consistently performed well during market chaos. In contrast, single-strat funds have struggled with success and are often plagued by underperformance. Multi-strats have become the preferred choice for pension funds, foundations, and endowments, willing to pay high fees for diversified investments. The industry is also seeing takeovers and a rise in pass-through fees, which can reach 10% or more on top of incentive fees.

site_title: F&N announces CEO appointment and other leadership changes
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) has appointed Hui Choon Kit as its new CEO, effective February 1, focusing on accelerating the group's growth strategy. Lee Meng Tat is retiring as CEO of non-alcoholic beverages after nearly 7 years, while Edmond Neo is stepping down as CEO of beer to focus on a leadership position in Thai Beverage Public Co. The company also announced leadership changes, including the appointment of Christopher Leong as director of group finance and Samuel Lee as company secretary.

site_title: Pfizer vaccine for children under 5 may be available in US by end-Feb
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech are expected to submit an emergency use authorization request to the US FDA for COVID-19 vaccines for children aged 6 months to 5 years as early as Feb 1. The vaccine could be available in the US by end-February, pending FDA review, with a potential two-shot regimen. This would allow for earlier vaccination of children, potentially reducing the risk of long-term health effects.

site_title: UK businesses scale back pay plans despite higher inflation: Lloyds
summary: UK businesses are scaling back pay rise plans, with 41% expecting a 2% increase, the lowest in five months, amidst rapidly rising costs. Meanwhile, 49% plan to raise prices, up from 45% in December. Hiring intentions are also at a five-month low, but 46% still plan to increase their headcount. The findings, from a Lloyds Bank survey, will influence the Bank of England's decision on a potential rate rise this week.

site_title: Berkshire, SoftBank early Paytm bets sour after stock rout
summary: Paytm's shares have plummeted 58% since its IPO on November 18, valuing its parent company One 97 Communications at $7.8 billion, down from $20 billion. Early investors SoftBank, Berkshire Hathaway, and T Rowe Price are taking losses, with SoftBank's $7 billion valuation and Berkshire's $10 billion valuation now irrelevant. Paytm reported a widening loss of 4.74 billion rupees in the July-to-September quarter, casting doubt on its business model and affecting the prospects for technology firms going public in India.

site_title: European gas demand seen falling this year due to cheaper coal, says IEA
summary: European gas demand is expected to decline by 4.5% this year due to high prices making coal more competitive for power generation, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). Despite this, Asian demand growth could slow to 5% due to high prices and reduced supply. European gas prices are expected to average $26/mmBtu, while Asian LNG prices are expected to average $27/mmBtu, both all-time high annual averages. US gas prices are forecast to average around $4/mmBtu, similar to 2021 levels.

site_title: Blackstone tees up US$11b in fresh capital for Asia deal
summary: Blackstone has raised US$11 billion for its second private-equity fund in Asia, nearly tripling its previous capital raised in 2018. The firm is doubling down on Asia despite risks from inflation and geopolitical tension. Amit Dixit, Asia head of private equity, says the selloff in global markets could present a good time to invest. The fund will focus on transforming traditional businesses into technology-driven companies and invest in healthcare technology, artificial intelligence, and renewable energy. Blackstone is working on 3 advanced deals in Australia, Japan, and India, and is also involved in 8 transactions in Singapore, India, and Australia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.36% or 96.75 points at 26,620.59, and the Topix index down 0.47% or 8.75 points at 1,868.14. The decline follows a rebound on Wall Street, with investors shifting focus to upcoming corporate earnings reports.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by tech, but mark worst month since late-2020
summary: Europe's stocks rose 0.7% on Monday, driven by a 3.5% gain in tech stocks, despite a 3.9% decline in January. The Stoxx 600 marked its worst month since late 2020 due to concerns over policy tightening, inflation, and geopolitical tensions. Technology stocks fell 12% in January, their worst month since the 2008 financial crisis. Energy stocks rose 8.6% in January, while banks added 7.4%. The European Central Bank and Bank of England meetings on Thursday are expected to provide clues to their policy paths.

site_title: Fewer China flights may worsen chip shortage with Shanghai port snarled
summary: China's congestion at the world's biggest port in Shanghai is worsening due to reduced air-cargo capacity. Goods are taking over two months to ship by sea to the US, affecting the semiconductor industry. Air-freight prices could rise by around one-third if disruptions continue, further exacerbating the chip shortage. The situation echoes a previous incident in August last year when Shanghai Pudong International Airport shut its cargo zone due to a COVID-19 outbreak, and is also compounded by trucking snarls in east China. This is likely to raise costs for the semiconductor industry.

site_title: Trends versus tradition
summary: Singaporeans are shifting their Chinese New Year celebrations towards more modern and trendy items, such as health supplements and eco-friendly products, as traditional goods see decreased demand. Retailers report a decrease in sales of traditional festive items like decorations and food. The trend reflects the country's growing focus on sustainability and health awareness.

site_title: From coding farm to VC destination: Vietnam's rapid rise
summary: Vietnam's startup ecosystem has experienced rapid growth in funding, with a hockey stick-shaped increase from US$44 million in 2015 to US$127 million in 2018, and further growth in 2019. The country has minted at least four unicorns, with three focused on the domestic market, and has become a hub for venture capital investment. A confluence of macroeconomic factors, including a young population and high internet penetration, has aided the country's glow-up. Despite a lack of exits from Vietnamese unicorns, investors expect exits to occur within the next year, leading to a continued funding boom.

site_title: IMF, World Bank again postpone annual meeting in Morocco
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank have postponed their annual meetings in Morocco to October 2023, citing ongoing uncertainty over the Covid-19 pandemic. The event, originally set for Morocco in 2020 and 2022, will now take place in Washington in 2022 and Marrakesh in 2023. This marks the third year in a row the meeting has been postponed due to the pandemic.

site_title: A better alternative exists for SMS - if players can be persuaded to use it
summary: The SMS technology, still widely used, has significant security vulnerabilities due to its unencrypted nature and lack of authentication. A more secure standard, RCS (Rich Communications Services), exists but has been slow to gain adoption. Google is a major champion of RCS, offering end-to-end encryption and backwards compatibility with SMS. Despite its advantages, telcos have been reluctant to adopt RCS, likely due to diminishing SMS revenue. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore is considering making SMS sender ID registration mandatory and exploring the use of RCS as an alternative to SMS.

site_title: Thai cafe serves up crypto advice with coffee and cake
summary: A cafe in northeast Thailand, HIP Coffee & Restaurant, has become a hub for cryptocurrency traders, offering investment advice and screens displaying market moves alongside coffee and cake. The cafe's popularity has doubled since its crypto makeover in 2020, with customers seeking alternative investment opportunities in the volatile market. Thailand is set to regulate digital assets as payments, citing potential risks to financial stability. The cafe's manager plans to launch its own cryptocurrency coin and provides free investment consulting, with customers citing the cafe's screens as a valuable resource for analyzing market trends.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.75 points to 1,512.27. Volume reached 1.213 billion lots worth RM1.091 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 451 to 325.

site_title: Macau Legend's shares plunge after CEO is arrested in junket clampdown
summary: Macau Legend's shares plummeted 19% after CEO Chan Weng Lin was arrested in a crackdown on junkets, which drove the city's US$3.5 billion VIP sector. The arrest is part of an unprecedented crackdown on junkets blamed by Beijing for transferring billions of dollars overseas. Macau authorities are overhauling laws to increase oversight and ban junkets sharing revenue with casinos. The move is seen as a death knell for the decades-long operating model, and shares of Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd also fell 2%.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng in JV to provide hospitality management services
summary: CHIP Eng Seng's wholly owned subsidiary CES Hospitality has entered a joint venture with Ariva Hospitality to provide management services to hotels and serviced residences. The JV, CES-Ariva Hospitality, will have a loan facility of up to S$10 million, with CESH owning 70% and Ariva holding 30%. The agreement aims to broaden the income stream and increase recurring income for the group through an "asset-light strategy".

site_title: Analysts see positives for XL Axiata from investment in Link Net
summary: Analysts are positive on XL Axiata's prospects following its acquisition of a 66% stake in Link Net. The deal, valued at 8.72 trillion rupiah, is expected to generate synergies and bring more customers to XL. Analysts UOB Kay Hian and CGS-CIMB predict a positive earnings accretion of 3-9% for XL, with the acquisition positioning the company to capture growth and strengthen its market position. The acquisition is also expected to increase XL's competitiveness and customer base.

site_title: China says average national smog levels down 9.1% in 2021
summary: China reported a 9.1% decline in average national smog levels in 2021, with PM2.5 concentrations dropping to 30 micrograms per cubic meter. This improvement was seen in 339 monitored cities, with the northern region of Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei and the Yangtze river delta manufacturing hub experiencing significant reductions. The decline is attributed to China's efforts to cut coal consumption and improve industrial efficiency. The country's official air quality standard is 35 micrograms, with the World Health Organization recommending levels of just five micrograms.

site_title: Employers turn to youth part-timers, paying more to relieve labour crunch
summary: Singapore employers are turning to youth part-timers to fill labor gaps during the festive period, offering higher pay rates of 5-20% more than the average S$9 per hour. The fourth quarter's hourly rate is around S$10-11, up from the previous year. This move aims to alleviate the labor shortage caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Can Spider-Man: No Way Home overtake Avatar's North American box office record?
summary: Spider-Man: No Way Home is on track to surpass Avatar's North American box office record, currently holding at $760 million. The movie has collected $735 million in the US and Canada, just $25 million shy of the record. With its strong legs and global box office performance, No Way Home is a likely candidate to become the third-highest grossing film of all-time.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: CGS International downgraded Grab to 'hold' citing slowing earnings growth in the second half. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring, with Tan Teck Long taking over. Sats CEO Kerry Mok received a 30.5% pay hike. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Tesla launched in India with a Mumbai event, while Citigroup targets 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices. Chinese banks are struggling due to Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Japan quarterly output gain signals growth return before Omicron; consumer confidence falls in January
summary: Japan's industrial production rebounded 1% in the latest quarter, driven by a bounce back in auto output, signaling a return to economic growth before the Omicron variant's spread. Retail sales increased 2% and auto production rose 12%, but supply chain disruptions and Omicron cases cast a shadow over the economy. Consumer confidence fell by 2.4 points to 36.7, the lowest since August, due to concerns over the jobs market and rising prices. Despite these challenges, manufacturers plan to raise output by 5.2% in January and 2.2% in February.

site_title: Chinese New Year celebrations in pandemic times: Chance to hone virtues like patience, endurance
summary: Singaporeans are celebrating Chinese New Year amidst pandemic restrictions, with a 5-person cap on social gatherings and daily unique household visitors. Despite the challenges, many are making do, with restaurants seeing increased demand for corporate lunches. The government encourages self-restraint and personal responsibility, emphasizing the need to balance individual freedoms with public health concerns. The celebration is seen as a chance to hone virtues like patience, endurance, and consideration, particularly as the Omicron wave continues to spread.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi to go on trial for election fraud on Feb 14
summary: Myanmar's deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi will face a trial for election fraud on February 14, after being accused of influencing the 2020 vote to win a second term. Suu Kyi denies the allegations, which carry a maximum prison term of over three years. The trial is part of a slew of cases against her, including more than a dozen, and comes as the international community criticizes the proceedings as a sham. Suu Kyi has been sentenced to six years in detention so far.

site_title: Buy Tesla as the EV maker 'checks all the boxes': Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse upgraded Tesla's shares to a "buy" recommendation, citing the electric vehicle maker's strong fundamentals and undervalued price. The stock soared 11% after the announcement, with analysts predicting a 9% upside from Monday's close. Tesla's valuation has fallen to its lowest since March 2020, but analysts believe the current pullback creates an opportune entry point to buy. The bank reiterated a price target of $1,025, citing volume growth and sustained margin strength.

site_title: Game of stones: Scottish island sweeps up Olympic curling
summary: A Scottish factory, Kays Curling, has been producing curling stones for over 170 years, using unique granite from the remote island of Ailsa Craig. The stones, made from volcanic rock, are ideal for the sport due to their low water absorption and resistance to heat transfer. The factory will supply stones to the Beijing Winter Olympics, with demand expected to grow following the event. Kays Curling has been providing stones for the Olympics since 1924 and exports to 70 countries, including South America and South Korea.

site_title: Fed unwind will impact Asia differently this time
summary: The Federal Reserve is poised to start raising interest rates and withdrawing liquidity, with 8 expected rate hikes over the next 2 years and a $1.5 trillion reduction in bond holdings by the end of 2023. This move is expected to impact Asia differently than in 2013, when emerging market investors experienced a surge in US treasury yields and capital exodus during the "taper tantrum." The Fed's tightening is likely to have far-reaching consequences for global markets and economies.

site_title: Macau Legend plunges 30% after CEO arrested in junket clampdown
summary: Macau Legend Development plummeted 30% after CEO Weng Lin Chan was arrested in a crackdown on junkets, a key driver of the city's gaming industry. Chan, a 49-year-old shareholder and chairman of Tak Chun Group, is suspected of illegal gambling and money laundering. This arrest follows the detention of Alvin Chau, founder of Suncity Group, two months prior. Macau authorities are overhauling laws to increase oversight and cap the number of licensed junkets, potentially ending the decades-long operating model that relied on junkets to lure gamblers.

site_title: Young lawyers find fulfilment, balance as they strike out on their own
summary: Young lawyers in Singapore, some as young as 29, are striking out on their own to gain more autonomy and fulfillment in their careers. Many left prominent firms to start their own practices, citing the desire to choose their own clients, set their own fees, and structure a sustainable working environment. These solo practitioners report a better work-life balance and greater sense of ownership, with some even pursuing passions outside of law. While starting a boutique practice comes with challenges, many find it rewarding and are encouraging others to explore alternative paths.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge higher in thin trade
summary: Asian share markets edged higher on Monday, driven by a rise in oil prices, despite thin trade conditions during the Chinese New Year holidays. The Bank of England is expected to hike interest rates this week, and markets are pricing in 5 hikes from the Federal Reserve this year. US 10-year Treasury yields surged 27 basis points, bolstering the US dollar and making bonds relatively more attractive. Oil prices near 7-year peaks, exacerbating concerns over tight energy supply.

site_title: US dollar holds near 18-month high ahead of busy central bank week
summary: The US dollar remains near an 18-month high against major currencies, holding at 97.131 on Monday, as investors seek safety amid potential renewed market volatility. The greenback had its best week in 7 months last week, driven by forecasts for US interest rate hikes and a sell-off in riskier assets. Key central bank meetings this week, including the Australian, UK, and European central banks, may influence market sentiment, with some analysts predicting rate hikes and others warning of shrinking ECB's action window.

site_title: CNY celebrations in pandemic times: Chance to hone virtues
summary: Singaporeans are celebrating Chinese New Year amidst the ongoing pandemic, with a five-person cap on social gatherings and daily unique household visitors. Despite the restrictions, people are making do, with restaurants booking up for reunion dinners and corporate lunches. The government encourages self-restraint and personal responsibility, urging families to abide by the curbs to avoid a severe healthcare crisis. The festive season is seen as a chance to hone virtues such as patience, endurance, and consideration, particularly in relation to testing for house visits or gatherings.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several key business and economic updates were reported. Companies like CGSI downgraded Grab's rating to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth, while Sats CEO Kerry Mok received a 30.5% pay hike. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index, while analysts expressed optimism about SGX earnings, raising target prices. Meanwhile, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, and Chinese banks stumbled due to Beijing's consumer lending push. The news highlights the ongoing impact of economic shifts and policy changes.

site_title: Strong dollar sets gold for worst monthly decline since September
summary: Gold prices fell for a fourth consecutive session, setting for their biggest monthly decline since September, as the US dollar strengthened ahead of key central bank meetings. Spot gold was down 0.2% at US$1,788.41 per ounce, and the metal has declined more than 2% so far this month. The US Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates in March may reduce the appeal of gold as a hedge against inflation, leading to a decline in prices.

site_title: Grab's share price fall reflects some difficult realities for the company
summary: Grab's US$5.51 share price on the Nasdaq reflects the company's difficult realities, with nearly half of its initial public offering market value lost in just two months. The decline surpasses the 11.43% slide in the Nasdaq 100 index, suggesting that market sentiment may not be the sole reason. Analysts have given Grab a buy rating, but the company faces challenges, including rising short interest, concerns over sustainability of growth, and potential regulatory hurdles in the digital banking space.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on positive note
summary: Hong Kong shares began trading on a positive note on Monday, January 31, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.31% to 23,624.14. The gains come ahead of the 3-day Chinese New Year break. Mainland Chinese markets remain closed.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares started Monday (Jan 31) with small gains in thin trade as investors prepare for a 3-day Chinese New Year break.

site_title: Dollar posts biggest weekly rise in 7 months on rate bets
summary: The US dollar posted its biggest weekly rise in 7 months, up 1.7% for the week, driven by market expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The dollar index rose 0.04% and shot above 97 for the first time since July 2020. US Treasury yields eased, with the 10-year yield falling to 1.77%. The euro remained steady, while the yen rose 0.14% to 115.21 dollars. The dollar is expected to gain further versus the euro and yen, but the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan are unlikely to raise rates.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts positive on MLT's stable results, increased distribution yield
summary: Analysts are positive on Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) stable results, with a 5.8% on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.185 Singapore cents for its third quarter. Brokerages UOB Kay Hian and DBS Group Research have upgraded MLT to "buy" calls, citing a healthy debt level and a rosy growth outlook. Despite gearing ratio expected to increase, analysts expect investors to remain optimistic, with target prices ranging from S$2.08 to S$2.35.

images.alt_text: ANALYSTS are positive on Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) ability to deliver stable results and maintain healthy debt levels.

site_title: Huawei takes Sweden to court following 5G ban
summary: Huawei has initiated arbitration proceedings against Sweden under the World Bank Group after the country banned the Chinese tech giant from rolling out its 5G products. The ban, which excludes Huawei from the 5G rollout and orders the removal of installed equipment, has significantly harmed Huawei's investment in Sweden, violating the country's international obligations. Huawei is seeking damages, with an initial sum of 5.2 billion Swedish kroner (S$745.4 million), although the amount could be higher. The move strains relations between Sweden and China.

images.alt_text: Huawei said on Sunday it has initiated arbitration proceedings against Sweden under the World Bank Group after the Nordic country banned the Chinese tech giant from rolling out its 5G products.

site_title: Australian PM Morrison's ratings tumble to lowest levels in nearly two years: poll
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's approval rating has dropped to 39%, its lowest level in nearly two years, according to a poll. The poll shows Morrison trails opposition leader Anthony Albanese 43-41% and predicts a Labor victory with a "sizeable majority" if the election were held now. Morrison faces criticism for his handling of the Omicron wave, with soaring cases and hospitalizations overwhelming the country. The ruling Liberal-National Party coalition trails Labor on a two-party preferred basis by 44-56, with Labor potentially losing up to 25 seats.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's approval rating fell to its lowest level in nearly two years as he faces heat just months out from a federal election over his handling of the Omicron wave, a widely watched poll showed on Monday.

site_title: Nurturing the shoots of recovery
summary: Singapore's Budget should focus on balancing post-pandemic recovery and growth, addressing the interconnected challenges of infections, inflation, and economic inflection. Experts recommend measures to support businesses, such as fueling economic growth, promoting social cohesion, and investing in emerging industries like carbon services. The government should also incentivize the development of skills, talent, and creativity in sustainability and climate issues. Additionally, support for manufacturers, technology adoption, and workforce upskilling are crucial for driving growth and competitiveness. The Budget should prioritize short-term recovery and midterm investments in talent development and digital transformation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.55 points or 0.04% to 1,520.57. The index saw 145.30 million lots traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 214 to 135. This follows recent market trends, where investors have been optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Miami's lure during Covid sends housing prices through the roof
summary: Miami's housing prices have skyrocketed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with median rent increasing 44% in November to $2,800. The city's warm weather, beaches, and business-friendly environment made it an attractive destination for investors and workers from other states, leading to a surge in demand and subsequent price hikes. Experts warn that Miami needs to address its housing shortage and diversify its economy to mitigate the effects of this trend, which has left many residents, like Maria Ruby, struggling to afford rising rents.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher in choppy trade ahead of RBA outcome
summary: Australia's shares edged higher in choppy trade on Tuesday, driven by technology stocks following a robust overnight Nasdaq session. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.2%, or 17.4 points, to 6,994, as investors awaited the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) monetary policy outcome. The RBA is expected to end its bond-buying program and wait until November to respond to inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Australia shares edged higher in choppy trade on Tuesday (Feb 1), after technology stocks tracked a robust overnight Nasdaq session, even as investors cautiously awaited the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) monetary policy outcome expected later in the day.

site_title: Love, Bonito CEO sees a year of growth ahead
summary: Love, Bonito, a fashion retailer targeting everyday Asian women globally, aims to grow its business in multiple directions. CEO Dione Song views the US as a key market, with plans to establish its first US-based store in California or New York. The company will maintain its focus on catering to Asian women's specific proportions, while refining its business to suit international expansion. Love, Bonito plans to democratize fashion through sustainable products, expand its omnichannel presence, and diversify its marketing campaigns to represent women from diverse backgrounds.

site_title: Nato concerned over Europe's energy security amid standoff with Russia
summary: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg expressed concern over Europe's energy security amid Russia's military buildup near Ukraine, urging diversification of energy supplies. Russia demands NATO withdraw troops and bar Ukraine from joining the Western defense alliance, while the US and Canada prepare for potential sanctions against Russia. The European Union relies heavily on Russian natural gas, exacerbating an existing energy crisis. NATO allies agree that diversification of supplies is crucial to mitigate the risk of energy disruptions.

images.alt_text: Europe needs to diversify its energy supplies, the head of Nato said on Sunday, as Britain warned it was "highly likely" that Russia, the continent's biggest natural gas supplier, was looking to invade Ukraine.

site_title: Investors find refuge from market turmoil in South-east Asia
summary: Investors are seeking refuge in South-east Asian markets amid global market turmoil, driven by high exposure to cyclical sectors, a stimulus-driven China, and potential easing of lockdowns. The region's stocks and bonds have shown resilience, with Asean equities rising to an 18-month high relative to the Asia benchmark. Economies in the Philippines, Thailand, and Singapore are expected to benefit from reopening economies, with their financials and energy shares poised to outperform.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore business optimism remains positive, but eased for manufacturers and services firms for the next 6 months. Retail properties surged for auction in 2021 due to Covid-19 restrictions. Corporate gifting increased during the pandemic, with businesses expecting higher sales this Chinese New Year. Chip Eng Seng entered a joint venture for hospitality management services, and Fraser and Neave appointed a new CEO. The STI rose 0.1% on muted trading on Chinese New Year eve, despite a possible interest-rate hike.

site_title: Execs struggle to fully embed sustainability in core business
summary: Global C-level business leaders acknowledge the climate crisis and believe the world is at a tipping point, but struggle to fully embed sustainability into their core business strategies. Despite optimism about limiting climate impacts, 64% of executives say their organizations are not yet taking decisive action. To move the needle, companies must adopt five key actions: developing climate-friendly products, requiring suppliers to meet sustainability criteria, updating facilities, incorporating climate considerations into lobbying, and tying senior leader compensation to sustainability performance.

site_title: Why frenemies can work together in property projects
summary: In the Singapore property market, frenemies often form partnerships to jointly develop sites or own investment properties, driven by the capital-intensive nature of property development and investment. This trend is evident in various partnerships, such as GuocoLand's tie-up with its major shareholder Guoco Group and Yanlord Land Group's partnership with Ho Bee Land in China. These collaborations allow parties to diversify risk and optimize use of capital, despite potential risks of disputes and project stalling. By ironing out issues upfront and establishing mutual trust, frenemies can prosper by working together in the property world.

site_title: Federal Reserve could raise rates by half a point if needed: official
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering a half-point interest rate hike if inflation remains high, according to Fed official Raphael Bostic. Chair Jerome Powell signaled a plan to hike rates in March, and Bostic said "every option is on the table" for future meetings. Bostic expects three quarter-percentage-point hikes by the end of the year, but would be comfortable with a half-point increase if data supports it. This move aims to slow inflation, which has been a priority for the Fed since growth returned to track.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts largely favourable towards CICT after FY2021 results
summary: Analysts have upgraded or maintained "buy" calls for CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) following its FY2021 results, citing a brightening outlook due to easing restrictions, development contributions, and completed asset enhancement initiatives. RHB upgraded its target price to S$2.20, while DBS Group Research lowered its target price to S$2.45. The positive assessment reflects the trust's resilience despite the challenging real estate market.

images.alt_text: Contributions from CapitaSpring (above), 21 Collyer Quay and 6 Battery Road post-AEI should underpin DPU recovery, said Maybank Securities analyst Chua Su Tye.

site_title: Abandoned by power retailers, SMEs zapped by electricity bill shock
summary: Small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) in Singapore are facing hefty electricity bill shocks after their power retailers closed shop amid high electricity spot prices. Many SMEs were forced to switch to SP Services's wholesale electricity price plan, which is a costly option. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) has introduced new contracts to help larger consumers, but these plans are only for one month, leaving businesses concerned about price volatility. The move aims to provide price certainty in volatile times, but SMEs are still struggling to secure fixed price contracts amid tight market conditions.

site_title: Boris Johnson brings back elections guru to revamp partnership
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has brought back elections guru Lynton Crosby to offer strategic advice, following a damning report into lockdown parties at Downing Street. Johnson vowed to get a grip on his government after the interim report slammed "failures of leadership and judgment." Many Conservative MPs want Johnson to focus on core issues, citing a distraction from "partygate" allegations and plummeting poll ratings.

site_title: Surge in Singapore retail properties put up for auction in 2021: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore saw a surge in retail properties put up for auction in 2021, with 84 mortgagee listings, a 62% increase from 2020. The number of owner-sale listings also rose, with 101 listings, up from 17 in 2020. Auction listings totalled 670 last year, a 35.4% increase from 2020, driven by owner-sale listings. However, mortgagee-sale listings fell by 5.6% to 289. Despite disruptions, auction success rates improved to 4.8% in 2021, with gross sales value tripling to S$85.9 million.

site_title: Spotify to link virus content to Covid facts after disinformation row
summary: Spotify is introducing a content advisory to guide listeners of Covid-19 discussing podcasts to more information, following a row over misinformation. The move comes after artists, led by Neil Young, demanded the removal of music from the platform due to a podcast host's promotion of false Covid-19 vaccine information. Spotify CEO Daniel Ek stated the company is working to balance creator freedom with listener safety, and will direct listeners to a dedicated Covid-19 Hub for accurate information.

images.alt_text: Music streaming giant Spotify announced Sunday that it would start guiding listeners of podcasts discussing Covid-19 to more information about the pandemic, following a row that saw artist Neil Young remove his music from the platform.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher in half-day trade ahead of Chinese New Year holidays
summary: Hong Kong's main Hang Seng index closed 1.07% higher, while China's H-shares index rose 1.7%, driven by technology stocks ahead of Chinese New Year holidays. The Hang Seng Technology Index gained 2.4%, with Meituan leading gains. Mainland Chinese markets will be closed for a week-long holiday, starting January 31.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's main Hang Seng index and China's H-shares index ended firmer in half-day trade on Monday (Jan 31) with technology stocks leading gains, ahead of market holidays in the city for most of the week.

site_title: CLCT posts 35.1% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.045 driven by pivot to 'new economy'
summary: CapitaLand China Trust reported a 35.1% rise in its half-yearly distributable per unit (DPU) to S$0.045, driven by its pivot to the 'new economy'. The real estate investment trust (Reit) faced challenges in the second half of FY2021 due to sporadic Covid-19 outbreaks in China, resulting in 96 days of mall closures. However, the diversification strategy implemented in September 2020 has helped the Reit build portfolio strength and income resilience.

site_title: CGS-CIMB partners ComChest in Change For Charity initiative
summary: CGS-CIMB Securities has partnered with Community Chest (ComChest) in the Change For Charity initiative, pledging to donate at least S$1 million over three years. The partnership allows customers to donate through subscription or trade, and employees can make regular donations through payroll. The initiative aims to foster a culture of giving and support communities in need, including children with special needs, youth at risk, and seniors.

site_title: US SMEs seen to bear brunt of rate hikes
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision to end market-friendly policies has led to a slowdown in the stock market, with the Russell 2000 index of small caps slipping into bear-market territory. The index, which is a pacemaker for larger indexes, fell 20% below its 2021 peak, signaling that small and medium-sized US companies will feel the pain from higher borrowing costs and lower demand. The Fed's decision to hike rates at its next meeting in March is expected to further exacerbate the situation, with some strategists predicting multiple rate hikes this year.

site_title: The law exodus: Where is the Promised Land?
summary: Singapore's legal industry is experiencing a mass exodus of young lawyers, with many fleeing to become baristas, bakers, or bitcoin traders. Despite the industry's lucrative growth, driven by low interest rates and corporate spending, burnout and poor work-life balance are major contributors. The issue is not solely due to toxic bosses, but rather a deeper structural change, including the rise of technology firms and changing career aspirations among young people. To address the problem, law firms must adopt a more holistic approach, prioritizing associate well-being, providing meaningful work opportunities, and fostering a sense of ownership and long-term engagement.

images.alt_text: Burnout, bitchy bosses, the relentless battering of unreasonable client demands. These are some of the reasons cited for lawyers fleeing the profession in droves, many to become baristas or bakers or bitcoin traders.

site_title: Taleban to reopen public universities, no word on female students
summary: Afghanistan's Taleban government announced the reopening of public universities in February, with warmer provinces opening on February 2 and colder areas on February 26. However, the government did not specify whether female students would be allowed to return, a condition Western governments have been demanding. This move comes after the Taleban took power in August and has reopened high schools for boys, but female students remain barred from attending.

site_title: Nadal comes from two sets down to make history with 21st Slam
summary: Rafael Nadal made history by coming from two sets down to win his 21st Grand Slam men's title at the Australian Open, defeating Daniil Medvedev in a five-set duel. Nadal, 35, trailed 2-6, 6-7 in the first two sets but staged an incredible comeback to win 6-4, 6-4, 6-4. This victory moved him ahead of Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer on the all-time list of men's major winners.

site_title: UOB raises more than S$700,000 for charity
summary: UOB raised over S$700,000 for charity through a series of art workshops as part of its annual UOB Heartbeat Chinese New Year tradition. The funds will support art, children, education, and local SME innovation through various charities. UOB executives and clients participated in workshops, where they created auspicious seals and gold-plated tiger art pieces. Each client donated at least S$10,000, with the bank matching their donations up to S$250,000. The event aims to celebrate new beginnings and support those in need.

site_title: Q42021 gold demand surges with inflation: World Gold Council
summary: Gold demand surged in Q4 2021, driven by soaring inflation, with a 50% year-on-year surge in gold prices and a 52% growth in gold jewellery consumption. Total annual demand rose 10% to 4,021 tonnes worth US$123 billion, matching the 2013 record. Central banks purchased 463 tonnes, raising their holdings to 34,592 tonnes, and global holdings of gold reached 205,238 tonnes worth US$11.8 trillion. However, the WGC warns of risks in 2022 due to a slowdown in China and uncertainty related to Covid restrictions.

site_title: Infrastructure projects, regulatory changes seen driving strong recovery in Vietnam construction
summary: Vietnam's construction industry is expected to continue its recovery in 2022, driven by large-scale infrastructure projects and regulatory changes. Analysts predict a 7.9% growth in the sector, with the government's five-year plan and transport plans expected to drive growth. Companies such as Pan-United Corporation and Jaks Resources have signed cooperation agreements, and foreign investors are increasing their presence in the country. Despite potential risks, including labor shortages and high input prices, experts are optimistic about the sector's prospects, citing the country's strengthening economy and attracting foreign investment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on February 1, 2022, following gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.6% or 160.52 points to 27,162.50, while the Topix index advanced 0.6% or 10.74 points to 1,906.67. The gains are attributed to investors keeping an eye on upcoming corporate earnings reports.

site_title: North Korea says Sunday test was Hwasong-12 missile
summary: North Korea confirmed it tested a Hwasong-12 "mid-range ballistic missile" on Sunday, its first such test since 2017. The launch, Pyongyang's seventh in January, was detected by Seoul's military and came amid tensions with the US. The test confirmed the accuracy and effectiveness of the Hwasong 12-type weapon system, with a warhead carrying a camera that took photos while in space. The move has raised concerns about North Korea's military modernization and its potential for nuclear and intercontinental missile tests, which could destabilize the region.

site_title: US airlines cancel almost 5,000 flights ahead of Nor'easter
summary: US airlines have canceled nearly 5,000 flights through the weekend due to a winter storm forecast to bring high winds and heavy snow across the North-east and Mid-Atlantic. Delta, American, and JetBlue have canceled flights, with Delta suspending operations at several New York airports and American expecting a "significant" impact. The cancellations are part of the airline industry's challenges, which include staff shortages due to Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Nadal beats Medvedev to win Australian Open tennis final
summary: Rafael Nadal defeated Daniil Medvedev 2-6 6-7(5) 6-4 6-4 7-5 in the Australian Open men's singles final on January 30, 2022, securing his 21st Grand Slam singles title.

site_title: Will Powell save Biden?
summary: The US economy experienced a 6.9% annual growth rate in the fourth quarter of last year, the strongest in four decades, with full-year growth of 5.7%. This rapid growth has raised questions about President Joe Biden's economic performance, with some suggesting he may have been unfairly written off. However, the economy's growth was largely driven by the global pandemic and government stimulus programs, and rising inflation poses a threat to the recovery. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's plans to raise interest rates aim to control inflation without slowing the economy, which will be crucial in determining the fate of the economic recovery and President Biden's political future.

site_title: China manufacturing loses steam as growth risks rise
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded at a slower pace in January, with the official manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) declining to 50.1, just above the median estimate. The slowdown was attributed to seasonal factors, Covid-19 outbreaks, and a housing market drop, affecting small firms the most. The non-manufacturing gauge also fell, and input prices rose at the fastest rate in 3 months, posing challenges for monetary policy. Despite efforts by the central bank to spur growth, the economy's growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Australia to seek part in China-EU trade row at WTO
summary: Australia plans to join EU-China trade dispute at the World Trade Organization, following China's launch of a challenge against Lithuania for allowing Taiwan to open a de facto embassy. The EU claims China's actions are discriminatory and threaten the single market. This move comes as Australia has already filed two WTO complaints against China over duties on wine and barley imports, and has expressed opposition to economic coercion and trade practices that undermine the international trading system.

site_title: Italy re-elects president; Draghi stays on as PM
summary: Italy re-elected President Sergio Mattarella, ending a week-long impasse, and allowed Mario Draghi to remain Prime Minister. Mattarella received 759 votes out of 983 cast, following a deal between Draghi and main parties. This outcome provides relief to investors by reducing the chances of early elections and allowing Draghi to continue with his reform agenda until 2023.

site_title: Marriages back to pre-Covid levels; smaller than expected fall in birth numbers: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's marriages have returned to pre-pandemic levels, with 483 couples filing to register their marriages on Feb 22, 2022. Birth numbers have also fallen, but not as much as expected. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong attributed this to government initiatives, including the Baby Support Grant. He urged Singaporeans to continue exercising social responsibility and getting vaccinated to keep families safe amid the ongoing Omicron variant.

site_title: Vatican sells scandal-tainted London building
summary: The Vatican has sold a luxury London building at the center of a financial scandal for an undisclosed price. The building, valued at 350 million euros, was acquired by US private equity group Bain Capital. The sale comes as the Vatican struggles financially, with fewer donations and lower ticket sales during the pandemic affecting its coffers. The Holy See will lose an estimated £100 million on the investment, which began in 2014. The sale is expected to be completed in June 2022.

site_title: Singapore property firms deepening presence in Vietnam
summary: Singaporean property firms are expanding their presence in Vietnam, driven by the country's growing affluent class and economic recovery. CapitaLand, Keppel, and Mapletree Logistics Trust are among the companies investing in luxury apartments, serviced residences, and logistics facilities. The Vietnamese economy is expected to grow 8% in 2022, boosted by an accommodative monetary policy, and is attracting significant capital from Singaporean developers. These investments signal a growing trend of Singaporean companies deepening their presence in Vietnam's property market.

site_title: Failure of first startup opened new doors for SGAG co-founder Karl Mak
summary: Karl Mak, co-founder of SGAG, credits his first failed startup, Televate, for shaping his entrepreneurial journey. Televate, a digital solution to eliminate customer hotline waiting times, won a hackathon and secured funding, but struggled with enterprise security and integration. Mak and his co-founder realized it was too costly to continue, leading to its demise. However, Mak received support from Quest Ventures, and the experience taught him valuable lessons on building connections and working with a co-founder. He eventually joined SGAG as a consultant and was hooked, eventually becoming a key player in the company's success.

site_title: Demand for jewellery drives surprising diamond rebound
summary: Polished diamond prices have jumped 6 months, driven by strong demand for jewellery, particularly in North America and Asia. Diamond miners Alrosa and De Beers raised rough diamond prices by significant percentages, with sales reaching record highs. Despite the pandemic's impact, marketing strategies and changes in consumer behavior helped the companies boost sales. Online sales of diamond jewellery surged during lockdowns, and luxury item purchases in China rose 35% in 2021. The rebound has led to a shortage of cut diamonds, with investors buying top-quality diamonds to hedge against inflation.

site_title: Halcyon Agri eyes return to profitability amid stronger rubber demand, prices
summary: Singapore-based natural rubber supplier Halcyon Agri Corporation is set to record a profit after tax for FY2021, driven by stronger demand and prices. The company's chief executive, David Li, attributes the turnaround to a "deleveraging plan" that cut out non-core assets and strengthened its capital structure. With an expected 14.1 million metric tonnes of natural rubber consumption this year, Halcyon Agri predicts a price increase due to supply-demand imbalance, fueled by growing demand for electric vehicles, medical gloves, and masks. Li remains confident in the company's sustainability of profitability.

site_title: Digital skills, sustainability expertise needed to build talent pool
summary: Singapore's workforce faces a growing digital skills crisis, with 64% of workers feeling unprepared for digital skills and only 29% actively upskilling themselves. To tackle the rising manpower shortage, businesses are calling for targeted support to develop digital and sustainability expertise. The government is expected to focus on bridging the talent gap in the mid-term, with initiatives such as Asia-focused climate research and training. This will help build a digitally empowered and connected workforce, as well as a happy and motivated talent pool equipped for the digital economy.

site_title: Swiss court seeks US$45m in Credit Suisse laundering case
summary: Swiss federal prosecutors are seeking approximately $61 million in compensation from Credit Suisse Group for its alleged failure to prevent money laundering by a Bulgarian drug ring over a 14-year period. The bank is accused of suffering from "serious organisational shortcomings" in preventing money laundering, with a former employee also targeted. Credit Suisse has rejected the allegations, stating it will defend itself vigorously in court, which is set to last for 20 days. This marks the second time the Swiss federal prosecutor has taken a bank to court, following the Falcon bank probe into 1MDB.

site_title: India forecasts GDP growth slowing to 8-8.5% in 2022/23 as risks rise
summary: India forecasts its economy will grow 8-8.5% in the fiscal year starting April 2022, down from 9.2% projected in the current year, due to rising inflationary pressure and global uncertainty. Despite this, India's economy will still be the fastest among major economies. The government warns of risks from global inflation, pandemic-related disruptions, and potential capital outflows. Private economists say policymakers must balance growth and inflation objectives, citing fiscal space to provide additional support if needed.

site_title: CEO Fernandes unfazed by AirAsia's 'financially distressed' label
summary: Capital A, formerly AirAsia Group, has been labeled "financially distressed" by Malaysia's stock exchange, but CEO Tony Fernandes remains unfazed, citing the group's efforts to raise funds and boost its balance sheet. Despite this, the airline business will continue to be known as AirAsia. Fernandes emphasized the group's focus on growth, affordability, and accessibility, with plans to expand its portfolio of companies and achieve 10 million monthly active users for its payments business. Capital A aims to achieve 1 billion connections in the region and become an industry leader in maintenance and repair services.

site_title: Morgan Stanley lawyer doubles down on Wall Street office return
summary: Morgan Stanley's top lawyer, Eric Grossman, has doubled down on his push to end remote work in the company's Wall Street office, citing the need for in-person training and mentoring for the next generation of lawyers. Grossman argues that remote work has frayed bonds between senior and junior lawyers and made it difficult for financial services firms to foster a common culture. He believes that lawyers are missing out on learning essential skills and experience by working remotely, and that the practice of law at its highest reform requires a creative element that allows the best to rise to the top.

site_title: Mao's favoured 'red flag' car seeks a new audience in Japan
summary: China FAW Group Co, the carmaker that transported Chairman Mao Zedong, is opening its first showroom in Japan, targeting wealthy Chinese residents. The Hongqi dealership in Osaka has sold 22 vehicles to Chinese living in Japan, with prices ranging from 15 million yen to 160 million yen. Despite differing safety and emission standards, FAW aims to crack Japan's premium car market, with plans for a fully electric SUV and more outlets in Tokyo's Ginza district. Sales are expected to be limited, but growing demand for Chinese-made cars may change this.

site_title: STI breaks its 3,200 resistance curse
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has broken its 3,200 resistance curse, with a strong weekly uptrend in play. After a brief downside correction, the index has regained momentum, forming a Marobozu-type candle and testing the resistance zone of 3,233-3,284 multiple times. A bullish trend structure is expected, with a possible small correction to 3,209 to form wave 4, followed by a target of 3,357-3,400 for wave 5.

site_title: Tax policy plays crucial role in averting climate crisis
summary: Tax professionals in Singapore emphasize the crucial role of tax policy in driving investment and action to mitigate climate change. The upcoming budget is expected to include changes to the carbon tax rate, with some experts predicting a rise to over S$15 per tonne of greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. To incentivize businesses and individuals to adopt green practices, tax professionals suggest introducing tax incentives such as grants, double tax deductions, and super tax deductions for carbon credits. Governments are also encouraged to review existing incentive schemes and enhance them with green parameters, and to consider co-funding research and setting standards for low-carbon technologies.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for January 28, 2022, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk ships. Capesize rates rebounded from a low, with the 5TC weighted average closing at $8,918. Transpacific and Brazil-China routes showed upticks, while the Transatlantic C8 continued to command a premium. Panamax rates declined further, with the Atlantic region experiencing significant losses. Ultramax and Supramax periods saw mixed fortunes, with stronger interest in the Indian Ocean and Asia. Handysize rates also fell, with limited activity in the US Gulf and Mediterranean. VLCC rates remained static, while Suezmax and Aframax markets plateaued.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at Monday's open, driven by positive US share market performance on Friday. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3255.21, with gains outnumbering losses 80-34. Key sectors, including local banks, also rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 1.2%, 0.7%, and 0.4% respectively. The market's gains followed a strong performance from US stocks, which ended 1.7% higher on Friday, driven by Apple earnings and moderation in inflation.

site_title: OCBC completes arrangements for full payouts to all 790 SMS phishing victims; S$13.7m in losses
summary: OCBC has completed full goodwill payouts to 790 SMS phishing scam victims, totaling S$13.7 million in losses. The majority of losses (S$8.5 million) occurred during the year-end festive period in December, with 469 victims reporting losses. The bank's investigation found victims provided login credentials and one-time PINs to phishing websites, allowing scammers to take over their accounts. OCBC made the full payout as a "one-off gesture of goodwill" after acknowledging its customer service response fell short of expectations. Payouts began on January 8.

site_title: EU pushes for cutting-edge chip plants
summary: The European Union is proposing a Chips Act to attract investment for cutting-edge semiconductor production sites, known as "mega fabs," with the goal of reducing the bloc's dependency on the US and Asia for semiconductors. The EU will publish its proposal on February 8, with a budget comparable to a US $52 billion proposal, and will include measures to secure supply, such as demanding companies prioritize crisis-relevant products. The EU may also implement an export control regime and fine companies for non-compliance, with the aim of becoming a bigger player in the global semiconductor industry by 2030.

site_title: Aeromexico reorganisation plan confirmed after creditor deal
summary: Aeromexico has secured court approval for its restructuring plan, allowing the airline to emerge from bankruptcy with new controlling shareholders. The plan, which has been ongoing since June 2020, includes new infusions of capital and provides for Apollo Global Management and Delta Air Lines to hold significant stakes. The airline has agreed to pay $1.1 million to Invictus Global Management, a major creditor opponent, and $800,000 to junior creditors to cover legal fees. The deal clears the way for Aeromexico to complete its bankruptcy process and is expected to boost its shares.

site_title: The compromises to be made when you go on long leave
summary: When taking a long leave from work, employees and employers must consider compromises on productivity, performance, remuneration, and the possibility of being no longer needed. Employers must trust employees to return to work at a similar level of productivity, but this may not be possible, especially after a life-changing event.
