site_title: US: Wall Street climbs at open on energy, banks boost
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, driven by gains in energy and financial stocks, despite hawkish comments from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.27% to 34,261.75, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 0.70% and 1.25% respectively. The gains followed a mixed session on Wednesday.

site_title: CICT posts H2 DPU of S$0.0522; acquisitions may intensify in FY2022, manager says
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0522 for the second half of FY2021, down 8.9% from the year-ago period. The Reit's manager, Tony Tan, stated that acquisitions may intensify in FY2022, with Singapore properties being a priority. CICT has been divesting non-core assets and setting up "beachheads" in Germany and Australia to position for future growth opportunities. The Reit's portfolio occupancy was at 93.9%, and it expects assets to contribute income from the second half of FY2022.

site_title: Climate talk will be replaced by action in 2022
summary: Singapore aims to replace climate talk with action in 2022, as the world needs a commercial, financial, and industrial overhaul to meet the net-zero transition by 2050. Governments, companies, and investors must convert statements of intent into verifiable action to avoid reputational and commercial penalties. In 2022, Singapore will finalize its green taxonomy, accelerate its renewable energy adoption, and enhance low-carbon transition technology. The financial sector will play a key role in embedding climate risk management principles and developing sustainable financing solutions. Large corporates and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will face pressure to disclose and reduce their carbon footprint, with SMEs requiring significant investment and support.

site_title: Ho Ching to advise Swedish firm EQT's longer-hold investment fund
summary: Former Temasek CEO Ho Ching is joining EQT's impact-driven longer-hold fund EQT Future as an advisor, bringing external objectivity to the fund's strategic direction and setting a commitment to drive positive impact.

site_title: Alpina IPO fully subscribed; Mah Bow Tan among substantial shareholders
summary: Alpina Holdings, a Singapore-based integrated building services provider, has fully subscribed to its 37 million placement shares, raising approximately S$8.1 million in net proceeds. The shares were priced at S$0.31 each, with former minister Mah Bow Tan, Lim Theng Sian, and others subscribing to a significant portion of the shares. The company's controlling shareholders also received S$1.6 million in net proceeds. The full subscription is seen as a positive sign for the company's future growth and development.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust sees better RevPAR in Q1
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 43.1% increase in RevPAR in Australian properties to S$113 per room for the 3 months ended Dec 31, 2021. RevPAR rose 12.9% in Singapore to S$143 and more than doubled in the UK. The trust's occupancy was boosted by the re-securing of a government quarantine business in Singapore. This recovery in international travel led to a general uplift in revenue across the portfolio.

site_title: Keppel posts 6-year high FY21 profit of S$1b, unveils S$500m share buyback programme
summary: Keppel Corporation, a Singapore-based conglomerate, reported a 6-year high net profit of S$1 billion for FY2021, driven by a 45.9% increase in revenue and asset monetization efforts. The company's asset monetization program has collected S$2.7 billion, exceeding its target of S$5 billion by end-2023. Keppel's CEO, Loh Chin Hua, stated that asset monetization will be a consistent feature of the company's business model, with a focus on sustainable urbanization solutions and a target return on equity of 15% per annum.

site_title: China approves AMD's US$35b acquisition of Xilinx
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation has approved AMD's $35 billion acquisition of Xilinx, clearing the way for the largest semiconductor deal in the global industry. The deal was previously approved by US, European, and UK regulators, and conditions include not discriminating against Chinese clients and continuing to supply Xilinx's products to the country. The approval comes as nations, including the US, Japan, and China, seek to protect and build their own chip technologies and supply chains amid global shortages and growing geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Maybank appoints Khairussaleh Ramli as group president and CEO
summary: Maybank appoints Khairussaleh Ramli as its new group president and CEO, effective May 1, succeeding Abdul Farid Alias. Ramli, 54, brings over 30 years of experience in the financial services industry, most recently as RHB Banking Group's former group managing director. His tenure at Maybank from 2008-2013 includes a business transformation program that led to an 81% profit growth in 2012. Ramli is seen as a strong leader to drive Maybank's next growth phase, focusing on digitalisation, sustainability, and new value drivers.

site_title: GIC and Equinix to build 2 data centres in Seoul with US$525m joint venture
summary: GIC and Equinix have formed a US$525 million joint venture to develop and operate two xScale data centers in Seoul, South Korea. The limited liability partnership is expected to close in Q1 2022. This joint venture aims to capitalize on the growing demand for data storage and processing in the region. The partnership will enhance Equinix's presence in Korea and GIC's expansion into the data center market.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS, Jefferies lower Ascendas India Trust target price on post-FY2021 results
summary: DBS Group Research and Jefferies lowered their target price for Ascendas India Trust to S$1.70 and S$1.65, respectively, following the trust's lower distribution per unit of S$0.078 for FY2021, 11% less than the previous year. Despite this, both brokerages maintain a "buy" call due to projected improvements in portfolio occupancy, acquisitions, and its emerging data centre player position.

site_title: 5 fiercely good reads for the Tiger year
summary: The article highlights five books featuring tigers as characters or central to their stories, each set in a unique cultural context. The titles include "The Paper Menagerie and Other Stories" by Ken Liu, "The Night Tiger" by Yangsze Choo, "Man Tiger" by Eka Kurniawan, "When You Trap A Tiger" by Tae Keller, and "Life Of Pi" by Yann Martel. These books draw on mythological and cultural traditions, exploring themes of identity, trauma, and the power of stories.

site_title: New data centres in Singapore to meet higher standards when moratorium lifts in Q2 2022
summary: Singapore to introduce new data centre standards with a moratorium lift in Q2 2022, requiring applications to meet higher efficiency standards, including a power usage effectiveness (PUE) of 1.3 and below. Three new data centre applications will be approved during a pilot phase, focusing on capacities between 10MW and 30MW. Applicants will need to include innovation and sustainability solutions, with existing operators having an edge. The government will evaluate its policies over a 12-18 month initial pilot phase, aiming to anchor "best in class" data centres that contribute to Singapore's economic and strategic objectives.

site_title: Formula One Grand Prix return puts Singapore back on track for glamour
summary: Singapore has secured a contract to host the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix until 2028, a move seen as a boost to the country's global branding and tourism sector. The event is expected to generate around S$50 million in revenue this year, a fraction of past takings, but could still have a significant impact on the battered tourism industry. Experts believe that the F1 Grand Prix could attract more visitors and stimulate hotel demand, particularly in areas like the Marina Bay area, and could also boost the services sector.

site_title: KORE reports strong leasing velocity, targets 'full steam ahead' on acquisitions
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported strong leasing velocity across its office properties, with 46% of tenants returning to the office amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Reit manager targets 'full steam ahead' on acquisitions, aiming for $150-200 million in deals in 2022. Strong rental reversion of 6% for FY2021, driven by tech hubs like Seattle-Bellevue/Redmond and Austin, is expected to continue. Occupancy stood at 91.9% as of December 31, 2021, with a focus on growth areas like tech, advertising, and media.

site_title: Struggling Air India sold after 69 years in government hands
summary: India's national carrier, Air India, has been sold to Tata Group after 69 years in government hands. The 180 billion rupee ($3.2 billion) deal marks the end of a long search by the government, which has spent nearly $15 billion propping up the airline since 2009. Tata will take on a quarter of Air India's debt and acquire a fleet of 120 aircraft, airport slots, and international routes. Analysts believe the deal will give the struggling airline a much-needed lift, but experts also warn of challenges in turning around the airline's fortunes.

site_title: The long trend of falling corporate taxes is being reversed
summary: The global trend of falling corporate taxes is reversing, according to a long-term trend since the 1920s. The League of Nations' principle of taxing profits where generated, not just where headquarters are located, has led to lower tax rates in bilateral treaties. This has resulted in companies shifting profits to tax havens, depriving governments of $100-240 billion annually, equivalent to 4-10% of global corporate tax revenues. Governments are now recognizing the need to reform tax policies to prevent tax avoidance and ensure fairer distribution of tax revenues.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's industrial space rents and prices rose in Q4 2021, with a 1.5% increase in total available stock. GIC and Equinix are developing two data centers in Seoul with a $525 million joint venture. Hyundai and PSA International are partnering to create logistics solutions for electric vehicles. Total food delivery GMV in South-east Asia reached $15.5 billion in 2021, with expats leaving Singapore due to ease of Covid controls. Singapore stocks fell 0.35% due to a Fed signal towards a March rate hike.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's Q3 net property income up 13.1%
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 13.1% increase in Q3 net property income to S$85.6 million, driven by higher gross revenue and lower rental reliefs. The trust's nine-month NPI grew 14.9% to S$247.4 million, while portfolio occupancy stood at 97.5%. Festival Walk recorded full occupancy and a 27.7% increase in footfall and tenants' sales. The trust's aggregate leverage ratio edged up to 42.1% as of end-December.

site_title: Frencken to take majority stake in Malaysian polymer company Penchem for S$5.4m
summary: Frencken Group has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 50% stake in Malaysian company Penchem Technologies for RM15.6 million (S$5.2 million). The deal includes purchasing 261,500 ordinary shares and subscribing for 10,058 shares. The transaction is expected to be completed in FY2022 and is not expected to have a material impact on Frencken's financials. The partnership aims to leverage synergies between the two companies, expanding Penchem's revenue baseline and Frencken's global market accessibility.

site_title: Time for a tiger
summary: This Chinese New Year, various brands and designers have released unique and auspicious tiger-themed red packets, ornaments, and accessories. Foreign Policy Design's "Tiger (Rug) Bao" features six tigers that can be used as ang baos or mini rugs. Schroders' ang bao encourages recipients to appreciate nature, while Scene Shang's design features a tiger on a mountain, symbolizing strength and prosperity. Other brands, such as Papercranes Design, Theseus Chan, and Ode to Art, have also created tiger-themed ang baos with various designs, from playful to majestic.

site_title: Edtech startup Cialfo raises US$40m in Series B round led by Square Peg and SEEK Investments
summary: Edtech startup Cialfo has raised US$40 million in a Series B round led by Square Peg and SEEK Investments. The funding brings the company's total raised to US$55 million. Cialfo aims to simplify college applications, connecting students with over 1,000 colleges. The startup plans to enhance its platform with Direct Apply, a tool for seamless global applications. With the fresh funds, Cialfo will explore acquisitions and expand its offerings. The company has over 170 employees across four countries.

site_title: AC Ventures leads US$1.1m seed round in Indonesian salary-on-demand platform
summary: Gajiku, an Indonesian earned wages and employee management startup, has raised $1.1 million in a seed round led by AC Ventures. The funding will be used to expand product offerings and operations, develop new clients, and increase headcount. Founded a year ago, Gajiku provides an on-demand payroll service for blue-collar workers and digitizes employers' human resource and accounting operations, primarily working with large Indonesian employers. CEO Sherman Tanuwidjaja aims to improve employee management and financial stability for workers as the company focuses on the Indonesian market.

site_title: Banks scramble to change Fed rate calls after hawkish shift
summary: US investment banks scrambled to adjust their Federal Reserve rate calls after a hawkish shift by policymakers, indicating a likely interest rate hike in March. Analysts at Nomura and BNP Paribas now expect 6 rate hikes in 2022, with the Fed funds target range projected to reach 2.25-2.50% by end-2023. The unexpected policy shift surprised investors who had anticipated 4 rate hikes until the end of the year, posing challenges to their bullish outlook for US equities.

site_title: Taiwan economy grows fastest since 2010 as TSMC gives boost
summary: Taiwan's economy experienced its fastest growth in 11 years in 2021, with a 6.3% expansion, driven by strong exports and an unprecedented spending spree by its largest company, TSMC. The growth is expected to continue in 2022, fueled by TSMC's plans to spend $40-44 billion on new plants. This boost is attributed to robust external demand, the US-China technology dispute, and the government's green-energy policy, which has increased investment across the board. The outlook remains bullish, with economists predicting a virtuous cycle of growth.

site_title: Brokers' take: Citi cuts iFast TP on dilutive M&A, possible Q4 earnings miss
summary: Citi Research has cut its target price for iFast Corporation to S$6.20 from S$7.50, citing dilutive merger and acquisition plans, uncertainty surrounding earnings, and execution risks in its recent acquisition, BFC Bank. The research team also expects iFast to miss Q4 earnings estimates due to project fees and faces pressure from competition in its platform margins.

site_title: More than 200 new species found in Mekong region: WWF
summary: Scientists discovered over 200 new species in the greater Mekong region in 2020, despite threats from climate change and human activities. The finds include a new primate, a colorless cavefish, and an iridescent snake. The region, which spans Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam, is a biodiversity hotspot home to endangered species such as the tiger, Asian elephant, and Mekong giant catfish. The WWF reports this discovery highlights the importance of preserving the region's fragile ecosystems, with over 3,000 new species discovered since 1997.

site_title: Keppel FY21 profit hits 6-year high of S$1b, unveils S$500m share buyback programme
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 6-year high net profit of S$1 billion for FY2021, driven by asset monetization and a turnaround in performance. Revenue for the second half of FY2021 was up 45.9% to S$4.9 billion. The company unveiled a S$500 million share buyback program and proposed a final cash dividend of S$0.21 per share. Keppel's CEO Loh Chin Hua emphasized the company's focus on sustainable urbanization solutions and asset monetization to achieve a target return on equity of 15% per annum by 2030.

images.alt_text: Keppel's chief executive Loh Chin Hua said the group's asset monetisation programme has led to strong earnings growth and cash inflow which allowed the company to pursue growth opportunities and reward shareholders with higher dividends

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log worst session since August 2020 as US rate hikes near
summary: South Korean stocks experienced their worst session in almost a year and a half, with the Kospi falling 3.5% to 2,614.49, amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's plan to combat inflation with higher interest rates starting as early as March. The benchmark bond yield rose, and the Korean won weakened. Shares of LG Energy Solution jumped in its debut, while technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix also declined. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell warned of persistent inflation and supply chain issues.

site_title: Regional markets fall as Fed's Powell signals an interest rate hike
summary: Regional markets fell on Thursday after Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell signaled interest rate hikes and bond purchases' end in March, amid stabilizing unemployment and increasing inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 ended lower, while the Nasdaq edged up. This move follows Powell's statement that the Fed will end pandemic-era support, marking a shift in the central bank's policy stance.

images.alt_text: During a policy meeting on Wednesday, Powell said the Fed would likely end the support it has provided to the US economy during the Covid-19 pandemic, amid stabilising unemployment and increasing inflation.

site_title: Singapore Grand Prix to make a comeback this year; Republic inks 7-year contract
summary: The Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix is set to return this year after a three-year hiatus due to the pandemic. A 7-year contract has been signed between the Singapore Tourism Board and Singapore GP, ensuring the event will remain on the calendar until 2028. To prioritize health and safety, measures will be implemented, and the event will continue to reduce its carbon footprint, aiming to be net-zero carbon by 2030. The contract aims to support businesses, create jobs, and drive tourism as Singapore reopens post-pandemic.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of the Marina Bay area from a previous night race.

site_title: Deutsche Bank raises revenue guidance after best year in decade
summary: Deutsche Bank reported its most profitable year in a decade, with revenue increasing 8% in the fourth quarter and beating estimates. The bank expects to "significantly exceed" its revenue guidance for the coming year, driven by gains in debt trading and merger advisory. Chief executive Christian Sewing sees this momentum as a strong step towards reaching a return on tangible equity of 8% this year, after cutting thousands of jobs and exiting equities trading. The bank is also returning 700 million euros to investors through buybacks and dividends.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank on Thursday (Jan 27) reported its most profitable year in a decade as its fixed-income traders held their own in the final months of the year and dealmakers posted their eighth quarter of growth.

site_title: Tastes of the Tiger this Chinese New Year
summary: Chinese New Year celebrations feature creative tiger-themed dishes, decorations, and treats, such as tiger-shaped fugu sashimi, nian gou, and tiger cookies. Restaurants like Si Chuan Dou Hua, Pulse Patisserie, and Ah Mah's Homemade Cake offer tiger-inspired desserts and snacks. Meanwhile, Tien Court's tiger buns and Da Paolo Gastronomia's tiger bread provide savory alternatives. Craft beer Deep Creek's Sentinel Hazy IPA also features a tiger design, available for purchase with a promo code.

site_title: Supersonic jet maker picks North Carolina for plant, lured by US$200m
summary: Boom Supersonic, a startup aiming to revive supersonic air travel, has chosen North Carolina for its 400,000-square-foot factory, set to bring over 1,750 jobs by 2030. The company, backed by investors including United Airlines and Japan Airlines, will receive over $200 million in incentives. Boom expects to double or triple its workforce this year and plans to roll out its Overture supersonic jet in 2025, with passenger flights in 2029. The facility will be built at the Piedmont Triad International Airport in Greensboro, North Carolina.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble on US Fed rate worries
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 1.99% on Thursday, January 27, amid US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's hawkish comments on interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Hang Seng Index fell 482.90 points to 23,807.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.78% and 2.87%, respectively. The US Fed's aggressive monetary policy stance has sent global markets into a tailspin, causing investors to reassess their portfolios.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index tanked 1.99 percent, or 482.90 points, to 23,807.00 on Thursday (Jan 27).

site_title: Philippines' 2022 GDP expected to grow 6.5% amid downside risks: UOB
summary: UOB has maintained its 2022 GDP growth forecast for the Philippines at 6.5%, citing downside risks including the pandemic, global supply chain disruptions, and financial volatility. The country's economy recovered faster than expected in the fourth quarter of 2021, driven by resilient household consumption and expansion in global demand. UOB expects inflation to average 3.5% this year due to a depreciating Philippine peso, and the central bank may keep its reverse repurchase rate unchanged until the second half of 2022, with a possible 25 basis point increase in Q3.

images.alt_text: A food truck at a shopping mall in Quezon City in Metro Manila. The Philippine economy expanded more than expected in the fourth quarter, lending a firmer base to a recovery, though there are downside risks from the fast-spreading coronavirus variants and tighter global financial conditions.

site_title: SoftBank plunges as US Fed inspires tech rout across Asian stocks
summary: SoftBank plummeted 9.8% in Tokyo, its largest decline since March 2020, amid a tech rout across Asia. The stock drop was triggered by hawkish signals from the US Federal Reserve, which led investors to wager against technology companies. SoftBank's Vision Funds, which bet on speculative tech bets, were also affected. Other Asian tech stocks, including Sony and Japanese startups, also fell significantly. Analysts warn that SoftBank's high leverage to asset bubbles could lead to further financing pressure.

site_title: SPH Media Trust will invest more in talent and technology in coming years, says chairman Khaw
summary: SPH Media Trust, the media arm of Singapore Press Holdings, plans to invest more in talent and technology in the coming years to address gaps in these areas. Chairman Khaw Boon Wan stated that the company will enhance its products, services, and user experience, while also investing in training and talent acquisition through the SPH Media Academy. SMT aims to be the leading multimedia organization in Asia, focusing on customer-centricity, data-driven decision-making, and collaboration. The company will explore multiple funding sources, including commercial revenue and government support, to achieve its ambitions.

site_title: Apple to let iPhones accept credit cards without extra hardware: sources
summary: Apple is planning a new service that will enable small businesses to accept credit card payments directly on their iPhones without extra hardware, using the iPhone's NFC chip. The feature, which has been in development since 2020, will likely be rolled out via a software update in the coming months. The service will turn the iPhone into a payment terminal, eliminating the need for merchants to use payment terminals or communicate with the phone via Bluetooth. The exact branding and partnership details are unclear.

site_title: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition ends first day trading at S$4.86, 2.8% below IPO price
summary: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition (NTAA) ended its first day of trading on the Singapore Exchange mainboard at S$4.86, 2.8% below its IPO price of S$5. The units traded within a band of S$4.82 to S$5.01, with 1.3 million units changing hands. The SPAC was 3.4 times subscribed, with 13 cornerstone investors subscribing for 16 million units. NTAA targets companies in technology and industrials sectors in the Indo-Pacific region, using S$150 million in gross proceeds for the initial business combination and other expenses.

images.alt_text: From the start of trading at 9am till market close, the units traded within a band of S$4.82 and S$ 5.01 after around 1.3 million units changed hands.

site_title: Hyundai, PSA International tie up to create logistics solutions for 'made in Singapore' EVs
summary: Hyundai Motor Group has partnered with PSA International's cargo solutions unit, PSA Cargo Solutions (SEA), to co-develop logistics solutions for the production of electric vehicles (EVs) in Singapore. The partnership will enable the production of the first 'made in Singapore' EVs. PSA will provide bespoke logistics solutions, including control tower management and EV pre-assembly, to support the smart factory in Singapore. The partnership aims to enhance Singapore's advanced manufacturing capabilities and promote sustainable supply chain ecosystems.

site_title: European stock markets sink at open after Fed meeting
summary: European stock markets declined in early trading on January 27, 2022, after the US Federal Reserve signaled the end of pandemic-era cheap cash and hinted at a rate hike in March. London's FTSE 100 dropped 1.0%, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC each fell 1.5%. The Fed's hawkish turn, led by Jerome Powell, was seen as a surprise, causing global stocks to slump.

images.alt_text: In initial trade, London's benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 1.0 per cent on Thursday (Jan 27).

site_title: TDCX expands into South Korea, appoints new VP of operations to helm office
summary: TDCX, a Singaporean digital customer experience solutions provider, is expanding into South Korea, its fourth new market in 2 years. The company will begin operations with 3 projects, including an omnichannel customer experience project for a gaming company. Tony Bruno, EVP of North Asia and Business Strategy, sees South Korea as an "exciting market" due to its tech-savviness. Kim Minjee, current head of TDCX's Korean teams, has been appointed VP of Operations to oversee site operations and team development. The expansion aims to strengthen TDCX's Korean language capabilities and increase its market share.

site_title: Ho Ching to advise Swedish firm EQT's longer-hold investment fund
summary: Former Temasek CEO Ho Ching will join EQT's impact-driven longer-hold fund EQT Future as an advisor, providing external objectivity to the fund's strategic direction and setting a commitment to drive positive impact. The mission board, also including former HSBC India head Naina Lai Kidwai and Yara International president Svein Tore Holsether, will support the fund's investment processes and work with the investment advisory team. The fund aims to address climate change through science-based targets and has a target fund size of 4 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Through Ho Ching's appointment to the fund's mission board, she will provide external objectivity to the fund's strategic direction and set the bar for its commitment to drive positive impact, the company said in a statement.

site_title: Samsung reports 53% jump in profit despite supply chain woes
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 53.3% increase in operating profit in the fourth quarter of 2021, reaching 13.87 trillion won, driven by record sales of 279.6 trillion won for the year, an 18% jump. Strong demand for premium smartphones and high memory chip prices helped overcome pandemic-induced supply chain challenges. The company's semiconductor business accounted for over 63.7% of the quarter's total operating profit, and Samsung expects the smartphone market to grow in the third year of the pandemic.

site_title: SMEs in expansionary mode for 4 straight quarters: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have continued their expansion for four consecutive quarters, according to the OCBC SME Index. The Q4 2021 Index reached 52.6, indicating improved activity. Despite challenges in the food and beverage and building and construction sectors, collections grew by 13% compared to the previous quarter. The index attributes the resilience of SMEs to digitalization and e-commerce, but notes that downside risks, such as tightening of safe management measures and monetary policy tightening, remain.

images.alt_text: Things are expected to continue to look up for businesses in the first 3 months of this year, even as challenges remain in the food and beverage (F&B) and building and construction sectors.

site_title: Software group SAP to buy majority stake in US fintech firm Taulia
summary: SAP has agreed to buy a majority stake in US fintech firm Taulia, expanding its presence in supply-chain financing and working capital loans. Taulia helps suppliers receive early payments on delivered goods and services, with around 2 million suppliers using the platform and $500 billion in annual transaction volume. The deal is valued at less than $1 billion and will help SAP remove limited growth rates for its own products. SAP's cloud business has also seen growth, with forecasted 2022 cloud revenue between $17.6 billion and $17.9 billion.

site_title: Asia markets tumble on Fed signal towards March rate hike, STI down 0.35%
summary: Singapore stocks tumbled 0.35% to close at 3,260.03, following a volatile session, as Asian markets fell due to the Federal Reserve's signal towards a potential March rate hike. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 11.54 points. South Korean shares saw their sharpest decline since August 2020, while Japan's Nikkei index hit a 14-month low. The Fed appears to be "more firm" about rate hikes, with Fed chair Jerome Powell dodging a question on subsequent meetings.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) sank 0.35 per cent or 11.54 points to close at 3,260.03, after a volatile session.

site_title: SingHaiyi to be delisted on Jan 31
summary: SingHaiyi Group will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on January 31 due to its free float dropping below 10%. The company received regulatory approval to delist after its owners, Gordon Tang and his wife Celine, offered to privatize the company at S$0.117 per share, a 21.8% discount to its net asset value. The offer secured 98.15% valid acceptances, with the remaining shares to be acquired compulsorily.

site_title: DWS-Hines tie-up buys Soilbuild industrial building for undisclosed sum
summary: German asset management company DWS Group and US-based property investment firm Hines have announced the purchase of an industrial building, Bukit Batok Connection, through a joint venture. The property, valued at S$93.8 million, was acquired from Soilbuild Business Space Reit. The 9-storey industrial asset has a net lettable area of 377,776 square feet. The deal was confirmed after an earlier report by The Business Times. No disclosed price was given for the joint venture.

site_title: Kobe Bryant statue erected at crash site on death anniversary
summary: A 160-pound bronze statue of Kobe Bryant, erected at the site of the 2020 helicopter crash that killed him and his daughter Gianna, was unveiled on the 2-year anniversary of the tragedy. The temporary installation was created by sculptor Dan Medina and features Kobe in full uniform with Gianna holding a basketball. The names of the crash victims are inscribed on the base. The statue is a tribute to the memory of the deceased and a step towards a more permanent installation with city permission.

site_title: US, China confer on Ukraine, urge de-escalation and calm
summary: US and China confer on Ukraine, urging de-escalation and calm. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, stressing de-escalation and warning of security and economic risks from Russian aggression. China calls for calm and avoids escalating tensions, while the US rejects Russia's demand for NATO to pull back troops and bar Ukraine from joining the alliance. The two countries discuss arms control and confidence-building measures, with China expressing support for a new Minsk Agreement.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall into correction territory after Fed signals hikes
summary: Australian shares fell into correction territory for the first time in over a year, closing 1.8% lower, as the US Federal Reserve signaled interest rate hikes as early as March. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index is now 10% below its August 2021 high and on track for its worst month since March 2020. Tech stocks plummeted 5.1%, with gold stocks also falling 6.5%, while oil prices rose due to a stronger US dollar and tensions in Ukraine.

site_title: China's Dec industrial profits grow 4.2% y-o-y
summary: China's industrial profits grew 4.2% in December, a slower pace than the 9% gain in November. For 2021, industrial profits rose 34.3% year-over-year, down from a 38.0% increase in the first 11 months. This marks a decrease in the growth rate, potentially raising pressure on policymakers to address economic concerns.

site_title: Tales of roe at Caviar
summary: A new restaurant, Caviar, has opened at Palais Renaissance in Singapore, offering a 5- and 7-course menu for S$248-S$328. The restaurant's name draws an economic divide, but its modern European cuisine is generic, with familiar flavors and some nice touches. The kitchen crew is young and local, but lacks experience. The meal is heavy and lacks rhythm, but the food is decent, with highlights including a botan ebi tartare and halibut. The restaurant's rating is 6.5, making it a promising but not exceptional dining experience.

images.alt_text: A display of various brands of caviar at the chef's counter.
Refreshing botan ebi tartare in buttermilk dill sauce.
Bressan pigeon is slow cooked over binchotan and served with a pair of drummettes.

site_title: Bank of America considers moving staff from Hong Kong to Singapore: source
summary: Bank of America is considering relocating staff from Hong Kong to Singapore due to the city's strict zero Covid-19 approach. The US bank is reviewing roles in various business lines and operations, with contingency planning underway. Hong Kong's strict measures, including 21-day quarantine for incoming travelers, are forcing businesses to reevaluate their operations and potentially leading to a large-scale exodus of international workers and executives. This move is part of a broader trend of global banks reevaluating their presence in the city, which faces a talent crunch and is at risk of losing its status as a financial hub.

site_title: Your Spotify playlist of Tiger songs
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content: 

A list of 20 tiger-themed pop songs is compiled for the Year of the Tiger, including 'Roar' by Katy Perry, 'Eye Of The Tiger' by Survivor, and 'Tiger Man' by Elvis Presley. The list aims to celebrate the iconic animal and provide a soundtrack for the Year of the Tiger. The article is a collection of tiger-themed pop songs without any specific narrative or conclusion.

site_title: Decked out for Chinese New Year with an eye on keeping traditions alive
summary: Chinese New Year celebrations will be muted this year, but Lynette Wong of 1B2G IMPORTANT DESIGN is determined to keep traditions alive. She decorates her home with vintage furniture, red accents, and symbolic flowers like chrysanthemums, which signify longevity. Wong also orders traditional snacks like pineapple tarts and kueh bangkit, and her mother cooks a special menu for reunion dinner. The family still wears new clothes in festive colors and exchanges ang pao gifts. Despite the smaller gatherings, Wong considers Chinese New Year one of her favorite times of the year, enjoying the festive atmosphere and time with loved ones.

images.alt_text: The Astral bench in the foyer provides another seating space for guests when they come to visit.

site_title: Paw-fect looks for the new year
summary: Luxury brands such as Gucci, Paul Smith, Louis Vuitton, Salvatore Ferragamo, Burberry, Valentino, and Moschino have launched tiger-themed collections for Chinese New Year, paying homage to the symbol of power and dominion. The designs feature tiger prints in various colors and patterns, from Gucci's 1960s archival design to Burberry's bold monogram print. The collections include clothing, accessories, home items, and even a jigsaw puzzle, showcasing the tiger's strong and confident spirit.

site_title: GIC and Equinix to build 2 data centres in Seoul with US$525m joint venture
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is establishing a $525 million joint venture with Equinix to develop and operate two xScale data centres in Seoul, Korea. GIC will own an 80% equity interest, while Equinix will hold 20%. The data centres are expected to provide over 45 MW of power capacity to serve hyperscale companies, including cloud service providers. This expansion will bring Equinix's xScale data centre portfolio to over $8 billion and 720 MW of power capacity.

site_title: Spotify removes Neil Young's music after ultimatum over Joe Rogan
summary: Spotify has removed Neil Young's music from its platform after the singer expressed concerns over Joe Rogan's vaccine misinformation on his popular podcast. Young had asked Spotify to remove Rogan or Young, but not both, after an episode promoted baseless conspiracy theories about the pandemic. This decision comes after 270 scientists and medical professionals urged Spotify to establish a misinformation policy. Spotify has previously removed 20,000 podcast episodes containing Covid misinformation, including over 40 episodes of Rogan's podcast with an estimated 11 million listeners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Thursday, down 0.54 points or 0.04% to 1,515.22. Volume reached 327.12 million lots worth RM188.58 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 204 to 142.

site_title: Five fiercely good reads for the Tiger year
summary: Five notable works of science fiction and fantasy for the Tiger year are highlighted, including "The Paper Menagerie and Other Stories" by Ken Liu, "The Night Tiger" by Yangsze Choo, "Man Tiger" by Eka Kurniawan, "When You Trap A Tiger" by Tae Keller, and "Life Of Pi" by Yann Martel. Liu's title story won major awards, while Choo's "The Night Tiger" became a New York Times bestseller after Reese Witherspoon's recommendation. These works draw on Asian mythologies and explore themes of identity, trauma, and the power of stories.

site_title: Barclays lost about US$100m on collapsed Advent bid: sources
summary: Barclays suffered a significant loss of approximately $100 million due to a collapsed $8 billion biotech acquisition bid by Advent International and GIC. The loss occurred after the bid failed to reach the required 90% tender threshold, resulting in Barclays holding exposure to the devalued Swedish krona. This incident highlights the risks associated with contingent hedging contracts in cross-border deals. The failed bid also impacted other banks, including Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank, which lost around $20 million each.

site_title: Early signs of rising inflation may emerge at year-end: Bank Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo warned of potential early signs of rising inflation by the end of this year, prompting a possible interest rate hike. The bank aims to mitigate global spillover and excess liquidity by normalizing its monetary policy. Indonesia recently announced a 300 basis points hike in the reserve requirement ratio, and Warjiyo plans to rely on bond yield flexibility to achieve its goals. This move is part of the bank's efforts to maintain price stability and address potential inflationary pressures.

site_title: US Fed's hawkish roadmap sets the path for peers in recovering Asia
summary: The US Federal Reserve's hawkish comments, led by Chair Jerome Powell, are pressuring Asian economies to accelerate policy tightening despite contained inflation and mixed pandemic recovery outlooks. This has led to a broad selloff in Asian markets, with Indonesia and Singapore already adopting more hawkish stances. At least 7 central banks in Asia have policy decisions coming up next month, with emerging economies most vulnerable to investor outflows and currency volatility. The Fed's stance is expected to influence policy decisions in countries like India, Malaysia, and the Philippines, with China easing monetary policy to support a slowing economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as Federal Reserve signals end of pandemic-era cheap cash
summary: Asia's equity markets plummeted on Thursday following the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on interest rates, with Jerome Powell signaling the end of pandemic-era cheap cash. The Fed's decision to raise interest rates in March was seen as a surprise, causing a late sell-off on Wall Street. The move was met with concern among investors, leading to a decline in Asian markets. The decision is expected to impact the region's economy and affect the global financial landscape.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank, RHB raise Suntec Reit target price on post-FY2021 results
summary: Maybank Securities and RHB have increased their target prices for Suntec Reit T82U to S$1.45 and S$1.77 respectively, maintaining "hold" and "buy" calls after the Reit's distribution per unit increased by 9.8% for FY2021. The target price revisions follow Suntec Reit's flat closing price at S$1.55.

site_title: Expats head for the exit as Singapore's Covid controls bite
summary: Expats in Singapore are fleeing the city-state due to its strict COVID-19 controls, including mask-wearing, social distancing, and travel restrictions. Many, like Israeli human resources professional Atar Sandler, have packed their bags for countries like the US, citing the difficulty of living without family, friends, and the ability to travel. The exodus is seen as a response to the prolonged pandemic measures, which have made life in Singapore feel isolating and unfulfilling.

site_title: HSBC's investment bank plots different path as Wall Street booms
summary: HSBC's investment bank is shifting its focus away from competing with Wall Street giants, instead concentrating on growth in wealth management and debt financing. The bank aims to become a more capital-efficient unit, cutting risk-weighted assets by $100 billion by the end of 2022. Greg Guyett, the new head of global banking and markets, believes the bank can excel in its core markets and add value, rather than trying to be a global leader in investment banking. This strategy may lead to a 20% increase in revenue, with a focus on Asia and debt financing.

site_title: Singapore industrial space rents, prices up in Q4 2021, fewer spaces completed: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space rents and prices rose in Q4 2021, with a 1.4% increase in prices and 0.2% rise in rentals. Total available stock rose by 11,000 sq m, but occupancy rates remained at 90.1%. Experts predict further growth in the industrial sector in 2022, with rental increases expected to range from 2-5% for multiple-user factory spaces and 3-5% for hi-tech factory and warehouse spaces. The incoming supply in 2022 is expected to cap the upside of rental growth, but manufacturing and logistics sectors are expected to drive rental improvements.

site_title: LG Energy Solution jumps in debut to become South Korea's second-most valuable company
summary: LG Energy Solution (LGES) made its debut as South Korea's second-most valuable company, with a market valuation of over 105.3 trillion won (S$118.1 billion). The company's shares opened at 597,000 won, but fell as much as 25% in early trading. LGES surpassed Samsung Electronics Co as the country's most valuable company, with the IPO attracting bids worth US$13 trillion.

site_title: New peaks for food delivery as the sector sees consolidation and maturity: Momentum Works
summary: The food delivery sector in South-east Asia reached a new peak of US$15.5 billion in 2021, with a 30% increase from 2020. The growth was uneven across the region, with Thailand and Malaysia experiencing the highest year-on-year growth. The sector is undergoing consolidation, with Grab accounting for half of the region's food delivery GMV. Players are shifting focus to creating new growth via cloud kitchens and quick commerce, and expanding services to increase customer retention and efficiency. The next frontier for food delivery players is groceries, which has a huge underpenetrated market in the region.

site_title: Job scams the next big worry, with S$6.5m lost in first half of 2021
summary: The number of reported job scams in Singapore has skyrocketed, with 658 cases in the first half of 2021, a 16-fold increase from 2020. Victims lost approximately S$6.5 million, with the largest sum lost by a single victim being S$676,000. The police attribute the surge to the pandemic, citing the increased use of digital payments as a double-edged sword. Authorities have responded by leveraging technology, including a robotic process automation system called Project Combat, which has enabled them to reach hundreds of potential victims in minutes.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends at 14-month low as tech stocks fall on Fed tightening timeline
summary: Japan's Nikkei index ended at a 14-month low, falling 3.11% to 26,170, due to technology heavyweights being affected by the US Federal Reserve's plans to tighten policy. The broader Topix also declined 2.61% to 1,842.44. Electric motor maker Nidec, technology startup SoftBank Group, and game maker Sony Group fell 6.17%, 9.15%, and 6.74% respectively. Only two industry sub-indexes on the exchange gained, with insurance firms and oil explorers rising 0.37% and 0.04% respectively.

site_title: Intel posts record quarterly revenue, sees supply strains through year
summary: Intel posted record fourth-quarter revenue of $19.5 billion, surpassing expectations, but forecasted first-quarter earnings below Wall Street expectations due to ongoing global supply chain challenges. The company expects supply constraints to persist this year and into next year, despite its confidence in demand for its chips. Intel forecasted a gross margin of 52%, which raised concerns about pressure on profitability.

site_title: Philippines' GDP grows 7.7% y-o-y in Q4, beats forecast
summary: The Philippines' economy expanded 7.7% in the fourth quarter of 2021, beating the forecast of 6.0% and exceeding the government's 5.0-5.5% target. This brings the full-year GDP growth to 5.6%, surpassing expectations. The growth is attributed to a slowdown in Covid-19 infections ahead of the Christmas holidays, leading to a pick-up in consumer spending. The stronger-than-expected growth suggests the country's economy is recovering well from the pandemic.

site_title: Mystery black diamond 'The Enigma' goes up for auction
summary: A 555.55-carat black diamond, known as "The Enigma", is up for auction at Sotheby's in Beverly Hills, with bidding starting February 3. The diamond, a carbonado, is believed to be one of the largest faceted Fancy Black Diamonds ever sold, with possible origins from outer space. Scientists theorize it formed deep within the Earth's interior or at impact sites, with interstellar hypotheses also considered. The diamond is expected to sell between $4 million and $7 million, with research into its origins potentially revealing insights into deep-Earth mineralogy and the evolution of the solar system.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell over 1% in early trading on January 27, following losses across Asia and the US. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.39% to 23,952.01, amid concerns the Federal Reserve will lift interest rates in March. This move was seen as a response to Jerome Powell's comments, which hinted at a rate hike. Other Asian markets, such as the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices, also saw minimal changes.

site_title: Gold flat near 1-week low after hawkish Fed, higher yields
summary: Gold prices remained steady near a 1-week low after the Federal Reserve announced plans to hike interest rates in March, pushing US Treasury yields and the dollar higher. Spot gold was unchanged at $1,817.29 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.7% to $1,817.20. The decision increased the opportunity cost of holding non-interest paying gold, making it less attractive as an inflationary hedge. The dollar index also rose to a high not seen since November 22.

site_title: New Pacific Alliance-Singapore trade pact creates opportunities for growth, jobs and prosperity: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the signing of the Pacific Alliance-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (PASFTA), a deal that aims to boost cross-Pacific links and foster economic growth, jobs, and prosperity. The pact, signed at the Pacific Alliance Summit, will create opportunities for businesses and individuals to trade and invest between Singapore and the Pacific Alliance countries, which include Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru. The agreement will institutionalize and strengthen economic ties between the five countries, and Singapore will become the first Associate State of the Pacific Alliance.

site_title: London is top global finance centre but beaten by Singapore in access to talent: study
summary: London remains the top global financial centre, but ranks second in access to talent, behind Singapore, according to a study by the City of London Corporation. New York is in third place, followed by Frankfurt, Paris, Hong Kong, and Tokyo. The study highlights the UK's challenges in attracting global talent due to the post-Brexit immigration system and high taxes, with the Finance Ministry reviewing some tax rates. The study urges policymakers to ensure businesses have access to the best global talent to maintain London's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: London remains the top global financial centre, according to a study from its own financial district, but is outgunned by New York and Singapore in access to talent, while Paris is adding competition from the European Union.

site_title: Russia, Ukraine agree to keep ceasefire, new talks next month
summary: Russia and Ukraine agreed to maintain a ceasefire in eastern Ukraine, following talks in Paris. The deal, hailed as a "good signal," aims to resolve separatist fighting since 2014. The talks did not address Russia's concerns over NATO's presence in eastern Europe. A ceasefire is set to be observed by all parties, with new talks scheduled for next month. This development follows concerns of a potential Russian military intervention in Ukraine.

site_title: Crypto exchange FTX US valued at US$8b as first fundraise draws SoftBank, Temasek
summary: Crypto exchange FTX US raised $400 million in its first funding round, valuing the company at $8 billion, with investors including SoftBank, Temasek, and others. The funding will be used to grow the user base and launch new business lines, with plans to expand staff and consider strategic investments and acquisitions. FTX US competes with leading crypto exchanges Coinbase and Binance, and has seen significant growth, including a 52% increase in users quarter-over-quarter and an average daily volume of $360 million.

site_title: China launches three-year anti-money laundering campaign
summary: China has launched a three-year anti-money laundering campaign to safeguard national security and social stability. The campaign, led by the People's Bank of China and the Ministry of Public Security, aims to curb the spread of money laundering and related crimes. This move comes after China published revised rules to strengthen financial firms' anti-money laundering ability. The campaign involves 11 Chinese government bodies and is seen as a response to the severe situation of combating money laundering.

site_title: Aruna reels in another US$30m in funding round led by Vertex
summary: Aruna, an Indonesia-based fishery and marine platform, has raised US$30 million in a follow-on Series A round led by Vertex Ventures South-east Asia and India. The funding brings Aruna's total Series A funds to US$65 million. The company aims to expand its global market share and hire more talent with the newly injected funds. Aruna has grown 400 times since 2017 and has created 5,000 job opportunities in rural areas of Indonesia, selling 44 million kg of seafood to 8 countries in 2021.

images.alt_text: Aruna's co-founders are, from left: Indraka Fadhlillah, Utari Octavianty and Farid Naufal Aslam.

site_title: Tesla reports record profit, sees more supply chain woes in 2022
summary: Tesla reported a record US$5.5 billion profit in 2021, driven by a 71% revenue increase to US$53.8 billion. Despite a 87% jump in auto deliveries, the company expects supply chain issues to continue affecting production through 2022. Tesla plans to grow its manufacturing capacity and increase production, but acknowledges that supply chain stability will be a key factor in achieving its 50% annual growth target. The company's shares were unchanged in after-hours trading at US$937.65.

site_title: Australia: Energy, miners push shares up 1% despite Federal Reserve's rate-hike signals
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Thursday, driven by gains in the energy and mining sectors, despite US Federal Reserve signals of potential interest rate hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index surged 1.1% to 7,042.1, with energy firms such as Woodside and Santos advancing 4% each, and mining companies like BHP and Rio Tinto gaining 0.5-4%. The rebound came despite Wall Street's decline overnight, with investors focusing on strong commodity prices and the Fed's lack of immediate rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% at the opening bell on Thursday, led by US stocks ending lower due to a possible March interest rate hike. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 12.91 points to 3,258.66. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the top losers, while oil exploration and production company Rex International rose 3.1% after receiving in-principle approval to transfer its listing to the mainboard.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) shed 0.4 per cent or 12.91 points to 3,258.66 as at 9.01 am.

site_title: Temasek-backed payments firm SumUp seeks new funds at 20b euro valuation: sources
summary: SumUp, a UK payments firm backed by Temasek, is considering a new funding round that could value the company at approximately 20 billion euros (S$30.3 billion). The company may seek over 500 million euros from investors, making it one of the most valuable startups in the UK. Deliberations are in the early stages, and no final decisions have been made on the timing or target of any fundraising. A representative for SumUp declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: General Motors plans 8,000 new tech hires to power EV goals
summary: General Motors plans to hire over 8,000 new technical staff this year to accelerate its electric vehicle and software development. The company aims to boost its North America EV production capacity to over 1 million units by 2025, competing with rival Ford and Tesla. GM also plans to expand its digital commerce footprint with an online used vehicle market called CarBravo, as the US automaker intensifies its efforts to become an EV leader.

images.alt_text: General Motors said on Wednesday (Jan 26) it would hire more than 8,000 new technical staff this year, as the US automaker accelerates its development of electric vehicles and software-driven services.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit Q3 DPU up 14.6% to S$0.0235
summary: AIMS Apac Reit reported a 14.6% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0235, driven by higher gross revenue and net property income. The real estate investment trust (Reit) acquired the fully-leased Woolworths Headquarters in Sydney, contributing to the revenue growth. Portfolio occupancy increased to 97.6%, with a weighted average lease expiry of 4.85 years. The Reit's aggregate leverage remains within the 50% limit set by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and it has financial flexibility to pursue new acquisition opportunities.

images.alt_text: Boardriders Asia-Pacific headquarters in Burleigh Heads, Queensland, one of AA Reit's properties in Australia. AA Reit's manager said the higher DPU was supported by the increase in gross revenue, which went up year on year by 14.5 per cent to S$36.8 million from S$32.1 million.

site_title: ESR-Reit posts 2.7% drop in Q4 core DPU to S$0.00721; manager sees improvement in leasing sentiment
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 2.7% drop in Q4 core DPU to S$0.00721, down from S$0.84 in the same period last year. However, the manager sees improvement in leasing sentiment, with a 3% increase in portfolio rental reversion in Q4, led by gains in the high-spec industrial and general industrial segments. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate increased to 92% in Q4, and leasing prospects for the business park sector are expected to remain stable despite ongoing Covid-19 challenges.

images.alt_text: ESR-Reit's higher gross revenue for FY2021 was in part due to contribution from 46A Tanjong Penjuru, which it acquired on Jun 29, 2021.

site_title: Chevron, Marathon raise quarterly dividend as energy prices rally
summary: US oil companies Chevron and Marathon Oil raised quarterly dividends amid a rebound in fuel demand and rising energy prices. Chevron increased its dividend by 8 cents to $1.42 per share, while Marathon raised it by 16.7% to 7 cents per share. The increase follows a 50% jump in US oil prices last year, driven by the global economic recovery. This move reflects companies' decision to return cash to shareholders through buybacks and dividends.

site_title: Samsung Electronics' operating profit up by 53.3% in Q4
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 53.3% increase in operating profit to 13.87 trillion won (S$15.6 billion) in Q4 2021, driven by record annual sales and solid demand for premium smartphone lines. The company attributed the growth to competitive products, despite ongoing uncertainty, and cited strong demand for devices powered by its chips, as well as home appliances. Consumer demand for high-end products such as foldable phones also contributed to the boost in profits around the holiday season.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics' operating profit was up by 53.3 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2021 driven by record annual sales, the company said in a regulatory filing Thursday.

site_title: Evergrande shares fall as restructuring roadmap disappoint creditors
summary: Evergrande shares plummeted 9.6% to HK$1.60, their lowest in nearly two weeks, after a thinly detailed plan to restructure the debt-laden developer was met with skepticism by creditors. Evergrande, once China's top developer, has racked up over $300 billion in debt and is struggling to repay creditors. The company's executives assured creditors that they would work together to achieve a risk management solution, but some bondholders were disappointed by the lack of insight into Evergrande's plans. The move comes as Beijing tightens control over the property sector.

site_title: Celebrating the Tiger year
summary: The article celebrates the Chinese New Year, focusing on the upcoming Tiger year. It provides a guide to dressing the part, decorating, and dining on traditional tiger-themed foods, including roe. The article also features lifestyle articles, such as a review of mod-Indian cuisine and a look at zero-waste living. Additionally, it highlights various business ventures, including a new restaurant and financial literacy initiatives.

site_title: North Korea fires unidentified 'projectile': South Korea
summary: North Korea fired an unidentified projectile into the East Sea, its sixth test this year, according to South Korea's military. The country has conducted multiple tests this month, including suspected cruise missiles and hypersonic missiles, amid stalled talks with the US and economic sanctions. The tests come at a delicate time, with China hosting the Winter Olympics next month and South Korea gearing up for a presidential election in March. The incident raises concerns about North Korea's nuclear ambitions and its potential to escalate tensions in the region.

site_title: Don't write off Hong Kong as a financial centre just yet
summary: Hong Kong has avoided being written off as a financial center despite its strict COVID-19 measures and crackdown on democratic opposition. The city's isolation, including 3-week quarantines for returning residents, has raised concerns about its survival. However, China's capital controls and the city's unique "one country, two systems" arrangement ensure its economic stability, making it more secure than most global rivals, with the exception of New York.

site_title: US: Dow ends volatile day lower as Federal Reserve signals likely March rate hike
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled a likely March interest rate hike amid elevated inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4% to 34,168.09, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2% to 4,349.93. Powell stated that the US economy is strong enough to handle higher borrowing costs, but also plans to reduce its massive bond holdings. The move was described as "hawkish" by economists, adding to market unease sparked by the Fed's pivot towards monetary tightening.

site_title: New Zealand's annual inflation surges to three-decade high
summary: New Zealand's annual inflation surged to a three-decade high of 5.9% in the fourth quarter, surpassing analyst forecasts. This is the fastest rate since 1990 and indicates the central bank will likely tighten monetary policy further next month. The inflation increase was driven by a 1.4% rise in the quarter ending December, following a 2.2% increase in the third quarter. This development highlights the country's struggle with rising prices, and its central bank's efforts to control inflation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after mixed US close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday following a mixed US close, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.39% and the Topix index gaining 0.51%. The move comes after Fed Chair Jerome Powell signalled an interest rate hike is likely in March. The positive start in Tokyo is attributed to investors brushing off new US tariffs and maintaining a positive outlook despite split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday following a mixed close on Wall Street after Fed Chair Jerome Powell signalled an interest rate hike is likely in March.

site_title: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition makes trading debut at S$5, unchanged from IPO price
summary: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition (NTAA) made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$5, unchanged from its IPO price. The SPAC's offering was 3.4 times subscribed, with 13 cornerstone investors subscribing to 16 million units. The gross proceeds of S$150 million will primarily be used for the consummation of the initial business combination and payment to independent shareholders. NTAA is targeting companies in the technology and industrials sectors in the Indo-Pacific region, including Industry 4.0 and next-generation semiconductors.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust H2 DPU down 14% to S$0.036
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 14% decline in its second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.036, down from S$0.0419 in the same period last year. Total property income increased 5% to S$97.4 million, primarily driven by income contributions from new acquisitions. However, lower portfolio occupancy and utilities income were partly offset by higher expenses. The trust's gearing ratio stood at 35% and had "ample debt headroom" of S$960 million. Despite a challenging leasing environment, the trust reported leasing momentum and expects leasing interest to pick up.

site_title: UBS agrees to buy robo-adviser Wealthfront for US$1.4b
summary: UBS has agreed to acquire US robo-adviser Wealthfront for $1.4 billion in cash, adding over $27 billion in assets under management and 470,000 clients. The deal aims to expand UBS's presence in the affluent market, targeting customers with $250,000 to $2 million in assets. The acquisition accelerates UBS's plan to launch a digital wealth manager in the US and marks the bank's first major fintech acquisition under CEO Ralph Hamers.

images.alt_text: UBS Group agreed to buy US robo-adviser Wealthfront for US$1.4 billion in cash, as chief executive officer Ralph Hamers tapped a fintech firm for his first major acquisition.

site_title: PropertyBT: Are private homes in Singapore too pricey? An in-depth look (Ep 3)
summary: Singapore's private home prices may not be too expensive, according to Leslie Yee's article. Industry experts, including Leonard Tay and Wong Siew Ying, suggest that income growth and affordability can help justify high prices. However, property cooling measures and cheap credit also impact the market. Experts also discuss the challenges of meeting private ownership aspirations in a global city like Singapore. Overall, the podcast presents a nuanced view of Singapore's property market, highlighting both the benefits and drawbacks of high prices.

site_title: Ackman's Pershing Square takes new position in Netflix
summary: Billionaire investor William Ackman's hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, has taken a new position in Netflix, buying over 3.1 million shares worth more than $1 billion since its stock price tumbled on January 20. Ackman praises Netflix's "best-in-class management team" and believes the company has pricing power and delivers industry-leading content. His move comes after the firm unwound a piece of its interest rate hedge, generating $1.25 billion in profits. Ackman sees streaming as a promising business model, alongside his investment in Universal Music Group.

site_title: Moderna begins trial of Omicron-specific vaccine booster: statement
summary: Moderna has begun clinical trials of an Omicron-specific vaccine booster, targeting 600 adults with varying vaccination histories. The trials will evaluate the booster as both a third and fourth dose. This move aims to combat the Omicron variant of Covid-19, which has raised concerns about vaccine effectiveness. The trials will provide insights into the booster's efficacy and potential impact on the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Federal Reserve pulling back on stimulus, preparing for rate hikes
summary: The US Federal Reserve will end its bond-buying stimulus program in early March, marking the end of quantitative easing (QE) and paving the way for interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The decision follows a series of rate hikes in 2021 and 2022, with economists expecting three or four rate hikes in 2022. The Fed has been preparing for this move amid rising consumer prices and a strong economy.

site_title: Denmark to lift Covid-19 curbs in return to 'life as we knew it'
summary: Denmark is set to lift virtually all Covid restrictions starting next Tuesday, becoming the first EU country to do so despite a record Omicron wave. The decision is based on Denmark's high vaccination rate and a milder Omicron variant. Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen stated that "life as we knew it before corona" will resume. This move is seen as a significant shift in Denmark's approach to the pandemic, with the country prioritizing a return to normalcy over strict controls.

site_title: Can Asean achieve its circular economy ambitions?
summary: Asean's pursuit of a circular economy to address climate change risks and enhance economic resilience is hindered by conceptual ambiguity and lack of clarity. Despite a framework launched in 2021, the grouping faces challenges in convincing corporations and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) of its viability. To dispel doubts, Asean can take concrete steps such as instituting industry monitoring standards and learning from the European Union's circular economy action plan. SMEs, which constitute 90% of Asean companies, must be specifically addressed to achieve buy-in for circular economy practices, with governments needed to show how they stand to benefit and receive support.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MCT, KIT, GuocoLand, ESR-Reit, Ascendas India Trust, AA Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Thursday included Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT), Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT), GuocoLand, ESR-Reit, Ascendas India Trust, and AA Reit. MCT reported a 5.6% increase in net property income, while KIT's distribution per unit rose 3.2%. GuocoLand posted a 195% rise in net profit, driven by higher revenue growth from residential developments. ESR-Reit's distribution per unit decreased 1.8% to S$0.01433. Ascendas India Trust's DPU fell 14% to S$0.036, and AA Reit's DPU rose 14.6% to S$0.0235.

site_title: GuocoLand H1 profit rises 195% to S$67.5m
summary: GuocoLand's first half profit soared 195% to S$67.5 million, driven by broad-based growth across its business segments. Earnings per share rose to 5.22 Singapore cents, up from 1.2 cents a year ago. The company attributed the growth to stronger revenue, without specifying the segments that contributed to the increase.

site_title: S Korea's 1,000t won household debt spurs bank bond sales
summary: South Korea's households have reached a record 1,000 trillion won ($1.12 trillion) in debt, exceeding the nation's economic output. This has prompted banks to sell bonds, known as contingent convertible notes (CoCos), to bolster their capital and protect against potential economic shocks. Korean lenders, including Shinhan Financial Group and Hana Financial Group, have priced additional CoCos to raise capital, despite elevated yields. The move is seen as a response to the nation's high household debt burden, which Fitch Ratings says "stands out" globally.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia to scrap QE on Feb 1, wait with rate hikes till Nov: poll
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) plans to end its quantitative easing (QE) program on February 1, but will delay its first interest rate hike until November, according to a Reuters poll. This decision comes after the country's underlying inflation surged at its fastest annual pace since 2014 in the December quarter, suggesting that recent price pressures may not be transitory. The RBA's cash rate has been at a record low of 0.10% since 2016.

site_title: Oil breaks US$90/barrel for the first time since 2014 on Russia tensions
summary: Oil prices surged to $90 a barrel for the first time in seven years due to rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine, which may disrupt global energy supplies. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 2% to $89.96 and $87.35, respectively. The US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on expected interest rate hikes were also seen as hawkish, contributing to the price increase. Russia's amassed troops on Ukraine's border and potential gas supply disruptions to Europe fueled market concerns, with US Secretary of State Tony Blinken assuring that global energy supplies would not be interrupted.

site_title: Grab and foodpanda go physical in race to win q-commerce grocery wars
summary: Grab and foodpanda are competing intensely in Singapore's q-commerce grocery market, aiming to win user mindshare and develop habits. Quick commerce, which delivers groceries within 15 minutes, has become a solution to in-store shortages. Both companies are racing to develop and refine their services, with Grab and foodpanda vying for market share. The competition is expected to drive innovation and potentially disrupt traditional grocery delivery models.

site_title: Opec+ delegates expect to ratify plan for modest output hike
summary: Opec+ delegates are expected to ratify a modest 400,000 barrel per day production hike for March, following a gradual monthly supply increase plan since July. However, the coalition's success in implementing this plan is uncertain due to capacity constraints and production shortfalls among members. The move aims to satisfy rebounding oil demand, but the oil market remains vulnerable to geopolitical risks, including a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine and Iran's nuclear negotiations.

site_title: Global supply chain woes may linger into 2023 as Covid-19 persists
summary: Global supply chain disruptions may persist into 2023 due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, particularly with the emergence of the Omicron variant. Key sectors such as energy, agriculture, and semiconductors are heavily impacted, leading to increased prices and delays. While some optimists expect improvements in the first quarter, the global supply chain remains vulnerable to disruptions, including geopolitical tensions and protectionism. Businesses must adapt by building resilience and leveraging technology to mitigate risks, with a robust risk-response framework essential for navigating the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: WTO lets China impose tariffs on US in Obama-era case
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has authorized China to impose $645 million in compensatory tariffs on the US, stemming from a decade-long case over anti-subsidy tariffs imposed by the US between 2008 and 2012. China challenged the tariffs, which targeted 22 Chinese products, and won a ruling that found the US could not treat Chinese companies with majority government ownership as controlled by the state. This is a symbolic victory for China, which had initially sought $2.4 billion in retaliatory tariffs.

site_title: Shanghai grannies knit love and pride into Olympic bouquets
summary: Shanghai pensioners have spent 3 months crocheting over 4,400 roses, which will be used to create Olympic bouquets for medal winners. The woolly roses, symbolizing the blossoming careers of athletes, are made with intricate stitching and will serve as a lifelong keepsake. The project, led by a crafting club, is the group's biggest and most important undertaking, with each rose taking several hours to make. The finished bouquets will represent China and be presented to athletes worldwide, bringing pride to the elderly women behind the labor of love.

site_title: CBDC must preserve defining features of physical money
summary: Retail central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) should preserve the defining features of physical money, including privacy, trust, and fungibility, to ensure broad and sustainable public access and adoption. CBDCs can offer additional enhancements such as programmability, automating transactions and decision-making processes, while minimizing risks to trust in the currency. Greater flexibility and autonomy for low-level transactions, such as anonymous payment tiers, can also be critical for inclusive reach among unbanked and underbanked populations.

site_title: Europe: Shares show signs of recovery as Federal Reserve meeting awaited
summary: European shares rose 1.7% to their best session since early December, with energy, travel, and technology stocks rebounding ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index extended its gains, with oil & gas stocks rising 4.0% and technology stocks bouncing after being pressured by hawkish Fed expectations. Markets are priced for a first rate hike in March and three more quarter-point increases by the end of the year, with investors awaiting the Fed's interest rate plan update.

site_title: Sultan Plaza collective sale closing date extended to Mar 3
summary: The closing date of Sultan Plaza's collective sale has been extended to March 3, 2022, to obtain an in-principle approval for the sale of an adjacent piece of land. The original closing date was February 10, 2022. The extension aims to give certainty to potential buyers and allow developers more time to evaluate the site's potential and land pricing. Interested developers can choose from three redevelopment options: a hotel, commercial and residential development, or a fully commercial building. The reserve price remains at S$360 million.

site_title: US dollar consolidates below 2½ week highs
summary: The US dollar consolidated below its 2½ week high on Wednesday, January 26, as risk sentiment stabilized before a Federal Reserve meeting where policymakers are expected to signal readiness to start raising interest rates from March. The dollar briefly touched a high of 96.30 against a basket of currencies on Tuesday before ending below that level. Market sentiment remains fragile, with traders waiting for clues on the timing and pace of interest rate hikes and quantitative tightening.

site_title: Yes, the Cold War is over
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict is not a rerun of the 1961 Berlin crisis, nor is it a Cold War 2.0. Experts question whether Russia should be designated a superpower due to its economic struggles and lack of global influence. President Vladimir Putin argues that the US and Western allies have taken advantage of Russia's weakness, expanding NATO beyond its borders and posing a threat to his country's national security. The US has no direct national interests at stake in Ukraine, and President Biden would not declare war on Russia if it invades parts of Ukraine. Instead, Germany, France, and European countries should lead the response to Russia's moves. The Cold War era is over, and the US is no longer at the height of its geo-strategic power.

site_title: 580 Covid-19 patients hospitalised in Singapore; 44 need oxygen support, 11 in ICU
summary: Singapore reported 580 Covid-19 hospitalizations, with 44 requiring oxygen support and 11 in the ICU as of January 26. This represents an increase of 71 hospitalizations from the previous day. No Covid-19 deaths were reported.

site_title: Elton John has Covid, postpones US tour dates
summary: Elton John has tested positive for Covid-19 and postponed some US concert dates of his "Farewell Yellow Brick Road" tour. Despite mild symptoms, John will reschedule the shows and expects to recover in time for concerts in Arkansas this weekend. The 50-year music career icon is fully vaccinated and boosted, prioritizing his safety and that of his team. His tour, which began in 2018, will continue across North America and Europe before concluding in 2023.

site_title: The reasons behind the current stockmarket turmoil
summary: US stocks have suffered a 10% decline in the first three weeks of 2022, with technology shares leading the downturn. The Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates twice in six months is expected to squeeze corporate profits from decelerating revenue growth and rising wage costs.
