Higher oil and commodity prices also contribute to raw-material costs. The market's valuation is considered expensive, with stocks priced at 36 times earnings. A potential correction in the market could benefit the Fed, but investors remain cautious, with concerns about labor bottlenecks and valuation.

images.alt_text: Stocks in America look terrifyingly expensive. A measure popularised by Robert Shiller of Yale University puts America's stock prices at a steep 36 times their earnings, adjusted for the business cycle.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 9.8% rise in H2 DPU
summary: Suntec Reit posted a 9.8% rise in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.04512, driven by higher distribution income from operations and contributions from newly acquired assets in London. Gross revenue and net property income also increased, with a 15.3% and 30.3% rise respectively. The Reit manager attributed the strong performance to retail business recovery and resilience in its office portfolio. The company aims to further enhance income stability through proactive lease management and sourcing of high-quality assets.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher ahead of Fed announcement
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on January 26, 2022, ahead of a Federal Reserve policy meeting announcement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 223.09 points, or 0.65%, to 34,520.82, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 51.98 and 332.47 points, respectively, or 1.19% and 2.46%. The gains were supported by a positive outlook from Microsoft and anticipation of the Fed's plans to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Wednesday (Jan 26) after 2 sessions of turbulent trading, supported by a stellar outlook from Microsoft and ahead of a Federal Reserve policy meeting announcement for cues on its plans to curb inflation.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 3.2% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.0192
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 3.2% rise in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0192 in FY2021, marking the first increase since FY2016. The FY2021 DPU of S$0.0378 was a 1.6% increase from FY2020. This uptrend in DPU is a positive sign for the trust, with FY2021's DPU representing the first increase from its historical annual payout of S$0.0372 since FY2016.

site_title: Hedge funds face new SEC disclosures
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission plans to propose requiring large hedge funds and private-equity firms to report significant losses, major redemptions, and other extraordinary events in near real-time. This change aims to help protect the financial system during market meltdowns and wild swings, as seen in the 2021 meme stock mania. The proposed rule would require funds to submit confidential forms to the SEC within one business day of certain events, such as changes to prime-brokerage relationships or counter-party defaults.

images.alt_text: The regulator says this will help it protect the financial system during meltdowns and wild swings like the meme stock mania that roiled markets a year ago.

site_title: 'Resilient' suburban malls lift FCT tenants' sales above pre-Covid levels
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's portfolio of suburban retail malls in Singapore saw sales rise 2 percentage points in the first quarter of 2022, drawing level with pre-Covid levels in October 2021. Tenant sales rose 6% above 2019 levels in December, driven by a shift towards more purposeful visits to the malls, with shoppers visiting for specific activities like eating or shopping. Despite a 66% drop in shopper traffic, the trust's sales have held up due to its diversified tenant base and the adaptation of F&B tenants to Covid-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: Responding to a question on whether FCT would be interested in acquiring the south wing of Northpoint City mall (above), Richard Ng, the CEO of the Reit manager, says that it is a "a question of when (sponsor) Frasers Property intends to sell the asset".

site_title: Crypto money laundering rises 30% in 2021, says Chainalysis
summary: Cryptocurrency money laundering rose 30% in 2021, with cybercriminals laundering $8.6 billion in cryptocurrencies, according to Chainalysis. This represents a 30% increase from 2020 and brings the total laundered since 2017 to over $33 billion. Most of the total has moved to centralized exchanges. Decentralized finance applications saw a 17% increase in receiving laundered funds, while wallet addresses associated with theft sent $750 million worth of crypto to these platforms. The increase is attributed to the growth of both legitimate and illegal crypto activity in 2021.

site_title: Brick-and-mortar education sectors in Asia-Pac likely to see rebound in 2022
summary: The Asia-Pacific education sector is expected to see a strong rebound in 2022, driven by economic recovery and higher Covid-19 vaccination rates in several countries. Traditional brick-and-mortar education sectors, including pre-school, K-12, and higher education, are expected to bounce back, while edtech investments are expected to continue, albeit at a lower pace. Countries with low gross enrolment ratios, such as Thailand and Vietnam, offer significant opportunities for growth, and the demand for workers with digital skills is expected to increase by 5 times by 2025.

images.alt_text: Based on a recent consumer survey conducted by LEK, there is a growing appetite to come back to school and have a physical education setting as early as possible.

site_title: Intel wins EU court bid to annul US$1.2b antitrust fine
summary: Intel has won a historic victory in the European Union courts, with the EU General Court ruling that the European Commission made key errors in slapping the chip giant with a record $1.2 billion antitrust fine. The court found the commission provided an "incomplete" analysis, stating the decision did not establish the rebates at issue were capable of having anti-competitive effects. This ruling follows a 2017 judgment that criticized the General Court for not properly checking factual and economic evidence. Intel's legal dispute with the EU's antitrust arm began in 2009.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's net property income up 5.6 per cent for 9-month period
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) posted a 5.6% increase in net property income for the 9-month period ending Dec 31, 2021, reaching S$291.3 million. This growth was attributed to lower rental rebates and higher compensation from lease pre-terminations. Gross revenue rose 7.2% to S$374 million, driven by VivoCity's strong tenant sales growth. The committed occupancy of MCT's portfolio was 96.3% as of Dec 31, with VivoCity's occupancy reaching almost 90% of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: China Evergrande aims for restructuring plan within six months as creditor talks begin
summary: China Evergrande Group aims to develop an initial restructuring plan within six months, following a call with creditors. The company, with over $300 billion in debt, is struggling to repay creditors and suppliers. Nearly $20 billion of international bonds are now considered in default. Evergrande's new executive director, Siu Shawn, said the company is working on a comprehensive plan and hopes to achieve a risk management solution with creditors. The company has set up a risk management committee and hired more financial and legal advisers to address creditor demands.

site_title: The exiled sculptor of 'all that is no longer there' in Syria
summary: Khaled Dawwa, a Syrian exiled sculptor, has created a massive installation titled "Here is my heart!" in Paris, France, to commemorate the devastating destruction in Syria. The piece, made from polystyrene, earth, glue, and wood, depicts a scene of destruction, including shattered doors and overturned chairs, with bodies and broken toys scattered throughout. Dawwa, who was imprisoned and wounded during the Syrian conflict, aims to convey the horrors of the war and urge viewers to remember the sacrifices made by the Syrian people. The installation, which has been on display in Paris and will soon move to a national museum, is a powerful act of revolt and memory.

images.alt_text: Using polystyrene, earth, glue and wood, covered in clay, Syrian sculptor Khaled Dawwa recreates a street in Syria destroyed by regime forces and their allies, in his workshop in Vanves, near Paris.
"When I'm working on this piece in my studio, I'm in Damascus. I do everything I can here, while not being there." - Khaled Dawwa (above), Syrian artist

site_title: After urban flight, corporate campuses add a taste of the city
summary: Corporate campuses in the US are shifting away from suburban isolation and towards a more urban experience, incorporating shops, restaurants, hotels, residences, and public parks. This trend reflects investments in dense, walkable, and bike-friendly communities, as well as the need to attract young employees who prefer lively workplaces. Companies like Capital One and Microsoft are designing mixed-use campuses that blur the line between work and leisure, with features such as rooftop parks, performing arts halls, and community-focused amenities. This approach aims to foster a sense of community and connection with the surrounding neighborhood, rather than creating isolated corporate enclaves.

images.alt_text: Inside Capital One Hall, a performance venue, at the Capital One corporate campus in Tysons, Virginia. Many companies are expanding and redesigning their suburban corporate campuses to add more urban style amenities that will integrate better with their communities, and attract skilled workers.

site_title: Reit managers, sponsors should get in front of evolving investor attitudes on mergers
summary: Reit managers and sponsors must adapt to evolving investor attitudes on mergers. Proxy advisory firms ISS and Glass Lewis have raised concerns about the lack of transparency in Reit mergers, citing the failure to shop around for alternative transactions. This has led to a perception that managers are conflicted, prioritizing their interests over those of unitholders. As Reit mergers become more common, investors are becoming more aware of the potential risks and are demanding greater transparency. To address these concerns, Reit managers and sponsors should proactively solicit alternative offers and prioritize the interests of unitholders, rather than simply stating that the merger has the unanimous support of independent directors.

site_title: Boeing sinks to loss on US$4.5b charges related to 787 delays
summary: Boeing incurred a US$4.5 billion charge in the fourth quarter due to delays in its 787 programme, resulting in a loss. Despite this, the company's shares rose 2% due to rebounding 737 MAX deliveries and increased production. Analysts attribute the surge to the planemaker's return to positive free cash flow. Boeing faces challenges in recovering from the pandemic and 737 MAX safety crises, while navigating industrial and regulatory hurdles on its flagship 787 and 777X programmes.

images.alt_text: Boeing said on Wednesday it incurred US$4.5 billion charges in the fourth quarter on its sidelined 787 programme, obscuring the US planemaker's long-awaited return to positive cash flow fueled by rebounding 737 MAX deliveries.

site_title: Citi to overhaul Canary Wharf skyscraper for flexible-work era
summary: Citi is refurbishing its 42-story office tower in London's Canary Wharf district, a 3-year project valued at over £100 million, as it adapts to the flexible work era. The Citi Tower, acquired in 2019 for £1 billion, will feature shared work spaces, energy efficiency, and carbon reduction measures. The overhaul, expected to be completed in 2025, will relocate 9,000 staff members to temporary spaces while the work is underway. The renovated building will be Citi's EMEA headquarters and aim to maximize collaborative workspaces.

images.alt_text: Citi emailed its London staff last week telling them to come in at least 3 days a week after the UK government ended its work-from-home guidance.

site_title: Mahathir recovering, moved to regular ward
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 96, has recovered from coronary treatment and moved to a regular ward at the National Heart Institute. His daughter reported that he is "cheerful and eager to fully recover" after being re-admitted on Jan 8. Mahathir, an active lawmaker, had requested people not be too worried about his health.

site_title: Thailand's PTTEP seen taking over big Myanmar gas field as majors exit
summary: Thailand's state-owned oil and gas explorer PTTEP is poised to take over Myanmar's largest gas field, Yadana, after TotalEnergies and Chevron Corp exit due to the country's coup. PTTEP, which already operates smaller fields in Myanmar, would have an 85% stake in Yadana if it takes over, ensuring vital gas supplies to Thailand and Myanmar. The move could safeguard revenues for Myanmar's government amid tightened US sanctions.

site_title: Astronomers predict SpaceX space junk will hit the moon
summary: A piece of SpaceX's abandoned rocket, launched in 2015 to deploy a NASA satellite, is predicted to crash into the moon's dark side on March 4, at a speed of over 9,000 km/h. Calculated by astronomer Bill Gray, the impact will create a crater that scientists can observe with spacecraft and satellites. The incident highlights the need for regulation of space junk, as similar unintentional lunar impacts may have occurred unnoticed. This is the first recorded unintentional lunar impact from a piece of space junk, according to Gray, who estimates there may be more such incidents in the future.

images.alt_text: A chunk of a SpaceX rocket that blasted off seven years ago and was abandoned in space after completing its mission will crash into the moon in March, experts say.

site_title: Johnson refuses to resign over lockdown parties; Gray report due soon
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has refused to resign over attending lockdown parties, despite opposition calls. He accepted that a rule applying to him, which states ministers should lose their jobs for knowingly misleading Parliament, should be applied to him. An official investigation by Cabinet Office official Sue Gray into Downing Street parties is due soon, amid police investigations into the matter.

site_title: Support your children if they are gay, pope tells parents
summary: Pope Francis has urged parents of gay children to offer support rather than condemnation, stating that the Church cannot accept same-sex marriage but can support civil union laws. He has previously said that gay children have the right to be accepted by their families. The pope's comments come amid criticism that the Church is giving mixed signals on homosexuality, with some conservatives accusing him of confusing the faithful. The Vatican has apologized for causing pain to the LGBTQ community and has removed resources from its website supporting gay rights advocacy.

site_title: Saudi launches group to develop esports
summary: Saudi Arabia has launched the Savvy Gaming Group, a state-backed organization aimed at developing the country's video gaming and esports industry. The group, led by Crown Prince Mohammed Salman, has acquired esports companies ESL Gaming and FACEIT, with the goal of being a "pioneer in the development of the gaming and esports industry locally and internationally." The move is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its oil-dependent economy, with the country's gaming market reaching $1 billion in 2021.

images.alt_text: Video gaming and esports have grown in popularity in the kingdom of some 35 million people, the majority of whom are under the age of 25.

site_title: Apple grabs record China market share as Q4 sales surge: research
summary: Apple achieved its highest-ever market share in China, reaching 23% in the 4th quarter, surpassing Huawei's market share for the first time in 6 years. The milestone coincided with the release of the iPhone 13, amid stagnant demand for handsets. Apple's unit sales volume grew 32% year-on-year, while total smartphone sales in China fell 9%. Lower starting prices and US sanctions against Huawei contributed to Apple's success.

site_title: US goods-trade gap widens to fresh record as imports jump
summary: The US merchandise-trade deficit widened to a fresh record of $101 billion in December, exceeding all estimates. This increase is attributed to rising imports outpacing shipments overseas, partly due to lean inventories and strained supply chains. The record gap in 2021 reflects solid consumer demand and business investment, making it challenging for exporters to ship goods.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Vicplas International with 'add', sees growth in medical business
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Vicplas International with an "add" call and a target price of S$0.275, citing growth in the company's medical business driven by an ageing population and increased demand for healthcare in developing markets. The brokerage expects Vicplas's earnings to grow at a compounded annual rate of 10.8% from FY2022 to FY2024, with a projected core EPS of S$0.027 in FY2024.

site_title: Glencore's Viterra buys Gavilon grains unit to expand in US
summary: Glencore's Viterra unit agreed to buy Gavilon's grains business from Marubeni for $1.13 billion, expanding its US presence and securing a significant agriculture footprint. The deal gives Viterra a bigger foothold in the US market, where crop prices have reached multiyear highs. This move comes after Glencore sold its agribusiness to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and British Columbia Investment Management five years ago, and new CEO Gary Nagle aims to unlock more value from the business.

site_title: Government to re-evaluate spending as Singapore adapts to living with Covid-19
summary: Singapore's government is re-evaluating its spending in areas such as infrastructure and office spaces as the country adapts to living with Covid-19. The Ministry of Finance has started reviewing the impact of Covid-19 on future plans and has identified opportunities to reduce spending in certain areas. The government aims to remain a global hub for talent and companies, but will prioritize flexibility in infrastructure planning and optimize public office spaces for hybrid work. Baseline spending is expected to increase due to the pandemic, but the public sector workforce will grow at a sustainable rate.

site_title: Nasdaq profit beats estimates on IPO rush, investment products demand
summary: Nasdaq reported a 16% jump in 4th-quarter profit, beating Wall Street estimates, driven by the rapid pace of US IPOs and strong demand for its investment products. The exchange saw a 19% surge in revenue from its solutions segment, led by growth in investment analytics products. Net revenue rose 12% to $885 million, while operating expenses increased 15% due to higher employee compensation. The strong performance follows Nasdaq's successful hosting of 1,000 companies, including Rivian Automotive, in 2021, valuing them at $181 billion.

site_title: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition SPAC IPO's public tranche 7.6 times subscribed
summary: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition's (NTAA) IPO public tranche was 7.6 times subscribed, exceeding its target of 3.4 times. The international placement tranche of 9.5 million units was 3.1 times subscribed. The offering raised S$150 million, which will be used for the business combination, underwriting commissions, and shareholder redemptions. NTAA's sponsor group, led by New Earth Group, aims to deliver a quality business combination and create sustained value for unitholders.

site_title: Hong Kong security chief says new laws will reflect 'importance of spies'
summary: Hong Kong's security chief, Chris Tang, announced that new laws against espionage will be drafted to reflect the "importance" of spying, as the city's existing laws against spying, in the British-era Official Secrets Ordinance, are deemed insufficient. This move comes as part of extra national security legislation. Tang stated that the new laws will better address the crime of spying, which he considers crucial to the city's security. The exact details of the new legislation have not been released.

site_title: STI up 0.7%; Asian markets mixed ahead of Fed meeting outcome
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.73% to 3,271.57, with Wilmar International and local banks OCBC, UOB, and DBS gaining. Asian markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei index down 0.44% and South Korea's Kospi falling for the fourth straight session. The outcome of the Federal Reserve meeting is expected to drive market performance, with some investors staying cautious ahead of the decision.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's fixed asset investment commitments in 2021 reached S$11.8 billion, exceeding the EDB's target range. The BCA projects 2022 construction demand of S$27b to S$32b. The manufacturing sector expanded 13.2% in 2021, while airfreight rates eased from peaks despite flight cancellations. Suburban retail malls lifted tenants' sales above pre-Covid levels, and the STI rose 0.7% on Wednesday.

site_title: China's Xiamen city to require property developers to place all deposits in escrow
summary: China's Xiamen city has implemented new rules requiring property developers to place all deposits from home buyers in escrow accounts, effective April 1. This move aims to protect home buyers' legitimate rights and interests, but may add financial strains on developers already struggling with liquidity issues. The city's decision comes as the country drafts nationwide rules to ease access to escrow funds, but a nationwide relaxation is unlikely due to concerns over misappropriation. Authorities will ensure funds are used for construction costs and taxes before paying developers.

site_title: AT&T profit beats estimates on strong streaming growth
summary: AT&T reported a beat on fourth-quarter profit and revenue estimates, driven by strong growth in its streaming platform HBO Max and a rise in wireless customers. WarnerMedia's revenue rose 15.4% to $9.9 billion, with HBO and HBO Max adding 4.4 million subscribers. AT&T also saw 271,000 net new fiber internet customers. The company expects 2022 revenue growth in the low-single-digit percentage range and annual adjusted earnings of $3.10-$3.15 per share.

site_title: Rex International gets in-principle go-ahead to move to SGX mainboard
summary: Rex International, an oil exploration and production company, has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) to transfer its listing from the Catalist board to the mainboard. The company will seek shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) and must comply with applicable listing requirements. The transfer is expected to enhance the company's long-term value, provide greater access to equity and debt markets, and increase visibility among public investors. The move aims to promote the company's corporate and business development profile and boost research coverage.

site_title: Singapore-based firms not affected by Russia-Ukraine conflict
summary: Singapore-based firms with operations in Russia and Ukraine appear unaffected by the ongoing conflict. Association of Small and Medium Enterprises president Kurt Wee stated that businesses are monitoring the situation, but none have reported concerns. Singapore Business Federation's Lam Yi Young also reported no concerns from members operating in Russia. Companies like Olam and Trafigura have stated they will continue to operate as usual and comply with regulations and sanctions.

site_title: Hong Kong risks exodus over extended Covid isolation, Euro chamber says
summary: Hong Kong risks losing its role as a financial hub due to its strict Covid-19 policies, potentially triggering an exodus of foreign firms and staff. The European Chamber of Commerce predicts Hong Kong won't reopen until late 2023 or early 2024, citing the limited effectiveness of locally developed vaccines. This could lead to a "cascade effect" of firms leaving, with multinational companies relocating China-focused teams to the mainland or Singapore. The chamber recommends accelerating vaccinations and shortening quarantine to mitigate the risk.

site_title: Governments need to coordinate and simplify air travel for demand to return: Airbus, Boeing
summary: Major airline players Airbus and Boeing emphasize the need for governments to simplify air travel and transition to a testing regime rather than quarantine to boost demand. They predict a recovery in travel demand by 2023 or 2024, with Asia-Pacific expected to bounce back to pre-pandemic levels. The industry is also focusing on sustainability efforts, with Airbus exploring hydrogen for "pure zero-emission" flights and Boeing developing sustainable aviation fuels. Labor shortages and a lack of female representation in the industry also pose challenges, with Airbus aiming to increase senior female representation by 25% in the next three years.

site_title: China shrugs off IMF warnings on zero-tolerance Covid approach
summary: China has dismissed IMF warnings about the economic impact of its zero-tolerance Covid approach, stating it has achieved "significant results" and remains a key driver of global growth. The IMF lowered its growth outlook for China and the world, citing the policy's slowdown in the country's economy. However, China's foreign ministry spokesman said the country's economic growth has not changed, and it has implemented effective prevention and control measures. China reported 24 domestic coronavirus cases, with harsh lockdowns imposed over handfuls of cases, despite the low numbers compared to other countries.

site_title: Elton John has Covid, postpones US tour dates
summary: Elton John has been diagnosed with Covid-19 and has postponed some US tour dates due to mild symptoms. The singer, who has been fully vaccinated and boosted, had recently resumed his "Farewell Yellow Brick Road" tour after a nearly two-year hiatus. He plans to reschedule the postponed shows in Dallas and expects to recover in time for concerts in Arkansas this weekend, which will mark a significant milestone in his retirement from performing on the road.

site_title: Riyadh and Bangkok restore ties, decades after gem theft
summary: Saudi Arabia and Thailand have restored diplomatic ties after more than three decades, following the 1989 theft of $20 million worth of precious gems from a Saudi palace. The thaw in relations comes after Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha met with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman, agreeing to appoint ambassadors and resume flights. The two countries aim to re-establish friendly relations, with Thailand seeking to benefit its tourism industry. The move comes after Thai police returned some stolen jewels and Saudi officials claimed most were fakes, with the whereabouts of a rare 50-carat blue diamond remaining unknown.

images.alt_text: The two countries announced in a joint statement late on Tuesday "the full re-establishment of diplomatic relations" during a visit by Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha to Riyadh.

site_title: Indian demand for Malaysian palm oil to moderate in 2022 from higher prices, domestic production: RHB
summary: RHB maintains its "underweight" call on Malaysia's plantation sector due to moderating Indian demand for Malaysian palm oil. Indian palm oil imports are expected to drop 5-8% to 8.2 million tonnes, driven by high CPO prices and India's increased oilseed production. The current import duty structure favors crude soya bean oil, reducing demand for CPO.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts 1.6% rise in H2 DPU to US$0.0318
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported a 1.6% rise in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0318, driven by contributions from acquired properties and positive rental reversions. The Reit's distributable income rose 10% to US$32.5 million, and net property income increased 2.4% to US$42.1 million. KORE secured new loan facilities to refinance a loan due in November 2022 and plans to focus on defensive sectors and accretive acquisitions in Super Sun Belts and 18-Hour Cities.

site_title: Property crisis means Chinese cities sell land to themselves
summary: China's local government financing vehicles have become the largest buyers of land for real estate development, with the city of Rizhao auctioning off land to itself for $170 million. This practice, known as self-selling, has raised concerns over the ability of these off-balance sheet borrowers to repay a debt pile estimated to be over $8.4 trillion. The shift away from cash-strapped property developers has led to a property crisis, with the government's involvement in the market sparking worries about the sustainability of China's real estate market.

images.alt_text: On the surface, the recent land auction by the Chinese city of Rizhao appeared routine. There were 4 bids, pushing the price up 11 per cent to US$170 million.

site_title: SKC consortium invests US$80m in UK anode startup Nexeon
summary: SKC consortium invests US$80 million in UK anode startup Nexeon to increase production of silicon anodes for electric vehicle batteries, boosting vehicle range and charging speed. The investment, combined with a new strategic partnership with SK, aims to meet "rapidly increasing demands" from automotive and consumer electronics industries across Europe, North America, and Asia. This move supports the growing demand for electric vehicles and helps carmakers compete in the market.

images.alt_text: A consortium including South Korean chemical company SK has invested US$80 million in British battery materials startup Nexeon to ramp up production of its silicon anodes to meet global demand, the firms said on Wednesday (Jan 26).

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 3.2% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.0192; unveils new growth strategy post review
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 3.2% rise in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0192, driven by strong performance at Australian chemicals group Ixom since its acquisition in 2019. The trust's DPU for FY2021 stands at S$0.0378, marking the first increase from its historical annual payout since FY2016. KIT's growth strategy focuses on evergreen yield-accretive assets, businesses benefiting from the low-carbon and decarbonisation economy, and socio-economic infrastructure. The trust's gearing has fallen to 20.3% as of Dec 31, 2021, and it expects to maintain a debt headroom of S$1.35 billion.

images.alt_text: The Senoko Waste-to- Energy Plant is one of Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Singapore-located assets.

site_title: China to start 3-year crackdown on money laundering
summary: China will launch a nationwide 3-year crackdown on money laundering from 2022 to 2024, involving 11 government agencies. The campaign aims to stop the spreading trend of money laundering and related crimes, with the People's Bank of China (PBOC) leading the effort. Authorities will adopt a national risk prevention system, improve laws and regulations, and enhance analysis and investigation of money laundering. This comes after increased regulatory efforts and a 2021 crackdown on cryptocurrency-related money laundering cases, which arrested over 1,100 people.

site_title: CNY breathes life into Chinatown, but businesses fear what comes next
summary: Chinatown in Singapore has seen a surge in business during the Lunar New Year, with many shops reporting a 10% increase in sales compared to last year. Consumers are more confident due to higher vaccination rates, leading to increased demand for CNY decorations, baked goods, and other festive items. However, some businesses, such as restaurants and retail stores, are struggling with reduced tourist footfall and increased competition. The Chinatown Business Association has introduced rental relief packages to help tenants, but concerns remain about the long-term sustainability of the business outlook after the festivities die down.

images.alt_text: Many Chinatown shops are reporting better performance compared to last year's Chinese New Year (CNY), thanks to greater consumer confidence that is partly due to higher vaccination rates.

site_title: 'Resilient' suburban retail malls lift FCT's tenants' sales above pre-Covid levels
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's (FCT) portfolio of suburban retail malls saw tenants' sales rise 2 percentage points to pre-Covid levels in Q1 2022, with a 6% increase above 2019 levels in December. Despite shopper traffic still being two-thirds of pre-Covid levels, tenants are making more purposeful visits to malls. The Reit manager attributes this to a shift towards online ordering and delivery options, which has boosted F&B tenants. FCT reported stable committed occupancy at 97.2% and remains on the lookout for "opportunistic" acquisitions.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Fullerton Health, a Singapore-based private healthcare solutions firm, may turn to judicial management as a potential sale to rescue the company seems elusive. The firm is facing mounting woes, including a sour shareholder stand-off. Meanwhile, Singapore's status as a financial center is under threat as experienced bankers and traders are drawn away by better prospects in other sectors. In other news, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second month in a row.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.85 points higher on Wednesday at 1,515.76. The index saw 2.362 billion lots worth RM1.845 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 618 to 254.

site_title: Don't write off Hong Kong as a financial centre just yet
summary: Hong Kong remains a secure financial centre despite its restrictive Covid-19 measures and authoritarian government. China's capital controls, which limit foreign investment and currency exchange, are a key factor in the city's enduring appeal. With its fully convertible currency pegged to the US dollar and unique "Connect" schemes, Hong Kong attracts foreign investors and Chinese companies seeking international capital. While China's gradual liberalization of capital controls may pose a long-term threat, Hong Kong's structural advantages and low-tax environment ensure its continued importance in global finance, at least in the near future.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust H2 DPU down 14% to S$0.036
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 14% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.036, down from S$0.0419 in the same period last year. The full-year DPU was S$0.078, 11% lower than the previous year. Unitholders will receive their H2 DPUs on Feb 25.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open, before Fed outcome
summary: European stock markets rose strongly at the open on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 up 1.0%, the DAX up 1.1%, and the CAC 40 up 1.2%. The rally came ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting outcome, with investors focusing on potential interest rate changes.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls as tech shares weaken ahead of Fed's policy update
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 0.44% to 27,011.33, its lowest point in 13 months, due to weakening tech shares ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy update. The broader Topix also declined 0.25%. US stocks slumped overnight, with rate-sensitive tech stocks leading the losses, and investors await the Fed's decision on interest rates and balance sheet reduction.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, driven by bargain buyers seeking to capitalize on recent losses and waiting for the conclusion of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.19% to 24,289.90, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains come despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC lowers fair value estimate for MIT after paring growth projections
summary: OCBC Investment Research lowered its fair value estimate for Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) to S$3.30 from S$3.42 due to pared growth projections and keen competition for quality data centre assets. The new estimate represents a potential upside of 26.4% from MIT's closing price of S$2.61. The trust's Q3 2022 results met OCBC's expectations, with net property income rising 34.2% to S$347.8 million and distribution per unit growing to S$0.1031.

images.alt_text: OCBC said in a report that the real estate investment trust's recently released Q3 2022 results met its expectations.

site_title: Singapore factory sector expands 13.2% in 2021 with uplift from better-than-expected December output growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded 13.2% in 2021, driven by electronics and precision engineering clusters, surpassing economists' expectations. Industrial output added 15.6% in December, with all industries except electronics showing growth. The sector's full-year growth is expected to be revised upwards to 7.3%, with UOB economist Barnabas Gan projecting an average 4% growth rate in 2022.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia X targets Asia cargo market in deal with logistics firm
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia X has signed a 6-month partnership deal with logistics firm Geodis to develop cargo capacity and generate revenue. The airline plans to operate dedicated scheduled cargo flights between Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong, Chennai, Shanghai, and Sydney. Cargo operations are expected to contribute 40-50% of total revenue, with passenger revenue offsetting any drop in cargo rates when flights resume. The move aims to capitalize on rising air cargo rates while passenger flights remain grounded due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Philippines' Q3 GDP yoy growth revised down to 6.9% from 7.1%
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.9% in the third quarter of 2021, lower than the previously-reported 7.1% growth rate. This is the first revision of the country's GDP growth since its release in November. The government is expected to release fourth-quarter GDP data on Thursday, projecting a slower expansion of 6.0% from a year earlier.

site_title: Over 40 corporate ventures launched in Singapore since 2018: EDB
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) has seen over 40 corporate ventures launched in the country since 2018, with a majority established since 2018. EDB's corporate venture building arm, EDB New Ventures, has supported companies such as AquaEasy, a startup using IoT solutions for aquaculture, and Dole Specialty Ingredients, which transforms fruit waste into high-value natural products. These ventures have achieved significant growth and are expected to contribute to the development of new growth areas in Singapore's economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall for fourth session as Fed decision looms
summary: South Korean stocks fell for a fourth consecutive session, with the Kospi index dropping 11.15 points, or 0.41%, to 2,709.24, amid anticipation of a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve in March and geopolitical concerns surrounding Ukraine. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 244 billion won worth of shares, and the Kospi has fallen 9.01% so far this year.

site_title: Airfreight rates ease from peaks but remain elevated amid passenger flight cancellations
summary: Airfreight rates have eased from record highs, but remain elevated due to flight cancellations and passenger capacity constraints. Despite a 2% cancellation rate over Christmas, demand is stabilizing, with companies like ANA Group utilizing passenger aircraft for cargo operations. Freight forwarders note airport ground handling congestion and labor shortages as issues. Rates for China-North Europe routes are still above typical ranges, at US$8.50/kg, and demand is picking up in the lead up to the Chinese New Year.

site_title: Spyware firm NSO discussing sale to US venture fund Integrity
summary: NSO Group, the Israeli developer of phone-hacking tool Pegasus, is discussing a sale of its assets to US venture capital firm Integrity Partners. The sale comes amid controversy and a plunge in revenue, with the company on its export blacklist and facing debt default. NSO has been focusing on defensive cyber security services, but its Pegasus tool has been accused of being used to spy on dissidents and journalists. Discussions with potential buyers continue, with terms not yet finalized.

site_title: URA awards Jalan Tembusu and Lentor Hills site to highest bidders
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has awarded the Jalan Tembusu site to City Developments (CDL) at S$768 million, and Lentor Hills Road Parcel A to a tie-up between Intrepid Investments, GuocoLand, and TID Residential at S$586.6 million. The Jalan Tembusu site will feature 4 blocks of residential units, while Lentor Hills will yield about 595 private homes. The winning bids were at the upper end of the expected price range, with the Jalan Tembusu site translating to S$1,302 per sq ft per plot ratio.

site_title: Thailand set to tax cryptos, stock trading to cut budget gap
summary: Thailand is considering taxing stock trading and cryptocurrency gains to raise revenue and cut its budget gap. The government aims to finance pandemic relief and reduce reliance on borrowing. The proposed tax on digital assets and stocks could be decided by the end of January, with the Finance Minister proposing a rate. This move follows Thailand's lower tax-to-GDP ratio compared to other developing economies, with a 16.1% tax rate in 2019. The government seeks to broaden its tax base to accommodate an upward shift in spending.

site_title: Singapore scored above-target S$11.8b in fixed asset investment commitments in 2021
summary: Singapore secured S$11.8 billion in fixed asset investment (FAI) commitments in 2021, exceeding the EDB's target range of S$8 billion to S$10 billion. The majority of FAI came from large manufacturing projects in the semiconductor and biotechnology sectors. Electronics accounted for 42.3% of FAI, with biomed manufacturing and chemicals following closely. The EDB remains optimistic about the semiconductor sector's prospects, despite the easing of the semiconductor cycle. Total business expenditure commitments are expected to be S$5.2 billion, with 17,376 jobs created, within the target range.

site_title: IMF urges El Salvador to remove Bitcoin as legal tender
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged El Salvador to remove Bitcoin as legal tender, citing "large risks" associated with the cryptocurrency. El Salvador became the first country to adopt Bitcoin as a form of payment in September 2021. The IMF's board, comprising representatives from member governments, including the US, has called on the government to reconsider the move, citing concerns over the cryptocurrency's volatility and lack of regulatory oversight.

site_title: Tycoons continue building Hong Kong offices as vacancies hit record
summary: Hong Kong's office market continues to face a record high vacancy rate of 9.1 million square feet, equivalent to nearly 158 football fields, in December. Despite the oversupply, real estate developers are building new office blocks, with Li Ka-shing's Henderson Land and Lee Shau Kee's CK Asset Holdings constructing towers in Central. However, demand from global banks is waning, and the border with the mainland remains shut, preventing Chinese companies from supporting the market. Experts predict it will take time to fill vacant space, with existing tenants potentially migrating to new buildings.

site_title: Mark Zuckerberg's Stablecoin ambitions unravel with Diem sale talks
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's Diem stablecoin project is unraveling after regulatory pressure, with the Diem Association considering a sale of its assets to return capital to investor members. The project, once backed by Meta Platforms, scaled back its ambitions after regulatory scrutiny and the departure of its founder, David Marcus. The US Federal Reserve expressed unease with the project's plans, and discussions are underway with investment bankers to sell intellectual property and technology. The sale is uncertain, with no guarantee of a buyer, and it's unclear how much value remains in the project.

site_title: Global supply chain woes may linger into 2023
summary: Global supply-chain bottlenecks are expected to persist into 2023 due to ongoing Covid-19 cases, capacity, logistical, and labor woes. The Omicron variant has intensified supply-chain disruptions, driving up prices of goods and services. Despite some optimists expecting improvements in the coming months, the global supply chain remains vulnerable to disruptions, with 53% of the world population not fully vaccinated. Businesses must adapt to the ongoing challenges by building resilience through pre-emptive measures and leveraging technology to mitigate the impact of the pandemic and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts mixed on Keppel Reit as H2 DPU drops 1.7%
summary: Keppel Reit (KReit) reported a lower-than-expected H2 FY2021 distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0288, down 1.7% from H2 FY2020. Analysts from Jefferies, RHB, and Maybank have mixed views on the Reit, with some maintaining "buy" calls and others retaining "hold" calls. Analysts highlight the Reit's office portfolio in Singapore, Australia, and Korea, as well as its improved environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets, which may attract ESG-focused investors. However, some analysts note the higher cost of equity and gearing, which may impact the Reit's DPU growth.

site_title: South-east Asian logistics firm snags US$15m from Creo Capital, East Ventures
summary: Inteluck, a Singapore-based logistics firm, has raised US$15 million in a Series B round led by Creo Capital, East Ventures, and Headline Asia. Founded in 2014, Inteluck provides a marketplace for companies to match with logistics providers for services like transportation and freight forwarding. The company has operations in the Philippines and Thailand and serves about 5,000 supplier partners and 250 companies in various industries. Despite the pandemic, Inteluck has seen a 512% increase in revenues over the last three years.

images.alt_text: Kevin Zhang, Inteluck's founder and chief executive officer, said: "Despite the fact that most businesses are hit by the epidemic and recruiting new consumers is more difficult, Inteluck has been able to increase revenues by 512 per cent in the last three years."

site_title: Robots delivering bento boxes trialled in Tokyo financial hub
summary: Mitsubishi Estate is trialling autonomous robots in Tokyo's Otemachi district to deliver bento lunch boxes and Starbucks coffee, as part of Japan's push for "robot-friendly" spaces. The robots, deployed with companies like NEC and Panasonic, can be ordered via a smartphone and have been shown to navigate through elevators and halls. The trial aims to address labour shortages and Covid-19 concerns, with the goal of creating environments where robots can work alongside humans. The trial involves 100 robots and is part of a broader effort to develop autonomous services in Japan.

images.alt_text: For office workers seeking an easier way to buy a meal, autonomous robots are a possible solution, and such services are part of Japan's push to create "robot-friendly" spaces.

site_title: ESG to launch courses on sustainability for businesses
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) is launching a series of courses on sustainability for businesses under the Enterprise Sustainability Programme, offering a 70% fee subsidy for up to 3 participants per eligible enterprise. The courses, developed in partnership with Global Compact Network Singapore, PwC Singapore, and the Singapore Environment Council, cover topics such as decarbonization, circular economy, and sustainability reporting. The first series of courses will start in March 2022, with up to 30 runs per year. This initiative aims to support small and medium-sized enterprises in their sustainability journey.

site_title: BCA expects 2022 construction demand between S$27b and S$32b, supported by public sector projects
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has projected 2022 construction demand to be between S$27 billion and S$32 billion, supported by public sector projects. The sector's prospects are "bright," with average annual demand expected to be between S$25 billion and S$32 billion from 2023 to 2026. Public sector demand is expected to contribute 60% of the total demand, with the private sector contributing between S$11 billion and S$13 billion. The industry is expected to overcome initial challenges from the Omicron variant and supply disruptions before looking forward to long-term growth.

images.alt_text: BCA has projected the total value of construction contracts awarded in 2022 to be between S$27 billion and S$32 billion.

site_title: Singapore banks see higher requests for physical tokens in January
summary: Singapore banks are seeing an increase in requests for physical security tokens amid heightened distrust and anxiety over digital banking services following recent SMS phishing attacks. UOB reported a 50% rise in physical token requests, while OCBC and DBS saw marginal increases. Despite digital tokens being considered secure, banks are issuing physical tokens on a case-by-case basis, particularly for vulnerable customers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has introduced additional security measures, including a 12-hour delay before activating new digital tokens, to combat scams and protect customers.

site_title: Robinhood says in 'strong position' to face unlikely market events
summary: Robinhood Markets Inc stated it is in a "strong position" to support customers through unlikely market events, with a net capital position of US$2.7 billion, exceeding the US SEC's requirement by 25 times. The online trading platform, which faced restrictions on "meme stocks" in January 2021, highlighted its efforts to avoid similar limits in the future. Robinhood's financial stability is seen as a positive development, with the company's capital position more than 25 times the required amount.

images.alt_text: Robinhood Markets Inc on Tuesday highlighted steps it had taken over the past year to avoid imposing trading restrictions and said it was in a "strong position" to support customers through unlikely market events.

site_title: AmEx soars most since 2020 after card spending hits record
summary: American Express (AmEx) surged 8.9% to $173.11, its largest gain since November 2020, after boosting forecasts for revenue and profit and reporting record spending on its cards. The company expects revenue to climb 20% and earnings to reach $9.25-$9.65 per share this year. Spending on AmEx's network soared 29% to $368.1 billion in the final quarter of last year, despite the Omicron variant disrupting holiday plans.

site_title: ADB plans to create blockchain network for Asia cross-border securities transactions
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has launched a project to create a blockchain network for cross-border securities transactions in Asia and the Pacific, aiming to improve efficiency and security. The network will connect central banks and securities depositories in the Asean+3 region, reducing transaction costs and risk. This initiative is expected to facilitate seamless exchange of securities within agreed timelines.

site_title: Una Brands acquires Singapore consumer brands ErgoTune and EverDesk+
summary: Una Brands, an e-commerce roll-up startup, has acquired Singapore consumer brands ErgoTune and EverDesk+ for an undisclosed 8-figure sum. The two ergonomic furniture brands, founded in 2017, reported 150% revenue growth in 2021. The acquisition is Una Brands' largest to date and marks the brands' expansion into international markets, with plans to enter Australia, the US, and Europe. The founders will retain an attractive upside share, allowing them to benefit from the brands' growth.

images.alt_text: From L-R: Joshua Chan, Lye Yi Hao, Kiren Tanna and Tan Jun Kiat, With the roll up of ErgoTune and EverDesk+, Una Brands is looking to scale these brands up internationally

site_title: SoftBank drops as US$40b Arm sale prospects diminish
summary: SoftBank shares dropped 2.5% as a Bloomberg report suggested Nvidia may abandon its $40 billion deal to buy Arm from the Japanese investment giant. The acquisition, initially valued at $40 billion, has faced regulatory concerns and objections from chip industry players. SoftBank chief Masayoshi Son had touted the deal as a major windfall, but the prospect of an IPO for Arm has raised uncertainty. Regulators, including the US Federal Trade Commission, had also sued to stop the transaction in December. The deal's prospects have diminished, causing SoftBank's shares to hit a 52-week low.

site_title: Investors seek refuge in China as Federal Reserve, inflation roil other markets
summary: Foreign investors are flocking to China as inflation and economic concerns plague other markets. Despite a 5.2% drop in the mainland blue-chip index last year, China's stability pledges and monetary and fiscal easing make it an attractive haven. Global fund managers, such as Matthews Asia and Fidelity International, are pumping money into mainland equities and bonds, citing lesser regulatory headwinds and a political mandate to maintain stability. Bond investors are also drawn to China's bonds, which are seen as a hedge against inflation and rate hikes in other countries.

site_title: Brokers' take: SAC Capital downgrades GKE Corp to 'hold', lowers TP
summary: SAC Capital has downgraded GKE Corp from "buy" to "hold" and lowered its target price to S$0.123, citing disappointing first-half results that missed expectations. The downgrade reflects a cut in revenue and net profit estimates for FY2022 and FY2023. The new target price represents a 10.8% potential upside from GKE's closing price.

site_title: KKR leads Philippines startup GrowSari's Series C round, invests US$45m
summary: KKR leads a US$45 million Series C round for GrowSari, a Philippine startup providing a tech platform for small retail stores and micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs). The platform has seen a 6.5 times increase in gross merchandise value and 2.5 times increase in revenue since 2019. The funds will be used to expand into more regions and enhance financial services capabilities. GrowSari claims the round is oversubscribed, with plans to double down on improving customer experience and expanding access to credit and basic financial services for MSMEs.

images.alt_text: GrowSari will utilise the funding to reach more regions across the Philippines.

site_title: Singapore equities open higher on Wednesday; STI rises 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,255.17, driven by gains from Shen Yao Holdings and Mapletree Logistics Trust. The US stock market declined, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2%, while European shares recovered 0.7% after upbeat earnings reports. Asian markets opened flat, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 flat and the Topix index up 0.2%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose.

site_title: Toyota's robotic-shuttle bet, May Mobility, raises US$83m
summary: May Mobility, a self-driving shuttle startup backed by Toyota and BMW, raised US$83 million in its largest funding round, bringing total funding to US$166 million. The company plans to use the funds to advance its self-driving software, enabling the removal of human safety drivers and replacing them with remote supervisors. This move aims to increase the ratio of robotic cars to humans, allowing May to become profitable. The company has already provided over 300,000 revenue-generating rides and plans to convert its fleet to hybrid Toyota Sienna minivans this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets open flat on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 dropping 0.04% and the Topix index edging up 0.18%. Investors maintained a wait-and-see mood ahead of a US Federal Reserve decision.

site_title: Sultan Plaza collective sale closing date extended to Mar 3
summary: The closing date of Sultan Plaza's collective sale has been extended to March 3, 2022, to obtain an in-principle approval for a potential sale of an adjacent piece of land. The original closing date was February 10, 2022. The reserve price remains at S$360 million, with interested developers having three redevelopment options: hotel, commercial and residential development, or fully commercial building. An in-principle approval for the state land will increase the site's area to 63,439.8 sq ft and gross floor area to 317,198.9 sq ft.

site_title: Indonesia runs early tests to produce palm oil petrol
summary: Indonesia has conducted early tests to produce petrol made from palm oil, aiming to expand its use in the energy sector. The country, the world's largest palm oil producer, plans to increase the palm oil content in biodiesel to produce other fuels. Following the launch of a mandatory B30 biodiesel, the energy ministry is now testing jetfuel mixed with palm oil and plans to conduct road tests for biodiesel containing 40% palm oil. The goal is to become more energy-independent and utilize the country's various energy sources.

site_title: Coinbase closes at record low as Mizuho warns on revenue
summary: Coinbase shares closed at a record low of $185.63 after a 3.1% decline, amid a broad market tumble and a warning from Mizuho Securities about a potential revenue miss in the first quarter. Mizuho analysts cut their price target to $220 from $300 due to subdued trading volumes and pressure to reduce fees. The bank lowered its first-quarter revenue estimate to $1.4 billion, below the consensus of $1.8 billion. Despite this, Piper Sandler analysts see the recent pullback as an attractive entry point for the growing cryptocurrency space.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong shares started the day with minor gains, adding 0.41% to 24,342.90, following initial losses at the start of the week. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, while traders remain cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the day.

site_title: Ford aims to be the Tesla of connected commercial vehicles
summary: Ford aims to expand its commercial vehicle business, positioning itself as the "Tesla of this industry," with a goal to increase revenue to $45 billion by 2025. The company has set ambitious targets, including increasing electric F-150 production to 150,000 units annually. Ford Pro, a standalone unit, will focus on commercial and government customers, offering software and services-based revenue. The company is ramping up a commercial electric vehicle charging business and partnering with Salesforce to develop software for digitizing paperwork.

site_title: Asia: Markets enjoy much-needed rally as Fed's big day arrives
summary: Asian markets experienced a much-needed rally on Wednesday as traders awaited the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, seeking guidance on interest rate hikes. The US central bank's minutes from its December gathering hinted at a more hawkish stance, with plans to speed up tapering its bond-buying program and three or four rate increases by the end of the year. This news boosted investor confidence, leading to a 0.4% increase in the Straits Times Index, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Income investing: A primer for your life stage
summary: Endowus has launched three income portfolios with a focus on risk and long-term sustainable income. The portfolios cater to distinct customer profiles, including those nearing retirement, working adults, and younger savers. Key considerations for income investing include selecting high-quality assets, understanding the tradeoff between current income and long-term growth, and being aware of potential pitfalls such as funds making distributions from capital. The company's approach emphasizes conservative fund managers and a focus on capital preservation.

site_title: 'We missed you': Dutch bars, cafes, museums to reopen
summary: The Netherlands is lifting some of its toughest Covid restrictions, allowing bars, restaurants, and museums to reopen from Wednesday, despite high contamination figures. Prime Minister Mark Rutte acknowledged "great tensions" with the catering and cultural sectors and warned that the move is taking a risk. The measures, which include reduced capacity and mask-wearing, will remain in place until at least March 8.

site_title: Oil rises on concerns global political risks could tighten supplies
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Tuesday due to concerns about tightening supplies amid Ukraine-Russia tensions, threats to infrastructure in the UAE, and Opec+ struggles to meet its output target. Brent futures rose to $88.20 a barrel, while WTI crude rose to $85.60 a barrel. Analysts warn of potential supply shortages and a tight oil market, despite low inventories. The US is in talks with energy-producing countries to divert supplies to Europe if Russia invades Ukraine.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 9.8% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.04512
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 9.8% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.04512, driven by higher distribution income from operations and contributions from newly acquired assets in London. Gross revenue and net property income also rose 15.3% and 30.3%, respectively. The Reit's office portfolio in Singapore, Australia, and the UK remained resilient. Valuation of its portfolio increased to S$11.8 billion, and the company plans to embark on proactive lease management and active capital management to enhance income stability.

site_title: At up to US$8,000 a week, America's travel nurses keep Covid-slammed hospitals afloat
summary: Travel nurses, who provide temporary care to hospitals struggling with the COVID-19 pandemic, are earning up to $8,000 per week, significantly higher than pre-pandemic rates. With hospitals facing staffing shortages and burnout, travel nurses are filling gaps, with some earning as much as they did in a full year before the pandemic. However, the sector has raised concerns about corporate greed and exploitation, with hospital groups accusing recruitment agencies of profiteering off the pandemic. Industry experts say the underlying issue is low nurse-to-patient ratios, driving nurses to burnout.

site_title: Gold flat, Fed meeting expectations offset Ukraine risks
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,847.51 per ounce as the US Federal Reserve meeting met expectations, offsetting concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict. US President Joe Biden stated he would consider personal sanctions on President Vladimir Putin if Russia invades Ukraine, while Western leaders prepared for military action and potential energy supply disruptions.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were little changed on Wednesday (Jan 26), ahead of a US Federal Reserve meeting that would decide on rate hikes for the year, while safe-haven bullion was supported by concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Microsoft offers strong forecast, lifting shares
summary: Microsoft forecasts revenue for the current quarter ahead of Wall Street targets, driven by its Intelligent Cloud unit, particularly Azure platform growth. The company expects Intelligent Cloud revenue of $18.8-$19 billion, beating analyst expectations. Full-year operating margins are expected to be slightly higher. Despite strong cloud growth, Azure revenue growth has slowed to 46% in the second quarter, down from 60% in 2020. The company also reported a 26% increase in cloud services revenue and a 19% increase in Office 365 revenue.

site_title: US firms have only few days' supply of semiconductors: government
summary: The US Commerce Department reports that American companies have an average of less than 5 days' worth of semiconductors, leaving them vulnerable to production shutdowns. A global shortage has already forced businesses to slash production, contributing to inflation. President Biden aims to invest $52 billion in domestic semiconductor research and production, but the House of Representatives has yet to approve the bill. The semiconductor supply chain remains fragile, with chip demand 20% higher than 2019 levels and companies expecting more orders than supply for another 6 months.

site_title: Hong Kong Covid isolation could last until 2024: EU Chamber of Commerce
summary: Hong Kong's zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19 may keep the city isolated until 2024, according to a draft report by the European Chamber of Commerce. Companies are advised to prepare for Hong Kong to remain "semi-closed" to international travel. A reopening could happen late next year or early 2024, pending China's development and immunization of its 1.4 billion people. This isolation could lead to a large-scale exodus of international workers and executives, further affecting the Asian financial hub.

site_title: GM to spend US$7b in Michigan to build electric auto capacity
summary: General Motors announced a $7 billion investment in Michigan to build electric auto capacity, creating 4,000 new jobs and retaining 1,000 positions. The investment includes $4 billion to remake the Orion Assembly plant and $2.6 billion to build a new battery plant in Lansing. GM aims to double revenues by 2030 and expects 50% of its North American capacity to be electric vehicles by then. The move is seen as a significant step towards the company's goal of establishing EV leadership.

site_title: Democrat leader Pelosi to run for US Congress
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, 82, announced plans to run for a 19th term in office, citing the need to combat existential threats to democracy. Despite predictions of a Democratic defeat in this year's midterm elections, Pelosi's San Francisco district is likely to be won comfortably. Pelosi, who would be the only female speaker in US history to seek re-election, did not reveal whether she would keep her leadership role. She emphasized the importance of the election, stating that "nothing less is at stake than our democracy."

site_title: YouTube will explore NFT features for creators
summary: YouTube is exploring features to help creators capitalize on non-fungible tokens (NFTs), a type of digital asset that exists on blockchain technology. This move comes as NFTs have seen a surge in popularity, with sales reaching $25 billion in 2021. The company's CEO, Susan Wojcicki, stated that YouTube aims to expand its ecosystem to help creators take advantage of emerging technologies like NFTs. This is the latest tech company to tap into the digital collectibles craze, following similar moves by Twitter, Meta Platforms, and TikTok.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower amid worries over Ukraine, Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday amid concerns over Ukraine and the Federal Reserve's upcoming policy meeting. Markets were volatile, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% and the S&P 500 1.2% lower. The International Monetary Fund trimmed its 2022 GDP forecast to 4.4%, citing the Omicron variant's impact. Analysts also cited a semiconductor shortage, with US firms averaging less than five days' worth of stock. The Federal Reserve's decision is expected to influence monetary policy, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell's focus on countering inflation.

site_title: China's Realme eyes Europe's high-end smartphone market with new launch
summary: China's Realme plans to launch its premium GT 2 Pro phone in Europe in February, priced at 700-800 euros, aiming to enter the high-end smartphone market and sell 50% more smartphones globally this year. The company, which has been expanding beyond budget offerings, is looking to capitalize on the European market's strong demand for high-end devices, with Apple and Samsung dominating the market. Realme's CEO, Sky Li, expects the new phone to appeal to European customers with its flagship Snapdragon 8gen1 processor, and the company aims to sell 90 million handsets globally this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares stage comeback on earnings cheer after Monday's rout
summary: European shares rebounded 0.7% on Tuesday after a 3.8% drop on Monday, driven by upbeat earnings reports from Ericsson and Logitech. The rally was fueled by rate-sensitive banking stocks and stabilizing commodity prices. Investors expect the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in March, which may offer buying opportunities. Tech stocks declined 1.1%, but analysts predict a 51% profit growth for Stoxx 600 companies in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: European shares recovered some lost ground on Tuesday following their worst sell-off since June 2020, after upbeat earnings reports from Ericsson and Logitech provided support.

site_title: RBA seen scrapping bond-buying programme at first meeting of 2022
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to scrap its bond-buying programme at its first meeting of 2022, as the economy shows signs of a strengthening recovery. All but one analyst polled by Bloomberg predict the end of quantitative easing (QE) at the February 1 meeting, with one predicting a taper to $1 billion. This move suggests the RBA no longer needs additional stimulus measures.

site_title: Offer to delist United Global closes with 99.02% valid acceptances
summary: United Global, a Catalist-listed lubricant manufacturer, has closed its offer to take the company private with 99.02% valid acceptances, representing a cash offer of S$0.45 per share. DMW Investments, the offeror, will proceed to delist the company. The offer was made on December 10, 2021, and marked a 12.5% premium to the company's last transacted price. DMW Investments stated it will not make major changes to the business or management team, and the Singapore Exchange had previously approved the delisting.

images.alt_text: United Global's tank farm where it stores oil.

site_title: ALog Trust posts H2 DPU of S$0.02464
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.02464 for the second half of 2021, down from S$0.02927 in the same period last year. The lower DPU was due to an enlarged unit base following a fundraising exercise and the payment of management fees in cash. Despite this, the Reit's gross revenue and net property income (NPI) grew 15.1% and 16.1% year-over-year, respectively, to S$68.7 million and S$53.5 million. The Reit's full-year DPU was S$0.05034, a 6.8% decrease from the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 5.74 points higher, or 0.38%, to 1,514.65 on Wednesday, driven by a 214-105 gain-to-lose ratio. The market saw gains in various sectors, including healthcare and mining, amidst US-EU trade talks.

site_title: New Zealand: Shares flat ahead of Federal Reserve rate meeting; Australia closed
summary: New Zealand shares remained flat on Wednesday, hovering near their 10-month lows, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate meeting. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 11.74 points to 12,139.95. Markets in Australia were closed due to a public holiday. Investors await the Fed's decision on rate hikes and balance sheet reduction. Key movers included Meridian Energy and Ryman Healthcare, which jumped 1.4%, while Air New Zealand advanced 1.8% and Infratil gained 0.8%.

site_title: The futility of unconditional debt support
summary: Low and middle-income countries (LMICs) are struggling with economic hardship due to limited vaccine availability, inadequate healthcare systems, and poor economic policies. Many LMICs are heavily indebted, with some countries, such as Sri Lanka, experiencing severe economic difficulties. Financial support from international institutions and NGOs is not enough, as it does not address underlying macroeconomic problems. Reforms are necessary to alleviate hardship and mitigate economic crises, but the international community must recognize the futility of ongoing assistance without accompanying reforms.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MIT, Keppel Reit, FCT, Starhill Global Reit, ALog Trust, Suntec Reit, UOB
summary: Key real estate investment trusts (REITs) and a bank reported financial results on Wednesday, with notable changes in distribution per unit (DPU) and income distributable to unitholders. Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) and Suntec Reit saw increases in DPU, while Keppel Reit and FCT reported decreases. Meanwhile, UOB injected 2 billion yuan into its Chinese subsidiary for regional opportunities. The Singapore stock market was steady, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Investments, a property developer and manager, is exploring listing a student housing real estate investment trust (Reit) in Singapore that could raise about US$1 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Omicron risk remains very high: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed that the risk level related to the Omicron variant remains very high, with 21 million new Covid-19 cases reported worldwide last week, a record high. The number of new infections increased by 5% compared to the previous week. Nearly 50,000 new deaths were also reported, and Omicron continues to dominate globally, accounting for 89.1% of sequenced samples, while Delta makes up 10.7%. Despite some countries experiencing declines in cases, the overall risk related to Omicron remains high.

site_title: Taiwan dangles incentives to boost global chipmaking lead
summary: Taiwan aims to strengthen its semiconductor industry by offering incentives to foreign chip gear suppliers and attracting overseas talent. The government will encourage domestic companies to develop technologies in the area and encourage local production of chip equipment. This move is part of a global effort to diversify semiconductor production, following a chip shortage that affected the global production of cars and electronics. Taiwan's TSMC, which makes the majority of the world's most advanced chips, relies heavily on foreign-designed equipment, and the government plans to support local businesses in developing expertise in semiconductor manufacturing equipment.

site_title: Qatar emir to meet with Biden in Washington on Jan 31: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden will meet with Qatar's emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani at the White House on January 31 to discuss security in the Middle East and ensuring global energy stability. The meeting comes amid concerns over Russia's energy supplies and tensions with Ukraine. Qatar, a close US ally, has significant gas reserves and is the world's largest exporter of liquefied natural gas, making it a key player in addressing energy contingency plans. The meeting also marks gratitude for Qatar's support in safely evacuating US citizens from Afghanistan.

site_title: Riyadh and Bangkok restore ties, decades after gem theft
summary: Saudi Arabia and Thailand have re-established diplomatic ties after over three decades, following the 1989 theft of $20 million worth of gems from a Saudi palace. The thaw in relations comes after long-standing efforts by both countries to rebuild trust. Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha's visit to Riyadh led to the announcement of the full re-establishment of diplomatic relations. Saudi Airlines has also announced the resumption of flights to Thailand in May. The move is seen as a significant step towards strengthening bilateral ties, with Thailand's tourism industry expected to benefit from the renewed relations.

site_title: Broaden the taxable property supply base to increase GST revenue
summary: A letter to the editor suggests broadening the taxable property supply base in Singapore to include non-owner-occupied residential properties and increase GST revenue. This would ensure progressiveness and fairness while supplementing the government's property cooling measures. The author believes this change would help increase the total cost of ownership for non-owner-occupied properties, making them more unaffordable. This, in turn, could curb speculation and reduce the demand for vacant residential properties, ultimately benefiting the market.

site_title: Encanto soundtrack returns to No 1 on Billboard
summary: The Encanto soundtrack returns to the No. 1 spot on Billboard's album chart, surpassing competition from The Weeknd, Gunna, and The Lumineers. The soundtrack achieved 104,000 sales in the US, including 125 million streams, and has been a hit on TikTok with the song "We Don't Talk About Bruno." This marks the second time Encanto has topped the chart, following a previous stint two weeks ago.

site_title: PM Lee, Jokowi review 'excellent state' of Singapore-Indonesia relations
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Indonesian President Joko Widodo signed agreements on airspace, extradition, and military training during their Leaders' Retreat in Bintan. These agreements are expected to enhance cooperation between the two countries in priority areas. Lee accepted Widodo's invitation to the G-20 Summit in Bali later this year, promising Singapore's contribution to the discussions and Indonesia's successful chairmanship.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts 2.3% rise in H1 FY21/22 DPU to S$0.0178
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 2.3% rise in first-half FY21/22 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0178, up from S$0.0174 in the same period last year. Net property income increased 7.2% to S$69.6 million, while gross revenue rose 2.9% to S$91 million. The Reit attributed the improved figures to lower rental assistance and a cessation of rental rebates in Malaysia. DPU excluding a deferred amount was down 5.3% year-on-year, and the group retained S$2.9 million for working capital requirements.

site_title: The titans of the metaverse have a bandwidth issue
summary: A record-breaking 25.5 terabits of data per second were transmitted in the UK on December 8, 2021, during Amazon Prime's simultaneous livestream of 6 Premier League football matches. This exceeded the UK's telecoms company BT's capacity, highlighting the bandwidth issue in the metaverse. The incident has cast a shadow on the ambitions of major companies, including Microsoft's acquisition of Activision Blizzard, and the potential of the metaverse. The event underscores the need for infrastructure upgrades to support the increasing demands of the metaverse.

site_title: Dozens of people missing after boat capsizes off Florida: US Coast Guard
summary: A US Coast Guard search is underway for 39 people reported missing after a boat capsized off the coast of Florida, suspected to be involved in a human smuggling venture. A survivor was rescued by a good Samaritan, but no life jackets were worn. The boat departed Bimini in the Bahamas on Saturday night and encountered rough weather, capsizing. The Coast Guard is actively searching for people in the water, with human smugglers known to use the Bahamas as a jumping off point for getting people into the US.
