images.alt_text: China has offloaded nearly 4 million barrels of Iranian crude oil into state reserve tanks in the southern port city of Zhanjiang over the past few weeks, a trade source and ship tracking specialist Vortexa Analytics said on Thursday (Jan 20).

site_title: US commercial-property deals hit a record high last year
summary: US commercial property deals reached a record high of $809 billion last year, according to Real Capital Analytics. Investor appetite for apartments and industrial properties drove the surge, with values jumping 23% across various property types. Demand for commercial real estate increased as the US recovery improved, with markets like Dallas seeing more traction. Manhattan ranked ninth, its worst position ever, due to uncertainty in the office sector and outsourced industrial needs. Income growth for warehouses and apartments contributed to the increase, with office prices also seeing gains driven by suburban properties.

site_title: Fed takes key step in deciding on US digital-coin issuance
summary: The US Federal Reserve has taken a key step in considering the creation of a digital currency, with a 35-page discussion paper released on January 20, 2022, exploring the potential benefits and risks of a central bank digital currency (CBDC). The Fed prefers legislation to authorise the currency and outlines potential benefits such as maintaining the dollar's dominance and improving cross-border payments. However, concerns include draining deposits from traditional banking and potential privacy issues. The Fed will take public input until May 20 and has no immediate plans to issue a digital dollar, instead relying on private sector intermediaries to offer accounts and facilitate CBDC payments.

site_title: UK backs Britishvolt battery plant, enabling £1.7b in private funding
summary: UK government backs Britishvolt battery plant, enabling £1.7 billion in private funding for a 30 gigawatt-hour plant in northern England, boosting national efforts to build zero-emission cars. The plant, valued at £3.8 billion, will directly employ around 3,000 people and produce battery packs for over 300,000 vehicles. The UK government will deliver its finances through its Automotive Transformation Fund, with Tritax and abrdn providing the private funding. This move aims to put the UK at the forefront of the global energy transition and support the country's goal of being a leader in electric vehicles.

site_title: Alphabet's unprofitable Verily unit in skin-care deal with L'Oreal
summary: Alphabet's Verily has partnered with cosmetics maker L'Oreal in a strategic, multi-year research collaboration to study skin health and develop new products. The partnership aims to provide personalized information on skin management and aid in diagnosis and treatment options. Verily, which has struggled with intermittent revenue, seeks sustainable revenue through this deal. The partnership follows a similar partnership with Colgate-Palmolive to study oral health, and marks Verily's first deal with a beauty company. Financial terms of the partnership were not disclosed.

images.alt_text: Alphabet's money-losing health-tech arm Verily on Thursday (Jan 20) announced a new tie-up in its search for sustainable revenue, saying it would study skin health and explore new products with cosmetics maker L'Oreal.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Yangzijiang, Geo Energy, Wilmar, Yanlord, Pegasus Asia, Metech
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on Friday, with several companies announcing significant events. Singtel acquired a 16.3% stake in Indonesian Bank Fama International for S$48 million, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding invested in a healthcare-focused venture capital fund. Geo Energy Resources resumed export sales after Indonesia lifted its coal export ban. Wilmar International listed its Adani Wilmar joint venture on the Securities and Exchange Board of India, and Yanlord Land Group sold 226 apartments in a Shanghai residential project. Pegasus Asia raised S$23.4 million in its IPO, while Metech International received a Trade with Caution alert from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: What market economics can teach Singapore's politics
summary: Singapore's politics can benefit from greater competition in the market, similar to the liberalization of its electricity market. The ruling party's monopoly has led to barriers to entry for opposition parties, high costs, and limited opportunities for smaller parties. To address this, the government can lower the cost of entering the market, reduce the number of Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and increase single-member constituencies, and make it easier and more transparent to access information about the election and candidates. By doing so, Singapore can foster a more diverse and competitive political landscape that serves the people better.

site_title: South Korean plant poacher jailed in US
summary: A South Korean man, Kim Byungsu, has been jailed in the US for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of Dudleya succulents from remote parks in northern California. Kim, who has a history of plant poaching, admitted to digging up $150,000 worth of the plants, which are native to the US and popular in East Asia for decoration. He was convicted of 1 count of attempting to export plants taken in violation of state law and sentenced to 2 years in jail.

site_title: Johnson's travails could have deep economic consequences
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's troubles could have significant economic consequences due to widespread distrust and breaches of Covid-19 lockdown restrictions at 10 Downing Street. The recent public apology to the Queen over parties held at the prime minister's residence on the eve of her late husband's funeral in April 2021 has fueled anger and embarrassment among mainstream Tories. Johnson's leadership is now in doubt, which could impact the Conservative party's ability to win elections and potentially affect the UK's economic stability.

site_title: Fintech giant Kakao Pay's top execs quit after investor revolt
summary: Kakao Pay's top executives, CEO Alex Ryu, CFO Kijoo Chang, and CBO Jin Lee, resigned following an investor revolt, taking immediate effect. The departures come after Ryu withdrew his candidacy to lead parent Kakao Corp, amid criticism from shareholders for selling down their stake in the stock-market darling. The resignations follow allegations of tax evasion against Kakao's founder, Brian Kim, which the company denies. Shares of Kakao Pay rebounded, gaining 6.3% after sharp losses the previous day.

site_title: Fintech Stacs wants to make ESG tracking easier for SMEs
summary: Fintech startup Stacs aims to simplify ESG tracking for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by developing a blockchain-based registry that integrates existing data on sustainability goals. The registry, in partnership with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, will help banks monitor companies' progress and access green loans. Stacs' goal is to make ESG tracking more accessible and reduce the fragmentation of data, enabling more companies to access sustainability-linked financing.

site_title: JPMorgan board lifts CEO Dimon's pay to US$34.5m
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon's annual pay will increase by 9.5% to $34.5 million, driven by a $33 million performance-based incentive and a $1.5 million base salary. The raise comes after Dimon received no increase in 2021, as the bank's performance in 2021, including a $48.3 billion net income, was cited as a reason for the decision. This is the latest in a series of pay increases for Dimon, who will turn 66 in March.

site_title: Google US lobbying jumps 27% as lawmakers aim to rein in Big Tech
summary: Google spent 27% more on US lobbying in 2021, reaching $9.6 million, compared to 2020. This increase follows a restructuring of its government relations teams in 2020. The move comes amid pressure on tech giants, including Google, Amazon, Meta, and Apple, to address allegations of market abuse. A bill aimed at reining in these companies' power has passed the Senate Judiciary Committee, but no laws have been enacted yet.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank keeps interest rate at record low
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, kept its benchmark interest rate at a historic low of 1.75% as it maintained support for the economy, which was hit by floods and the omicron variant. The central bank expects the economy to expand 5.5-6.5% in 2022, driven by global demand and private sector expenditure. Risks to the growth outlook remain tilted to the downside, but a speedy vaccine rollout has fueled optimism for a potential rate hike later this year.

site_title: Netflix's weak subscriber forecast evaporates pandemic-fuelled stock gains
summary: Netflix has dashed hopes for a quick rebound, forecasting weak first-quarter subscriber growth of 2.5 million, less than half of analyst expectations. The company cited late content releases, including the second season of Bridgerton, as reasons for the tempered growth. Despite posting strong adjusted earnings per share, shares sank nearly 20% due to the disappointing forecast. Netflix's global subscriber total reached 221.8 million at the end of 2021, and the company is now focusing on overseas growth to offset stagnating growth in the US and Canada.

site_title: UK property sellers keep upper hand as supply squeeze persists
summary: The UK housing market remains competitive, with rising prices driven by a persistent shortage of homes for sale. A Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey found new listings are stagnant or falling across regions, while demand increased in January, despite tax changes and economic uncertainty. This imbalance is expected to continue, with UK house prices continuing to rise strongly.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Joyas International Holdings plans to enter the non-fungible token (NFT) market through a wholly owned subsidiary holding 60% of a new company that digitizes artwork as NFTs with blockchain technology. The subsidiary has entered into a joint cooperation agreement with Splendid Powerful. The planned deal is expected to have minimal impact on Joyas' net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year to Dec 31, 2022. Nutryfarm International, another listed company, has called a trading halt due to significant price movements, but the board believes it was premature to disclose potential developments involving third-party loans or legal proceedings.

site_title: Buzz!
summary: The Blue Lotus Group, in partnership with Tuck Lee Ice, is delivering its signature New Year's dish, tea-smoked salmon yusheng, to customers' doors. The dish, priced at S$98 for 6-10 pax, features 10 herbs and vegetables, crispy salmon skin, and a refreshing twist with spring onion oil and wild honey yuzu dressing. Customers can also top up S$38 for braised mini abalones, delivered in a large red box with convenient Chinese sayings for tossing. This delivery service aims to preserve the dish's pristine condition, making it a convenient option for home reunion dinners.

site_title: US Congress can trade stocks or keep the public trust. Not both
summary: The US Congress is pushing for stricter regulations on lawmakers trading stocks while in office, amid concerns about corruption and the public's trust. Following a recent investigation revealing dozens of lawmakers violating reporting requirements, bills have been introduced to bar lawmakers from trading individual stocks and require blind trusts. Senator Elizabeth Warren has long argued for more stringent measures, citing the example of Senator Richard Burr's stock trades during the Covid pandemic. Lawmakers from both parties are proposing varying solutions, with some aiming to prevent personal profits from policy influence.

site_title: Banks loan growth focus could impact US Treasuries: Credit Suisse
summary: US banks are shifting focus to loan growth, potentially reducing their appetite for US Treasuries, amid the Federal Reserve's plans to shrink asset holdings and raise interest rates to combat inflation. This could lead to lower trading volumes and increased yields in the long-term Treasury market. Analyst Zoltan Pozsar from Credit Suisse notes that banks' interest in making loans is growing, which could have a negative impact on the Treasury market, particularly as interest rates rise. This could also boost banks' margins.

site_title: Market, Omicron risks pose new challenge for Fed policy pivot
summary: US Federal Reserve officials face a complex challenge in their upcoming meeting as economic data and investor expectations diverge. Despite initial plans to combat high inflation, the Omicron variant's impact on the economy and markets may prompt a faster tightening of monetary policy. Recent retail spending data and real-time economic activity measures have been disappointing, and hiring may ease due to the Omicron variant. The Fed must balance its commitment to fighting inflation with the risk of slowing growth and triggering a recession.

site_title: Private equity firm CVC lines up Goldman, JPMorgan for IPO: sources
summary: CVC Capital Partners, a European private equity firm, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) that could value it at over $20 billion. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley are lined up as banks for the listing, which could be one of the biggest-ever floats of a private equity firm in the UK. The firm, founded over 40 years ago, is expanding beyond leveraged buyouts into various areas, including tech and credit investing, and is considering selling shares in London in the second half of the year.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to put 900m yuan into Jiangsu-based venture capital fund
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has invested 900 million yuan (S$190.9 million) in a Jiangsu-based venture capital fund, Wuxi Jinyu Yangchuan Venture Capital Investment Partnership. The fund will focus on sectors like healthcare, technology, and the green economy, with an operational term of 7 years. The investment is funded through internal resources and is not expected to significantly affect the group's earnings. This move aims to support innovation and growth in these industries.

site_title: Europe: Travel stocks lead shares higher as airlines soar
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, led by travel stocks, as Ryanair expressed confidence in a 2022 recovery, boosting airline shares. Bond yields retreated, easing pressure on equities. The Stoxx 600 extended a recovery into a second consecutive session. Travel stocks rose 2.9% as airline shares jumped, while mining and healthcare stocks also contributed to gains.

site_title: Kim Jong Un blasts US, signals return to nuclear and ICBM tests
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has indicated he may resume major nuclear and ICBM tests, threatening to escalate tensions with the US and revive the country's nuclear program. In a recent order, Kim told ruling party leaders to "promptly examine the issue of restarting all temporarily suspended activities." This move comes ahead of unprecedented talks with former US President Donald Trump and signals a shift in North Korea's stance. The news has led to a rise in South Korean defense stocks.

images.alt_text: People in Seoul watching a news broadcast with footage of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on Jan 20. Forcing a crisis with Washington may be the 38-year-old's best chance to break a diplomatic stalemate that has kept crippling sanctions in place and left the economy smaller than when he took power a decade ago.

site_title: US dollar dips as Treasury yields stall
summary: The US dollar declined on Thursday as Treasury yields stalled, while the Canadian and Australian dollars gained due to rising commodity prices and optimism about economic growth. The euro and sterling rose after a brief dip, with the dollar index 0.1% lower at 95.563. Despite expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike as early as March, the dollar has not performed as well as expected recently. The Aussie and Loonie were boosted by a strong Australian labour market reading and speculation of tighter policy.

site_title: Still relevant after 400 years
summary: Two film adaptations of stage works, Macbeth and West Side Story, offer fresh interpretations. Joel Coen's The Tragedy Of Macbeth is a dark, stark adaptation of Shakespeare's classic, focusing on aging and desperation rather than ambition. The film features Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand. In contrast, Steven Spielberg's West Side Story is a big, energetic, and inclusive musical, with a diverse cast and rewritten lyrics to address criticisms of racism. Despite its positive reception, the film has been a commercial flop. Both films offer thrilling and relevant interpretations for contemporary audiences.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops as bargain-hunting loses steam
summary: US stocks dropped sharply on Thursday as bargain-hunting lost steam, erasing a rally in the session. The Nasdaq, which fell over 10% below its November all-time high, confirmed it was in a correction. The tech-heavy index has fallen nearly 12% from its record high. Despite a 0.4% gain in the Straits Times Index, Wall Street's main indexes ended lower, ending a rally that had seen major US indexes gain solidly for much of the day.

site_title: Citi asks London staff to return to office 3 days a week
summary: Citi has asked London staff to return to the office at least 3 days a week as the UK lifts its work-from-home guidance. Finance firms, including Fidelity International and Standard Chartered, are also encouraging staff to return to their offices. The move comes after the government announced the lifting of most Covid-19 restrictions in England. Citi's protective measures, including lateral flow testing, will remain in place, and staff are expected to continue wearing face coverings in crowded areas.

site_title: Deliveroo meets top growth forecast as dining-in trend stays intact
summary: British food delivery company Deliveroo exceeded its forecast for 60-70% growth in gross transaction value in 2021, driven by a dining-in trend. Despite a tough comparison due to new lockdown restrictions, Deliveroo's performance was "really encouraging," according to founder Will Shu. The company's average order value decreased 5% year-over-year, but the frequency of orders increased, and it maintained its guidance for gross profit margin at 7.5-7.75%. Deliveroo's shares rose 2.6% following the announcement.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on upbeat earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by positive earnings results from American Airlines and Travelers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.21%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.32% and 0.85%, respectively. The positive momentum follows a day of volatility, with the Nasdaq index plunging into correction territory. Investors are shrugging off new Trump threats, focusing on the ongoing US-EU trade talks and the ongoing fourth-quarter earnings season.

site_title: Former Caldecott Broadcast Centre to be redeveloped into 15 leasehold GCB plots
summary: Perennial Holdings plans to redevelop the former Caldecott Broadcast Centre site into 15 Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) in District 11. The GCB plots range from 15,070 sq ft to 250,801 sq ft, with the potential to be subdivided for more GCBs. The site, which was purchased for S$280.9 million, will feature a new public park and widen vehicle carriageways. Prices for the GCBs are expected to be more attractive than new freehold GCBs in the area, given the site's tenure.

site_title: American Airlines suffers loss as Omicron clouds outlook
summary: American Airlines reported a quarterly loss of $931 million due to the Omicron wave of Covid-19, which depressed bookings early in 2022. However, the airline saw an uptick in reservations beyond 60 days, with CEO Doug Parker citing consumer confidence in traveling. Revenues more than doubled to $9.4 billion compared to the same period in 2020. The airline projects lower capacity and revenues in the first quarter, with a 8-10% decrease in capacity and 20-22% decrease in revenues from pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Hatten Land to come up with alternative options for Gold Mart divestment
summary: Hatten Land has shared bank documents to prove its funds for the US$83 million payment to Tayrona Capital Group Corp for the proposed divestment of its Malaysian unit Gold Mart. If the transaction fails, Hatten Land will consider resuming construction for Project Harbour City and exploring alternative investors. The company has RM1.15 billion worth of unsold properties, including Gold Mart, and has secured refinancing packages for US$20 million and US$25 million. Despite potential delays, Hatten Land believes it can continue as a going concern due to its cash flow and recent business recoveries.

site_title: Malaysian glove maker Supermax says other Canadian contracts not affected by termination of government supply deal
summary: Malaysia's Supermax Corp, a glove maker, has stated that its Canadian contracts, worth US$12.67 million, are not affected by the termination of a government supply deal due to forced labor allegations. The company has been working to meet International Labour Organisation (ILO) standards since 2019 and has implemented improvements to improve workers' welfare. Despite the Canadian government's decision to terminate the contracts, Supermax's other personal protective equipment products in Canada remain in place.

site_title: Get back on the health track
summary: Experts offer solutions for those struggling with New Year's resolutions to eat healthier, exercise more, and sleep better. A gut healing makeover program, available through Balanced Living, helps participants kick-start their journey to better health by focusing on gut health and nutrition. Meanwhile, OSbiome provides personalized gut wellness platforms using microbiome technology and AI to analyze users' gut health. Muse S, a brain-sensing headband, tracks sleep quality and provides guided meditation sessions to improve restful sleep. Urban Den and Freedom Gym offer convenient workout spaces, while The Flow Pilates by Lab Studios provides a reformer-only Pilates studio for dynamic strength training.

site_title: Rags to riches tale of Asia's growth dynamo
summary: Vietnam, once the world's poorest country, has transformed into one of East Asia's most dynamic economies. The country boasts a gold-plated hotel and a growing number of high net-worth individuals, expected to reach 25,000 by 2025. A positive work culture is being cited as a key factor in the country's wealth boom, with employers focusing on employee well-being rather than entitlement. Vietnam's cityscapes have undergone significant changes, from slums to luxury condos, as the country's increasingly affluent population spends its new-found wealth.

site_title: Yanlord bags 4.02b yuan in pre-sales in second phase of Shanghai project launch
summary: Yanlord Land Group has sold 226 apartments in the second phase of its Shanghai residential project, Yanlord Arcadia, for 4.02 billion yuan (S$852.5 million). The units were sold at an average price of 115,000 yuan per square meter. This marks a significant pre-sales milestone for the project, which is expected to comprise 1,171 residential units when completed. The announcement comes after the company sold 299 units in the first phase for 5.08 billion yuan in November 2021.

site_title: Fashion goes green
summary: The fashion industry is working to reduce waste and promote sustainability. In Singapore, the Textile and Fashion Federation (TaFF) has launched a sustainability programme to advocate and promote good practices. Local fashion labels such as Love, Bonito and Graye are also adopting sustainable practices, including using eco-friendly materials and designing products with longevity in mind. International brands like Levi's, Uniqlo, and Kipling are also incorporating sustainability into their production. Consumers can make informed choices by checking labels and looking for products that are made with sustainable materials and designed to be recycled or upcycled.

site_title: IMF warns on balance of risks facing Hong Kong economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that Hong Kong's economy is facing a balance of risks tilted to the downside, primarily due to ongoing pandemic-related uncertainty, a slower-than-expected global recovery, and disruptions to global supply chains. The IMF forecasts economic growth to slow to 3% this year from 6.4% in 2021. However, the report also notes that a quicker reopening of borders could drive a stronger recovery in private consumption and that fiscal policy should focus on addressing structural challenges such as population aging and income inequality.

site_title: Red Cross appeals to hackers after major cyberattack
summary: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has appealed to hackers who stole sensitive data of over 515,000 vulnerable individuals, including those in conflict and detention. The data breach, affecting 60 national Red Cross and Red Crescent societies worldwide, has not been publicly leaked but poses a risk of exposure. The ICRC has suspended access to affected systems and will communicate directly with the attackers to mitigate the impact and ensure business continuity. The organization is urging the hackers to come forward to discuss the protected status of the data.

images.alt_text: Hackers seized International Committee of the Red Cross data of more than 515,000 vulnerable people, including people who have fled conflict and others in detention.

site_title: China AInnovation said to price Hong Kong IPO at bottom of range
summary: Qingdao AInnovation Technology Group, a Chinese AI startup backed by SoftBank Group, priced its Hong Kong IPO at the bottom of its marketed range at HK$26.30 per share, raising about HK$1.18 billion. The company's AI solutions, including ManuVision, MatrixVision, and Orion, provide platforms for detecting defects, encoding images, and processing big data. This follows the successful debut of Chinese AI firm SenseTime Group last month, which raised US$741 million despite US sanctions. The IPO is part of a challenging period for Hong Kong's IPO market due to regulatory uncertainty.

site_title: About 100,000 people have entered Singapore from Malaysia via land and air VTLs
summary: About 100,000 people have entered Singapore from Malaysia via the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme since its launch on Nov 29, with 55,000 entering via land and 44,000 via air. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has temporarily reduced land VTL capacity by 50% due to concerns over the Omicron variant, and stricter testing requirements have been introduced for air VTLs. The VTL scheme has helped support Singapore's air hub recovery, with passenger traffic reaching 15% of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: France to announce plan for lifting Covid restrictions
summary: French Prime Minister Jean Castex will announce a plan for lifting Covid-19 restrictions, with a gradual timetable set for the coming months. France has seen a record 464,769 new cases in a 24-hour period, but the number of Covid patients in intensive care has been falling. The Omicron variant is less contagious and results in fewer serious cases, leading to hopes that the wave could peak soon. The government has already implemented measures, including a vaccine pass for public venues, and will provide a clearer timeline for easing restrictions.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase amid Omicron surge
summary: US weekly jobless claims increased to 286,000 for the week ended Jan 15, higher than forecasted 220,000, amid the Omicron surge disrupting business activity. The US is reporting an average of 732,245 new coronavirus infections a day, but cases are starting to subside in some regions. Economists expect claims to trend lower as infections decline, despite tight labor market conditions with 10.6 million job openings and a 22-month low unemployment rate of 3.9%.

site_title: The Straits Times launches book on Singapore's pandemic story
summary: The Straits Times has released a 352-page book, "In This Together: Singapore's Covid-19 Story", detailing the nation's two-year fight against the pandemic. The book features interviews with over 300 people, including President Halimah Yacob, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and frontline workers, as well as photographs and graphics. The book aims to pay tribute to frontliners and chronicle the pivotal period in Singapore's history, providing a comprehensive account of the nation's response to the crisis. The book retails for S$28.

site_title: Catalist-listed Joyas unveils plans to enter non-fungible token art market
summary: Joyas International Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, plans to enter the non-fungible token (NFT) market through a tie-up with Splendid Powerful, a British Virgin Islands-incorporated fintech firm. Joyas' wholly owned subsidiary will hold 60% of a new company that digitizes artwork as NFTs with blockchain technology. The deal aims to diversify revenue streams, but Joyas will seek shareholder approval for further transactions. Joyas' involvement will be on marketing and sales, with most work outsourced to Splendid Powerful.

site_title: Licensed trust company fined S$1.1m for lack of anti-money laundering scrutiny
summary: A licensed trust company, Vistra Trust (Singapore), has been fined S$1.1 million by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for failing to comply with anti-money laundering controls. The firm failed to identify higher-risk accounts and inadequate enhanced customer due diligence, putting it at risk of being used as a conduit for illicit activities. The MAS described the breaches as "serious" and ordered the firm to appoint an independent party to assess remediation measures. The firm has since paid the penalty and taken steps to address risk management deficiencies.

site_title: Wilmar's India joint venture moves forward with planned initial public offering
summary: Wilmar International's joint venture Adani Wilmar is moving forward with its planned initial public offering (IPO), involving the issue of up to 36 billion rupees (S$651 million) in new shares. The IPO will open for public subscription on Jan 27 and close on Jan 31. The proceeds will be used for capital expenditure, debt repayment, acquisitions, and investments. The listing is dependent on factors such as investor interest and market conditions, with no assurance of proceeding. The IPO will take place on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and the National Stock Exchange of India.

site_title: Pegasus Asia raises S$23.4m in Singapore public offer, 7.8 times subscribed
summary: Pegasus Asia, a European asset manager backed by Tikehau Capital, raised S$23.4 million in its Singapore public offer, 7.8 times subscribed. The company's units will start trading on the Singapore Exchange on January 21. The initial public offering included 25.6 million units, with 1,108 valid applications for 4.7 million units. Stabilising manager UBS AG oversaw an additional 4 million units, which will be covered by units issued by the company. This marks the second SPAC to trade on the Singapore Exchange, following Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation's debut on Thursday.

site_title: STI climbs 0.3 per cent on upbeat Wall Street earnings
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,294.82 points, following upbeat Wall Street earnings. Bank of America and Procter & Gamble beat analysts' estimates, lifting market sentiment. Thai Beverage was the top performer, while Hongkong Land was the worst. Regional indices also saw gains, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 1.1% and 3.4%, respectively.

site_title: Companies on IMDA's SMS registry can still be spoofed
summary: Companies registered with Singapore's SMS SenderID protection registry pilot can still have their IDs spoofed. Despite over 2,000 signatures on a petition calling for mandatory registration, scammers have found ways to send spoofed SMSes from protected companies such as DBS, Lazada, and SingPost. IMDA has confirmed that the registry pilot is not foolproof, with at least one reported scam on the r/Singapore subreddit. The issue highlights the need for improved security measures to prevent SMS spoofing.

site_title: Cracks in Thai PM's chaotic coalition as major party expels lawmakers
summary: Thailand's ruling coalition is experiencing cracks as the second-largest party, Palang Pracharat, expels 21 lawmakers for causing party disunity. The move comes amid criticism of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's handling of the Covid-19 crisis and slow vaccine rollout. The faction, led by Thammanat Prompao, has yet to decide whether to continue backing the prime minister. Analysts say the spat could lead to a cabinet reshuffle, making it harder for Prayuth to govern, but the coalition is expected to remain intact.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's crypto industry is concerned about the Monetary Authority's (MAS) guidelines against public promotion of digital payment token services, potentially hindering its growth. Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition is set to start trading on January 27. Fullerton Health may seek judicial management due to mounting woes and a shareholder stand-off. The Singapore Institute of Technology is partnering with Siemens to develop an Industry 4.0 degree specialisation. Restaurants face a dining-in crunch during Chinese New Year due to Covid-19 curbs and high demand. The Straits Times Index rose 0.3% on upbeat Wall Street earnings.

site_title: Nutryfarm didn't give loan updates when SGX queried because it was 'premature', says board
summary: Nutryfarm International, a MAINBOARD-listed company, did not disclose loan updates or legal proceedings when queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to its premature nature. The company has been in talks with creditor Corpbond IV Ltd to restructure third-party loans of HK$126.9 million (S$21.9 million) set to expire between March and November 2022. A trading halt was called on January 18 after significant price movements, and the board is awaiting responses from Corpbond on the restructuring plan, which could strengthen the company's balance sheet if successful.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 3.42% on Thursday, driven by China's easing monetary policy, which boosted tech and property giants. The Hang Seng Index rose 824.50 points to 24,952.35, while China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 0.09% and 0.92% respectively. China reduced bank lending costs, lowering the one-year loan prime rate to 3.7%, and lowered policy loans. Property firms, including China Evergrande, Sunac, and Country Garden, rallied, while tech firms like Meituan and XD also saw significant gains.

site_title: Container waiting times approaching new high, says K+N
summary: Container waiting times are approaching a new high, with Kuehne+Nagel's sea freight disruption indicator showing 11.6 million TEU days, a 15% increase from last Christmas. The majority of congestion, 80%, is caused by the US, according to executive vice-president Otto Schacht. This represents a significant increase from the usual one or two-day waiting times for container ships. The disruption indicator reflects waiting times in major ports worldwide, highlighting the ongoing challenges in the global supply chain.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday, down 2.58 points to 1,527.75, with 518 gainers outnumbering 403 losers.

site_title: Inflation, GST hike key concerns raised at SBF panel discussion on business outlook
summary: A panel discussion by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) on the business outlook highlighted concerns over inflation, the impending Goods and Service Tax (GST) hike, and rising manpower costs. Experts noted that monetary policy tightening and positive wage growth could mitigate these impacts. However, they emphasized the need for clarity on the timing of the GST hike to allow businesses to prepare. The discussion also touched on the issue of decarbonisation, with experts suggesting that the current tax rate is too low to make Singapore companies competitive in the push towards sustainability.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly up at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.3% and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 also gaining 0.2% and marginally higher, respectively. Asian markets rose as investors returned to buying after recent losses, driven by easing measures from China's central bank. In contrast, Wall Street stocks fell on Wednesday due to surging inflation and higher interest rate concerns, with oil prices reaching new multi-year highs.

site_title: Evergrande offshore bondholders criticise 'opaque' restructuring
summary: Evergrande offshore bondholders are criticizing the Chinese developer's 'opaque' restructuring efforts, stating that the company has failed to substantively engage with them. The ad-hoc group, representing international investors, will consider enforcement actions to protect investors' interests, including being consulted before further asset sales. Evergrande, saddled with $305 billion liabilities, missed US dollar bond payments in December and is seeking to restructure its debt. The developer's lack of engagement and decision-making process is seen as contrary to international restructuring standards.

site_title: DHL expects freight rates to stay high in 2022
summary: German logistics company DHL expects freight rates to remain high in 2022, with short-term rates rising slightly in air and ocean freight. The company advises customers to sign longer-term contracts to hedge against future price rises. The Covid-19 pandemic has disrupted global supply chains, causing shortages of freight capacity and pushing up shipping costs. DHL aims to keep its operating result at the same level as the first 9 months of 2021 and plans to maintain an operating margin above 5.5% by 2025.

images.alt_text: German logistics company Deutsche Post DHL does not expect freight costs to ease this year and is advising customers to agree to longer-term contracts as a hedge, the head of the DHL freight business said in an interview.

site_title: Philippine bank to launch crypto trading service
summary: Union Bank of the Philippines plans to launch a crypto trading service to capitalize on the growing adoption of digital tokens in the Asian nation. The bank estimates 5% of Filipinos have dabbled in cryptocurrencies, similar to the global average. Union Bank's head of blockchain and API group, Cathy Casas, predicts the average Filipino investor will hold 3-5% of their assets in digital assets like Bitcoin in 5 years, assuming stable markets. The move aims to future-proof the bank's business.

site_title: Fullerton Health could turn to courts for rescue as woes mount and white knight seems elusive
summary: Fullerton Health, a Singaporean private healthcare solutions firm, is facing financial woes and a stalled sale process. The company's largest creditor, RRJ Capital, is pressuring for a rescue plan. With time running out, Fullerton Health may resort to judicial management (JM) to avoid bankruptcy. A shareholder stand-off has hindered the sale process, leaving the company with limited options. A reliable source suggests that the JM path has become a possibility due to the prolonged sale process.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 5-day rout as LG Energy IPO volatility eases
summary: South Korean stocks ended a 5-day selling spree on Thursday, closing 0.72% higher as bargain hunting helped counter volatility. The Kospi index rose 20.40 points to 2,862.68, its first gain in 6 sessions. Heavyweights Samsung Electronics, LG Chem, and Samsung SDI also saw gains, with LG Energy's IPO volatility easing. The Korean won remained nearly unchanged, and the benchmark bond yield rose ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting and earnings reports.

site_title: China put a record number of solar panels on rooftops last year
summary: China installed a record 51 gigawatts of solar capacity in 2021, with over half coming from rooftop installations, surpassing its total solar capacity of 108 GW. Most of the growth occurred in the fourth quarter as developers met a subsidy deadline. China's main industry body forecasts 75 GW of solar additions in 2022, driven by government support for residential solar and clean energy hubs. Despite high costs and project delays, local authorities are encouraged by growth, with Shandong province adding over 12 GW in the past 2 years.

site_title: Unilever will not raise rejected £50b bid for GSK consumer arm
summary: Unilever has abandoned its £50 billion bid for GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK) consumer healthcare business after the company rejected the offer for the third time, citing that it "fundamentally undervalued" the business. Unilever's shares rose 10.1% while GSK's fell 2.8% on the news. The decision marks the end of Unilever's attempts to acquire the business, which is home to brands such as Sensodyne, Emergen-C, and Panadol.

site_title: Deliveroo's surprise strength in orders provide post-IPO
summary: Deliveroo reported a 70% year-over-year increase in full-year gross transaction value (GTV) in constant currency, exceeding its guidance. The company saw a 36% gain in fourth-quarter GTV to £1.7 billion, with orders rising 10% sequentially and GTV per order increasing 1% to £21.40. Deliveroo's CEO, Will Shu, attributed the results to strengthened customer proposition and execution against its strategy. This positive report lifted the company's shares, which have fallen 56% since its market debut last March.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues 'trade with caution' alert on Metech International
summary: SGX RegCo has issued a "trade with caution" alert on Catalist-listed Metech International due to recent trades driven by individuals connected to one another. The company's share price surged 51% from Nov 1, 2021 to Dec 21, 2021, before falling 44% by Jan 19, 2022, contradicting the Straits Times Index direction. SGX RegCo is reviewing trades in Metech shares amid concerns over potential manipulation.

site_title: Bank of Indonesia sends first hints of policy normalisation
summary: Bank Indonesia, the country's central bank, has hinted at policy normalization, with Governor Perry Warjiyo stating plans to raise the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) to 5% in March. The benchmark interest rate remains unchanged at 3.5%. The move aims to balance economic growth with currency stability, as the country rebounds from last year's recession but faces challenges from the Omicron variant and declining currency value. The decision was seen as a cautious step towards tightening monetary policy.

site_title: Defining trends of Singapore Art Week 2022
summary: Singapore Art Week 2022, organized by the National Arts Council and Singapore Tourism Board, was a success with over 130 events spanning 10 days. Key trends included musicians creating visual art, such as The Observatory's "music, mushroom and de-composition" show, and the rise of NFT art. Art outside galleries proved challenging, with some experiments not working well due to crowds. Millennials dominated emo art, with exhibitions featuring sensitive and emotional themes. The event also celebrated the pioneers and trailblazers of the Singapore art scene, with shows paying tribute to their work and legacy.

site_title: Hong Kong shuts secondary schools over Covid-19 fears
summary: Hong Kong's Education Bureau suspended face-to-face teaching in secondary schools starting January 24 due to rising coronavirus infections. This follows earlier suspensions in primary schools and kindergartens, as well as curbs such as restaurant dining bans and venue closures. The move aims to mitigate the spread of the virus.

site_title: Cantonese cooking that aims high at 5 on 25
summary: A new Cantonese cooking restaurant, 5 on 25, has opened on Fraser Street, Level 25. The restaurant aims to elevate traditional Cantonese cuisine. No specific events, key facts, or conclusions are mentioned in the provided articles.

site_title: TikTok owner ByteDance's revenue growth slowed to 70% in 2021: sources
summary: ByteDance, owner of TikTok, reported a 70% year-on-year revenue growth to around $58 billion in 2021, slower than the 100% growth in 2020 due to China's regulatory crackdown. The company retained its 2nd-ranked position in China's online advertising market with a 21% market share. Online ad sales in China declined 9.3% in 2021, down from 13.8% the previous year. ByteDance's revenue growth is attributed to its popular app TikTok, which saw a 77% year-over-year increase in user spending to $2.3 billion.

site_title: Private equity bonds gained traction as investors seek to diversify portfolios: Azalea
summary: Private equity bonds have gained traction as investors seek to diversify their portfolios. According to Azalea Asset Management, the asset under management of private equity funds grew to $7.6 trillion as of June 2021, outperforming public equities historically. CEO Margaret Lui attributes the growth to investors' desire for diversification.

site_title: Fashion goes green
summary: The fashion industry is a significant contributor to plastic microfibers entering the oceans and waste in landfills. In Singapore, fashion and textile products account for 137,000 tonnes of waste, with only 4% being recycled. To address this, the Textile and Fashion Federation (TaFF) has launched a sustainability programme to promote environmentally friendly practices among local fashion businesses. Several local brands, such as Love, Bonito and Graye, are already adopting sustainable practices, including using eco-friendly materials, reducing waste, and designing products for longevity. International brands like Levi's and Uniqlo are also incorporating sustainability into their production processes. Consumers can make informed choices by checking labels and choosing products that allow for multiple wearings and can be easily repaired or recycled.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound as China cuts lending rate
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed 1.11% higher on January 20, rebounding from previous losses, following China's central bank cutting key lending rates, which brightened market sentiment. The Nikkei 225 rose 305.70 points to 27,772.93, while the Topix index gained 18.81 points to 1,938.53.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on gold stocks boost, banks cap gains
summary: Australian shares ended 0.1% higher at 7,342.40, snapping a 2-day losing streak, despite banks capping gains due to US earnings reports. Gold stocks surged 7.3% in their best session since April 2020, driven by firm bullion prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index hovered near a 1-month low. Tech shares fell 0.6%, while the jobless rate fell to its lowest since 2008.

site_title: Thailand to resume quarantine waiver for arrivals from February
summary: Thailand to resume its "Test & Go" quarantine waiver for vaccinated arrivals starting February 1, after a month-long suspension due to the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. The policy requires visitors to test on arrival and 5 days later, while agreeing to have their whereabouts tracked. Authorities also extended restaurant hours to 11 pm and expanded the "Sandbox" program to include more beach destinations. The moves aim to revive Thailand's tourism sector, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up, China rate cut helps property sector
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Thursday, with Chinese property firms benefiting from the People's Bank of China's rate cut, which aims to boost the country's economy. The move lifted shares of companies like China Evergrande, Sunac, and Country Garden, while tech giants also saw gains. However, concerns about the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy plans and potential interest rate hikes weighed on global markets, with the Nasdaq falling into a correction.

site_title: Qantas raises stakes in battle over long-haul cabin crew contract
summary: Qantas is seeking to terminate its contract with long-haul flight attendants, citing the need for flexible rostering to restart its international network post-COVID. The move, which would bring large pay cuts, was rejected by 97% in a vote in December. Qantas claims a union counteroffer would have raised costs by $60 million over 4 years. The airline is seeking an expedited hearing with Australia's Fair Work Commission, which is expected to deal with the application in the coming weeks.

site_title: Singapore-based Crypto.com CEO says regulators haven't reached out after hack
summary: Crypto.com CEO Kris Marszalek stated that regulators have not reached out to the company after a cybersecurity breach affecting approximately 400 customer accounts, with all funds reimbursed. The breach occurred on January 18 and involved the theft of Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies, with estimated losses in the millions. Marszalek expressed confidence in the company's infrastructure and preparedness to share information with regulators upon request. Crypto.com is currently awaiting licence approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Crypto players concerned advertising curbs may dent Singapore's crypto hub drive
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued guidelines restricting the promotion of digital payment tokens (DPT) services in public areas and through third-party influencers. The move, effective immediately, aims to protect retail investors from the risks associated with crypto trading. Industry players, including the Blockchain Association and Access, have expressed concerns that the ban could deter development and advancement of blockchain technologies in Singapore, potentially hindering its ambitions to become a crypto hub.

site_title: Recovery on the cards for APAC despite near-term volatility: Moody's Analytics
summary: Moody's Analytics forecasts Asia-Pacific region's growth and recovery despite near-term volatility from the Omicron wave. Real GDP forecasts for India, Hong Kong, and Thailand have been revised to slower growth in the early-2022 period, with India's expected economic rebound pushed back to the second quarter. While Covid-19 impacts will create volatility, it will diminish over time. Risks of further domestic movement restrictions in Indonesia and the Philippines could hobble near-term growth, with policy shifts to the forefront in the second half of the year, potentially leading to over-aggressive monetary policy tightening.

images.alt_text: India, which is facing many new state-level movement restrictions and has seen foreign trade disappoint in recent months, will likely see its expected economic rebound in the first quarter pushed back to the second.

site_title: Malaysia's top badminton player quits national team
summary: Malaysia's top badminton player, Lee Zii Jia, has quit the national team to play as an independent, following weeks of speculation. The 23-year-old, ranked seventh in the world, cited inability to cope with pressure after poor performances in recent months, including a loss to China's Chen Long at the Olympics. Badminton Association of Malaysia (BAM) president Norza Zakaria expressed disappointment but acknowledged Lee's talent and potential. World number 1 Viktor Axelsen voiced support for Lee's decision, stating it's his career and life to manage.

site_title: Natural immunity more potent than vaccines during US Delta wave: study
summary: A new US study found that natural immunity from a previous Covid-19 infection was more potent than vaccine-acquired immunity during the US Delta wave. The study, based on data from 1.1 million people, showed that unvaccinated individuals who survived Covid were better protected than vaccinated individuals who had not previously been infected. However, the CDC warned against relying on infection as a strategy due to higher risks of hospitalization and death. The study's findings contradict previous CDC positions and highlight the need for further research on the duration of protection from previous infection.

site_title: Beijing sends strong policy easing signals, cuts mortgage reference rate for first time in 2 years
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, cut the 1-year loan prime rate (LPR) by 10 basis points to 3.70% and the 5-year LPR by 5 basis points to 4.60%, signaling a strong easing of monetary policy. This is the second consecutive month of LPR cuts, the first reduction in nearly 2 years. Analysts expect further policy easing, with Goldman Sachs predicting another 50 basis point RRR cut in the first quarter and an additional 10 basis point policy rate cut by the end of the second quarter.

site_title: KPMG proposes S$1b green energy investment fund in Budget 2022 wishlist
summary: KPMG has proposed a S$1 billion green energy investment fund in Singapore's Budget 2022 wishlist to drive low carbon technology adoption and combat greenwashing. The fund, which could be a partnership between the government and private sector, aims to support sustainable infrastructure projects. Additionally, KPMG suggested setting up a green financing bank, implementing stricter ESG regulations, and offering tax incentives for green buildings and digitalization efforts to boost Singapore's "green" agenda and become a leading global player in environmental, social, and corporate governance.

site_title: CNY dining-in crunch as restaurants face strong demand but curbed capacity
summary: In Singapore, restaurants face strong demand for Chinese New Year dining-in but curbed capacity due to Covid-19 restrictions. 9 out of 11 restaurants were fully booked for reunion dinner peak timings within the first week of January, with some being filled within days of their set menus launching online. To accommodate demand, hotels are repurposing function rooms and restaurants are increasing dine-in capacity. Takeaway orders have also increased, but dine-in orders are prioritized due to lower profitability.

site_title: Omicron risk to pin rates in Indonesia, Malaysia
summary: Central banks in Indonesia and Malaysia are expected to maintain record-low benchmark interest rates, citing concerns about the potential impact of the Omicron variant on growth. Bank Indonesia and Bank Negara Malaysia will likely keep rates at 3.5% and 1.75% respectively, with forecasts suggesting a potential rate hike in the second half of the year. The decision comes as both countries face economic challenges, including supply-chain issues and inflation concerns, amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 2.72 points or 0.18% to 1,527.61. Losers outnumbered gainers 169 to 110, with a total volume of 215.89 million lots worth RM79.84 million.

site_title: US Senate sinks Biden push for major voting rights reforms
summary: The US Senate blocked President Joe Biden's push for major voting rights reforms, including the Freedom to Vote Act and John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act, after all 50 Republicans voted against the measures. Democrats failed to overcome the 60-vote filibuster threshold, despite attempts to lower it. The legislation aimed to address Republican efforts to restrict voting, particularly among Black and Latino Americans, by guaranteeing mail-in voting, ballot drop boxes, and early voting, as well as addressing gerrymandering. Biden vowed to continue advancing necessary legislation and pushing for Senate procedural changes to protect the right to vote.

site_title: Vividthree enters Filecoin mining partnership with option to acquire 51% stake
summary: Vividthree Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, has entered a 2-year partnership with JVS Management Holdings for Filecoin mining, with an option to acquire a 51% stake for up to S$6 million. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for blockchain and digital assets, and will allow Vividthree to participate in the decentralized storage services of Filecoin. The deal is expected to be financially and strategically beneficial for the group and its stakeholders.

site_title: Singapore consumer spending to normalise from 2022: Fitch Solutions
summary: Fitch Solutions predicts Singapore's real consumer spending will increase by 3.1% in 2022, following a normalization of Covid-19-related restrictions and an ongoing vaccination program. This growth is expected to support overall consumer spending and return to a medium-term growth trajectory from 2022 to 2026. The forecast also projects a 3.6% economic growth in 2022, driven by a recovery in the tourism industry and a decline in unemployment to 2.2%.

site_title: Vertex Tech, Singapore's first SPAC, closes up 1% at S$5.05 after trading debut
summary: Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation (VTA) closed its trading debut at S$5.05, up 1.0% from its initial public offering price of S$5, after trading 1.69 million units. The SPAC's market capitalization is approximately S$202 million, following a retail tranche that was 36 times subscribed and an international placement that was 8.8 times subscribed. Cornerstone investors, including Temasek-backed entities, subscribed for 22.2 million units, with sponsor Vertex Holdings investing S$30 million in capital. The units and warrants will start trading separately on March 7.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on Thursday morning, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 7.63 points to 3,276.31. The decline was attributed to lower US shares on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1% and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 1.2%. The tech-rich Nasdaq index confirmed a correction after falling 10.7% from its record high in November.

site_title: China suspends 6 more flights from US over Covid-19 cases
summary: China's aviation regulator suspended 6 more flights from the US due to Covid-19 cases, bringing the total cancellations this year to 96. The cancellations include American Airlines' flights from Dallas to Shanghai from Feb 7 and China Southern Airlines' flights from Los Angeles to Guangzhou from Feb 28, affecting return flights to China in March. No flights were available for booking from the US to China in February.

site_title: Japan's Dec exports, imports hit record high by value as supply bottlenecks ease
summary: Japan's exports and imports reached record highs in December, with exports jumping 17.5% and imports rising 41.1%, driven by easing supply bottlenecks and rising prices. Yen-denominated exports and imports hit records of 7.9 trillion yen and 8.5 trillion yen, respectively. Despite a trade deficit of 582.4 billion yen, the country's economy is expected to have grown 6.5% in the last quarter of 2021, driven by domestic consumption.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.56% to 24,263.15, driven by tech firms. However, investor confidence remains cautious due to concerns about higher US interest rates. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.10%. Despite ongoing market uncertainty, stocks have shown resilience, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records in the US.

site_title: SIT collaborates with Siemens to develop degree specialisation in Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) partners with Siemens to develop a degree specialisation in Industry 4.0, focusing on robotics and artificial intelligence. The programme, set to begin in 2023, will combine academic learning with hands-on experience in the advanced manufacturing sector. Students will alternate between classroom and work-based learning, acquiring relevant skills and knowledge to boost employability. The collaboration aims to enhance industry relevance and career-readiness of graduates, following a competency-driven model.

site_title: White House meets small and mid-sized firms to discuss competition in tech sector
summary: The White House met with small and mid-sized tech firms to discuss competition issues in the tech sector, following President Joe Biden's executive order to promote more competition in the US economy. The meeting focused on fees charged by large tech companies, marketplace operations, and business rankings. The discussion comes ahead of a Senate Judiciary Committee vote on a bipartisan bill that would bar companies like Amazon and Google from favoring their products and services. The meeting aims to address concerns and potentially lead to regulatory changes to promote competition in the tech sector.

site_title: Gold holds around 2-month peak as firmer US yields weigh
summary: Gold prices steadied near a 2-month high on Thursday as US Treasury yields rose, preventing gains. Spot gold was flat at $1,839.36 per ounce, while US gold futures were down 0.1% at $1,840.60. Higher US interest rates, expected to be tightened by the Federal Reserve to combat inflation, weigh on gold prices. The US central bank's Federal Open Market Committee meets on January 25-26, amid concerns about inflation and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Gold prices on Thursday (Jan 20) steadied near a 2-month high hit in the previous session, with higher US Treasury yields preventing any gains amid caution building around developments at the US Federal Reserve's meeting due next week.

site_title: Djokovic holds major stake in firm developing Covid drug: CEO
summary: Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic, recently deported from Australia, is a co-founder and majority shareholder of Danish biotech firm QuantBioRes, which aims to develop a Covid-19 treatment. Djokovic, along with his wife Jelena, holds an 80% stake in the company, which employs around 20 staff in four countries. The company plans to launch clinical trials in the UK this summer, with the goal of using the Covid-19 treatment as a testing ground for its technology to fight viruses and resistant bacteria.

images.alt_text: Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic, recently deported from Australia due to his coronavirus vaccine status, is co-founder and majority shareholder of a biotech firm developing a Covid-19 treatment, the Danish company's CEO said Wednesday (Jan 19).

site_title: Oil up, settles near seven-year highs after Iraq-Turkey pipeline outage
summary: Oil prices rose near seven-year highs after a fire on a pipeline from Iraq to Turkey briefly stopped flows. The Kirkuk-Ceyhan pipeline, carrying crude from northern Iraq to Turkey, resumed operations after an explosion caused by a falling power pylon. The incident increased concerns about a tight short-term supply outlook. Oil prices have settled higher, with the fire exacerbating existing concerns about global supply.

images.alt_text: Oil prices settled higher on Wednesday after a fire on a pipeline from Iraq to Turkey briefly stopped flows, increasing concerns about an already tight short-term supply outlook.

site_title: StaffAny raises US$3.4m in Series A round led by GGV Capital
summary: StaffAny, a workforce management startup, has raised US$3.4 million in a Series A funding round led by GGV Capital. Founded by NUS alumni, StaffAny helps businesses optimize staff scheduling, time-tracking, and timesheet consolidation. The startup saw strong growth despite the pandemic, tracking over 11 million employee hours last year. New features include auto-scheduling and sales-based scheduling. StaffAny plans to expand beyond Singapore to target Malaysia and Indonesia, and develop a new product to improve employee engagement and retention.

site_title: Omicron intensifies Australia staff squeeze as wage demands rise
summary: Australia is experiencing a severe staff squeeze due to the Omicron variant, with waterfront resorts, restaurants, and cruises being forced to cancel bookings and shut down. A record number of job vacancies and rising Covid-induced absenteeism are providing leverage for labor over capital, potentially leading to the country's first wage growth in nearly a decade. This could have a positive impact on the economy, with economists predicting core inflation to reach the Reserve Bank's 2-3% target and wages rising to 3% by the end of 2022.

site_title: Google forms blockchain group under newly appointed executive
summary: Google has formed a group dedicated to blockchain and related technologies under newly appointed executive Shivakumar Venkataraman, an engineering vice-president. The group will focus on "next-gen distributed computing and data storage technologies" as part of Labs, a business division overseeing virtual and augmented reality efforts. This marks Google's entry into the blockchain space, where rivals such as Meta and Twitter have devoted significant resources. Google has previously offered cloud services to blockchain companies, but this new unit is relatively small compared to other product areas.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.16% lower on Thursday, following a 3% drop in the previous session due to Sony's 2.7% decline. The broader Topix index rose 0.11%. Despite market volatility, investors remain positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition to start trading on Jan 27
summary: NOVO Tellus Alpha Acquisition (NTAA), a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) backed by Novo Tellus Capital Partners, will start trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on January 27. The company has issued 30 million units, with 9.5 million offered via an international placement and 500,000 units available through the public offer. Cornerstone investors, including Temasek-owned Venezio Investments, have subscribed to 16 million units. NTAA is seeking a target business in the technology and industrials sector in the Indo-Pacific region, focusing on companies with a strong technology-enabled platform and global reach.

site_title: Most Covid rules in England to be scrapped as infections fall
summary: The UK government announced that most COVID-19 restrictions in England will be lifted due to falling infections. Guideline to work from home was immediately lifted, and mask mandates and COVID passes will be dropped starting mid-February. Prime Minister Boris Johnson attributed the decision to the country's successful booster campaign, aiming to boost his political future amid a scandal.

images.alt_text: The UK government announced on Wednesday that restrictions reimposed in England last month to fight the surge in Omicron coronavirus cases would be lifted, citing data that showed infections had peaked.

site_title: US, UK open talks to resolve steel, aluminum tariff dispute
summary: The US and UK have started talks to resolve the steel and aluminum tariff dispute, citing a "serious threat" posed by excess global capacity, mainly blamed on China. The tariffs imposed by the Trump administration caused friction with trading partners, including Britain, which retaliated with punitive duties on American goods. The two countries aim to work towards an "expeditious outcome" and have expressed commitment to resolving the dispute.

site_title: United Airlines reports Q4 loss on latest Covid-19 drag
summary: United Airlines reported a Q4 loss of $646 million, about a third of the loss from the year-ago period, due to the lingering drag from Covid-19. Revenues were $8.2 billion, a 25% drop from the 2019 quarter. The company expects a 16-18% capacity decrease in Q1 and below 2019 levels in 2022. CEO Scott Kirby remains optimistic about the spring and summer, citing a travel comeback. Despite this, shares fell 1.4% to $43.79 in after-hours trading.

site_title: Europe: Luxury goods, mining gains help shares regain lost ground
summary: European shares ended 0.2% higher on Wednesday, regaining lost ground, as luxury goods and mining sectors showed resilience. Mining stocks surged 2.7% due to iron ore price increases amid stimulus signs in China. The Stoxx 600 index fell 1% in the prior session but rebounded.

site_title: Instagram tests letting creators charge subscriptions
summary: Instagram is testing a subscription model, allowing popular content creators in the US to charge fans for exclusive content, including live streams. The platform aims to provide creators with a predictable income source, with CEO Adam Mosseri stating that subscriptions should be integrated throughout the Instagram experience. A small number of creators will participate in the test, with the goal of expanding the feature in the future, allowing creators to take their subscriber lists to other apps. This move aims to compete with other platforms that already offer subscription-based models.

site_title: US: Wall Street sell-off deepens, Nasdaq confirms correction
summary: US stocks ended sharply lower on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq confirming a correction after corporate earnings and concerns over US Treasury yields and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening. The Nasdaq fell 10.7% from its November record high, marking its fourth correction since the pandemic. This decline follows a period of record highs for the tech-heavy index.

site_title: Antibiotic-resistant superbugs killed 1.2 million in 2019: study
summary: A study published in the Lancet found that antibiotic-resistant superbugs killed 1.2 million people worldwide in 2019, with an estimated 3.68 million additional deaths. This represents a significant increase, surpassing the death toll from HIV/AIDS and malaria. The study urges global action to combat antimicrobial resistance, which has become a major global health crisis. Researchers also explored alternative treatments, such as bacteriophage therapy, which showed promise in treating antibiotic-resistant infections.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Vertex Technology, OCBC, Vividthree, Roxy-Pacific
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 31.4% drop in distribution per unit to S$0.0157 for the second half ended Dec 31, 2021. Vertex Technology Acquisition Corp's initial public offering closed 36 times subscribed, with units set to trade on Thursday. OCBC pledged to make goodwill payouts to 100+ customers affected by SMS phishing scams, totaling S$8.5 million. Vividthree entered a 2-year partnership with JVS Management for Filecoin mining, with an option to acquire a 51% stake. Roxy-Pacific's shareholders were advised to accept a buyout offer of S$0.485 per share, valuing the company at S$630.5 million.

site_title: German 10-year bond yield above 0% for first time since May 2019
summary: Germany's 10-year bond yield rose above 0% for the first time since May 2019, marking a potential turning point for euro area debt. The yield note rose 2 basis points to 0.009%, with fund manager Gareth Hill calling it a "very key level" indicative of policy tightening by the European Central Bank. The move reflects record-high inflation and an economy recovering from the pandemic, allowing the ECB to pare back monetary stimulus. Eurozone bond markets expect a 10 basis-point rate hike from the ECB by September and another by December.

site_title: Australia: Shares dragged lower by financials, tech stocks
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.3% to 7,332.5 points, driven by a weak finish on Wall Street and declining tech stocks. Financials dropped 1% and energy stocks declined 0.8%, while resource-related stocks rose 1.1% on robust commodity prices. The gold sub-index advanced 6% after bullion prices rose on a weaker dollar, with miners like BHP Group and Evolution Mining jumping 1.4% and 9% respectively.

site_title: Biden says fight to lower US inflation will 'be a haul'
summary: President Joe Biden stated that lowering US inflation will be a challenging task, likening it to a "haul." He attributes the high inflation rate to supply chain issues, citing examples such as gas pumps and grocery stores. Biden believes provisions in his Build Back Better spending proposal can help alleviate the situation, but it will require significant effort and work.

site_title: Banks ready sale of US$10b debt for McAfee buyout
summary: Banks are preparing to launch a $10 billion debt financing package to back the leveraged buyout of cybersecurity software maker McAfee, valued at over $14 billion. The deal, led by Advent International and Permira Advisers, will include a $5.66 billion first-lien loan, $1 billion of secured bonds, and $2.3 billion of unsecured bonds. The financing is expected to be priced at around 4.5% for the first-lien loan and 6.5% for the unsecured notes, although these figures may change due to recent market weakness. JPMorgan Chase is leading the loan portion, while Bank of America is leading the bond offerings.

site_title: North Korea hints at possible restart of nuclear or long-range missile tests: KCNA
summary: North Korea has hinted at a possible restart of its nuclear and long-range missile tests, citing a "hostile policy and military threat" from the US as a reason. The statement comes after a politburo meeting led by leader Kim Jong Un, which instructed a sector to "promptly examine" resuming suspended activities. This warning could lead to a "long-term confrontation" with the US.

site_title: World Bank chief takes swipe at Microsoft's US$69b gaming deal as poor countries struggle
summary: World Bank President David Malpass criticized Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, saying it's a questionable allocation of capital at a time when poor countries are struggling with debt restructuring and poverty. He noted that the deal dwarfs the $8 billion annual contributions by wealthier donor countries to the International Development Association, and most capital flows to the bond market, where only a small portion of developing countries have access. Malpass called for a return to normal global investment returns to bring more financing capacity to small businesses in developing countries.

site_title: USD near week high, pound up after inflation data
summary: The US dollar reached a weekly high, driven by rising US yields and expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Sterling also surged after British inflation rose 5.4% in December, its highest level in 30 years. The pound was tempered by talks of a leadership challenge to Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Biden says 'not there yet' on possible easing of tariffs on Chinese goods
summary: President Joe Biden stated that it's too soon to make commitments on lifting US tariffs on Chinese goods, despite his chief trade negotiator, Katherine Tai, working on the issue. Biden referred to China's commitments under a Phase 1 trade deal signed by his predecessor, Donald Trump. The President emphasized that the US needs to see China meet its commitments before easing tariffs.

site_title: GIC-backed Novotech Health eyes IPO again after gaining US$3b valuation
summary: Private equity firm TPG's Novotech Health Holdings raised US$255 million in equity through a private placement, valuing the business at US$3 billion. This marks a third increase from its previous valuation of US$2.3 billion. The company, a clinical research and testing provider, refinanced US$505 million of debt and plans to pursue strategic M&A and tech enablement initiatives to grow. TPG is preparing to bring the business to public markets, with New York and Hong Kong being considered as listing destinations, and an IPO potentially this year.

images.alt_text: Private equity giant TPG's Novotech Health Holdings raised fresh financing valuing the business at US$3 billion, as it considers another run at an initial public offering (IPO) after a deal was pulled last year.

site_title: Mandatory Chinese Olympics app has encryption flaws
summary: A mandatory Chinese Olympics app, MY2022, has encryption flaws that could allow personal information to leak, including health data and voice messages. The app, used to track Covid-19, is required for athletes, journalists, and attendees of the Beijing Olympics. A cyber security watchdog report warns of a "simple but devastating flaw" that could compromise sensitive information. The report was authored by Jeffrey Knockel for Citizen Lab, a cyber security watchdog.

site_title: New Omicron infections in Singapore more than double to 1,185
summary: Singapore reported 1,185 new Omicron cases on Jan 19, nearly doubling the previous day's 589 cases. The total cases now stand at 296,077, with 844 deaths. 965 cases were local, while 220 were imported. The weekly infection growth rate rose to 1.96, with 281 patients in hospital and 18 requiring oxygen supplementation.

site_title: US: Stock indexes bounce back on strong earnings
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on January 19, 2022, after a host of companies reported strong earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.12% to 35,412.30, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.24% and 0.52%, respectively. This rebound partially offset a wobbly start to the 4th-quarter reporting season, with Big Tech stocks also making a comeback.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Wednesday (Jan 19) after upbeat results from a host of companies partially offset a wobbly start to the 4th-quarter reporting season, while Big Tech stocks also made a comeback.

site_title: Sustainability in style: Eco-friendly fashion takes centre stage
summary: Singapore's eco-friendly fashion scene is gaining momentum, with local labels prioritizing sustainability. Brands are reducing waste and carbon footprint through recycling, innovative designs, and longer-wearing garments. This shift towards eco-friendly fashion is part of a broader movement towards a more sustainable lifestyle. As consumers become increasingly environmentally conscious, the demand for sustainable fashion is expected to continue growing, with Singapore's labels at the forefront of this trend.

site_title: Activision's CEO looking at US$375m payday in Microsoft sale
summary: Activision Blizzard CEO Bobby Kotick is set to receive a $375.3 million payout upon Microsoft's completion of its $68.7 billion deal to buy Activision. This comes after Kotick received a 50% pay cut last year amid employee complaints over sexism and mismanagement of assault claims. Despite controversy surrounding his leadership, Kotick will remain CEO until the deal is completed, according to a Microsoft statement.

site_title: Sabana Reit posts 31.4% drop in H2 2021 DPU to S$0.0157; seeks growth via AEIs, acquisitions
summary: Sabana Reit, a Singaporean industrial real estate investment trust, reported a 31.4% drop in its half-yearly distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0157 in FY2021. The trust aims to increase its portfolio value to over S$1 billion in 3-5 years through asset enhancement initiatives (AEIs) and acquisitions, with CEO Donald Han stating the move is to benefit unitholders.

site_title: The transformation of video communications
