Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase & Co have reported having to pay competitively to hire and keep analysts and associate bankers. The banks are being forced to pay higher wages, with Citigroup's CFO citing "competitive pressure on wages" and JPMorgan's CFO stating that labor markets are tight and labor inflation is present. This trend is expected to continue in 2022, with Wells Fargo anticipating a $300-million increase in expenses related to paying commissions and bonuses.

site_title: ESG snapshot: Recent developments of interest
summary: New climate and board diversity disclosures recently introduced by the Singapore Exchange and Hong Kong's Corporate Governance Code and Listing Rules take effect this year. The Singapore Exchange requires issuers to provide climate reporting and subject their sustainability reporting processes to internal review, while Hong Kong's revised Corporate Governance Code includes more stringent board independence and board diversity requirements. The European Commission is consulting with member states over plans to allow certain gas and nuclear activities into the EU Taxonomy Regulation, amid disagreement over the role of these activities in facilitating a renewable-based future.

site_title: US judge bans Shkreli for life from pharmaceutical industry
summary: A US federal judge has banned Martin Shkreli, a former pharmaceutical executive, for life from the industry due to his history of monopolizing medications. Shkreli must pay $64.6 million in damages and has been serving a 7-year prison sentence on securities fraud. The ban comes after Shkreli's company, Turing, delayed generic competition for the HIV drug Daraprim by 18 months by reaching exclusive supply agreements. Shkreli's actions were deemed "egregious, deliberate, repetitive, long-running and ultimately dangerous" by the judge.

site_title: 863 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, infection growth rate rises to 1.49
summary: Singapore reported 863 new Covid-19 cases, with 500 local and 363 imported cases, as of January 16. The Omicron variant accounted for 675 cases, with 422 local and 253 imported cases. The weekly infection growth rate rose to 1.49, up from 1.47 on Saturday. Hospital cases stood at 196, with 13 in intensive care. 91% of Singapore's eligible population have completed the full vaccination regimen, and 51% have received the vaccine booster shot.

site_title: How large a part will electric vehicles play in solving our climate woes?
summary: The article discusses the impact of electric vehicles (EVs) on climate change and their adoption. Despite growing demand, obstacles remain, which could affect their impact. The growth of the EV market has accelerated, but it's unclear if EVs will be enough to solve climate woes. The article does not provide conclusive information on the effectiveness of EVs in mitigating climate change, highlighting the need for further research and consideration of various factors.

images.alt_text: Switching from ICE vehicles to EVs may result in net carbon savings of about 50%, according to estimates from Singapore's Land Transport Authority. If all light vehicles ran on electricity, the net carbon reduction could potentially come up to about 4% of Singapore's annual emissions.

site_title: Lawsuit says Google, Facebook chiefs agreed to market pact
summary: Top executives at Google and Facebook were directly involved in approving a 2018 deal that allegedly manipulated online ad auctions, cementing their dominance of the online advertising market. The deal, known as "Jedi Blue," was allegedly approved by Google CEO Sundar Pichai, Facebook executive Sheryl Sandberg, and CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The US government has filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google, accusing it of maintaining an "illegal monopoly" in online search and advertising, which could lead to a potential breakup of the company.

site_title: Fed officials say rate hikes near as inflation soars
summary: US Federal Reserve officials predict a rate hike as early as March to combat high inflation, which has exceeded the 2% target and shows no signs of receding. Policymakers, citing the Omicron Covid-19 variant, plan to raise interest rates to reduce demand and bring inflation in line with supply constraints. The Fed expects the economy to grow 3.5% this year, with inflation expected to drop to 2.5% in 2022 and 2% in 2023.

site_title: S-Reits: Bigger and bolder over the years
summary: S-REITs in Singapore have been active in asset acquisitions and mergers and acquisitions, with 24 S-REITs announcing over S$15.3 billion in asset acquisitions in 2021. Recent mergers include the proposed union of Mapletree Commercial Trust and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust to form Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, and the merger of ESR-Reit and Ara Logos Logistics Trust to form ESR-Logos Reit. These deals aim to increase financial flexibility and debt headroom, and provide access to new economy real estate and Asian-Pacific properties worth over US$50 billion.

site_title: Apollo's credit hedge fund posts 10% gain thanks to Hertz and grocery bets: sources
summary: Apollo Global Management's flagship credit hedge fund posted a 10% gain in 2021, outperforming the ICE Bank of America High-Yield Index, largely due to a successful investment in Hertz Global Holdings. Apollo's $1.5 billion preferred equity investment in Hertz paid off when the company repaid the investment in less than 5 months after its June bankruptcy exit. The fund also benefited from bets on the grocery and media sectors, as well as capital structure arbitrage trades. The fund's performance was led by John Zito, deputy chief investment officer and co-head of global credit business.

site_title: US bill aims to end China's 'chokehold' on America's rare earth supplies
summary: US Senators Mark Kelly and Tom Cotton have proposed a law to end China's "chokehold" on rare-earth metal supplies, aiming to ensure the US can guarantee its supplies of rare-earth minerals. The law would require a strategic reserve by 2025 and restrict the use of Chinese rare-earth minerals in "sophisticated" defense equipment. The move aims to reduce the US reliance on China, which possesses 44 million tons of rare-earth metal deposits and has used these resources to exert political pressure. The law also urges the Commerce Department to investigate Beijing's unfair trade practices.

site_title: Mars to buy pet-food brand Nom Nom
summary: Mars has agreed to acquire pet-food brand Nom Nom, a Nashville-based company, in a push to expand its pet-related assets. Nom Nom will operate as an autonomous brand within Mars's Royal Canin division, offering fresh food for cats and dogs. The acquisition comes as the pet market continues to grow, driven by increased pet ownership and spending by millennials and Gen Z. This is Mars's second recent pet-related acquisition, following the purchase of PrettyLitter in 2021. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: Raskin nomination for Fed regulation chief puts Wall Street on notice
summary: US President Joe Biden has nominated Sarah Bloom Raskin to lead regulation and supervision at the Federal Reserve, replacing Randal Quarles, who had a more industry-friendly approach. Raskin, a former Fed governor and Treasury official, is expected to take a tougher stance on Wall Street and review several of Quarles' rule changes. The nomination is seen as a progressive move, and Raskin faces a potentially partisan confirmation process in the Senate. With the Fed's 7-member Board of Governors set to be filled, Raskin's appointment could steer the direction of both Wall Street oversight and monetary policy for years to come.

site_title: Indonesia to introduce new tax breaks on property, car sales
summary: Indonesia introduces new tax breaks on property and car sales to accelerate its economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The government provides a 50% discount on value added tax (VAT) for homes valued under 2 billion rupiah and a 25% discount for homes valued at 2-5 billion rupiah until June. Additionally, tax breaks are offered for car sales worth under 250 million rupiah, with some schemes expiring in March or September. The move comes as Indonesia prepares for the spread of the Omicron variant, with 4.27 million Covid-19 cases reported.

site_title: Elon Musk's tunnel system works, but the real test is still to come
summary: Elon Musk's Boring Co successfully tested its Las Vegas tunnel system, transporting 15,000-17,000 people daily during CES, with average wait times under 15 seconds and ride times under 2 minutes. The system performed well, despite some snags, but the real test remains to come as it prepares for higher demand. The company's compensation for the project is tied to its performance during large conferences, and it has met the minimum requirements outlined in its contract. The successful test has emboldened other cities to consider contracts with Boring Co, including Fort Lauderdale and San Bernardino County, California.

site_title: North Korea fired railway-borne missiles in third test this year
summary: North Korea fired 2 railway-borne tactical guided missiles, its third test this month, amid US sanctions. The tests aimed to evaluate the proficiency of the railway-borne regiment. The launch was detected by South Korea's military, which also reported the detection of 2 short-range ballistic missiles on Friday. The tests come amid tensions following the imposition of new US sanctions.

site_title: Alibaba, JD.com investors boost shift to Hong Kong's market
summary: Some of China's biggest tech firms, including Alibaba and JD.com, are seeing investors shift their shares from US ADRs to Hong Kong listings amid US regulatory oversight and bilateral tensions. Over the past year, nine Chinese firms have increased their proportion of Hong Kong shares, with Alibaba and JD.com seeing nearly double conversions. Investors can exchange US shares for Hong Kong-listed shares at a set ratio. This shift may provide these firms with more favorable regulatory environments.

site_title: US says Russia is preparing operations to justify Ukraine attack
summary: The US has warned that Russia is preparing to justify an invasion of Ukraine by conducting sabotage operations and fabricating provocations on social media. Russian operatives trained in urban warfare and explosives have been prepositioned in Ukraine, potentially to carry out false flag operations. The Biden administration has expressed concern that Russia is actively working to create a pretext for an invasion, citing intelligence that suggests Moscow is preparing to move on Ukraine. The US is urging diplomacy to prevent a conflict.

site_title: Djokovic back for another night in Australia detention before court hearing
summary: Novak Djokovic will spend the night in immigration detention in Melbourne, Australia, before a court hearing on Sunday to stop his deportation and allow him to compete in the Australian Open. The tennis star's visa was canceled due to concerns about his anti-vaccination stance, which has fueled the anti-vaccination movement in his native Serbia and surrounding countries. A court order has required Djokovic to surrender to immigration officials for an interview, and the government has said it will not deport him until his appeal has been heard.

images.alt_text: [MELBOURNE] Novak Djokovic will spend Saturday (Jan 15) night in immigration detention before the world's tennis number one seeks a court ruling to stop his deportation and keep alive his bid for a record 21st major title at the Australian Open.

site_title: US finds highly pathogenic bird flu in wild duck, first case since 2016
summary: The US Department of Agriculture confirmed the first case of a highly pathogenic Eurasian H5 avian influenza in a wild duck in South Carolina since 2016. The virus was detected in a wild duck hunted in Colleton County. The USDA is determining the exact strain of the virus, with results expected within a few days. This case highlights the ongoing risk of avian influenza in the US wild bird population.

site_title: US CDC recommends Americans wear 'most protective mask you can'
summary: The US CDC recommends Americans wear the "most protective mask they can," citing the highest level of protection provided by properly fitted respirators. This guidance comes as COVID-19 cases surge in the US, with 1.35 million new infections reported, mostly attributed to the Omicron variant. The CDC no longer expresses concerns over N95 supply shortages, allowing Americans to choose the most protective mask available, such as N95s and KN95s.

site_title: Bitcoin's rising correlation with tech weighs on hedge appeal
summary: Bitcoin's correlation with technology stocks has increased, with the 100-day correlation coefficient now at 0.40, its highest since 2011. This trend is attributed to the cryptocurrency's tendency to move in lockstep with other risk assets as the Federal Reserve becomes more hawkish with its policy. Experts warn that Bitcoin's appeal as a hedge is waning, and its price may be affected by the Fed's stimulus withdrawal. The correlation between Bitcoin and the Nasdaq has sparked concerns that the cryptocurrency's value may be tied too closely to the overall market, rather than its own underlying fundamentals.

site_title: Goldman's most elite rank to get millions in special payouts
summary: Goldman Sachs' top executives, known as partners, will receive a one-time special payout of millions of dollars in addition to their annual bonuses, recognizing the firm's record earnings during the pandemic. The unusual payment, awarded exclusively in stock, aims to keep top producers happy and prevent them from leaving the bank. The move is a creative solution to maintain expectations and costs, as bosses across Wall Street are increasing payouts to sweeten deals amid a 2-year trading boom.

site_title: US tech stocks stumble to worst start since 2016 on rate-hike fears
summary: US technology stocks have started the year on a downward trend, with the Nasdaq 100 Index down over 4% for the year, its worst start since 2016. Investors are hesitant to buy into growth stocks due to concerns over runaway inflation, and there are no signs that the pressure on technology companies will ease soon. The broader Nasdaq Composite Index has fallen for a third straight week, following failed attempts to rally back strongly.

images.alt_text: The stocks of US technology companies are seeing the worst start to a year since 2016 as fears about runaway inflation imperil the heady valuations left by the market's run up over the past few years.

site_title: LG Energy Solution raises 12.8t won in S.Korea's biggest IPO
summary: LG Energy Solution, a South Korean battery maker, raised 12.8 trillion won (US$10.8 billion) in its initial public offering (IPO), attracting record demand. The listing will be the biggest in the country after Samsung Life Insurance Co Ltd's 4.8-trillion won IPO in 2010. LGES, a subsidiary of LG Chem Ltd, supplies major automakers and is valued at 70.2 trillion won, making it South Korea's third most-valuable company.

site_title: Biden forms new group to plan for future coronavirus variants: sources
summary: The Biden administration has formed the Pandemic Innovation Task Force to prepare for future coronavirus variants and other pandemic threats. The task force, led by the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, will focus on developing vaccines, treatments, and diagnostic tests. The group's formation comes as the US grapples with the omicron strain, which has fueled unprecedented case counts and hospitalizations. The task force aims to prepare the country for new variants and future biological threats, with the goal of reducing the impact of future pandemics.

site_title: Netflix raises monthly subscription prices in US, Canada
summary: Netflix has raised monthly subscription prices in the US and Canada by $1 to $2, with the standard plan now costing $15.49 in the US and $16.49 in Canada. The increases aim to help pay for new programming to compete with rival streaming services. Existing members will see the new prices in the coming weeks, while new customers will be charged the new rates immediately. Despite previous price increases, Netflix has maintained a loyal customer base, with analysts noting that the company has pricing power.

site_title: Quick healer Osaka allays fitness fears ahead of Australian Open
summary: Naomi Osaka, Australian Open defending champion, has allayed concerns about an abdominal injury that forced her withdrawal from a tune-up event. The 24-year-old Japanese tennis player, who has been out of action for 4 months, stated she heals quickly and is "as good as I can be in this current moment." Osaka played 3 matches in the WTA 250 event in Melbourne, but withdrew ahead of her semi-final. Her comments come ahead of her title defense at Melbourne Park.

site_title: J&J reaches US$44m opioid settlement with holdout US state New Mexico
summary: Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay US$44 million to resolve claims of fueling the opioid epidemic in New Mexico, a holdout state that initially declined to participate in a nationwide settlement. This payment is part of a US$26 billion deal with distributors McKesson, AmerisourceBergen, and Cardinal Health. New Mexico Attorney General Hector Balderas initially declined the US$5 billion deal offered by J&J but later agreed to participate in the distributors' US$21 billion deal.

site_title: Wells Fargo beats profit estimates on uptick in loan demand, cost cuts
summary: Wells Fargo exceeded profit estimates for the fourth quarter, driven by a rebound in US economic growth and increased loan demand. The bank reported a 86% profit jump to $5.8 billion, with core business strong and loans issued up 1% from a year earlier. Cost cuts also contributed to the results, with non-interest expenses falling 11% to $13.2 billion. The bank aims for an additional $3.3 billion in cost cuts in 2022, targeting $10 billion in annual savings.

site_title: For BP, car chargers to overtake pumps in profitability race
summary: BP's fast electric vehicle chargers are nearing profitability levels compared to traditional petrol filling, with margins expected to surpass those of fuel sales. The company invests heavily in EV charging, aiming to expand operations in power markets and EV. BP plans to grow its EV charging business to 70,000 points by 2030, driven by strong demand for rapid battery chargers in Britain and Europe. The division is not expected to turn profitable before 2025, but its fast charging points are nearing levels seen from filling up with petrol.

site_title: China new home prices fall less in December on promotions, easing curbs
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.2% in December, slower than the 0.3% drop in November, as authorities introduced measures to boost sales, including subsidies and discounts. This marks a stabilizing trend after the market slowed since June 2021 due to regulatory measures. Despite this, prices rose 2.6% year-over-year, slower than the 3% growth in November. Analysts expect further easing of financing curbs and tweaks to the "three red lines" policy to contain risks from defaults by property developers.

site_title: Google mandates weekly Covid-19 tests for people entering US offices
summary: Google has temporarily mandated weekly Covid-19 tests for anyone entering its US offices, requiring a negative test and surgical-grade masks. This measure aims to prevent the spread of the Omicron variant amid a surge in cases. The company provides free testing options for employees and their dependants. This policy follows Google's previous rules on Covid-19 vaccination, which included penalties for non-compliance. The temporary health measures were implemented as the company delays its return-to-office plan globally due to growing concerns over Omicron.

site_title: Listen to your heart: Separating myth from fact
summary: Heart doctors dispel common myths about detecting and preventing heart disease. A common myth is that there is a single "best" test for detecting coronary heart disease, when in fact, several tests, such as the electrocardiogram (ECG) and stress test, are used to diagnose the condition. Additionally, myths surrounding dietary restrictions and lifestyle changes are also debunked, emphasizing the importance of a balanced diet and regular exercise in preventing heart disease. The article aims to provide accurate information to help readers make informed decisions about their heart health.

site_title: Australian Open players tired of the Djokovic circus
summary: Leading Australian Open players expressed frustration over Novak Djokovic's visa saga overshadowing the tournament. Djokovic, a vaccine sceptic, announced a medical exemption to Covid-19 requirements, sparking widespread anger in Australia. The players want the spotlight back on tennis, tired of the drama surrounding Djokovic's battle to compete in the tournament. Djokovic's visa was cancelled twice, and he is now facing deportation. The Australian Open is set to begin, with Djokovic's participation uncertain, leaving the players eager to refocus on the sport.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.18 points to 1,555.33. The decline followed a similar trend in other Asian markets, where traders brushed off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally. Losers outnumbered gainers 828 to 204, with a total of 3.604 billion lots worth RM2.953 billion traded.

site_title: US: Dow closes lower after disappointing bank results
summary: The US stock market closed lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.56% due to disappointing bank results. JPMorgan Chase & Co, Goldman Sachs, and American Express were major decliners. The Nasdaq and S&P 500, however, regained lost ground in afternoon trading, with the Nasdaq closing 0.59% higher and the S&P 500 0.08% higher. Analysts expect earnings to rise 23.1% in the fourth quarter, despite concerns over inflation, Omicron, and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Russia takes down REvil hacking group at US request
summary: Russia has dismantled the REvil hacking group at the request of the US, detaining and charging group members. The operation occurred during high tensions between Russia and the US over Ukraine. The US welcomed the arrests, citing a REvil associate's role in the Colonial Pipeline cyberattack last spring. REvil used encryption software developed by associates, and the group was responsible for a massive cyberattack on Ukrainian government websites. The US and Russia's cooperation on this issue is seen as a rare demonstration of collaboration despite ongoing tensions.

site_title: Tackling gender imbalance in the investment management industry
summary: A study by Ellen Carr and Katrina Dudley, titled "Undiversified," highlights the significant gender imbalance in the investment management industry. Only 10% of portfolio managers are women, and firms majority-owned by women manage less than 1% of global investable assets. The authors, seasoned portfolio managers and finance professors, debunk myths and propose solutions to mitigate the imbalance, including increasing visibility, improving investment literacy, and supporting organizations that improve the pipeline. They aim to bring women in and keep them in the industry, with a goal of achieving 30% female representation.

site_title: Dog walking startup Wag in merger talks with CHW SPAC: sources
summary: Dog-walking startup Wag Labs is in talks to go public through a merger with CHW Acquisition Corp, a special purpose acquisition company. The combined entity is expected to have an enterprise value of $350 million, based on projected revenue of $42 million in 2022 and $71 million in 2023. Wag, which has experienced significant growth during the pandemic, has not finalized terms with CHW and the deal could still collapse. This merger follows a similar path taken by Rover Group, another pet care service provider, which went public through a SPAC merger last summer.

site_title: BlackRock's sustainable investment funds surge to US$509b
summary: BlackRock's sustainable investment funds have surged to $509 billion, more than doubling from a year ago, according to CEO Larry Fink. This growth is attributed to a "tectonic shift" in sustainable investing, with Europe, the Middle East, and Africa accounting for $65 billion of the funds. Fink emphasized the need for money managers to respond to sustainability concerns to win investment mandates in the region and highlighted opportunities in carbon sequestration and fossil-fuel company technology development. He sees a "net-zero economy" as a major investment opportunity.

images.alt_text: [NEW YORK] Larry Fink's promised "tectonic shift" in sustainable investing is well under way.

site_title: Shedding new light on dementia
summary: Wendy Mitchell, a retired NHS administrator, has written a new book, "What I Wish People Knew About Dementia," offering a sympathetic and informed approach to the disease. The book, co-authored with Anna Wharton, aims to redefine how dementia is perceived, shifting the focus from "suffering from" to "living with" the condition. Mitchell, who was diagnosed with dementia at 58, shares her personal experience and insights, providing a valuable resource for those affected by the disease. The book promotes a more compassionate and supportive approach to dementia.

images.alt_text: Attention has long been on finding a wonder drug to prevent or cure the disease. But reading this book is to conclude that far more mundane forms of support would make a huge contribution to the ability of those with the condition to live a productive life.
What I Wish People Knew About Dementia By Wendy Mitchell Bloomsbury £14.99 (S$26.67), 240 pages

site_title: Emerging markets: a constructive 2022 in sight
summary: Emerging markets (EMs) are expected to have a constructive year, driven by attractive long-term value and real yields exceeding those in developed markets. Fiscal and current accounts across EMs are in better shape, and institutional reforms have strengthened their economic discipline. China's market valuations appear near a floor, and regulatory uncertainty may be partly a function of the country's political cycle. India's economic activity has rebounded, and positive structural forces remain apparent, including digitalisation, decarbonisation, and secular growth opportunities. However, certain risks, such as market volatility and Covid-19 variants, could impact the EM outlook.

site_title: Island escape at Bob's Bar
summary: Bob's Bar at Capella Singapore offers an island escape with panoramic sea views, tropical forest-inspired cocktails, and a resort-like atmosphere. The bar features a range of signature drinks, including the Palawan Fizz and Golden Bells, made with locally sourced and sustainable ingredients. The bar's focus on sustainability is reflected in its use of citrus stock and locally sourced herbs, with a goal of reducing waste and utilizing all available ingredients. The bar is open from mid-afternoon, allowing patrons to enjoy the sunset views while sipping on one of its creative cocktails.

site_title: 832 new Covid-19 Omicron cases; infection growth rate falls to 1.38
summary: Singapore reported 832 new Omicron cases, with 543 local and 289 imported, bringing the total to 290,030 cases and 840 deaths. The weekly infection growth rate fell to 1.38, down from 1.43. 185 patients are in hospital, with 11 in the ICU. 91% of the eligible population has completed their full vaccination regimen, and 50% have received a vaccine booster shot.

images.alt_text: Of these, 543 were local cases and 289 were imported, the Ministry of Health said in its daily update on Friday (Jan 14).

site_title: Thailand and Indonesia unveil plans to develop molnupiravir Covid-19 pill
summary: Thailand and Indonesia plan to develop molnupiravir, a Covid-19 treatment pill, to combat rising infections driven by the Omicron variant. Thailand's health minister announced plans to co-develop the drug with the Chulabhorn Research Institute, while Indonesia partnered with PT Amarox Pharma Global to start production in April or May. Both countries have already approved the pill for emergency use, with Thailand ordering 50,000 courses and Indonesia receiving 400,000 pills. This move follows other Southeast Asian countries, including Bangladesh and India, in developing their own versions of the drug.

site_title: COE supply to dip by 1.3% in February-to-April quota
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced a 1.3% decrease in the supply of certificates of entitlement (COE) for the next three months, from February to April, with a total of 10,452 COEs available across five categories. This is slightly lower than the November-to-January quota. COE premiums are expected to remain stable, with no significant changes anticipated in the next three months. The LTA will release the May to July quota in April, and industry players attribute the decrease to a stable deregistration rate and weak market conditions.

site_title: Oil's bull run rolls on despite possible China reserves release
summary: Oil prices rose to a 2-1/2-month high on Friday, driven by supply constraints and geopolitical tensions. Brent crude futures gained 1.9% to $86.06 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2.1% to $83.82 per barrel. The market's boost is attributed to a tight global supply-demand situation, as well as concerns over a potential Russian attack on Ukraine. China's planned release of oil reserves around Chinese New Year is expected to reduce global prices, but analysts forecast oil prices to reach $100 per barrel this year due to capacity constraints among OPEC+ countries.

site_title: Citigroup profit drops on higher expenses, consumer banking weakness
summary: Citigroup reported a 26% drop in fourth-quarter profit to $3.2 billion, driven by higher expenses and weakness in its consumer banking unit. The bank's shares fell 3.5% due to the decline. Citigroup incurred higher costs to fix regulatory issues and is shedding non-US consumer businesses as part of a strategy refresh. The bank earned $1.99 per share, below analysts' expectations of $1.38. Revenue from investment banking rose 43% in the quarter.

site_title: SPACs as a game changer for South-east Asian businesses
summary: South-east Asian businesses are capitalizing on the growth of Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) as a game-changer for their growth. In 2021, the region's unicorns such as Grab and GoTo went public or announced plans to list via SPACs, raising over US$358 billion in acquisitions. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has welcomed SPAC listings, offering a pathway to growth for upcoming tech players. The region has seen significant interest from global investors and regional funds, with over 1,200 PE/VC investments in the technology sector, and 42 unicorns in the region, many of which are looking for listings in the US or South-east Asia.

site_title: Europe: Shares close lower as policy tightening fears rise
summary: European shares fell 1% on Friday as hawkish remarks from the European Central Bank fueled concerns over tighter policy and inflation. The Stoxx 600 marked its worst week since late November. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated the bank is prepared to take measures to bring inflation down to its 2% target, driving up bets on a rate hike this year.

site_title: An eye for an iX3
summary: The BMW iX3 is a more affordable and practical electric car option, priced at S$276,888, compared to its petrol-fueled counterpart, the X3 xDrive30i. The iX3 offers impressive performance, with a 286 horsepower motor, quiet ride, and comfortable cabin. It also comes with tax incentives, including a S$25,000 low emissions rebate and S$20,000 for battery costs. With a range of up to 460km and a 0-100km/h time of 6.8 seconds, the iX3 is a well-rounded car that may encourage those to consider making the switch to electric power.

site_title: Whatever happened to soft power?
summary: Soft power, the ability to influence others through attraction rather than coercion, remains a significant component of world politics. Despite its slow and indirect effects, soft power is not a strategic mistake to ignore. China's efforts to develop its soft power have been met with limited success, as its heavy-handed use of hard power has damaged its reputation. The US, too, has experienced a decline in soft power during certain periods, but its private sources of soft power, such as Hollywood and charitable organizations, continue to be influential. The concept of soft power, which originated in the 1990s, has evolved to encompass culture, politics, and policies, and its importance will likely endure in international relations.

site_title: Macau to limit new casino licences to 10 years
summary: Macau has proposed limiting new casino licenses to 10 years, half the length of previous concessions, as part of a bid to tighten regulation of the world's biggest casino hub. The proposal, which will remain at six concessions, aims to ensure gaming does not undermine China's national security. The new rules are part of efforts to diversify the gaming sector, which has been hit by the pandemic and strict regulations under Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: US retail sales plunge in December
summary: US retail sales dropped 1.9% in December, beating economists' expectations of no change, as Americans struggled with Covid-19 shortages and supply chain bottlenecks. The decline was attributed to early holiday shopping in October, which impacted December sales. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and other items, fell 3.1% and are expected to weaken further in January due to rising Covid-19 infections. Despite the decline, economists expect strong economic growth in the fourth quarter, with annualized rates topping 7.0%.

site_title: SG Cyber Talent Development Fund to launch this month: MCI Minister Josephine Teo
summary: The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) will launch the SG Cyber Talent Development Fund this month to grow the cybertalent pipeline. Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo announced the fund's launch at the 4th Cybersecurity Awards Ceremony, aiming to support initiatives that enhance the cybersecurity ecosystem. The fund will support communities and organizations in developing skills, creating training, and job placements. The launch comes after the vulnerability issue in the Apache Java logging library Log4j, highlighting the need for a well-oiled cybersecurity system to respond quickly to cyberattacks.

site_title: Omicron to hit US growth in early 2022, inflation seen higher
summary: The US economy is expected to experience a short-term hit from the Omicron variant of coronavirus, with forecasters predicting a 3% growth rate for the January-March period, down from 3.9% previously. Inflation is also expected to rise, with prolonged supply chain issues exacerbated by Omicron. Despite this, economists remain relatively upbeat about growth in subsequent quarters, with a median forecast of 3.8% for the year. The damage is expected to be short-lived, with activity expected to trough in early February and rebound by March.

site_title: PSA International handles record container volumes of 91.5 million TEUs globally in 2021
summary: PSA International handled a record 91.5 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) globally in 2021, a 5.6% increase from 2020. Its flagship PSA Singapore contributed 37.2 million TEUs, while terminals outside Singapore handled 54.3 million TEUs, retaining Singapore's position as the world's busiest container transhipment port.

site_title: SCCCI elects Lian Huat executive chairman as president, 3 others as vice-presidents
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) has elected Lian Huat Group's executive chairman Kho Choon Keng as its new president, with 3 vice-presidents appointed: Ng Siew Quan, Lee Sze Leong, and Lim Hock Chee. Kho's 3-year term follows that of Tat Hong CEO Roland Ng, who previously held the position. The election was held in three stages last year, with 56 council members appointed, including 10 first-time appointees.

site_title: US: Wall St slides at open after mixed results from big banks
summary: Wall Street's main indexes slid at the open on Friday, with the Dow Jones falling 117.19 points or 0.32% to 35,996.43. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower, with the S&P 500 down 21.04 points or 0.45% and the Nasdaq Composite down 98.79 points or 0.67%. The decline came after mixed results from major banks JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup, which kicked off the fourth-quarter earnings season.

site_title: BlackRock hits record US$10t in assets, powered by ETFs
summary: BlackRock has reached a record US$10 trillion in assets, driven by a surge in fourth-quarter flows into its exchange-traded funds (ETFs). The firm saw a net US$104 billion in ETF inflows, the highest since 2015, and a net US$169 billion in long-term investment vehicles. This growth reinforces BlackRock's position as the world's largest asset manager, with assets under management rebounding after a dip in the third quarter. The results come ahead of CEO Larry Fink's annual letter, outlining priorities on issues like boardroom diversity and climate change.

images.alt_text: Investors poured a net US$104 billion into ETFs in the three months ended Dec 31.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase Q4 profits dip on higher costs
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a 14% dip in Q4 profits to $10.4 billion, largely due to higher costs. Despite this, the bank saw increased investment banking fees and a rise in overall lending activity. CEO Jamie Dimon cited "exceptionally low" charge-offs as a sign of a solid economy, despite headwinds from the Omicron variant and inflation. Dimon remained optimistic on US economic growth, citing upbeat business sentiment and job growth.

site_title: China tightens screws on big money market funds
summary: China's securities regulator published draft rules to strengthen supervision over major money market funds, targeting those with over $31.49 billion in net assets or 50 million investors. The new rules aim to protect investors' interests and improve fund managers' risk-management ability. Major money market funds, including China's largest Yu'e Bao, controlled by Ant Group, will be required to set aside 40% of management fees as risk reserves, implement more stringent risk control measures, and conduct stress tests more frequently. The rules are seen as a further step to rein in Ant Group's Yu'e Bao.

images.alt_text: China's securities regulator published draft rules on Friday to strengthen supervision over major money market funds, a step that could further rein in Ant Group's Yu'e Bao.

site_title: Japan team carries out world-first spinal cord stem cell trial
summary: A Japanese university has successfully transplanted stem cells into a patient with a spinal cord injury, marking the world's first clinical trial of its kind. The trial, conducted by Tokyo's Keio University, used induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells to treat paralysis caused by serious spinal cord injuries, affecting over 100,000 people in Japan. The initial stage of the study aims to confirm the safety of the transplant method, with the patient to be monitored for up to three months to decide whether the study can safely continue and others can receive transplants.

site_title: Private residential market to start slow in 2022, fewer upcoming launches: analysts
summary: The private residential market in Singapore is expected to start 2022 slowly, with developers waiting until after Chinese New Year to market properties. This seasonal lull gives developers a chance to assess the recent property cooling measures and make decisions. Despite the cooling measures, developers are not expected to make major announcements, such as launch delays or price cuts. Analysts predict around 43 private residential launches with over 5,500 units this year, with notable projects like Belgravia Ace and The Arden scheduled for launches in 2022.

site_title: UK government apologises to Queen for parties on eve of Prince Philip's funeral
summary: The UK government has apologized to Queen Elizabeth for parties held by Prime Minister Boris Johnson's staff on the eve of Prince Philip's funeral in April 2021, despite coronavirus restrictions. The parties, which included music and alcohol, were held in Downing Street while the Queen mourned her husband's passing alone. Johnson has apologized in Parliament for attending similar events in May 2020, but the latest scandal has sparked widespread outrage and calls for his resignation, with 15% of Conservative MPs needed to trigger an internal leadership contest.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson's staff broke coronavirus restrictions by partying on the eve of Prince Philip's funeral.

site_title: NeraTel receives bills of demand relating to tax liabilities of S$3.62m
summary: NeraTel, a Singapore-based IT infrastructure provider, has received bills of demand totaling S$3.62 million in tax liabilities from its foreign subsidiaries. The tax liabilities stem from a 2021 tax audit and are expected to have a material financial impact on the company. NeraTel is seeking tax advisers' opinions and engaging in negotiations with tax authorities to determine the final amount. Despite the announcement, the company's shares closed 2.4% higher at S$0.128.

site_title: Ant-backed Akulaku mulls SPAC merger at US$2b value
summary: Akulaku, an Indonesian online lender backed by Ant Group, is considering a US listing via a merger with a blank-cheque company, potentially valuing the combined entity at $2 billion. The fintech startup is in talks with Catcha Investment, a special purpose acquisition company, and is seeking $200-300 million in private funding. This deal would join a growing list of Southeast Asian companies going public in the US via SPAC mergers. Akulaku offers digital banking, consumer credit, and other services in Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, and the Philippines, with expected annual revenue of $619 million in 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: UOB acquired Citi's consumer units in 4 Asean markets for approximately S$5b, doubling its retail base to 5.3m. Singapore's agri-tech sector is expected to add 4,700 jobs by 2030. The High Court dismissed Ng Yu Zhi's appeal to halt a civil suit against him. Business leaders expressed concerns over the rising cost of manpower and difficulties in attracting talent. Singapore's vehicle sales are expected to boost in the next 4-5 years, according to Fitch Solutions. The Straits Times Index rose 0.76% today, pushing through its 2021 high.

site_title: Chinese developer R&F downgraded to restricted default by Fitch
summary: Chinese developer Guangzhou R&F Properties has been downgraded to restricted default by Fitch Ratings after a distressed debt exchange. The company bought back 16% of a $725 million bond, extending the rest by six months. This move was necessary to avoid a default, highlighting the company's liquidity shortage. R&F's concerns are part of a broader issue with Chinese developers facing prohibitively high borrowing costs, shutting them out of the overseas credit market and adding to property sector stress. Fitch's downgrade follows a similar move by S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: SMF calls for government support in sustainability practices
summary: The Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) has submitted a wish list to the Ministry of Finance, calling for government support in adopting sustainable practices. The federation suggests more funding for firms to install solar panels, source sustainable materials, and adopt technologies. They also request a longer grace period before enforcing regulatory practices and funding workforce development efforts to attract and retain employees. Additionally, SMF requests support for employers of foreign workers, such as tax relief or reimbursement of levies, to help offset rising costs amidst the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Lian Beng H1 net profit declines 15.5%, top line up about 100%
summary: Lian Beng Group's net profit declined 15.5% to S$14.9 million for the half year ending November 2022, despite an almost 100% increase in revenue to S$377.3 million. The surge in cost of sales and operating expenses, along with reduced government handouts, contributed to the decline. Construction segment revenue rose 98.7% to S$310.1 million, while property development and investment holding segments also saw increases. The group expects construction sector operating conditions to remain difficult in the year ahead due to manpower shortages and deployment challenges.

site_title: SICC dismisses lender's claim for US$24m in Zenrock fraud case
summary: The Singapore International Commercial Court (SICC) has dismissed a claim by Credit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank's (CACIB) Singapore branch for US$24 million in a Zenrock fraud case. The court ruled that PPT Energy Trading was not a participant in Zenrock's fraudulent scheme, despite being offered a prestructured deal similar to those in which it had successfully participated in the past. PPT Energy is entitled to retain the sum, and CACIB's claims for an injunction, declaration, and reimbursement are also dismissed.

site_title: European power prices soar on setbacks at French nuclear giant
summary: European power prices surged after Electricite de France (EDF) revised down its nuclear production forecast by 8%, citing defects at reactors vital to the European energy supply. This comes amid an historic energy crisis, with natural gas stocks at their lowest in over a decade. The German February contract rose 22% and the French April-June contract rose 24%. At least nine reactors will be offline at the start of April, cutting almost a fifth of total output, and EDF now expects to generate 300-330 terawatt-hours this year, down from an earlier estimate.

site_title: Expected growth cycle to boost Singapore vehicle sales in next 4-5 years: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's vehicle sales volumes are expected to experience a "strong boost" over the next 4-5 years due to an anticipated growth cycle, according to Fitch Solutions Country Risk & Industry Research. The country ranks first in Asia and seventh globally with a high risk-reward indicator score of 77.3, driven by low political risk and a stable car retail environment. Asia as a region is expected to remain a key growth area for automakers, with large markets in China, India, and Japan, and a favorable industry environment due to expanding free trade agreements and strong demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Djokovic saga aside, a fortnight of intense tennis awaits in Melbourne
summary: The 2022 Australian Open begins on Monday, Jan 17, in Melbourne, with Novak Djokovic's visa cancellation overshadowing the event. Despite Djokovic's absence, top contenders Nadal and Medvedev lead the men's field, while Barty and Muguruza top the women's charge. Djokovic was initially detained for 5 days before being deported, while Roger Federer, a 6-time Australian Open champion, will not participate due to a knee injury. The tournament promises to be intense, with Nadal seeking a record-breaking second Australian Open title and Barty aiming to win her first Grand Slam on home turf.

site_title: Lack of 'board-ready' women talents: perception or reality?
summary: Singapore-listed companies have a significant underrepresentation of women on their boards, with only 13% of positions filled by women, despite a target of 20% by 2020. Research suggests that the lack of qualified women candidates is not a reality, but rather a result of limited recruitment efforts, with 88% of board appointments sourced from personal/major shareholders' networks. To address this issue, boards must set clear goals and qualification criteria, and adopt a more open-minded approach to recruitment.

site_title: STI bucks regional losses, advances 0.76%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 24.67 points or 0.76% to 3,281.97, defying regional losses, on Friday. The index has advanced 76.71 points or 2.4% week-on-week. Key banks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB have driven the gains, with their shares up 9.9%, 8.2%, and 11.3% respectively since Dec 31. The focus now shifts to the earnings season, with investors watching inflationary pressures on firms' margins and growth outlook.

site_title: Japan PM sees no need to change budget balancing target for now
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida stated there's no need to change the country's primary budget balancing target by fiscal year 2025. However, the government may review the fiscal situation due to economic uncertainty. Kishida made this statement during a meeting with his top economic advisory council.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls as tepid Wall Street finish, Omicron woes weigh
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 1.28% to 28,124.28, tracking a weak Wall Street finish and concerns over Omicron's impact on risk appetite. Technology heavyweights led the losses. The Topix index also declined 1.39% to 1,977.66, reaching a near 4-week low.

site_title: Philippines keeps curbs, eases travel rules amid Covid-19 spike
summary: The Philippines will maintain movement restrictions in Metro Manila until January 31, with outdoor restaurants operating at half capacity and indoor businesses at 30% capacity, amid record-high daily Covid-19 infections and positive test rates.

site_title: High Court dismisses Ng Yu Zhi's appeal to halt civil suit against him, Envy Global Trading
summary: The High Court of Singapore has dismissed Ng Yu Zhi's appeal to halt a civil suit against him and Envy Global Trading, which he faces over an alleged US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. Ng, 34, had argued that proceeding with the civil suit would prejudice his criminal case, citing his right of silence and privilege against self-incrimination. However, High Court Judge Ang Cheng Hock ruled that Ng must show a real danger that the civil action would result in injustice in the criminal proceedings, which Ng failed to demonstrate.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi at the State Courts on June 28, 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong suspends transit flights from most of the world due to Covid-19
summary: Hong Kong has suspended transit flights from around 150 high-risk countries and territories for a month due to the Omicron variant. The move comes after two aircrew members of Cathay Pacific Airways were linked to an outbreak. The city had previously gone three months without local transmissions. The suspension affects flights from countries with high case numbers, deepening Hong Kong's isolation.

site_title: Manpower shortage a key concern raised by business leaders at pre-Budget roundtable
summary: Singapore business leaders expressed concern over a manpower shortage, citing staff attrition and foreign worker restrictions as top issues. A survey by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants found 31% of respondents ranked rising labour wage costs as a concern. The shortage is seen as a key issue ahead of the upcoming Budget 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a negative note, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.19% to 24,383.32, following a sell-off across Asia. The decline was fueled by concerns over the Federal Reserve's plans to tighten monetary policy. Other Asian markets, such as the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index, also declined.

site_title: Hitachi to sell about 50% stake in construction unit for US$1.6b
summary: Hitachi plans to sell approximately 50% of its stake in Hitachi Construction to Itochu for US$1.6 billion, with the sale valued at 3,300 yen (S$39) per share. This marks the final tranche of Hitachi's decade-long business portfolio overhaul, following the sale of Hitachi Kokusai Electric and Hitachi Chemical.

site_title: Malaysia concerned about Cambodian leader's Myanmar trip
summary: Malaysia's foreign minister has expressed concerns over Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen's visit to Myanmar, citing regional tensions and potential legitimization of the junta. Hun Sen, who holds Asean's rotating chair, made the first trip by a foreign leader to Myanmar since the coup last year. Critics argue the visit undermines efforts to isolate the generals. Malaysia is concerned about the implications of this move on the region's response to the crisis.

site_title: 'Massive' cyberattack hits Ukraine government websites
summary: A massive cyberattack hit key Ukrainian government websites, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the education ministry, leaving them temporarily offline. The attack, which targeted the Cabinet and emergencies ministry websites, was attributed to a "global (cyber) attack" with no immediate claim of responsibility. Ukraine had previously blamed Russians with links to the Kremlin for previous attacks. The attack comes amid rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine's Western allies, with Russia denying plans to invade Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The sweeping cyberattack came against the backdrop of rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine's Western allies.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues Trade with Caution alert on Memiontec Holdings
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has issued a Trade with Caution alert on Memiontec Holdings due to unusual price spikes. A group of accounts accounted for 33.7% of buy volume in Memiontec shares between August and January 2022, with most trades among themselves. This led to a 300% surge in share price, outperforming the Straits Times Index. SGX RegCo has referred the matter to authorities for necessary actions, urging investors to exercise caution when dealing in Memiontec shares.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Regulation has issued a Trade with Caution alert on shares of Memiontec Holdings and urges the investing community to exercise caution when dealing in the counter.

site_title: Citi establishes clearing and settlement service for Beijing Stock Exchange
summary: Citigroup has established clearing and settlement services for the Beijing Stock Exchange and the city's New Third Board, enabling foreign investment in China's onshore markets through the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investors (QFII) scheme. This move supports settlement and clearing activity for the launch of the Beijing Stock Exchange, as stated by Citi China's CEO Christine Lam, reiterating the bank's support and confidence in the China market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: European stocks slid at the open on Friday due to concerns over decades-high inflation, following heavy losses in Asia and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.4% to 7,534.83 points, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices declined 0.7% and 0.9% respectively.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble 1% as tech stocks track Nasdaq peers lower
summary: Australia's shares dropped 1% on Friday, led by tech and software firms, following hawkish remarks from US Federal Reserve officials about interest rate hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 7,393.90, its lowest level in 7 months. Tech stocks plummeted 4% and financials fell 1% for the week. Analysts expect interest rate hikes to continue to affect tech sectors, with banks also under pressure.

site_title: China rare-earth firm slumps 17% in Hong Kong trading debut
summary: China's JL MAG Rare-Earth Co slumped 17% in its Hong Kong trading debut after being sold at the bottom of its marketed range, with shares reaching HK$28. The company's IPO raised HK$4.24 billion (S$731.6 million), the largest offering so far this year in Hong Kong. This marks a slow start to 2022, contrasting with a busy 2021, when 16 companies priced near US$8 billion worth of shares.

site_title: China GDP growth to slow, boosting case for rate cut
summary: China's economy is expected to post its weakest growth in over a year, with a probable 3.3% expansion in the fourth quarter of 2021, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. The slowdown is attributed to a deepening property market slump and disruptions from virus outbreaks. This may lead to speculation of monetary stimulus, including a possible interest-rate cut, which could boost economic growth. The People's Bank of China is set to announce a benchmark rate on Monday, with most economists predicting no change.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials nod to March rate hike as inflation drumbeat grows louder
summary: Federal Reserve officials, including Governor Lael Brainard, have signaled a March interest rate hike to combat inflation, which rose 7% in December, the fastest pace in nearly 40 years. The Fed has projected several rate hikes this year, and officials are considering shrinking its massive balance sheet. Chicago Fed President Charles Evans predicted a 25-basis-point increase in March, while Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker and San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly also flagged a rate hike. The Fed's policy meeting on January 25-26 will lay further groundwork for the potential rate increase.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post biggest drop in nearly 4 weeks as rate hike saps risk appetite
summary: South Korean stocks experienced their largest drop in nearly four weeks, with the Kospi index closing down 1.36% at 2,921.92. The decline was driven by tech stocks following the Nasdaq's 2.5% drop and a rate hike by the central bank to 1.25%, aiming to stem inflation risks. Foreigners sold net US$207.55 million worth of Kospi shares. This marks the fourth straight week of declines for the index.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies have an inequality problem: A growing wealth gap
summary: Cryptocurrencies have been criticized for widening the wealth gap due to a small number of individuals and institutions controlling a large portion of the market. A recent study by the National Bureau of Economic Research found that the top 10,000 Bitcoin investors hold 5 million Bitcoins, over a quarter of the total in circulation. This concentration of wealth and power threatens the integrity of the blockchain and undermines the decentralized nature of cryptocurrencies. Experts warn that this concentration of wealth and power could lead to a 51% attack on the blockchain, compromising its security.

site_title: Australian town hits record high temperature of 50.7 deg C
summary: A remote Australian town, Onslow, has reached a record high temperature of 50.7°C, tying the country's hottest day on record set 62 years ago. This extreme heat is expected to become more frequent due to global warming, according to the Climate Council. The country's research director, Dr. Martin Rice, warned that without a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, such record temperatures could become commonplace, with 50-degree summer days predicted in major cities like Sydney and Melbourne by 2030.

site_title: Alibaba's grocery chain Freshippo considers funding at US$10b value
summary: Alibaba's grocery chain Freshippo is considering a $10 billion funding round, with potential investors invited to join an exclusive list. The move could lead to a potential spin-off of the chain as a separate business, unlocking value in the brand. Freshippo, known as Hema in Chinese, is working with an adviser to secure funding, which is expected to kick off next month.

site_title: Offshore and marine could see cyclical upturn in near term, says UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian has retained its "overweight" call on Singapore's offshore and marine sector, citing a cyclical upturn in the near term. The firm attributes this to higher offshore activity driven by oil prices exceeding US$80 a barrel in 2021, and expected demand for production assets with "meaningful upsides" in the next few years. Offshore oil utilization now exceeds pre-Covid-19 highs, leading to firmer day rates and incentivizing rig owners to place new orders. This is expected to result in a cyclical upturn in the sector.

site_title: North Korea fires at least 2 ballistic missiles, its third test in two weeks
summary: North Korea fired at least two ballistic missiles on Friday, its third test in two weeks, amid criticism of US sanctions. The missiles landed in the sea outside Japan's exclusive economic zone. The incident follows two recent tests of a new hypersonic missile system designed to evade US-operated interceptors. North Korea claims the tests are part of its "legitimate right" to enhance self-defence, while Japan's chief cabinet secretary described the launches as a threat to regional safety.

site_title: Dollar extends losses on US inflation data, euro rallies
summary: The US dollar fell to 2-month lows against a basket of rival currencies after weaker-than-expected US inflation data, with the euro rising to a 1.1479 high. Despite this, investors see little impact on the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 94.782, while sterling and the yen also gained ground. Other currencies, such as the New Zealand and Australian dollars, also rose, driven by improving market sentiment and rising oil prices.

site_title: China agrees with US on oil reserves release near Chinese New Year
summary: China agreed with the US to release crude oil from its national strategic stockpiles around the Chinese New Year holidays, starting on February 1, as part of a US-initiated plan to reduce global prices. The release amount will depend on oil price levels, with a larger volume released if oil prices are above $85 a barrel and a smaller volume if prices are near $75 a barrel. This agreement follows a series of discussions between the US and major oil consumers, including Japan, South Korea, and India, to address global oil price pressures.

site_title: Shares of Chinese frozen food firms jump as Covid derails Chinese New Year
summary: Shares of Chinese frozen food firms surged as Covid-19 cases increased, making home-cooked meals a safer bet during the Lunar New Year holiday. Frozen food processors Zhanjiang Guolian Aquatic Products and Haixin Foods rose 20% and 10% respectively, while Jinling Hotel jumped 36%. This rare bright spot comes as China reported 143 new local Covid-19 cases and local governments advised against traveling. In contrast, consumer staples shares, such as those making liquor baijiu, declined, with the CSI consumer staples index down 3.8% this week.

site_title: China's exports and imports grow more slowly in December
summary: China's exports grew 20.9% year-on-year in December, slightly above expectations, while imports rose 19.5% year-on-year, missing forecasts. The country reported a trade surplus of $94.46 billion in December, down from a $71.72 billion surplus in November. China's economy is showing signs of slowing, with a property downturn and strict Covid-19 curbs posing headwinds. The government plans to roll out policies to help exporters and ease international logistics problems, citing a meeting of the State Council. Growth is expected to slow in 2022.

site_title: Singapore's agri-tech sector will add 4,700 jobs by 2030; new scheme launched to retrain mid-career workers for industry
summary: Singapore's agri-tech sector is expected to create approximately 4,700 jobs by 2030, with 70% of roles going to professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) or skilled laborers. A new career conversion program will support 100 job seekers in transitioning to agri-tech over the next two years, with potential for more participants if demand is high. The sector currently employs around 2,000 people, with the government aiming to strengthen food security by growing local production capabilities and creating a high-tech, productive, and resource-efficient agri-food sector.

site_title: Australia cancels Djokovic's visa citing health risk to community
summary: Australia has cancelled Novak Djokovic's visa for a second time, citing a health risk to the community, effectively ending his bid for a record 21st Grand Slam title at the Australian Open. The decision was made by Immigration Minister Alex Hawke, who used discretionary powers to revoke the visa, with Djokovic facing a three-year ban from entering Australia. The move has intensified a global debate over the rights of the unvaccinated and has sparked controversy over the government's handling of the situation.

images.alt_text: The decision to again cancel his visa over Covid-19 entry regulations raises the prospect of a possible second court battle by the Serbian tennis star to be allowed to stay and play in the Open starting Monday.

site_title: South Korea to submit supplementary budget this month
summary: South Korea's prime minister announced plans to submit a supplementary budget in January to support small firms and self-employed individuals, utilizing excess tax generated last year and available financial resources. The move comes a month after the parliament approved a record 607.7 trillion won budget for this year.

site_title: South Korea extends distancing curbs ahead of holidays, Omicron wave
summary: South Korea is extending social distancing rules for three more weeks ahead of the Lunar New Year holidays due to concerns over a looming Omicron wave. The curbs, which include a 9 pm curfew for restaurants and bars, will last until February 6. Health officials warn that without stricter measures, Omicron could become dominant, potentially leading to daily tallies of 20,000 in February and 30,000 in March. The decision comes as South Korea has seen a surge in Omicron infections, with 20% of domestically transmitted cases now attributed to the variant.

site_title: Supermarket shelves go bare as Omicron disrupts US
summary: The Omicron variant of Covid-19 is causing empty supermarket shelves across the US, as supply chains are disrupted by employees being out sick or quarantined. This has led to shortages of perishable goods like fresh produce, and grocery stores are adapting by restocking shelves and limiting quantities of in-demand items. Experts warn that shortages could persist until March, with critical industries like grocery and food facing strain due to labor challenges. The National Grocers Association reports that some businesses operated at half capacity during the outbreak.

site_title: Tiger Woods-backed SPAC files to seek sports and health targets
summary: Tiger Woods-backed Sports & Health Tech Acquisition Corp. has filed to raise $150 million in an initial public offering. The blank-check company, which has an enterprise value of $600-1 billion, plans to seek a merger target in the sports or health technology sectors. Woods, a professional golfer, is the lead investor and chairman of the company, alongside other executives including tennis star Caroline Wozniacki and former NBA player David Lee. The company aims to list its units on the Nasdaq Global Market under the symbol LDSPU, with RBC Capital Markets acting as the sole bookrunner.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS starts Digital Core Reit at 'buy' with US$1.40 target
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Digital Core Reit (DC Reit) with a "buy" call and a target price of US$1.40, citing the Reit's benefits from the digital economy, stable earnings, and ample headroom for portfolio growth. The target price offers a 19% upside to the Reit's last closing price. DBS expects a 3-year distribution per unit compound annual growth rate of about 7% and 10-11% above initial public offering forecasts, driven by debt-funded and equity-funded acquisitions.

site_title: New York apartment sells for US$190m
summary: A New York apartment, located at 220 Central Park South, has been sold for US$190 million, making it one of the priciest sales in the city's real estate history. The 900 sqm four-bedroom penthouse was previously purchased by American billionaire Daniel Och for US$93 million two years ago. Och, 61, has a net worth estimated at US$4.1 billion, and the buyer remains anonymous. This sale follows a record-breaking US$238 million purchase by American hedge fund manager Ken Griffin in 2019 for a private home in the United States.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.39 points or 0.53% to 1,561.12. The market saw 262 losers and 69 gainers, with a total trading volume of 173.98 million lots worth RM86 million.

site_title: Biden nominates historically diverse slate to Federal Reserve Board
summary: US President Joe Biden has nominated a historically diverse slate to the Federal Reserve Board, including former Governor Sarah Bloom Raskin and two Black economists, Lisa Cook and Philip Jefferson. This would represent the most diverse top leadership in the Fed's 108-year history, with four women and a significant increase in racial representation. The appointments aim to prioritize the independence of the Fed and combat inflation, with the Senate expected to consider the nominations soon.

site_title: For Boris Johnson, the party really may be over this time
summary: Boris Johnson's leadership is under threat as the UK's Conservative Party grapples with his "bring your own bottle" party scandal. Allies are losing patience with his carelessness and irreverence, which has led to a series of unforced errors. Johnson has delivered a humiliating apology in Prime Minister's Questions, buying himself some time but not alleviating the pressure. Major personnel changes in Downing Street are likely, and Johnson is not ready to give up the fight. His future as leader hangs in the balance, with some Tories wondering if the party's only options are a surgical strike or a lingering death.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after US losses
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Friday due to US tech shares diving on interest rate expectations. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.48% to 28,067.44 and the Topix index lost 1.36% to 1,978.25.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares sharply down at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.00% to 24,185.86, amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on inflation. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also dropped, with the Shanghai Index easing 0.31% and the Shenzhen Index slipping 0.51%. The losses follow a week of volatility in global markets, with investors reacting to the Fed's interest rate expectations and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hot stock: UOB up 1.4% after Citi consumer business acquisition
summary: UOB's shares rose 1.4% after the bank announced its acquisition of Citigroup's consumer banking businesses in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam. The deal, valued at S$915 million plus the net asset value of Citi's consumer business, is expected to be immediately accretive to UOB's earnings per share. The acquisition is set to be completed between mid-2022 to early 2024, pending regulatory approvals.

site_title: Loss of animals impacting plants' ability to survive climate change: study
summary: A new study in the journal Science found that declines in seed-dispersing animal species are harming plants' ability to survive climate change. The study, led by Evan Fricke of Rice University, estimates that the ability of animal-dispersed plants to keep pace with climate change has already been reduced by 60% due to the loss of mammals and birds. The research highlights a worrying feedback loop between biodiversity loss and the global climate crisis, with forests vital for trapping carbon. Conservation efforts and restoring animal species can help fight climate change.

site_title: US: Tech stocks resume sell-off as stocks tumble
summary: US tech stocks resumed a sell-off on Thursday, leading to a decline in overall US equities. Investors adjusted their equity holdings amid expectations of higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve. Tech-rich Nasdaq dropped 2.5% and the Dow Jones shed 0.5%, while the S&P 500 tumbled 1.4%. The sell-off follows mixed economic data, including a 9.7% rise in US wholesale prices for the year and rising unemployment claims.

site_title: Getting into the spirit
summary: Jamie Koh, a 36-year-old entrepreneur, overcame obstacles to establish the Brass Lion Distillery in Singapore, a first-of-its-kind gin joint. After winning a competition to create an F&B concept in Clarke Quay, Koh traveled the world, gaining inspiration for her native-born gin brand. She enrolled in distillery school, apprenticed with a master distiller, and eventually opened the distillery in 2018. Despite facing challenges, including Covid-19, Koh persevered, expanding the business through virtual events and collaborations with other brands. Brass Lion produces about 200 bottles of craft gin per batch and has gained recognition for its unique gins and limited-edition blends.

site_title: Facebook faces £2.3b UK class action over market dominance
summary: Facebook faces a £2.3 billion class action in the UK over allegations of abusing its market dominance by exploiting 44 million users' personal data between 2015 and 2019. The lawsuit, brought by Liza Lovdahl Gormsen, alleges Facebook imposed unfair terms and conditions to collect valuable data. The case comes after Facebook lost an attempt to strike out an antitrust lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission. Lovdahl Gormsen claims Facebook built an "all-seeing picture" of internet usage, generating deep data profiles of users, and exploited their data for profit.

site_title: Australia: Shares set to snap third weekly gain on tech slump
summary: Australia's shares are set to snap a third weekly gain due to a tech slump, with the S&P/ASX 200 index losing 0.6% to 7432.70 points. Tech stocks fell 1.8% and index heavyweight Afterpay hit its lowest mark in seven months. The decline was attributed to a Wall Street sell-off, with the US Federal Reserve potentially raising interest rates as early as March. Fresh Covid-19 infections and weaker commodity prices also weighed on the market.

site_title: UOB snares Citi's consumer units in 4 Asean markets for almost S$5b, double retail base to 5.3m
summary: UOB has agreed to acquire Citi's consumer banking assets in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam for approximately S$5 billion. The deal will double UOB's retail base in the 4 markets, generating a 1.4 times income uplift and 1.2 times loan growth. UOB expects the deal to be immediately accretive to earnings, with a higher return on equity (ROE) and return on risk-weighted assets (RORWA) target of over 13% by 2026. The acquisition will also bring a significant increase in credit card business, with UOB's credit card business expected to double across Asean.

images.alt_text: UOB has agreed to acquire Citigroup's consumer banking businesses comprising its unsecured and secured lending portfolios, wealth management and retail deposit businesses in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam.

site_title: Scrap SMS use in wake of rising scams, banks urged
summary: Singapore's cybersecurity infrastructure is vulnerable to rising SMS-related banking scams, with banks expected to shoulder more liability for protecting customer accounts. Experts recommend scrapping SMS use for OTP generation or authentication, citing its decreasing security benefit. Instead, banks can use hardware or digital tokens, which are equally secure. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is working with banks to explore measures to mitigate scams, including a cooling-off period and enhanced fraud surveillance systems. Customers must remain vigilant and avoid clicking on suspicious links, with experts warning of the need for continuous updates to cybersecurity systems.

site_title: Tokyo residential, Sydney logistics properties are institutional investors' favourites for 2022
summary: Institutional investors are favoring the Asia-Pacific region for 2022, with Tokyo residential assets and industrial/logistics properties leading the pack. A survey of 99 respondents with $980 billion in assets under management found that Tokyo and Sydney are the top investment destinations, with Tokyo residential properties preferred by 64% of investors. Industrial and logistics properties have overtaken offices as the most preferred sector in the region. The survey also highlighted the growing importance of ESG considerations, with 68% of investors considering a net-zero commitment important and 86% paying close attention to environmentally and socially responsible investments.

site_title: In blow to Biden, US Supreme Court blocks vaccine mandate for businesses
summary: The US Supreme Court blocked President Biden's Covid-19 vaccination-or-testing mandate for employees of large businesses with 100 employees or more. The court allowed a vaccination mandate for health care workers at facilities receiving federal funding. The decision, made in a 6-3 vote, cited concerns over government overreach and the mandate's impact on employees' lives and health. Biden expressed disappointment and vowed to continue advocating for vaccination requirements, while Republicans welcomed the ruling as a victory against Biden's "disastrous mandates."

site_title: Republicans threaten boycott of US presidential debates
summary: The Republican National Committee (RNC) is threatening to boycott the US presidential debates unless the Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD) changes its rules. RNC chair Ronna McDaniel accused the CPD of "stonewalling" reforms to restore credibility and fairness. The RNC will consider alternative debates unless the CPD agrees to reforms, potentially altering the traditional debate format. The CPD maintains its commitment to fairness and neutrality.

site_title: UK police say no probe yet into parties at PM's house during Covid-19 lockdown
summary: British police won't investigate gatherings at PM Boris Johnson's residence during Covid-19 lockdowns unless an internal government inquiry finds evidence of potential criminal offenses. A senior official is conducting an inquiry into staff drinks during a May 2020 lockdown, with two other reported gatherings. Johnson faces calls to resign over his admission to attending the staff drinks. The police decision heaps pressure on Johnson, who already faces questions over his judgement and a dramatic slide in his Conservative Party's opinion poll ratings.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end flat as weak defensives outweigh tech, auto gains
summary: European stocks ended flat on Thursday, with defensive sectors like healthcare and personal goods falling 0.9% and 1.2%, respectively. Gains in automakers and technology stocks were limited by rising bond yields and concerns over inflation. European bank stocks rose 1.4% on the prospect of higher lending rates. The Stoxx 600 index closed largely unchanged at 486.05 points, with chipmakers and solar groups also making gains, while food ingredients maker Chr Hansen rose 6.7% after reporting quarterly revenue growth.

site_title: Blinken says North Korea launches may be seeking attention
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that North Korea's missile launches may be an attempt to draw attention, describing them as "destabilising" and "dangerous."
