MLT has a portfolio of 163 logistics assets with S$10.8 billion in assets under management, while MIT has a portfolio of 143 assets worth S$8.5 billion. Unitholders are set to vote on resolutions at an EGM on January 13.

site_title: Asean at take-off point towards economic integration: panel
summary: Asean is at a historic take-off point towards economic integration, according to a panel of former leaders from Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand. They emphasized the need for the 10 Asean member countries to integrate their economies and enhance intra-regional trade, amid global economic headwinds. This comes as the region faces disruptions from US-China tensions and the Covid-19 pandemic. The former leaders called for cooperation to overcome these challenges and capitalize on opportunities, positioning Asean for long-term growth and prosperity.

images.alt_text: Singapore's former foreign minister George Yeo (left) said Asean has the economic foundation to create a 600-million-strong consumer market. Malaysia's former deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim (right) noted that disruptions in global supply chains have forced the bloc to refocus on regional economic integration.

site_title: Singapore's carbon tax needs 'stronger price signal' amid decarbonisation push: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore's carbon tax needs a "stronger price signal" to steer the economy towards a low-carbon future, said Sustainability and the Environment Minister Grace Fu. The current S$5 per tonne tax is too low, and a more significant increase is needed to drive companies to decarbonize. Fu emphasized the need for a broad-based pricing across the economy while balancing administrative costs on businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. The government will consider global developments and industry experiences before deciding on the approach for mandatory climate-related financial disclosures.

site_title: When doing good resonates with the company's core business, it's win-win
summary: Three companies, Shiseido, Johnson & Johnson, and Xylem, have been recognized as Champions of Good for their impact in areas resonating with their core business. Shiseido's Shiseido Life Quality Centre provides beauty services to those with skin concerns, while Johnson & Johnson's Sight for Kids program provides eye health services to low-income schools. Xylem's Xylem Watermark program aims to raise awareness and access to clean water and sanitation solutions for millions. These initiatives demonstrate how businesses can create value beyond their products and services, and amplify their positive impact through strategic collaborations and employee volunteering.

site_title: Tunnelling works for Circle Line MRT extension completed
summary: Tunnelling works for the Circle Line MRT extension in Singapore have been completed, connecting the western and eastern ends of the orbital line. The 4km extension, which will make the Circle Line a complete loop, is expected to open in 2026, reducing travel time for commuters. The project, which started in 2019, marks 55% completion of civil works and includes 12 interchanges with other MRT lines, offering greater resilience to the network.

site_title: IMF chief warns of turbulence as nations withdraw stimulus
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warns of potential turbulence in the global economy this year due to slowing momentum, inflation risks, and supply-chain bottlenecks. Central banks face a delicate balancing act, and the spillover of monetary policy tightening on emerging markets could exacerbate economic divergence. The IMF is preparing for increased lending demands and may discuss a Resilience and Sustainability Trust to provide long-term funding for countries affected by the pandemic and climate crises.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Real estate investment platform RealVantage secured a capital markets services licence from MAS, allowing access to private equity real estate investments globally. Google launched professional certificates in Singapore, offering self-paced programs for IT, project management, data analytics, and user experience design. Property cooling measures may boost demand for rental housing. VC deals in Asia-Pacific reached $152 billion in the first 9 months of 2021, surpassing the 2018 record. The STI gained 0.3% amid a regional rally fueled by Powell remarks.

site_title: US consumer prices increase strongly in December
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.5% in December, the largest annual increase in nearly four decades, with a 7.0% year-on-year surge. This follows a 6.8% rise in November, driven by inflation and supply chain issues. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to start raising interest rates as early as March to combat inflation, which is above the 2% target. The labor market remains strong, with a 22-month low unemployment rate of 3.9% in December, but soaring Covid-19 cases could slow progress towards supply chain normalization.

site_title: Bitcoin climbs after inflation jump rekindles hedging debate
summary: Bitcoin surged above $44,000 for the first time in a week after the US inflation rate jumped 7% in 2021, its largest annual gain since 1982. The increase reignited debate about Bitcoin's potential as a hedge against inflation. Despite some analysts touting its benefits, others argue it's too new and behaves like a speculative asset. The cryptocurrency's price rise is seen as a reprieve for investors who had been watching prices slump due to the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance.

site_title: Thailand plans to impose tourist fee from April
summary: Thailand plans to impose a 300 baht (S$12.14) fee on foreign tourists starting April to develop attractions and cover accident insurance for foreigners who cannot afford costs themselves. The fee is part of the government's sustainable tourism plans and will be priced in with airline tickets. Thailand expects 5-15 million foreign arrivals this year, generating 800 billion Thai baht in revenue, with a forecast of 5-6 million arrivals by a leading business group. The fee aims to revive the tourism sector, which was badly hit by the pandemic-induced slump.

site_title: Startups raked in US$621b in 2021, shattering funding records
summary: Startups globally raised a record-breaking $621 billion in funding in 2021, more than doubling the previous year's total. The US accounted for about half of the world's funding, with Silicon Valley and New York retaining their top spots. However, cities like Philadelphia, Austin, and Miami saw significant growth in early-stage deal activity, with Philadelphia's startups representing 63% of total deals. The boom in remote work and ease of video calls have made it easier for founders to access funding, regardless of their location.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to build 14,000 km of railway, enact new investment law
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to build 14,000 km of railway, aiming to expand its rail network across the country. The country is also preparing a new investment law, which will be enacted this year to address the needs of domestic and international investors. The move comes as Saudi Arabia competes with Dubai for foreign investment, with the latter giving foreign firms until 2023 to set up headquarters or risk losing government contracts. The new investment law aims to boost foreign direct investment, which remains short of targets five years after Crown Prince Mohammed Salman launched Vision 2030.

images.alt_text: The Haramain high-speed railway in Saudi Arabia. The country will build another 14,000 km of railway that will criss-cross the kingdom.

site_title: Daily Covid-19 Omicron count in Singapore nearly doubles to 797 infections
summary: Singapore reported 797 new Covid-19 Omicron cases, nearly doubling the previous day's count. This brings the total to 882 new cases, with 513 local and 284 imported cases. The weekly infection growth rate decreased slightly to 1.60. There was one death, and 167 patients in hospital, with 13 requiring oxygen supplementation. As of Wednesday, Singapore has recorded 288,125 Covid-19 cases and 839 deaths, with 91% of the eligible population and 87% of the total population fully vaccinated.

site_title: What beckons for the crypto-economy in 2022
summary: Cryptocurrencies are expected to undergo significant changes in 2022, with stronger regulation by governments and central banks worldwide. This will include tighter "know-your-customer" requirements and anti-money laundering measures for exchanges. Additionally, decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs) are expected to mature, allowing for more social missions and public goods. China will also roll out its Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) ahead of the Winter Olympics, potentially influencing other countries to follow suit. The metaverse is expected to experience incremental gains, with debates over ethics, legal rules, and intellectual rights emerging.

site_title: Metro forms strategic tie-up with Daiwa House Industry for investments
summary: Metro Holdings has formed a strategic tie-up with Japanese real estate player Daiwa House Industry to deepen investment collaboration in various asset classes, primarily focusing on logistics, commercial, and housing facilities in Japan, Singapore, and the Asia-Pacific region. This follows Metro's S$41.3 million investment in Daiwa House Logistics Trust, and aims to enhance the group's diversified investment strategy and long-term growth prospects.

site_title: Tokyo, Osaka record most Covid-19 cases in 4 months as Omicron spreads
summary: Japan's Tokyo and Osaka recorded the highest Covid-19 cases in 4 months, with 2,198 and 1,711 new cases respectively, due to the spread of the Omicron variant. The country's daily cases are expected to exceed 10,000, the highest number since September 9. Japan has maintained strict border restrictions through February to slow the spread of Omicron. The Omicron variant has been detected in most regions, prompting the government to step up restrictions in areas hosting US military facilities.

site_title: Real estate investment platform RealVantage bags capital markets services licence from MAS
summary: Real estate investment platform RealVantage has obtained a capital markets services (CMS) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). This licence allows the company to provide Singapore-based retail investors with access to private equity real estate investments globally. The licence will enable RealVantage to pool capital and compete with big institutional investors, offering a wider range of investment options, including co-investment mandates and managed funds. RealVantage is the first digital fractional private equity real estate platform to receive the licence.

site_title: India said to seek US$203b insurer value in mega IPO
summary: India is pushing for a valuation of around $203 billion for the Life Insurance Corp of India (LIC) in its upcoming initial public offering (IPO), which could be the nation's largest. The valuation, estimated to be around 4 trillion rupees ($73.1 billion), would make LIC one of India's biggest companies, joining Reliance Industries and Tata Consultancy Services. The government seeks to raise $203 billion from the IPO, which is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to mop up cash and reduce the budget deficit.

site_title: 87 Singapore listcos account for S$62b of proposed audit adjustments in 2018-2020: Acra
summary: 87 Singapore-listed companies accounted for S$62.3 billion of proposed audit adjustments from 2018 to 2020, according to a study by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra). This represents about one-fifth of the 412 companies analyzed, with 22,051 audit adjustments totaling S$78.7 billion over the same period.

site_title: Asean startups shine with Asia-Pacific VC deals set to surpass US$152b record
summary: South-east Asian startups saw a record year for venture capital (VC) deals in 2021, with Asia-Pacific VC deals surpassing the US$152 billion record set in the US. The largest deal was Grab's US$40 billion merger with Altimeter Growth Corp. Notable deals include Flipkart's US$3.6 billion raise and Bukalapak's US$1.5 billion SPAC listing. VC exits in the first 9 months of 2021 totaled US$98 billion, with China accounting for 74%. Despite uncertainty in China, investors are eyeing India, Indonesia, and Vietnam.

site_title: China's inflation pressures ease, adding to rate cut calls
summary: China's inflation pressures eased in December, with the producer price index rising 10.3% and the consumer price index increasing 1.5%, lower than economists' expectations. This moderation gives policymakers scope to cut interest rates, potentially as early as next week, to cushion the economy's downturn. The central bank's pro-growth bias has shifted this year due to the property market slump and virus outbreaks.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to award bonus of over 20% to top performers
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to award bonuses of over 20% to top-performing staff, with those in equity underwriting and M&A advisory businesses expected to receive significant increases due to strong performances in 2021. Staff in these divisions anticipate bonuses up to 20% higher than the previous year, while those in other businesses may see flat or single-digit increases. The bonus payouts will be announced on Thursday and received in early February.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 2.79% to 24,402.17, driven by Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's comments on monetary policy. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, while global markets were boosted by Powell's comments.

site_title: UK's Johnson apologises for attending lockdown party
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson apologized for attending a "bring your own booze" party at his official residence during the first coronavirus lockdown in May 2020. Johnson admitted to the gathering, which was not publicly disclosed, and expressed regret for not following the rules. He said he would not pre-empt the findings of an independent inquiry into parties during lockdowns, but faced calls for his resignation from opposition leader Keir Starmer. Two opinion polls showed over half of respondents thought Johnson should resign, putting his survival in the balance.

site_title: Neil Road shophouse up for sale with S$16.2m guide price
summary: A 3-storey conservation shophouse at 51 Neil Road in Singapore's District 2 has been put up for sale with a guide price of S$16.2 million. The property occupies 1,883 sq ft of land and has an existing built-up area of approximately 6,000 sq ft. Its guide price reflects $2,700 per square foot, indicating a premium price for the conservation shophouse.

site_title: Omicron surge threatens to slow down Australia's economic recovery
summary: Australia's economic recovery is threatened by a surge in Omicron infections, leading to staff shortages and disruptions in supply chains. New South Wales reported its deadliest day of the pandemic, with Omicron infections scaring customers away from affected sectors. The Omicron surge is also affecting businesses, with workers out sick or isolated, and is seen as a major setback for the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall Street as Powell eases inflation fears
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday, driven by a strong Wall Street performance, as Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell eased inflation concerns by pledging to maintain a healthy economy recovery. Minutes from the December meeting revealed a hawkish stance by officials to speed up monetary tightening, including multiple interest rate hikes, but Powell's words reassured investors. The rally followed a torrid start to the year, with markets affected by hawkish Fed signals.

site_title: Fact-checkers urge YouTube to fight disinformation
summary: More than 80 fact-checking organizations have urged YouTube to combat disinformation, offering to help debunk false statements. In an open letter, the groups cited YouTube's failure to surface fact-checked information and promote authoritative content, despite investing in policies and products to address misinformation. YouTube has seen "important progress," but the groups argue that surfacing fact-checked information is more effective than deleting content.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on tech, resources boost; Afterpay jumps
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to 7,390.1, driven by gains in technology stocks and a 6.8% jump in Afterpay, following the approval of its $29 billion buyout by Block Inc. Strong commodity prices also supported resource-related shares.

site_title: North Korea says it tested hypersonic missile: state media
summary: North Korea tested a hypersonic missile, its second in less than a week, according to state media. The missile, carrying a hypersonic gliding vehicle, successfully hit a target 1,000 km off the coast. The test was overseen by leader Kim Jong Un, verifying the missile's superior maneuverability. The move is seen as a demonstration of North Korea's advanced military capabilities and a potential escalation of tensions in the region.

site_title: Sony is dealing with PlayStation 5 shortage by making more PS4s
summary: Sony will continue producing PlayStation 4 (PS4) consoles in 2022 to address the global supply chain disruptions limiting PS5 production. The move aims to add about a million PS4 units, offsetting pressure on PS5 production, and provide a budget-friendly alternative. This strategy will also give Sony more leverage when negotiating with manufacturing partners. The decision comes as the PS5 faces a shortage due to the coronavirus pandemic and increased demand for basic components.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.92% on Wednesday, following a 3-day losing streak on Wall Street, as investors bought growth shares. The Nikkei index rose to 28,765.66, and the Topix index to 2,019.36. This gain extends the US stock market's recent rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Gold flat as traders focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Wednesday as traders focused on US inflation data, despite Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's less hawkish comments. Spot gold was unchanged at $1,819.51 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.1%. Powell said the Fed aims to prevent entrenched inflation, indicating a potential shift towards higher interest rates. US inflation data, due later, is expected to show a 5.4% rise in core CPI, its highest in decades.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange's head of green finance Hui leaves firm
summary: Hong Kong Exchange's head of green finance, Grace Hui, left the firm after 20 months in the position, without a clear successor in place. Hui, a former UBS Group executive, played a key role in the exchange's push to boost sustainable investments. Her departure may slow development of a carbon market and a green bond retail market, as experts are scarce and highly sought after with premium pay. The exchange will now need to find a replacement, a process expected to take time.

site_title: STI gains 0.3% amid regional rally fuelled by Powell remarks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.61 points, or 0.27%, to 3,254.98, driven by a regional rally fueled by Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's remarks that the US economy's recovery is intact, but no indication of speeding up the tightening cycle. The gains were also boosted by a rally on Wall Street overnight. The STI has added over 125 points, or 4%, since the start of the year.

site_title: Take action against non-compliance with corporate governance code
summary: Singapore's corporate governance framework, established in 1998, has room for improvement. Despite the disclosure-based regime, smaller firms tend to fall short on adhering to the Code of Corporate Governance, particularly in remuneration disclosure. The government-appointed Corporate Finance Committee recommends swift and firm disciplinary action against non-compliant companies to raise the standard of disclosure, increase transparency, and provide remedies for enforcement. Currently, investigations often take years, and public censures are rare, undermining market trust and integrity.

site_title: Property cooling measures could increase demand for rental housing: analysts
summary: Singapore's rental market for Housing Board flats and condominium units recovered slightly in 2021, with 58,613 condo units rented out and 21,924 HDB flats rented. Despite recent property cooling measures, analysts believe the market will remain well-supported in 2022, with increased demand for rental housing driven by foreign arrivals and homebuyers selling existing properties. Rental rates are expected to continue to rise, with condo rents up 11.4% year-on-year and HDB rents up 10.4%.

site_title: Hong Kong to create more 'national security' crimes
summary: Hong Kong's leader announced the creation of new national security crimes, including sedition and inciting hatred, to be outlawed under the city's existing national security law. This move comes as the city's new "patriots only" legislature takes effect, replacing opposition lawmakers. The law will further empower authorities to crack down on dissent, transforming the international finance hub. The new crimes will be added to the existing list of four national security crimes: secession, subversion, terrorism, and colluding with foreign forces.

site_title: HSBC beefs up investments and wealth solutions team with Endowus, UBS hires
summary: HSBC has appointed Tan Wei Mei, former Endowus chief advisory officer, as global and Asia head of advisory, and Michael Wong, former UBS executive, as regional head of ultra-high net worth solutions group. Both roles are effective immediately, and report to Stefan Lecher, regional head of investments and wealth solutions for the Asia-Pacific. The appointments aim to leverage the duo's expertise to deliver at pace and provide best-in-class capabilities to serve the whole wealth continuum. HSBC is committed to providing actionable insights and solutions to its clients.

site_title: Hong Kong warns Covid-19 curbs on air cargo to hit goods supply
summary: Hong Kong is set to face significant disruptions to its air cargo supply due to tightened Covid-19 quarantine measures. The city's cargo traffic and import of goods are expected to drop, with Cathay Pacific Airways canceling most of its planned flights. Authorities have attributed the outbreak to two air crew members who broke self-isolation rules, prompting a 7-day hotel quarantine for returning crew and a 21-day hotel quarantine for most residents. The measures are expected to impact the supply of essential goods, including food, electronics, and medicine.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore's MAS and CAD are investigating online trading platform Samtrade FX for potential offences under the Securities and Futures Act. Three individuals have been arrested in connection with the probe. Meanwhile, Peter Kwee's new project, Nassim Quattro, aims at the super wealthy with a price point of S$6,000 psf. A crowdfund for badminton world champion Loh Kean Yew has raised over S$108,000 in two days. Aggrieved noteholders of the Laguna National golf club are launching a class-action suit against Peter Kwee.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on energy boost; Afterpay jumps
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.66% to 7,438.9. Energy stocks led gains, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos climbing 4.1% and 3.3%, respectively. Afterpay jumped 6.8% after the Bank of Spain approved its takeover by Block. Oil prices surged after the Federal Reserve chief signaled slower interest rate hikes, supporting oil demand. The highly anticipated US inflation data later this week will be key for investors.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS downgrades Econ Healthcare to 'hold' as S$4m share investment nosedives 84%
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Econ Healthcare to "hold" from "buy" and lowered its target price to S$0.28 due to a significant investment loss in Crosstec, a Hong Kong-listed interior design firm. Econ invested S$4 million in Crosstec, which plummeted 84% on Tuesday, resulting in a potential loss of over S$3.2 million. Analysts advise the company to reconsider its investment strategy and tighten its mandate, citing heightened uncertainty and risk in the company's financials.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post best day in 6 weeks on Powell remarks
summary: South Korea's Kospi index rose 1.54% to 2,972.48, its best day in 6 weeks, after US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's less-hawkish stance on inflation. The benchmark Kospi tracked overnight gains on Wall Street, while the Korean won strengthened and bond yields fell. Foreigners bought 452 billion won worth of shares, and the won reached its highest level in over a week. The Bank of Korea is expected to raise its policy rate to 1.25% at its meeting on Friday to restrain inflation and debt.

site_title: Maersk targets bigger and faster cuts in carbon emissions
summary: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's largest shipping line, is accelerating its plan to become carbon neutral by 2040, 10 years earlier than initially planned. The company aims to cut emissions by 50% for transported containers and 70% for port terminals by 2030. To meet the targets, Maersk will introduce green products, invest in natural climate solutions, and explore alternative fuels like methanol and ammonia. The company's carbon neutral goal now covers indirect emissions and its own emissions, with a focus on reducing its massive oil consumption, equivalent to a day's oil production.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Wednesday after US Federal Reserve Chair's remarks fell within expectations, lifting Wall Street. The Nikkei index rose 0.80% to 28,447.40 and the Topix index added 0.72% to 2,001.15.

site_title: Body-monitoring tech trend comes with concerns
summary: A trend of body-monitoring tech is emerging, with startups showcasing devices that track body temperature, respiration, and other vital signs. Companies like Circular Ring and Swiss Biospectal offer wearable technology that provides personalized health recommendations. However, experts warn that excessive tracking could lead to stress and addiction, raising concerns about the potential blurring of lines between well-being and obsession. The market is expected to grow, with CES forecasters predicting over $14 billion in spending on health-monitoring devices this year.

site_title: Google launches professional certificates in Singapore, forms employer consortium
summary: Google has launched professional certificates in Singapore, expanding its Skills Ignition SG programme. The certificates, available on Coursera, can be completed in 3-6 months and cover IT support, project management, data analytics, and user experience design. The programme aims to equip Singaporeans with in-demand digital skills, and Google will cover course fees for 5,000 scholarship recipients. Graduates will be connected with potential employers, and the programme has already seen 3,200 completions since its launch in 2020.

site_title: Japan service sector sentiment slightly improves in Dec as Covid-19 cases kept low
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose 0.1 point to 56.4 in December, marking the fourth straight month of increase, due to low domestic Covid-19 cases despite concerns over the new Omicron variant. This is based on a survey of workers in the economy, such as taxi drivers and hotel staff.

site_title: Indonesia rolls out booster shots, amid fears of Omicron spread
summary: Indonesia has launched its Covid-19 booster programme for the general public, prioritizing elderly and immunocompromised residents, amid a surge in Omicron cases. The country has seen over 4 million infections, and residents are hopeful the booster shots will improve their immunity.

images.alt_text: Elderly people wait at an observation area after receiving their Covid-19 booster vaccine injections during the kick off of the third dose of Covid-19 at a vaccination drive in Jakarta, Indonesia, 12 January 2022.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says inflation likely to gradually accelerate
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that Japan's consumer inflation is expected to gradually accelerate due to rising energy costs and a moderate economic recovery. The economy remains in a severe state due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Kuroda's comments come as the country's economy picks up as a trend.

site_title: China's annual auto sales climb for first time since 2017
summary: China's auto sales rose 3.8% in 2021, the first time since 2017, driven by a 157.5% growth in new energy vehicle (NEV) sales. NEV sales reached 3.52 million units, with December sales of 531,000 units, a 114% year-over-year increase. Industry expectations are for better production and sales in 2022, despite chip shortages and high raw material prices. China has also set plans to cut subsidies on NEVs by 30% in 2022 and withdraw them by the end of the year.

site_title: HSBC hires CIMB's Omar Siddiq as CEO of Malaysian unit
summary: HSBC has appointed Omar Siddiq, the head of CIMB Group's wholesale banking division and deputy CEO of CIMB's Malaysia business, as the CEO of its Malaysian unit. Siddiq will become the first Malaysian to lead the local HSBC unit, replacing Stuart Milne, who is retiring in March. Siddiq has been with CIMB for over 3 years, having previously worked at RHB Bank, Malaysia Airlines, and Khazanah Nasional. HSBC's Malaysian unit operates over 60 branches and employs 4,000 people, and will now be led by a Malaysian executive.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% at the open on Wednesday, driven by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's reassurance that the US central bank will tackle inflation to extend the economic expansion. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 12.26 points to 3,258.63, with local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising 0.6% each. US stocks also advanced on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reaching new highs.

site_title: South Korea's 2021 jobless rate falls to lowest since 2017
summary: South Korea's annual unemployment rate dropped to 3.7% in 2021, the lowest since 2017, according to government data. The seasonally adjusted rate in December was 3.8%, higher than the November rate of 3.1%. This marks a significant improvement from the previous year's rate of 4.1%. The decline is attributed to the country's robust labor market and economic growth.

site_title: Indonesia's Karim Family Foundation raises S$200,000 to support badminton world champion Loh Kean Yew
summary: The Karim Family Foundation, backed by Indonesian tycoon Bachtiar Karim, has raised S$200,000 to support badminton world champion Loh Kean Yew, the first Singaporean to win the Badminton World Federation World Championships. This donation complements the S$158,000 already raised by a crowdfunding initiative and donations from 5 business leaders in Singapore. The foundation, which focuses on sports development, art, and culture, aims to inspire future athletes like Loh, who was praised for his perseverance and humility. The donation was made through a donor-advised fund with The Community Foundation of Singapore.

site_title: Wreck of Taiwan's most advanced fighter jet found after crash
summary: Taiwanese rescuers found the wreckage of a F-16V fighter jet that crashed into the sea on Tuesday, less than two months after its deployment. The 28-year-old pilot did not eject in time, and the jet plunged into the sea. The incident occurred during a routine training mission from a base in southwestern Taiwan. The air force is investigating the cause of the crash.

site_title: Unilever 'clearly lost the plot' over ESG, says influential fund manager Terry Smith
summary: Terry Smith, a prominent fund manager, criticized Unilever for prioritizing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) efforts over business fundamentals. In his annual letter to investors, Smith stated that Unilever "clearly lost the plot" by obsessing over sustainability credentials. This criticism comes as companies worldwide face pressure to enhance their ESG efforts.

site_title: US on 'threshold' of living with coronavirus: Fauci
summary: US Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Anthony Fauci says the US is approaching the "threshold" of living with the coronavirus, despite record-high hospitalizations. He acknowledges that eliminating the virus is unrealistic, but hopes the country will soon have enough community protection and treatment options to manage severe cases. Fauci criticizes vaccine skeptic Senator Rand Paul for threatening his life and family, and emphasizes that vaccine efficacy against infection has fallen.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.42 points or 0.03% to 1,563.87. Volume reached 244.14 million lots worth RM88.97 million. The market saw a higher number of gainers than losers, with 231 stocks rising compared to 125.

site_title: India said to seek 15t rupee value for state insurer in country's biggest IPO
summary: India is seeking a valuation of about 15 trillion rupees (S$273.9 billion) for state-owned insurer Life Insurance Corp (LIC) in its largest initial public offering (IPO). The government's proposed valuation is based on the embedded value of the firm, which combines current profits with assets. If investors agree, LIC would join India's top companies, including Reliance Industries and Tata Consultancy Services, with a market capitalization of over 17 trillion rupees. The IPO is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to mop up cash and reduce a widening budget deficit.

site_title: Cathay Pacific will cooperate with probes on Omicron outbreak
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways will cooperate with two government investigations into the Omicron outbreak, which was traced back to crew who were allowed to skip strict quarantine requirements. Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam criticized the airline for non-compliance and vowed to take legal action once evidence is gathered. The airline's crew brought in the infections that sparked the local Omicron outbreak, prompting Lam to reimpose strict virus curbs, including closing kindergartens and primary schools.

site_title: Three phases of US politics will shape 2022: Covid-19, elections and China
summary: US politics in 2022 will be shaped by three phases: Covid-19, mid-term elections, and the 2024 presidential race. The year will start with unfinished business from 2021, including passing President Biden's "Build Back Better" proposals and addressing the debt limit. The mid-term elections, set for spring, will be a key test for Democrats, with inflation and Covid-19 concerns weighing heavily. The 2024 presidential race will dominate the final phase, with uncertain candidates and a fragile field likely to emerge.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden meeting with China's President Xi Jinping during a virtual summit from the White House in Washington, D.C. last Nov 15. How each of the US' two major parties say they will handle a newly-ascendent China will be among the factors determining whether they emerge dominant in the presidential race of 2024.

site_title: What issuers, shareholders should be aware of in respect of proxy votes for scheme of arrangement meetings
summary: A scheme of arrangement meeting in Singapore requires a majority in number and value of shareholders to approve corporate proposals. However, the one proxy rule restricts intermediaries from submitting separate values for "for" and "against" votes, potentially underrepresenting shareholder votes. Recent court rulings have allowed intermediaries to submit more accurate proxy votes, with the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) encouraging issuers to adopt these practices.

site_title: Under-pressure Biden gambles big on voting rights reform
summary: President Joe Biden is pushing for an end to the Senate's supermajority rule to pass voting rights reforms, which he calls crucial to saving US democracy. He urges Democrats to stand up for two bills expanding access to polls and preventing voter suppression. Biden proposes using a rarely used maneuver to circumvent the filibuster, but faces opposition from Republicans and skepticism from some Democrats, which could lead to his political weakening.

site_title: Walgreens starts strategic review for UK-based Boots business
summary: Walgreens Boots Alliance has initiated a strategic review of its UK-based Boots business, focusing on renewing its priorities and strategic direction towards US healthcare. The review comes as the company invests in healthcare providers and expands its pharmacy services. Boots UK saw a 8.8% increase in comparable pharmacy sales in the quarter ended November. The process is at an exploratory stage, with the company expecting to move quickly.

site_title: A new business model for shipping - just going round in circles or a straight path to sustainability?
summary: A new business model for shipping is being proposed, focusing on adopting circular economy principles to increase sustainability and reduce costs. The Global Maritime Forum suggests that shipping companies consider alternative models, such as "access-over-ownership" and remanufacturing, to reduce waste and extend the life of vessels. These models could enable cost savings, create a competitive advantage, and reduce environmental impact. However, the feasibility of these models remains to be seen, and the industry must weigh the benefits against the potential costs and environmental implications.

site_title: Biogen stung as US limits coverage of Alzheimer's therapy
summary: The US government has limited Medicare coverage of Biogen's Alzheimer's disease treatment, Aduhelm, to patients enrolled in clinical trials, citing concerns over potential harm and lack of clear evidence. The decision restricts coverage to those participating in randomized controlled trials, which must examine the impact of amyloid therapies on cognition and function in people with mild Alzheimer's. The move is expected to limit access to the treatment, which is priced at $28,200 a year, and may also affect other drug companies working on similar treatments.

site_title: Amazon union vote re-do date set in US
summary: Amazon has set a re-do date for its union vote at an Alabama warehouse, with ballots to be mailed out on February 4 and votes to be counted on March 28. The National Labor Relations Board previously found Amazon interfered with the election, leading to a re-vote after the initial 2021 ballot resulted in a defeat for union organizers. The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union is backing the organizing effort, which has drawn attention from lawmakers and media outlets. Amazon has stated it looks forward to its team's voices being heard again, amid a separate union effort at a New York warehouse.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, AEM, Accrelist, Jubilee Industries, HC Surgical Specialists
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported an improved overall business in the first quarter to November, with 98.7% of its target revenue achieved in student accommodation. AEM Holdings provided revenue guidance of S$670-720 million for FY2022, anticipating margin compression. Accrelist's managing director was discharged by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, while HC Surgical Specialists' net profit slipped 7.2% due to a decline in elective medical treatments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks advance at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.39% in early trading on January 12, driven by a strong performance on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased to 24,069.52, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The rally was fueled by easing concerns about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening plans.

site_title: Omicron pushing Covid out of pandemic phase: EU agency
summary: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) states that the spread of Omicron is pushing Covid-19 towards becoming an endemic disease that can be lived with. The agency expresses doubts about giving a fourth vaccine shot to the general population, citing repeated boosters as not a sustainable strategy. The risk of hospitalization from the Omicron variant is estimated to be between one-third to one-half of that posed by the Delta strain, according to studies. The EMA recommends spacing out boosters at longer intervals and synchronizing them with the start of the cold season.

site_title: To banish negative yields, emerging debt traders watch inflation
summary: Emerging markets are expected to report a slowdown in inflation this week, potentially paving the way for a shift away from negative real yields. After a year of supply chain disruptions and worker shortages, 15 developing nations are set to release their inflation readings, with all but two having inflation-adjusted policy rates below 0. If inflation moderates, it could validate bets on local-currency debt and lead to a reversal of negative real yields, but a failure to deliver could exacerbate investor exodus.

site_title: Flight bookings for Singapore travel spike before halt of VTL ticket sales in December
summary: Singapore's Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme was suspended on December 22, prompting a surge in flight bookings from and to the city-state before the halt. Outbound ticket sales more than quadrupled, while inbound bookings doubled, as travelers rushed to book before the quota was halved. The top 10 source markets for Singapore saw a double-digit decline, except for Hong Kong and the UAE, which saw a 20% and 8% increase, respectively. The suspension is expected to continue as Singapore plans to reopen its border gradually.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood slips as rising costs pressure profit margins: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers turned less positive about their business conditions in January, with the Reuters Tankan poll showing a sentiment index for manufacturers fell to 17 from 22 in December. Rising energy and raw material costs are squeezing profit margins, with some firms citing commodity inflation as a major concern. However, manufacturers remain optimistic about the coming months, with a forecasted increase in business confidence to 29 in April. The service sector also showed improvement, with a 23-month high of 8 in the index.

site_title: US dollar flat as focus turns to Powell testimony
summary: The US dollar remained flat on Tuesday as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony, with the dollar index around 0.1% lower at 95.842. Global stocks edged higher, and US Treasury yields rose slightly. The euro hit a 7-week high against the Swiss franc, while the Swiss franc is seen as a safe haven for hedging Italian political risk. Japanese households' inflation expectations rose to a 2-year high, and the US dollar gained 0.1% against the Japanese yen.

site_title: Judge rejects Facebook bid to derail US antitrust suit
summary: A federal judge has ruled that the US Federal Trade Commission's re-worked antitrust case against Meta (Facebook) can proceed, rejecting the company's bid to derail the suit. The FTC alleges Meta holds an illegal monopoly by acquiring Instagram and WhatsApp. Judge James Boasberg found the re-worked complaint to be more robust and detailed than the previous version, which was denied last year. The case may face a "tall task" in proving allegations, but it will not be dismissed. The FTC seeks to order Meta to divest assets, including WhatsApp and Instagram, to restore competition.

site_title: Oscars will have a host again in 2022
summary: The Oscars will return to having a host for the 94th Academy Awards in 2022, after a year without a host due to low TV ratings. The event, scheduled for March 27, will be held at the traditional Dolby Theatre venue in Hollywood. ABC's Craig Erwich confirmed the news, but declined to reveal further details, including whether Jimmy Kimmel will return as host. Last year's hostless ceremony drew 10 million viewers, a 56% decline from 2020. The Academy also announced veteran Glenn Weiss as the show's director for a seventh consecutive year.

site_title: Oil jumps nearly 4% as Omicron impact seen as short-lived
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 4% on Tuesday, with Brent crude reaching its highest settlement since early November, as tight supply and expectations of a short-lived economic impact from the Omicron variant supported demand recovery. Analysts predict that the global recovery will continue after the variant subsides, with US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and analysts Jeffrey Halley and Phil Flynn citing strong demand and limited supply as key factors.

site_title: Japan-Australia agreement augments anti-China alliance
summary: Japan and Australia have signed a Reciprocal Access Agreement (RAA), a first-of-its-kind deal that eases restrictions on military cooperation and economic collaboration. The agreement highlights Japan's growing strategic importance as a partner in an emerging international, anti-China alliance. The deal is seen as a template for other Western nations to establish a stronger presence in the Asia-Pacific. Japan's commitment to international trade and security is gaining traction, with key Western countries welcoming its invigorated commitment to international relations. The agreement underscores Japan's role as a bulwark against China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Europe: Stocks recover as tech snaps seven-day rout
summary: European stocks recovered on Tuesday, closing 0.8% higher after a seven-day tech rout. The Stoxx 600 index rose despite concerns over rising interest rates and inflation. Technology stocks led the gain, adding 1.9% after tumbling 8% in the previous week. Investors are optimistic about the fourth-quarter earnings season, with Refinitiv predicting a 49.3% profit jump. The European Central Bank does not expect euro zone inflation above 2% in the medium term, and companies are expected to deliver double-digit earnings growth this year.

site_title: As an ER doctor, I fear health care collapse more than Omicron
summary: An ER doctor in New York City is expressing concern about the healthcare system's ability to cope with the Omicron variant, despite vaccines and treatments being available. Hospitalizations have tripled in the past few weeks, with nearly every state and territory seeing a rise in Covid admissions. The doctor notes that while patients are experiencing milder illness, the influx of coronavirus-positive patients is creating a strain on healthcare workers and hospitals, with many being sidelined due to infection. The doctor calls for collective actions such as mask distribution, staying home when unwell, and vaccination to prevent hospitals and healthcare workers from sliding into crisis.

site_title: Half of Europe on track to catch Omicron, world economy at risk
summary: The World Health Organization warns that more than half of Europe's population will likely catch the Omicron variant by March, posing a risk to the global economy. The highly transmissible strain has led to fresh measures and vaccine booster shots, but the WHO calls for new vaccines that better protect against transmission. The World Bank predicts global economic growth will decelerate to 4.1% in 2022 due to labor shortages and supply chain disruptions caused by Omicron.

site_title: Singapore property auction listings likely to gain pace as rates rise
summary: Singapore's property auction market is expected to gain pace this year due to rising interest rates, expiring government credit support, and cooling measures. In 2021, the market saw a 35.4% increase in listings, with a success rate of 4.8%. Analysts predict more properties will be listed for auction, with interest rates creeping up and government credit support measures ending. The auction sector's success rate is expected to ease to around 5% this year, with distressed properties being more likely to be put up for auction.

site_title: Singapore's foresight practices should be taken beyond the government
summary: Singapore's foresight practices, which originated from the US military in the 1940s, have been adopted by the government and other organizations to anticipate and prepare for future possibilities. However, these practices have been limited to government sectors, with non-governmental organizations and citizens often missing out on the benefits. To address this, the government can share its expertise and encourage foresight initiatives in various sectors, including academia and private companies, to foster collective resilience and address pressing issues such as inequality, climate crises, and an aging population.

site_title: Singapore unlikely to be hit with work stoppages, service disruption when Omicron wave crests
summary: Singapore is expected to avoid significant disruptions to essential services when the Omicron wave hits, thanks to its high vaccination rate and revised healthcare protocols. With 87% of the population fully vaccinated, the country is unlikely to experience a massive labor crunch. Employers are encouraged to implement regular testing for staff, and new rules allow infected workers to return to work sooner, easing the strain on businesses. The government aims to minimize disruptions to businesses and livelihoods, with contingency plans in place to ensure operational resilience.

site_title: How will Web 3.0 go? Watch out for players like Musk
summary: The article discusses the potential future of Web 3.0, a term referring to the next generation of the internet, which includes blockchain, cryptocurrencies, and the metaverse. While some see it as a natural successor to Web 2.0, others view it as a speculative bubble. The article notes that past "productive bubbles" in technology, such as the dot-com era, have created long-term value and led to significant advancements in industries like telecommunications. It concludes that investors should focus on companies building hard assets, such as fibre optic cables, rather than those in the metaverse, and cites Elon Musk's efforts in building out satellite broadband as an example of a promising investment opportunity.

site_title: EU to block South Korean shipping mega-merger: sources
summary: The EU's antitrust authority will block the merger of South Korean ship-making giants Daewoo and Hyundai due to concerns that the deal may restrict the supply of cargo vessels, particularly those transporting liquefied natural gas. The EU commission has vetoed the operation, citing a lack of successful remedies to competition concerns. The merger, which would have created a group controlling nearly two-thirds of the global LNG cargo ship market, has been put on hold. The decision comes two years after similar vetoes were imposed on Indian and German companies.

site_title: US: Stocks shrug off weakness, Nasdaq jumps 1.4%
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq jumping 1.4% to a record high, as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell outlined steps to combat inflation. Powell described inflation as "very near the top of the list" of his priorities, indicating a possible rate increase in March. Tech shares led the gains, while the 10-year US Treasury yield declined. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.5% and the S&P 500 rose 0.9%. Analysts viewed Powell's comments as not overly hawkish, but still hinting at a rate increase.

site_title: Bank of Korea likely to hike rates again over high inflation, household debt: poll
summary: The Bank of Korea is likely to raise its policy rate by 25 basis points to 1.25% at its Jan 14 meeting, aiming to control high inflation and household debt. This move would bring the rate back to its pre-pandemic level in February 2020. Inflation in South Korea accelerated to its highest level since 2011, and policymakers are concerned about the increasing debt and rising housing prices. The decision is seen as a response to financial imbalances, despite economic uncertainties at home and abroad.

site_title: Repeated Covid boosters not a viable strategy, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has stated that repeating booster doses of the original Covid vaccines is not a viable strategy against emerging variants. Experts warn that existing vaccines are less effective at preventing symptomatic Covid disease in people who have contracted the new Omicron variant. Instead, WHO recommends developing vaccines that not only protect against severe disease but also prevent infection and transmission. New jabs are needed to address evolving variants, and current vaccines may require updates to ensure continued protection.

site_title: Fed's Powell vows to stop inflation from becoming 'entrenched'
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell vowed to combat inflation, saying the economy's recovery from the pandemic has led to persistent supply and demand imbalances, elevating inflation. He pledged to use the central bank's full policy tools to prevent high inflation from becoming entrenched. The hearing is a step towards Powell's expected confirmation as Fed chair for a second term. The Fed has already decided to end its Treasury and mortgage-backed securities purchases by March and signal potential interest rate hikes this year, amid rising inflation and COVID-19 infections.

site_title: SPH sees improvement across business segments
summary: SPH reported improved business performance across segments, with 98.7% of its target revenue achieved for its purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) and a 98.8% occupancy rate for its SPH Reit. Sales of PBSA exceeded those of the previous year, while repeat booking rates doubled. Asset-enhancement initiatives, including refurbishment and forward-funding projects, are underway. The group's aged-care business in Singapore and Japan performed stably, and its digital businesses, such as sgCarMart and Chope, showed growth.

site_title: SPH sees improvement across business segments
summary: SPH, a Singaporean media conglomerate, reported improved business performance across its segments in the first quarter to November, driven by a gradual economic recovery. The group achieved 98.7% of its target revenue for its purpose-built student accommodation segment and secured 32.7% of its target revenue for the upcoming academic year. Its digital businesses, including sgCarMart, FastJobs, and Chope, also performed well. Meanwhile, the company's aged-care business in Singapore and Japan maintained stable performance, and its retail and commercial segment saw increased occupancy rates at several malls.

images.alt_text: SPH owns PBSA assets under the Student Castle and Capitol Students brands

site_title: Even as competition intensifies, Tesla is still leaving rivals in the dust
summary: Tesla continues to outperform its rivals in the electric vehicle (EV) market despite increased competition. The company delivered a record 308,600 vehicles in Q4 2021, surpassing analysts' estimates, and delivered 936,172 vehicles in 2021, a 87% increase from 2020. Tesla's ability to scale will be a key competitive advantage, with new factories set to come online in Texas and Berlin, and existing factories expected to ramp up production capacity. Despite potential risks, including regulatory issues in China and supply chain disruptions, Tesla's valuation is justified by its rapid growth, with some analysts projecting deliveries of 1.5 million units in 2022.

site_title: Eerily quiet awards season is making Hollywood uneasy
summary: Hollywood's traditionally hyped awards season has been reduced to a whisper due to the Omicron spike and NBC's decision not to televise the Golden Globes. The AFI Awards were postponed, the Critics' Choice Awards were pushed back, and the Palm Springs Film Festival was cancelled. The Academy Awards remain scheduled for March 27, but the event's format and viewership are uncertain. The absence of award shows may have a significant impact on the box office, as prestige films rely on recognition to draw audiences. The pandemic has already hurt the box office, and the diminishing of the Globes may prove devastating if viewing habits have permanently altered.

site_title: US: Wall St muted at open ahead of Powell testimony
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 10.02 points or 0.03% at 36,058.85, the S&P 500 down 1.15 points or 0.02% at 4,669.14, and the Nasdaq Composite down 23.57 points or 0.16% at 14,919.26. The move comes ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony, which may provide insight into policy tightening and inflation plans.

site_title: Exxon buys stake in biofuels company Biojet in clean energy push
summary: ExxonMobil has acquired a 49.9% stake in Norwegian biofuels company Biojet, aiming to strengthen its low-carbon business and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The deal will allow Exxon to purchase up to 3 million barrels of Biojet's biofuels annually, which can be used in passenger vehicles and heavy trucks. Biojet plans to develop up to five facilities to produce biofuels from forestry and wood-based construction waste, with commercial production expected to begin in 2025. This move aligns with Exxon's goal to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions from US Permian assets by 2030.

site_title: Johnson under fire over 'bring your own booze' lockdown party
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under fire for attending a "bring your own booze" lockdown party in the garden of Downing Street on May 20, 2020, despite strict COVID-19 rules. The gathering, attended by around 40 staff, was organized by Johnson's private secretary Martin Reynolds and included the PM and his partner Carrie. The move has drawn criticism from the Labour Party, who say Johnson lacks the moral authority to lead the country. The incident is the latest in a series of lockdown parties that have emerged, sparking widespread outrage and calls for Johnson's resignation.

site_title: iFast prices private placement at top end of range; raises S$105m
summary: iFast Corporation priced its private placement at S$7.50 per share, raising S$105 million and issuing 14 million new shares. The placement will fund the acquisition of a majority stake in BFC Bank, aiming to accelerate wealth management business growth. Despite market volatility, the exercise was "well oversubscribed" with over S$150 million in subscriptions, exceeding the initial base size of S$75 million. The acquisition is expected to add a digital bank to iFast's fintech ecosystem, helping the company meet its S$100 billion assets under administration target earlier than 2028.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.12 points to 1564.29 on Tuesday, driven by higher volume of 4.154 billion lots worth RM2.838 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 639 to 357.

site_title: STI closes 0.6% higher in 4-day winning streak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.6% higher on a 4-day winning streak, finishing at 3,246.37 points. Despite cautious market sentiments, the index has shown resilience, driven by preferences for value investments. Market strategist Yeap Jun Rong attributed this to the index's ability to gain traction from value preferences.

site_title: Germany's 'traffic light coalition' is flashing yellow
summary: Germany's new government, led by Chancellor Olaf Scholz, is reviewing its stance on Asia, particularly China, due to Beijing's ageing and overborrowing issues. The "traffic light coalition" has laid out an agenda prioritizing modernisation, digitalisation, and climate neutrality, but with a greater focus on human rights and democratic values. The shift in policy is attributed to the new foreign policy chief, Annalena Baerbock, who favours a more assertive approach towards China. The change may have implications for Germany's economy, as exports to China are crucial for the country's jobs and growth.

site_title: Maersk expects cargo delays to persist
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping firm, has warned that cargo delays will persist due to the ongoing pandemic and congestion at ports. Despite some easing in Northern Europe, the company expects constraints to continue for some time. The longest waiting times are currently on the US West Coast, with a 38-45 day wait at the Long Beach port in Los Angeles. Maersk attributed the delays to the pandemic's ongoing impact on its ability to move cargo.

site_title: Europe: Stocks bounce back at open
summary: Europe's stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.6% and Frankfurt's DAX index gaining almost 1.0%. Investors took advantage of recent dips in the market ahead of key US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's plans to lift interest rates. Asian markets retreated due to concerns about inflation and the Fed's plans. Traders are bracing for volatile markets in the coming days.

site_title: United Airlines CEO says 3,000 of its workers have contracted Covid
summary: United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby announced that approximately 3,000 of its workers have contracted COVID-19 due to the rapidly spreading omicron variant. The airline will reduce its near-term flight schedule in January and February to adjust to staffing levels, with no specific capacity figures disclosed. Kirby emphasized the company's mandatory vaccination policy, stating no vaccinated employees are hospitalized due to the virus. This move follows a surge in omicron infections nationwide, resulting in tens of thousands of flight cancellations across the US airline industry.

site_title: More SMEs pivot to digital during pandemic: PayPal survey
summary: A PayPal survey of 210 SMEs with an online presence found that a quarter experienced a positive outcome during the pandemic, while 18% were not impacted. The pandemic led to a shift towards digital payment methods, with 57% citing a greater reliance, and online purchasing increasing by 48%. Additionally, 39% preferred shipment options, with some expanding their reach overseas aided by global payment systems.

site_title: Gold rises as dollar, Treasury yields ease; focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,806 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and easing Treasury yields. Traders await December inflation data and expect 3-4 interest rate hikes this year, limiting gold's upside potential.

site_title: Auto parts supplier Aptiv to buy software firm Wind River for US$4.3b
summary: Aptiv, an auto parts supplier, agreed to buy software firm Wind River for US$4.3 billion. The deal aims to capitalize on automakers' spending on digitalization, with Wind River's software and cloud systems to be combined with Aptiv's Smart Vehicle Architecture platform. The acquisition will expand Aptiv's presence in the digital automotive space, with the company forecasting 2021 revenue of US$15.1 billion, its highest in seven years. Wind River will operate as a standalone business within Aptiv.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private home sales fell 58% in December 2021, largely due to cooling measures and the holiday season. The country's Finance Minister, Lawrence Wong, said new securities for transferring official foreign reserves will not increase risks. Indranee Rajah suggested the GST hike's impact can be delayed through policy design. Meanwhile, PwC proposed zero-rating carbon and plastic credits to relieve buyers from GST costs. The Straits Times Index closed 0.60% higher, extending its four-day winning streak.

site_title: World Bank cuts 2022 global growth forecast on virus flare-ups
summary: The World Bank has cut its 2022 global growth forecast to 4.1% due to Covid-19 flare-ups, diminished policy support, and supply-chain bottlenecks. This is lower than the previous 4.3% forecast in June. Emerging-market and developing economies are expected to remain below the pre-pandemic trend, while advanced economies will close the gap. The global outlook is clouded by exceptional uncertainty, with downside risks including renewed Covid-19 outbreaks and financial stress.

site_title: China developer R&F delays bond maturity as buyback falls short
summary: China developer Guangzhou R&F Properties has delayed payment on a dollar bond due to a buyback shortfall, despite repurchasing 16% of the note. The company will extend repayment on the remaining principal by six months. R&F initially planned to set aside $300 million for the buyback, but cited delays in completing asset sales as the reason for the shortfall. The company's dollar bonds plunged last week after it announced the potential for "materially less" funds.

site_title: Calls for China to cut rates grow louder as economic risks grow
summary: China's central bank is expected to cut interest rates as early as next week, according to several strategists, amid growing economic risks. The People's Bank of China may lower the cost of medium-term loans by 5-10 basis points, the first cut since April 2020. The move aims to ensure economic stability, which has been challenged by weak private consumption and a property market slowdown. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike rates four times this year, contrasting with China's potential policy shift.

site_title: Thai economy to take 0.3% hit from Omicron
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to take a 0.3% hit from the Omicron variant of Covid-19, according to the country's central bank governor. The impact is expected to be managed within the first half of 2022. The economy is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in the first quarter of 2023, with recovery remaining fragile.

site_title: Indonesia claims graft in Garuda deal for French-Italian planes
summary: Indonesia's state-owned enterprises minister, Erick Thohir, claims graft in Garuda's deals to lease aircraft made by ATR, a joint venture between Airbus and Leonardo. An audit found irregularities in the procurement contract, including too many unsuitable aircraft and excessive costs. This is related to earlier deals involving Bombardier planes and comes as Garuda struggles to keep flying after the pandemic. Thohir stated that it's not just accusations, but facts, and that further investigation into other procurement processes is possible.

site_title: SGUnited host organisations not obliged to hire trainees, says Manpower Minister
summary: Manpower Minister Tan See Leng stated that SGUnited trainees are not obligated to be hired by their host organizations, saying it would hinder the program's effectiveness. As of August 2021, 2,300 of 7,200 trainees were hired by host organizations, with 3,500 employed at other companies. Tan emphasized that the traineeship experience boosts employability, even if they're not hired by their host organizations. Workforce Singapore provides support and resources for job seekers, including career-matching services.

site_title: Shimao plans to repay yuan bond due on Saturday after cash inflow
summary: Shimao Group Holdings plans to repay a US$300 million local bond maturing on Saturday after receiving higher-than-anticipated cash inflows from property sales in December. The company's onshore subsidiary Shanghai Shimao has set aside funds to repay the 4.65% bond, which was previously considered investment grade. Shimao is among Chinese developers facing stress following a government crackdown on excessive borrowing and speculation. The payment plan comes after credit rating company Fitch downgraded Shimao due to concerns over its financial health, citing a lower margin of safety in preserving liquidity.

site_title: Chinese cities tighten Covid-19 curbs as Tianjin battles Omicron outbreak
summary: Chinese cities are tightening COVID-19 curbs as the Omicron variant spreads, with Tianjin imposing travel restrictions and mass testing. The city of 14 million people has confirmed 49 cases and is enforcing strict controls, including negative test requirements for residents. Other cities, including Anyang and Wuxi, have also reported Omicron cases, and authorities are advising people to stay put before the Lunar New Year, a peak travel period. China has also cancelled flights from the US after passengers tested positive for COVID-19, and reported 192 new confirmed cases nationwide.

site_title: Germany needs greater immigration to avoid labour shortages
summary: Germany's economy minister, Robert Habeck, warns of severe labour shortages if the country doesn't increase immigration. With 300,000 job openings expected to rise to 1 million, Germany faces a demographic crisis. The labour force is shrinking due to low birth rates and uneven immigration, leading to a projected shortage of 5 million working-age individuals by 2030. To address this, the government has agreed to lower immigration hurdles and make working more attractive, including lifting the national minimum wage to $13.60 per hour.

images.alt_text: The labour force is expected to shrink by more than 300,000 people this year as there are more older workers retiring than younger ones entering the labour market.

site_title: Meet the world's best investor
summary: A seasoned investor at Standard Chartered shares his approach to investing, citing Harry Hindsight, the world's best trader, as a reference. The investor emphasizes the importance of an optimistic outlook, adding to investments during periods of weakness, and rarely selling into market strength. He also highlights the challenges of timing market sell-offs and the need for diversification. Despite the uncertainty and complexity of the market, the investor believes equities tend to rise over the long run and are more likely to outperform bonds. His advice to investors is to determine their target allocation, start small and invest regularly, and stay diversified.

site_title: Japan-Australia agreement augments anti-China alliance
summary: Japan has signed a reciprocal access agreement with Australia, dubbed the Japan-Australia Reciprocal Access Agreement (RAA), marking the first deal of its kind for Japan since the US Status of Forces Agreement in 1947. The agreement facilitates joint military training, disaster relief, and economic collaboration, including Australia's Clean Hydrogen Trade Programme, which aims to export clean hydrogen to Japan. The move strengthens Japan's anti-China alliance and positions it as a key player in Western-led international relations, potentially paving the way for Japan's involvement in the "5 Eyes" intelligence alliance.

site_title: Accrelist chairman discharged by Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau
summary: Accrelist's chairman, Terence Tea, has been discharged by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) following an investigation into a S$5,000 hongbao given to a customer by Jubilee Industries Holdings, a subsidiary of Accrelist. The CPIB also questioned expenses incurred during a Chinese New Year gathering. Despite the investigation, Accrelist's shares closed down 3.5%, while Jubilee Industries shares rose 9.6%. The company's board expressed gratitude to shareholders for their continued support.

images.alt_text: Terence Tea, executive chairman of Catalist-listed Accrelist and its subsidiary Jubilee Industries Holdings.

site_title: Germany's 'traffic light coalition' is flashing yellow
summary: Germany's new traffic light coalition, led by Chancellor Olaf Scholz, has laid out an ambitious agenda focusing on modernisation, digitalisation, and climate neutrality. However, a significant shift in Germany's attitude towards Asia, particularly China, is expected. The coalition agreement emphasizes democratic values and human rights, and mentions China more frequently than its predecessor, indicating a more critical stance. This could potentially impact Germany's economy, as its exports to China are crucial for growth and jobs. The coalition is instead focusing on cooperation and dialogue with the rest of Asia, seeking to capitalize on the region's growing importance.

site_title: PM Johnson under fire over 'bring your own booze' lockdown party
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced intense scrutiny after it emerged he attended a "bring your own booze" party in the Downing Street garden during the first coronavirus lockdown, with around 40 staff members in attendance. The gathering, which included Johnson and his partner Carrie, was held on May 20, 2020, despite strict controls on social mixing and lockdown restrictions. Johnson's spokesman declined to comment on the reports, and a government official apologized for the upset caused. The incident has drawn criticism from opposition leaders, who say it undermines Johnson's moral authority to lead the country.

images.alt_text: Johnson and his partner Carrie were among those who gathered with about 40 staff in the garden of Downing Street on May 20, 2020, after the PM's Principal Private Secretary Martin Reynolds sent an invite by email, ITV reported.

site_title: HC Surgical Specialists posts 7.2% fall in H1 net profit to S$4.6m
summary: HC Surgical Specialists posted a 7.2% decline in H1 net profit to S$4.6 million due to a 5.2% drop in revenue amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell to S$10.4 million from S$11 million. The company reported a 60.8% gain in other income and a fair-value gain of S$689,000 on financial assets. Earnings per share decreased to 3.12 cents, and the board recommended a 1.40 cents interim dividend. HC Surgical Specialists expects business to pick up as the pandemic stabilizes.

site_title: Keeping Singapore's status as Asia-Pacific's global Reit hub
summary: Singapore's status as Asia-Pacific's largest real estate investment trust (Reit) hub remains strong, with 44 Singapore-listed Reits and a combined market capitalization of over S$110 billion. Despite growing competition from other Asia-Pacific markets, Singapore's dominance is attributed to its strong governance, international investor base, and vibrant secondary capital market. However, industry stakeholders suggest adjustments, including a streamlined regulatory approach, higher loan-to-value ratios, and a broader sustainability framework. While competition is not a zero-sum game, maintaining Singapore's position as a global Reit hub will require consistent fundamentals and a strong investor base.

site_title: Asia-Pacific dividend growth to ease as global dividend payouts hit US$2 trillion in 2022: IHS Markit
summary: Global dividend payouts are expected to rise by 6% to $2.09 trillion in 2022, driven by growth in the Americas and Europe. However, Asia-Pacific dividend growth is expected to ease from 23% in 2021 to 3% this year, with Japan and Hong Kong playing a smaller role. US dividend payouts are forecast to rise 5.4% to $670 billion, led by tech companies, while healthcare and industrial sectors are also expected to see growth.

site_title: As an ER doctor, I fear health care collapse more than Omicron
summary: A New York City ER doctor expresses concern over the healthcare system's ability to cope with the Omicron variant, despite its milder symptoms. Hospitalizations have tripled in the past few weeks, and nearly every state is seeing a rise in Covid admissions. The doctor notes that while vaccines and treatments have helped reduce severe cases, the influx of patients is still overwhelming hospitals and healthcare workers, who are at risk of infection and are being sidelined due to staffing shortages. The doctor calls for collective actions, such as mask-wearing, staying home when sick, and getting vaccinated or boosted, to prevent a healthcare system collapse.

site_title: Taiwan passes extra US$8.6b defence budget as China threat grows
summary: Taiwan's Parliament passed a special defence budget of nearly $8.6 billion to boost defense capabilities against China's increasingly bellicose stance. The five-year budget aims to acquire precision missiles and mass-manufacture naval ships to enhance the island's sea and air capabilities. Taiwan recorded 970 Chinese warplane incursions into its air defence zone last year, more than double the 2020 figure. The move is seen as a response to China's growing threat and will also be welcomed by the US, which has remained a leading ally and arms supplier to Taipei.

site_title: Gloomy outlook for global recovery, says WEF survey
summary: The World Economic Forum's annual survey found that only one in 10 respondents expects the global recovery to accelerate over the next three years. Climate change is identified as the number one danger, with erosion of social cohesion, livelihood crises, and mental health deterioration as rising concerns. Global leaders are urged to adopt a coordinated approach to tackle global challenges.

site_title: Filmgarde to shut Bugis+, Century Square cinemas
summary: Filmgarde Cineplexes will shut two of its three cinemas in Singapore, Bugis+ and Century Square, due to lease expiry. The cinemas will close for reinstatement works starting in Q1 2022, with plans for the third outlet at Leisure Park Kallang and new business initiatives to be announced later.

site_title: Singapore's foresight practices should be taken beyond the government
summary: Singapore's foresight practices, originating from the US military in the 1940s, involve systematic study of potential future possibilities through trend analysis, scenario planning, and design fiction. These practices encourage participants to think critically about present assumptions and prepare for the future. A study at the National University of Singapore found that foresight practices have been introduced in Singapore by senior public servants over several decades. The practices have the potential to extend beyond the government, benefiting various sectors and organizations, and could be a valuable tool for shaping Singapore's future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end day on negative note
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day marginally lower, following a US sell-off due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans. The Hang Seng Index fell 7.48 points to 23,739.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.73% to 3,567.44. The decline mirrored a drop across most of Asia.

site_title: AEM sets FY22 revenue guidance at S$670m to S$720m, anticipates margin compression
summary: AEM Holdings set FY22 revenue guidance of S$670m to S$720m, anticipating margin compression due to higher supply chain costs and increased R&D spending. Capital expenditure is projected at S$10 million. Shares rose after CGS-CIMB raised its target price to S$7.90, citing Intel's US$7.1 billion investment in Malaysia. The company reported a 33.4% fall in net profit to S$53m in the 9 months ended Sep 30, 2021.

site_title: Cerberus cuts Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank stakes in US$500m share sale
