summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that the country will not shut its borders due to the Omicron variant and will only tighten domestic safe management measures as a last resort. The key objective remains to live with Covid-19 as an endemic disease. Vaccination and boosters remain crucial, and the government is preparing to ramp up capacity at public treatment facilities. Ong noted that Omicron infections appear less severe than Delta, but warned that daily cases could double every 2-3 days to reach 10,000 or more.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on Omicron worries, tech slide
summary: Australian shares ended 0.1% lower on Monday, despite a 1.3% gain from Friday, due to concerns over Omicron-led Covid-19 infections and a potential US inflation report. Technology stocks fell nearly 1% and sector heavyweight Afterpay retreated 2.3%. Energy stocks, however, rose 1.1% for a second consecutive session, driven by oil price gains. The country's total infections surged past 1 million cases, straining healthcare infrastructure and supply chains.

site_title: More digital innovations to support legal profession; 3 new Senior Counsel appointed
summary: Singapore's Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon announced several digital innovations to support the legal profession, including an online dispute resolution service and a new Data and Digital Economy specialist accreditation scheme for lawyers. The online service aims to reduce the cost of resolving lower-value cases, while the accreditation track will benefit lawyers dealing with data and emerging technologies. Additionally, three new Senior Counsel were appointed, bringing the total to 94 out of 6,333 legal practitioners. These initiatives aim to support the profession's digital transformation and enhance access to legal resources.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS lowers iFast target price to S$11.37 on UK bank acquisition
summary: DBS Group Research has lowered its target price for iFast Corporation to S$11.37, citing expected startup losses and integration costs from the proposed acquisition of an 85% stake in UK bank BFC Bank. The acquisition is expected to take 12-18 months, with the group targeting profitability in 2025. Despite this, the brokerage maintains a "buy" rating on iFast due to its strong growth momentum and scalable business model. Analysts also expect iFast to capture more market share in Singapore, where it currently holds 10% of the estimated S$128 billion in assets under management.

site_title: Australia vows to 'push through' Omicron wave as infections cross 1m
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison has vowed to "push through" the Omicron outbreak, despite record infections and hospital admissions, as the country surpasses 1 million cases. Morrison plans changes to isolation rules to allow workers in food production and distribution to continue working despite close contact with asymptomatic infections. Hospital admissions have forced officials to restore curbs in some states, and supply issues may persist for another 3 weeks.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi faces 6 years in jail after new sentences: source
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been sentenced to 6 years in jail after receiving 4-year sentences in two separate cases, including charges of possessing unlicensed walkie-talkies and breaching a natural disaster management law. Suu Kyi, 76, denies all charges and faces nearly a dozen cases carrying combined maximum sentences of over 100 years in prison. Rights groups have criticized the proceedings as a farce, calling for her release along with thousands of others unjustly detained since the coup.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,218.44 at the open on Monday, driven by gains from local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. This follows a weak US stock market, which fell for the third straight session due to disappointing job growth in December. European stocks also slipped on Friday due to concerns over rising inflation and Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Gold holds steady near 3-week low as markets weigh quicker Fed hikes
summary: Gold prices remained steady near a 3-week low on Monday, hovering at US$1,795.11 per ounce, amid anticipation of US inflation data and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Traders await December US inflation data to assess the case for earlier-than-expected rate hikes, which could impact gold prices. US Treasury yields surged last week following Fed policy meeting minutes, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Palihapitiya SPAC in talks to merge with Temasek-backed Akili Interactive: sources
summary: Social Capital Suvretta Holdings Corp I, a special purpose acquisition company led by Chamath Palihapitiya, is in talks to merge with Akili Interactive, a technology-based cognitive therapies startup, valued at over $800 million. The potential deal is being discussed with Akili's backer, Temasek. However, no official comment has been made by the parties involved, and terms may change or the deal may not be reached.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Invest like Peter Lynch in 2022 (Ep 15)
summary: Ben Paul, a senior correspondent, discusses market trends and corporate issues in Singapore in the 15th episode of the Mark To Market podcast. He advises investors to tread carefully in 2022 due to rising inflation and interest rates, which could spur market turbulence. Paul suggests that Peter Lynch-like investors look for multibagger stocks in the Singapore market, highlighting 7 local stocks that have returned over 1,000% in the past decade.

site_title: UK gives housebuilders US$5b bill to remove cladding
summary: The UK government has ordered housebuilders to pay around $5.4 billion to remove cladding from buildings, following the 2017 Grenfell Tower fire that killed over 70 people. The government has already committed $5 billion for repairs and will collect $2 billion from housebuilders over the next 10 years. The new plan targets buildings between 11-18m high, where tenants face tens of thousands of dollars in bills to remove cladding. Housing Minister Michael Gove stated that it's unfair for leaseholders to be charged for problems they didn't cause.

images.alt_text: The blaze had ripped through the 27-storey Grenfell Tower in west London in the early hours of June 14, 2017, trapping residents inside as 200 firefighters battled the blaze. Seventy people lost their lives. The cladding used on the Grenfell block was identified as central to the rapid spread of the fire.

site_title: Hong Kong crypto exchange allegedly hit by frozen funds
summary: A Hong Kong-based cryptocurrency exchange, Coinsuper, is allegedly facing issues with frozen funds, with at least 7 customers reporting problems to police. Customers claim they cannot withdraw money or tokens, totaling around $55,000, since late November. The exchange's administrators have stopped responding to queries and have asked affected users to provide their email addresses. The incident may fuel calls for broader regulatory oversight in Hong Kong, which is considering a licensing regime for all crypto-trading platforms.

site_title: Modern Land shares dive after some bondholders demand early repayment
summary: Shares of Chinese developer Modern Land plummeted nearly 40% to an all-time low after it said it's in talks with noteholders on a restructuring plan for its $1.3 billion offshore bonds. The developer missed a payment for its 12.85% notes due October 25, 2021, and has received notices from creditors demanding early repayment. Modern Land has appointed financial advisers to formulate a plan for remediation actions amid a liquidity squeeze for Chinese developers due to regulatory curbs on borrowing.

site_title: IMF says emerging economies must prepare for Fed policy tightening
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned emerging economies to prepare for potential economic turbulence due to faster-than-expected US interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. A gradual tightening of US monetary policy is expected to have little impact, but broad-based wage inflation or supply bottlenecks could lead to faster rate hikes and fuel expectations for inflation. The IMF advised countries with high debt and weaker institutions to act swiftly to let currencies depreciate and raise interest rates, and urged central banks to clearly communicate their policy plans.

site_title: EC World Reit receives notice of compulsory expropriation of Hangzhou port property
summary: EC World Reit received a notice of compulsory expropriation of its Fu Zhuo Industrial property in Hangzhou, China, for the development of the Grand Canal National Cultural Park. The notice was issued by the People's Government of Linping District on January 6. The property is located on the east bank of the Beijing-Hangzhou Grand Canal.

site_title: Musings on a brand new year
summary: Leaders from various industries share their hopes and fears for 2022, focusing on key areas such as global economic recovery, technological advancements, and societal progress. Key hopes include a shift towards collaboration, community, and compassion; a de-escalation of tensions between superpowers; and the adoption of environmentally friendly technologies. Fears include inflation, geopolitical tensions, and the potential for governments to overreact to economic challenges. Many experts emphasize the importance of embracing collective similarities, fostering innovation, and prioritizing sustainability in 2022.

site_title: Fed rate hikes make outlook even worse for slammed South Korean won
summary: The South Korean won has been Asia's worst performer over the last 6 months, dropping to a 17-month low against the dollar. Technical indicators suggest further decline, with the Bank of Korea potentially disappointing investors if it doesn't signal a slowdown in policy normalisation. The Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and a possible rate hike by the Bank of Korea may not be enough to stem the currency's decline, increasing pressure on policymakers.

site_title: More people couldn't fully repay CPF after selling property in 2020
summary: More Singapore residents were unable to fully repay their Central Provident Fund (CPF) monies after selling their properties in 2020, with a higher number of cases compared to the previous two years. However, none of these individuals were required to top up their CPF in cash, as most sold their properties at market value. This allowed them to avoid topping up their accounts, as the selling price was sufficient to refund the CPF monies used plus accrued interest.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB lowers target price for Food Empire on rising costs
summary: RHB lowered its target price for Food Empire to S$1.01 from S$1.13, citing potentially higher operating costs and lower estimated profit. Analyst Jarick Seet expects a temporary dip in group margins until Q1 FY2022 but a strong turnaround in FY2022 after margins normalize. Seet maintains a "buy" call on the stock, citing robust revenue growth and a rebound in margins. The new target price represents a potential upside of 32% with a dividend yield of 2%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.84 point or 0.05% to 1,542.27. The market saw 525.6 million lots traded worth RM159.6 million, with 221 gainers and 210 losers.

site_title: Vietnam could be Asia's next startup hub, VC says
summary: Vietnam's startup sector is on pace to become Asia's next tech hub, according to Binh Tran, co-founder of Ascend Vietnam Ventures. Venture funding for startups in Vietnam reached $2.1 billion in 2021, with top-tier Silicon Valley venture capitalists investing in the sector. The country is forecast to have the second-largest digital economy in South-east Asia by 2030, driven by growth in e-commerce, fintech, and healthcare. This growth has attracted significant investment, with Tran's firm having invested in about 70 companies.

site_title: Co-living providers look to higher demand
summary: Co-living providers in Singapore expect higher demand in 2022 due to the opening of more Vaccinated Travel Lanes and a return of expats and locals. This was evident in Hmlet's 35% quarterly rise in enquiries and bookings in Q4 2021. The anticipated increase in demand is driven by the growing popularity of co-living spaces, with more companies entering the market. This trend is expected to continue, with co-living providers looking to capitalize on the growing demand for flexible and affordable housing options.

site_title: China health stocks post worst start in 6 years as woes deepen
summary: Chinese healthcare stocks plummeted 5.5% in the first week of trading, the worst start since 2016, amid concerns over Beijing's plans to cut medical costs and stricter drug development rules. Biotech and pharmaceutical companies led the decline, with Asymchem Laboratories Co falling 19% and the sector trading at 33 times its 12-month forward price-to-earnings ratio. Regulatory uncertainty and potential policy updates have investors cautious, with pharmaceutical names potentially seeing a recovery in valuations due to new product launches and mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Carsome raises US$290m Series E round from Temasek-backed 65 Equity Partners and Seatown
summary: Carsome, a car e-commerce platform, has raised US$290 million in its Series E round, valuing the company at US$1.7 billion. The funding round was led by Qatar Investment Authority and Temasek-backed 65 Equity Partners, along with Malaysian and Filipino conglomerates. The funds will be used to invest in talent, products, and technology across Carsome's business, with expansion plans for its retail brand in key Southeast Asian markets. This comes after speculation over a possible US$200 million pre-IPO round in September 2021.

site_title: No concessions, no breakthroughs: Russia, US cast pall on Ukraine talks
summary: Russia will not make concessions under US pressure, Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said, warning that talks on the Ukraine crisis might end early. The US hopes negotiations will avert a new Russian invasion, but no breakthroughs are expected. The talks, starting in Geneva on Monday, come at a tense point in US-Russia relations, the most fragile since the Cold War ended. The prospects for negotiations remain fragile, with Moscow pushing for de-escalation from the US.

site_title: Philippines urges Indonesia to lift coal export ban
summary: The Philippines has urged Indonesia to lift its coal export ban, which was implemented due to low inventory levels at domestic power stations. The ban has caused delays in shipments to major buyers such as Japan, China, and India, driving up coal prices. The Philippines, heavily reliant on coal for power generation, imports nearly 70% of its coal supply from Indonesia. Energy Secretary Alfonso Cusi has appealed to Indonesia's Minister of Energy & Mineral Resources to reconsider the ban, citing potential economic consequences for the Philippines and other affected countries.

site_title: China venture funding hits record US$130.6b in 2021 despite crackdown
summary: China's venture funding reached a record US$130.6 billion in 2021, despite a government crackdown on the technology industry that led to plummeting startup valuations. The sudden rebound is attributed to the resilience of the startup machine, which kicked back into gear after a brief pause. The performance is notable given the devastation to major industry players such as Alibaba, Tencent, and Didi Global. The record-breaking year surpasses the US$86.7 billion total in 2020, marking a significant recovery for China's innovation boom.

site_title: Australian judge raises concerns about Djokovic's airport interview
summary: Australian Judge Anthony Kelly expressed concerns about Novak Djokovic's treatment after being detained on arrival in Melbourne for the Australian Open tennis tournament. Djokovic had obtained a medical exemption from Covid-19 vaccination before traveling, but officials allegedly pressured him into making a decision quickly, despite agreeing to allow him to speak with lawyers and tournament organizers beforehand. The judge questioned the government's decision to revoke Djokovic's visa and the treatment of long-term asylum seekers in immigration detention hotels, where Djokovic has been held since January 6.

site_title: Cypriot scientist says Deltacron Covid variant isn't error
summary: A Cypriot scientist, Leonidos Kostrikis, has defended his claim that a new Covid-19 variant, Deltacron, exists by combining characteristics of the Delta and Omicron variants. Kostrikis stated that the cases identified "indicate an evolutionary pressure to an ancestral strain" rather than laboratory contamination. The samples were processed in multiple countries, and at least one sequence exhibits genetic characteristics of Deltacron. The Cypriot Health Minister has deemed the variant not a concern, and more details will be provided in a news conference this week.

site_title: 'Power of the Dog', 'West Side Story' win at untelevised Golden Globes
summary: The 2022 Golden Globes ceremony was held without a traditional broadcast, with winners announced via a live blog due to the Hollywood Foreign Press Association's (HFPA) ongoing controversy over ethical lapses and racism. Jane Campion's "The Power of the Dog" and Steven Spielberg's "West Side Story" won top film prizes, with "The Power of the Dog" becoming the second film directed by a woman to win best drama. The ceremony's subdued atmosphere was reflected in the absence of celebrity winners celebrating on social media, despite the wins potentially boosting their Oscar hopes.

site_title: Facebook parent Meta expands in Texas with major office lease
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has leased 589,000 square feet in Austin, Texas, across 33 floors, making it the social media giant's largest office in the state. The lease is for the entire commercial half of a 66-story tower set to open in 2023. Meta plans to hire 400 more people in the area and has the capacity to accommodate many more. This expansion follows other major businesses, including Samsung and Tesla, which have also relocated to Austin in recent years, as the city attracts businesses seeking lower costs amid the shift to remote work.

site_title: ComfortDelGro acquires 90% stake in Ming Chuan Transportation for S$8.5m
summary: ComfortDelGro's subsidiary, ComfortDelGro MedCare, has acquired a 90% stake in Ming Chuan Transportation for S$8.5 million. Ming Chuan provides transport services for passengers with limited mobility and has a fleet of 76 specialized vehicles. The acquisition allows CDG MedCare to expand its medical escort and transport services for the elderly and persons with mobility needs. This move is expected to enhance ComfortDelGro's specialized medical services.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering proceeds with conditional subscription agreement with investors
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering has signed a conditional subscription agreement with an associate of Vibrant Group and Tian Yuan, CEO of CGC Group, to subscribe for S$8 million in new shares. The plan is to transfer the company's listing status to a new entity, with Hiap Seng Engineering becoming a fully-owned subsidiary.

site_title: China probes head of top life insurer in anti-graft campaign
summary: China's top anti-graft watchdog has placed the chairman of China Life Insurance Co under investigation, citing "serious violations of discipline and law". Wang Bin, 64, is the most senior finance industry executive caught in an anti-corruption drive this year. Shares of China Life Insurance Co dropped 2.4% following the announcement. The probe is part of a nationwide anti-graft crackdown on financial institutions and regulators, which has taken down over 20 officials since October. China Life has pledged to cooperate with investigations and support the government's efforts to cleanse the country's political and financial systems.

site_title: Will Asean startups realise their IPO potential in 2022?
summary: South-east Asia's tech startups are poised to go public in 2022, driven by investor appetite for technology and a growing number of listings in the region. At least 24 tech startups have signaled plans for an initial public offering (IPO), following successful listings by e-commerce marketplace Bukalapak and ride-hailing firm Grab. Despite volatility and concerns over market performance, investors like Adams Street Partners' Sunil Mishra are optimistic about the potential for blockbuster exits. The region's exchanges have revamped their rulebooks to attract tech listings, and companies like Carousell and Carsome are eyeing a listing in the US through an IPO or SPAC merger.

site_title: Removing barriers to the unbanked and accelerating financial inclusion in Asean
summary: The Asian Development Bank has revised its 2022 forecast for the Asean region upward to 5.1%, despite ongoing Covid-19 disruptions. However, an estimated 290 million unbanked adults in the region continue to lack access to formal banking services. Barriers to financial inclusion include cash wage payments, low account ownership, and low adoption of electronic payments. To address these issues, governments and financial institutions are promoting digital solutions, such as mobile banking and e-wallets, and investing in financial literacy programs. A tipping point for regulation and standardization is needed to protect consumers and drive financial inclusion.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal delighted with 'special' title win on return from injury
summary: Rafael Nadal won his 89th career title at the Melbourne Summer Set 1, defeating American qualifier Maxime Cressy 7-6(6) 6-3. The 35-year-old's victory marked a successful return from a nearly 4-month absence due to a foot injury. Nadal praised his performance, stating it was his best match since arriving in the tournament. He expressed happiness with his title win and plans to continue improving, aiming to regain match sharpness and add to his record 20 majors.

site_title: NTUC Income's corporatisation: striking a balance between profits and purpose
summary: NTUC Income, a Singaporean co-operative, is considering corporatisation, which may lead to higher dividends and share value for its members. However, this move raises concerns about diluting its social mission. The proposed entity, Income Insurance Ltd, will offer more generous dividends but its impact on the co-op's purpose is unclear. The decision will be closely watched by its members and the wider community, who value NTUC Income's social mission.

site_title: World's biggest crypto fortune began with a friendly poker game
summary: Crypto pioneer Changpeng Zhao, founder of Binance, has vaulted into the ranks of the world's wealthiest people with a net worth of $96 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Zhao, 44, made his fortune in the unshackled cryptoverse, where Binance's success underscores the vast riches being created. However, controversy surrounds the firm, with regulatory probes globally, including the US Department of Justice and Internal Revenue Service investigating money laundering and tax evasion. Binance generated at least $20 billion in revenue last year, making it significantly bigger than Coinbase Global. Despite volatility in the crypto market, Zhao is optimistic about the future, stating he welcomes regulation and is willing to give away almost all his fortune before he dies.

site_title: Bitcoin's swoon deepens as bears begin to test US$40,000
summary: Bitcoin's price dropped below US$38,000, its lowest point in three months, as bears tested the US$40,000 mark. The cryptocurrency has lost about 42% since its peak three months ago. The decline is attributed to the Federal Reserve's potential rate hikes and balance-sheet reduction, which could reduce liquidity in the system. This move could negatively impact high-growth and speculative assets.

site_title: Dirty-money ties worried some at Swedbank while bosses kept mum
summary: Swedbank has been fined in Sweden and is under investigation by US authorities due to its alleged ties to dirty money flows from the former Soviet Union. Documents released by Sweden's Economic Crime Authority suggest that some Swedbank managers were aware of significant links to potential laundering, including through Danske Bank, which has admitted to handling suspicious funds in a major money laundering scandal. Former CEO Birgitte Bonnesen denies charges of serious fraud and insider information, while Swedbank executives have been accused of downplaying the bank's role in money laundering.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro, EC World Reit, SPH Reit, mm2 Asia
summary: ComfortDelGro announced the acquisition of a 90% stake in Ming Chuan Transportation for S$8.5 million, expanding its medical escort and transport services. EC World Reit's port property in Hangzhou, China, is to be expropriated by the Chinese government for development, with the Reit entitled to receive compensation. Shares of EC World Reit closed flat at S$0.76.

site_title: DBS Foundation awards record S$3m to 19 social enterprises
summary: DBS Foundation has awarded a record S$3 million to 19 social enterprises across Singapore, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, and Taiwan. The recipients, including Eden+Elie and Magorium, aim to tackle issues such as autism employment, plastic waste recycling, and income disparity. The grant will support the growth and deployment of innovative solutions, with a focus on sustainability and social impact. The move is seen as a significant boost to the social entrepreneurship ecosystem in the region.

site_title: Greenback suffers biggest drop in 6 weeks after US jobs report
summary: The US dollar experienced its biggest daily percentage drop in 6 weeks, falling 0.546% to 95.734, following the December US jobs report, which missed expectations. Despite this, the dollar is still on track for a slight weekly gain, its first in 3 weeks. The Federal Reserve's tightening path remains intact, and the dollar's strength is seen as a positive sign for the central bank's monetary policy.

site_title: Market trends in 2022
summary: Key market trends and events in 2022 include manpower shortages and the metaverse's impact on markets. Companies like Sam Goi's mandatory offer for PSC and Airalo's $220 million funding round are noteworthy. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite US-EU trade tensions. Meanwhile, Asia's stocks rally, driven by mining and healthcare, and US-EU trade talks are in focus. These trends are expected to have a significant impact on the economy in the coming year.

site_title: Maybank Singapore woos near-retirees to grow
summary: Maybank Singapore is focusing on growing its wealth management services for near-retirees and retirees, who are considered stickier customers and less inclined to switch to digital banks. The bank has a significant market share in this segment, with 67% of customers over 50 years old. Maybank aims to leverage its wealth services, including healthcare and Islamic financing, to expand its domestic franchise, which contributes significantly to the bank's broader group target of achieving a 13-15% return on equity by 2025.

site_title: Worst may be over for iron ore markets
summary: Iron ore markets may have reached their worst, as prices have recovered by 50% since their November low. The Chinese government's recent announcements of infrastructure investments and easing fundraising policies for the property sector have boosted optimism. The contract is currently near resistance levels and is expected to break out to the upside, with potential support levels at US$115.15/MT and US$107.60/MT. This bullish trend is supported by a sloping 20-day simple moving average, indicating a likely continuation of the uptrend.

site_title: SGX-listed ETFs' AUM surge by close to 50% in 2021
summary: The assets under management (AUM) of Singapore Exchange (SGX)-listed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) surged by 47% in 2021, reaching S$12.55 billion, with the overall product offering expanding from 30 to 35 ETFs. The top 3 ETFs with the highest AUM increases were the iShares USD Asia High Yield Bond Index ETF, Lion-OCBC Securities Hang Seng Tech ETF, and ICBC CSOP FTSE Chinese Government Bond ETF. These ETFs also generated mixed returns, with total returns ranging from -11% to +10%.

site_title: Wall Street's big stock rotation: tech's out, old-school laggards in
summary: The US stock market experienced a significant rotation, with tech stocks declining and old-school laggards such as banks and oil producers rising. This shift was driven by the Federal Reserve's plan to tighten monetary policy, leading to a surge in inflation-adjusted bond yields. The Nasdaq 100 dropped 4.5%, its largest decline since February, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.3%. The rotation has benefited value strategies, with the long-short value strategy posting its largest rally in 14 months.

site_title: Shares, bonds brace for high US inflation, hawkish Fed
summary: Major share markets were muted on Monday due to investor concerns over high US inflation and potential interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The Fed's consideration to turn off liquidity spigots coincides with a surge in coronavirus cases, threatening consumer spending and growth. As a result, S&P 500 futures fell 0.1%, while Nasdaq futures rose 0.1%. Bond yields and tech stocks are expected to be punished by an early rate hike.

images.alt_text: Major share markets were muted on Monday (Jan 10) as investors count down to another US inflation reading that could well set the seal on an early rate hike from the Federal Reserve, lifting bond yields and punishing tech stocks.

site_title: Pandemic fuels online exercise boom
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has fueled a boom in online exercise, with internet-connected fitness gear and services experiencing significant growth. Home workouts have taken on a social aspect, with companies offering virtual reality headsets and online communities. The market for fitness tech has grown by double-digit percentage, reaching $3.8 billion in 2021. As cases of the Omicron variant rise, home fitness tech companies are expected to benefit, with some analysts predicting continued growth.

site_title: Should I stay or should I go?
summary: A growing trend of "The Great Resignation" is expected to see around half of the global workforce leave their jobs within the next six months, with a recent survey in Singapore showing nearly a quarter of workers intend to quit their jobs in 2022. However, experts advise considering three reasons to stay: financial constraints, growth opportunities, and lack of clarity on what would drive purpose and fulfillment. Conversely, three reasons to go include a growth plateau, loss of confidence, and misalignment of values with the corporate value proposition. Ultimately, the decision to stay or go depends on individual circumstances and requires careful consideration.

site_title: 'I have seen the future, and it works.' But is it Web3?
summary: Web3, a decentralized Internet, is an exciting but experimental concept. It aims to disrupt Big Tech corporations by giving users control over their data and resisting censorship. However, the term is often misused, and its true nature is unclear. Decentralization is a trade-off between community engagement and quick iteration. Governance tokens incentivize community participation but don't guarantee legitimacy. Institutions, large investors, and wealthy individuals accumulating investments in DeFi ventures can exert control. A discerning investor should examine the community's engagement and decentralization vision rather than solely focusing on governance tokens. Web3 is not yet a clear concept, but it has the potential to revolutionize the internet.

site_title: Unrest-hit Kazakhstan says situation now stable
summary: Kazakhstan has reported a stabilized situation after the deadliest outbreak of violence in 30 years, following a week of unrest sparked by a fuel price rise. Troops from a Russian-led military alliance, the Collective Security Treaty Organisation (CSTO), have been guarding strategic facilities, including the Baikonur Cosmodrome, to restore order. Authorities have reported dozens of deaths, thousands of detentions, and public building torched, but normal life is returning in the city of Almaty. President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev has vowed to consolidate his authority following the violence.

site_title: Ambani's Reliance to buy stake in Mandarin Oriental New York
summary: Reliance Industries, led by Mukesh Ambani, has agreed to buy a 73.37% stake in Mandarin Oriental New York for US$98.15 million. The acquisition will add to the company's consumer and hospitality footprint. This deal follows Reliance's recent purchases, including Stoke Park and a 25.8% stake in Bangalore-based delivery company Dunzo. The transaction is expected to close by the end of March, and Reliance will also seek to buy the remaining stake from other owners at the same valuation.

site_title: SPAC race heats up in Asia with first Singapore listings due
summary: Singapore is set to host its first blank-cheque company listings, with Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation and Pegasus Asia seeking at least S$170 million and S$150 million, respectively. The listings, scheduled for January 21 and 25, come after a dry spell for initial public offerings in Singapore, and are seen as a response to Hong Kong's competitive move with its own rulebook. Singapore's requirements for minimum market capitalization are lower than Hong Kong's, making it a preferred destination for fundraising, particularly for companies in the new-economy industries.

site_title: Built environment industry has reason to be optimistic in its outlook
summary: The built environment industry is cautiously optimistic about its outlook for the new year, driven by developments such as the Vaccinated Travel Lane that has improved the transportation of construction materials between Malaysia and Singapore. A shared materials bank is proposed as a sustainable solution to reduce waste and volatility in the sector. The industry is also shifting towards digitalization, with the adoption of building information management systems and virtual design and construction processes. Additionally, adaptive re-use of space and nature-based design thinking are emerging as key trends, with a focus on creating flexible and sustainable urban spaces.

site_title: MCT-MNACT merger makes most sense when viewed from perspective of Mapletree Investments
summary: Mapletree Investments' proposed merger of Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) has received a thumbs-down from the market, with MCT's market value falling 8.5% and MNACT's slipping 1.8%. Analysts recommend that MCT unitholders vote against the merger, while MNACT unitholders should sell their holdings to take advantage of MNACT's elevated but falling unit price. The merger may prioritize Mapletree Investments' interests over those of investors, and may not lead to a superior market valuation for the combined entity.

site_title: Credit Suisse chairman to get warning on quarantine breaks
summary: Credit Suisse chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio is likely to receive a warning for repeatedly violating quarantine rules, rather than a dismissal. The bank's board of directors will issue a reproach of his conduct, citing breaches of Swiss and UK quarantine rules in November and July. Horta-Osorio, who has been steering the bank through a disastrous year, has apologized for his actions and cited the need to revamp the bank's culture with individual responsibility. A public warning is expected in the coming weeks.

site_title: Acquisitions by S-Reits exceed S$12 billion in 2021
summary: In 2021, S-Reits in Singapore achieved significant asset acquisitions, exceeding S$12 billion in total purchase price consideration. The sector saw 24 S-Reits make acquisitions, with Mapletree Logistics Trust, Ascott Residence Trust, and Ascendas India Trust being among the most active. The acquisitions included student accommodations, office, retail, and nursing homes, with a focus on logistics and supply chain resiliency. The year also saw S$1.4 billion in net retail inflows and S$1.0 billion in institutional outflows.

site_title: Tesla raises Full Self Driving software price to US$12,000 in US, Musk says
summary: Tesla will raise the US price of its Full Self Driving software to $12,000 on January 17, according to CEO Elon Musk. This 20% price increase comes less than two years after a similar price hike to $10,000 in 2020. The monthly subscription price will also rise as the software approaches mass production. Tesla has been expanding its test release of the upgraded FSD software, which provides advanced driving features but does not make vehicles autonomous.

site_title: Starbucks Arizona union election ordered by US labour board
summary: The US National Labor Relations Board ordered an Arizona Starbucks store to hold a union election, rejecting the company's request to hold a single-store vote. This follows a landmark victory at a New York store last month, where employees voted to unionize. The ruling allows employees in other cities, including Boston and Chicago, to potentially unionize with the same labor group, Workers United. The union has also petitioned to overturn its loss at a second New York store and is awaiting results at a third. Employees are currently on strike over Covid-19 safety and staffing concerns.

site_title: China reports nation's first community spread of Omicron
summary: China has reported its first community spread of Omicron, with two cases confirmed in Tianjin, sparking a mass testing blitz. The cases are from the same transmission chain but the strain's origin is unclear. China's "Covid Zero" policy has led to widespread restrictions, including lockdowns in cities like Xi'an and Shenzhen, and a ban on inter-provincial bus services. This marks the most protracted stretch of infections in China since the virus emerged in Wuhan 2 years ago, raising concerns about new lockdown measures that could disrupt the economy.

site_title: US trade chief expresses support for Lithuania amid China 'coercion'
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai expressed strong support for Lithuania and the European Union amid "economic coercion" from China. This is the second such statement from Tai this week, following a call with EU Executive Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis. Lithuania faces pressure from China over its decision to allow Taiwan to open a de-facto embassy in Vilnius. Tai emphasized the US commitment to working with the EU to address China's "coercive diplomatic and economic behaviour."

site_title: Hollywood calls in sick with Covid: What's delayed and cancelled
summary: Several high-profile events and productions have been delayed or cancelled due to the surge in COVID-19 cases in Hollywood. Notable cancellations include the BAFTA Tea Party, Disney's theatrical release of "Turning Red", and the Grammy Awards. Meanwhile, the Sundance Film Festival has moved online, and the Super Bowl, SAG Awards, and Oscars remain unaffected. Productions on TV shows like "Grey's Anatomy" and "Star Trek: Picard" have been paused, and several concerts, including Dead and Company's in Cancun, have been cancelled.

site_title: Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou to direct Olympic ceremony again
summary: Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou, who directed the 2008 Beijing Summer Olympics opening ceremony, will reprise that role for next month's Winter Games in Beijing. Zhang promised a "totally innovative" ceremony featuring around 3,000 performers and a bold idea for the Olympic torch lighting. The event will incorporate Chinese Lunar New Year elements and focus on environmental protection, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic and global tensions surrounding China. The Winter Games coincide with China's Lunar New Year holiday and will be held under strict COVID-19 protocols.

site_title: Palihapitiya SPAC said to be in talks with ProKidney
summary: Blank-check firm Social Capital Suvretta Holdings Corp. III, backed by Chamath Palihapitiya, is in talks to merge with medical technology company ProKidney LLC. The combined company would be valued at over $1 billion. ProKidney is developing a technology that restores kidney function using the patient's own cells. The merger talks could lead to an announcement as soon as next week, but no final agreement has been reached. Representatives for both companies have declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: The so-called 'Great Resignation' is no workers' revolution, but an opportunity
summary: Singapore's workforce is experiencing a shift, but it's not a "Great Resignation" revolution. A recent survey found 24% of workers intend to leave in 2022, but this is not a mass exodus. In fact, Singapore's labor force participation rate rose to 70.5% in 2021, with workers across all age groups, including seniors, opting in to the workforce. The surge in job exits is mainly driven by blue-collar workers seeking better deals in industries like leisure and hospitality, with wages outpacing the rest. This presents an opportunity for employers to advocate for healthier work practices and well-being perks, rather than a workers' revolution.

site_title: Jessica Alba to skip National Retail Federation's New York conference amid Covid surge
summary: Jessica Alba and Honest Co. CEO Nick Vlahos will skip the National Retail Federation's New York conference due to the recent spike in Covid-19 cases. The event, which is one of the industry's most important gatherings, will proceed with vaccinated attendees and mask-wearing requirements. Alba and Vlahos were set to appear in a keynote session at the 20,000-person event. The decision was made after considering the risks associated with the Omicron variant.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for January 7, 2022, reveals mixed market trends across various vessel types. The Capesize index rose to $20,167, driven by West Australia iron ore flows to China. In contrast, the Panamax market experienced a correction due to decreased demand from Australia and NoPac. The Supramax/Ultramax market saw limited opportunities, with rates remaining under pressure. The Handysize market continued its negative trend, while the VLCC market saw relatively flat rates. The Suezmax market remained stable, and the Aframax market softened slightly. The Clean tanker market saw rates drop across most markets, with the LR2s being the most impacted.

site_title: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam orders probe of 13 officials who went to Covid-hit party
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has ordered an investigation into 13 senior officials who attended a birthday party for a delegate to China's legislature, where two guests tested positive for Covid-19. The officials, including Home Affairs Secretary Casper Tsui, will not continue to discharge their duties and are required to take quarantine leave. The incident comes as Hong Kong struggles to contain a new wave of cases, with the city's first local infection with the Omicron variant confirmed on December 31. Authorities have imposed strict restrictions, including a ban on dining in restaurants after 6 pm.

site_title: 845 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; weekly infection growth rate rises to 1.8
summary: Singapore reported 845 new Covid-19 cases, with the weekly infection growth rate rising to 1.8 for the 16th consecutive day. The Ministry of Health (MOH) also reported 1 new death from complications linked to Covid-19, bringing the total number of deaths to 838. As of Sunday, there were 285,647 total Covid-19 cases and 164 patients in hospital, with 11 critically ill in the ICU. 91% of Singapore's eligible population and 87% of the total population have completed the full vaccination regimen.

site_title: The chairman of the board plays a critical role
summary: The collapse of Archegos Capital Management highlights the importance of corporate governance and culture. The chairman of the board plays a critical role in setting the tone and engaging management on issues related to culture. Effective leadership and boards can establish candour and trust by defining values, providing cultural clarity, and building relationships with executive management. The board chair must drive the desired culture within the board and galvanize the collective board to invest time and engage management on culture-related issues. Establishing trust and candour is essential for building a strong organisational culture that affects the risk profile of a company.

site_title: Singapore's industrial champions are rewriting their playbook
summary: Singapore's industrial champions are undergoing significant transformations in response to the pandemic, disruptive tech, and climate change. At least 8 state-linked companies have announced major restructuring efforts, including Keppel Corp pivoting to clean energy, Sembcorp Industries shedding its oil business, and Singtel entering digital banking. The government has invested billions in transforming various industries and set a 2030 roadmap for a regional hub for carbon trading and green finance. While some companies acknowledge the need for gradual change, investors are adopting a wait-and-see attitude, and the restructuring has had a mixed impact on the companies' stock performance.

site_title: Future queen: Duchess of Cambridge turns 40
summary: The Duchess of Cambridge, Kate, turned 40 on January 9, 2022, marking a milestone in her rise to popularity as a member of the British royal family. Since marrying Prince William in 2011, Kate has become a central figure in the monarchy, known for her down-to-earth nature and commitment to various initiatives, including early years education and mental health. Her profile has soared alongside William's, and she is seen as a dependable and empathetic figure in royal circles, particularly at a time of transition for the monarchy.

site_title: World Bank approves US$90m in pandemic aid for Iran
summary: The World Bank has approved $90 million in additional pandemic aid for Iran to help fight against COVID-19, with the funds to be used for procuring medical equipment. This aid is separate from the Iranian budget and will be managed by the World Health Organization. Iran has reported nearly 132,000 deaths and over 6.2 million cases of COVID-19, and the World Bank's support aims to mitigate the humanitarian crisis and limit the spread of the disease beyond its borders.

site_title: UN Security Council to meet Dec 12 on Sudan
summary: The UN Security Council will hold an informal session on December 12 to discuss developments in Sudan amid ongoing protests against military rule. The meeting, requested by six council members, including the US and UK, will be behind closed doors due to expected opposition from China and Russia. The session aims to address the situation following Prime Minister Abdallah Hamdok's resignation and the deaths of three demonstrators. The UN special representative, Volker Perthes, will brief council members on the current conditions in Sudan.

site_title: German economy minister replaces over half of department heads
summary: German economy minister Robert Habeck is replacing 6 out of 11 department heads, keeping only the heads of economic policy, European policy, and small- and medium-sized enterprise policy. This move comes after Habeck's predecessor, Peter Altmaier, had replaced only 2 heads of department. The change in department heads aims to revamp the ministry's format and reduce the weight of GDP as a measure of prosperity in the annual economic report.

site_title: After fiery speech on democracy, can Biden deliver on promises?
summary: US President Joe Biden delivered a fiery speech on the one-year anniversary of the Capitol riot, vowing to defend democracy from "mortal danger" and criticizing his predecessor Donald Trump. The speech aims to galvanize his party ahead of midterm elections in November, but Biden faces a major political risk with limited options to deliver on his promises. His approval rating is 43%, and he is struggling to push legislation through a progressive-centrist split in his party. Biden has pivoted to focus on protecting voting rights, but some civil rights activists question the sincerity of his pledges.

site_title: Hong Kong faces worst of both worlds as Omicron ruins Covid Zero
summary: Hong Kong, once considered a Covid-19 zero-tolerance zone, is now facing a crisis as the highly transmissible omicron variant spreads, forcing renewed curbs. The city's low vaccination rate, with just 62% of its population fully vaccinated, has left it vulnerable to the outbreak. As a result, residents can no longer gather in public, and businesses are struggling to stay afloat. The government's decision to require vaccination to enter public venues has also been criticized for being too little, too late. With the city's economy and expatriate population at risk, Hong Kong is now considering a shift towards relying on vaccines to mitigate the spread of the virus.

site_title: Reddit tapping Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley for IPO: Bloomberg News
summary: Reddit is tapping Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley for its initial public offering (IPO), aiming for a valuation of over $15 billion, according to Bloomberg News. The social media platform's message boards were central to the 2021 meme stock trading frenzy. Reddit did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

site_title: Citigroup to fire unvaccinated staff this month: memo
summary: Citigroup has announced that staff in the US who have not been vaccinated against Covid-19 by January 14 will be placed on unpaid leave and fired at the end of the month unless they are granted an exemption. This move makes Citigroup the first major Wall Street institution to enforce a strict vaccine mandate, following similar measures taken by Google and United Airlines. The bank's decision comes as the financial industry grapples with bringing workers back to offices safely amidst the Omicron variant's spread.

site_title: BT Explains: What is BFC Bank and why is iFast buying it?
summary: iFast Corporation is acquiring an 85% stake in BFC Bank, a UK-incorporated online bank focused on international payments and cash management services for small to medium-sized enterprises. The £40 million investment will help iFast build a global business model as part of its 5-year plan, targeting assets under administration of S$100 billion by 2028. BFC Bank has a UK licence, which iFast plans to leverage to expand into other countries, including Europe.

site_title: Biden to deliver State of the Union address on Mar 1
summary: US President Joe Biden will deliver the State of the Union address on March 1, later than usual due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The delayed address aims to provide Biden with time to address the pandemic and find momentum for his stalled legislative agenda, including his Build Back Better plan and landmark voter rights legislation. The speech comes at a time of low approval ratings for Biden and looming November midterm elections.

site_title: PayPal explores launch of own stablecoin in crypto-push
summary: PayPal is exploring the launch of its own stablecoin, backed by the US dollar, as part of its cryptocurrency push. The development was discovered in the company's iPhone app and was confirmed by senior vice president Jose Fernandez da Ponte. A stablecoin would need to support payments at scale and have security, with clarity on regulation and licensing required. This move follows similar efforts by Meta Platforms and Visa, and PayPal plans to work closely with regulators if it proceeds.

site_title: American Airlines to seek short-term contract with pilots in sped-up talks
summary: American Airlines and its pilots union, the Allied Pilots Association, will accelerate talks to reach a short-term contract agreement, focusing on scheduling and compensation. The two sides will meet daily for a month starting January 17, aiming for a two-year or less contract. This strategy is driven by the need to address compensation disparities with competitors and improve work scheduling rules. The negotiations are part of the airline's efforts to deliver pay raises, enhanced profit sharing, and benefits to pilots, as well as quality of life improvements.

site_title: Japan household spending extends declines in November, raising recovery doubts
summary: Japan's household spending declined 1.3% in November from a year earlier, marking the fourth straight month of drops and raising doubts about a consumer demand recovery. The weaker-than-expected reading was attributed to cautious spending despite lower Covid-19 infections. Despite this, economists expect a fourth-quarter rebound in consumer spending, but private consumption is unlikely to recover to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Oil posts third weekly advance as market tightens on outages
summary: Oil prices rose for a third consecutive week, driven by supply constraints across the Opec+ coalition and beyond. West Texas Intermediate crude climbed 5% this week, despite closing down 0.7% on Friday. Protests in Kazakhstan's Tengiz field and Libya's militia unrest have reduced production, while a deep freeze in Canada and the US has disrupted oil flows. The market remains tight, with Opec+ sticking to its output boost plan, but concerns remain about curbs on demand in Europe and Asia.

site_title: Gold ticks up from 3-week lows after US jobs data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,797.10 per ounce after US jobs data showed slower growth, contradicting expectations of a stronger report. The jobs growth was lower than forecast, with 199,000 new jobs added, but the unemployment rate fell toward a multi-year low. Despite this, gold remains on track for a weekly drop due to rising US interest rates and inflation concerns ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. The dollar fell 0.6%, making gold cheaper for overseas buyers.

site_title: Canada's oil sands exports to Asia reach record with new link
summary: Canada's oil sands producers have reached a record high in exporting crude to Asian markets via the US Gulf Coast, with India being the leading destination. This new link, facilitated by the reversal of the Marathon Pipe Line's Capline pipeline, has increased shipments of heavy crude to over 266,000 barrels a day in December. This marks a significant shift for Canada's oil industry, which has faced opposition and infrastructure limitations in exporting to global markets. The development is expected to continue, with Canadian crude exports showing strength in the changing market dynamics.

site_title: US appeals court revives Boeing 737 MAX shareholder suit
summary: A US appeals court revived a 2019 shareholder lawsuit against Boeing Co, citing false and misleading statements made by officers and board members about the 737 MAX plane. The lawsuit, filed by the Seafarers Pension Plan, alleged the company misled investors about the plane's safety. The court's 2-1 decision reversed a lower court ruling that dismissed the lawsuit due to a Boeing bylaw requiring the lawsuit to be filed in a Delaware court. The decision allows the lawsuit to proceed, potentially leading to further action against Boeing.

site_title: Stocks are great for the very young - and the very old
summary: A growing number of economists argue that conventional wisdom on retirement investing is flawed, suggesting that older Americans should increase their exposure to the stock market as they age and spend down their assets. Laurence Kotlikoff, an economics professor, recommends a high allocation to stocks when young, low in the years just before and after retirement, and higher again in the final stage of retirement. This approach is based on the idea that most young people's wealth is tied to human capital, which can be offset by a financial portfolio tilted towards stocks.

site_title: Disney shifts Pixar's Turning Red to Disney+ in latest blow to theatres
summary: Disney has shifted Pixar's animated film "Turning Red" to a streaming-only release on Disney+, marking another blow to theatres struggling to recover from COVID-19 shutdowns. The film, about an Asian teenager who turns into a giant red panda, was originally scheduled for a theatrical release on March 11. Instead, it will premiere exclusively on Disney+ on March 11, with a theatrical release in international markets where Disney+ is not available. This move is part of Disney's efforts to boost its streaming service and ramp up subscribers.

site_title: Firms eager to get staff back into the office
summary: Firms in Singapore are eager to bring staff back to the office as the country eases COVID-19 curbs, allowing up to 50% of WFH-capable employees to return to workplaces. Employers cite benefits such as improved communication, productivity, and collaboration. They also note that physical meetings are more effective for presenting business plans and learning processes, particularly for new hires. Most firms plan to gradually bring staff back, with some already implementing alternate days or management staff coming in a few days a week, while adhering to safe management measures.

site_title: Striking a balance: risks to growth require 'light-touch' policy on inflation
summary: Global economic shutdowns due to Covid-19 have disrupted supply chains, leading to sharply rising inflation in both developed and emerging markets. Major central banks have taken a cautious approach to taming inflation, influenced by the pandemic's aftermath. Inflation is expected to peak before mid-2022 as economic growth normalizes, but may stabilize at a higher level than pre-pandemic levels. Policymakers must balance the need to control inflation with the risk of slowing growth, and investors are advised to favor equities over bonds due to robust corporate earnings.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SPH Reit reported a 98.8% occupancy rate as of end-November, an improvement from 97.9% last year. The real estate investment trust's weighted average lease expiry (WALE) remains stable at 5.5 years. In Australia, tenant sales at Westfield Marion Shopping Centre rose 6% year on year despite the pandemic. Nordic Group made a firm offer for Starburst Holdings at S$0.238 per share, representing a 4.16% premium to Starburst's 1-month VWAP.

site_title: China's Covid policy will be a wild card for markets in 2022
summary: China's zero-Covid policy is expected to remain in place until the end of 2022, according to experts, despite a potential easing after the Winter Olympics in February. This stance is likely to keep a lid on consumption and global markets, with China's GDP growth potentially falling below its trend rate. The country's trade surpluses will continue to benefit the renminbi, and the recycling of these surpluses will help keep global bond yields low, benefiting equities. Investors should prepare for strict lockdowns and closed borders throughout 2022.

site_title: Enjoying the water of life
summary: Agrim Singh, a 29-year-old hacker, started collecting whisky nine years ago after attending his first whisky showcase in 2013. He has since tried over 1,000 bottles from around the world, with a focus on learning about each whisky's unique characteristics. Singh's collection includes rare and hard-to-find bottles, as well as those from local whisky bars, and he enjoys sharing his knowledge and collection with others. He emphasizes the importance of trying different whiskies to develop one's palate and encourages newcomers to join the whisky-collecting community.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rates rise to highest since spring 2020
summary: The average 30-year US mortgage rate rose to 3.22% as of Jan 6, the highest since May 2020, according to Freddie Mac. This increase follows indications of continued high housing demand and limited supply, potentially prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to combat inflation. Freddie Mac's chief economist predicts further rate hikes due to inflation and economic growth, despite modest impact on purchase demand. The Federal Reserve may raise interest rates by 3 quarter-percentage points by the end of 2022.

site_title: Bitcoin ETF goes from boom to bust after a record US debut
summary: A Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) launched with a record US debut, ProShares Bitcoin Strategy (BITO), has experienced a 30% drop in value two months after its public listing, making it one of the worst performers in the industry. Bitcoin itself has lost 34% in the same period, largely due to the Federal Reserve's readiness to withdraw pandemic stimulus. The fund drew in $1 billion in assets in just two days but has seen no inflows since 2022 started, highlighting the challenges of timing in the ETF market.

site_title: Downtown Los Angeles draws flood of new renters in boon for gritty area
summary: Downtown Los Angeles is experiencing a resurgence in renters, with most apartments that emptied in 2020 now filled again. Rents have climbed 16% to a record-high average of $2,701, and the vacancy rate has fallen to 6.2%. The demand is driven by the overall scarcity of rental housing and the area's proximity to amenities like museums, sports venues, and universities. New high-rises are being developed, with over 4,700 apartments set to become available in 2022, further fueling the growth of the area.

site_title: Finding a vision for our time
summary: The world is wealthier than ever, yet a pervasive sense of pessimism prevails. Historically, humanity's progress towards a utopia has been repeatedly thwarted due to the politics of wealth distribution. The Malthusian era, where population growth offset technological advancements, has given way to unprecedented productivity growth. However, global wealth is maldistributed, with the bottom billion lacking access to basic dignity. Governance institutions have failed to address climate change, and the gap between rich and developing countries remains vast. Without a vision for a more equitable society, pessimism may prevail, and humanity's potential for progress may be hindered.

site_title: Eurozone inflation hits 5%, marking another record high
summary: Eurozone inflation reached a record high of 5% in December, surpassing analysts' expectations of 4.7%. Energy prices, up 26% from last year, drove the increase, with food, services, and imported goods also rising above the European Central Bank's 2% target. The ECB predicts inflation will return to target by the end of 2022, but some policymakers question this, citing underlying prices above target and potential risks of higher inflation. No policy action from the ECB is expected in the near future.

site_title: Soybeans rally, following soymeal gains
summary: Chicago soybean futures rallied on Friday, supported by soymeal demand and South American weather issues. Soybeans rose 23 US cents to end at US$14.10-1/4 a bushel, while corn added 3-1/4 US cents to US$6.06-3/4 a bushel. Wheat rebounded from a 2-1/2-month low, and grain markets await US Department of Agriculture crop reports scheduled for January 12. The gains are attributed to dryness in Brazil and Argentina, as well as fresh US export notices.

site_title: Shipping and decarbonisation - what happens next?
summary: Shipping industry faces increased pressure to decarbonize in 2022, driven by growing concerns over climate change and supply chain disruptions. The upcoming COP27 conference in Egypt may spark new expectations for shipping's carbon footprint reduction. Major companies, including container shipping giant AP Moller-Maersk, are investing in zero-carbon technologies, such as methanol fuel, and exploring green financing options. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has proposed a research and development fund and a levy-based carbon price, but the industry is pushing for clearer regulations, citing the need for swift action to meet net-zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Window for merger between mm2's Cathay and Golden Village lapses
summary: A merger between Cathay Cineplexes, owned by mm2 Asia, and Golden Village cinema businesses appears to be off the cards as the long-stop date for the potential deal lapsed on December 31. The deal, announced in December 2020, aimed to create the biggest cinema operator in Singapore. Following the lapse, mm2 announced it would continue to "explore new avenues" to maximize stakeholder value. The company had previously planned to sell its cinema business to Kingsmead Properties but the deal fell through due to uncertainty over the Omicron variant.

site_title: Mice calendar quiet for 2022, but may pick up after Chinese New Year
summary: The MICE (Meetings, Incentives, Convention, and Exhibition) industry is cautiously optimistic about resuming large-scale events in 2022, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Organizers are banking on a travel revival and expect a cautious process as restrictions are lifted. Several major events have already been scheduled, including the Apec Business Advisory Council Meeting in February and the Singapore Airshow in mid-February. Industry experts predict that travel restrictions, particularly those related to the Omicron variant, may impact event attendance, but most organizers have existing contingency plans in place.

site_title: Tales of a place formerly known as Aukang
summary: A Singaporean historian Shawn Seah weaves together personal and public histories in "My Father's Kampung: A History of Aukang and Punggol". The book explores the region's origins, cultural characteristics, and the lives of its former residents from the 1940s to 1970s. Seah delves into historical records, interviews, and anecdotes to recreate the daily rhythms of life in Aukang, a predominantly Catholic Teochew enclave. The book aims to bridge the gap between personal and public histories, preserving the memories of a lost era.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again after weak December job growth
summary: US stocks fell for the third consecutive session following a disappointing December job growth report, which showed the US economy added only 199,000 positions, less than half of analysts' estimates. Despite a lower-than-expected unemployment rate of 3.9%, the decline in new jobs created was offset by strong wage growth. The S&P 500 fell 0.4% for the day and 1.9% for the week, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 1%. The 10-year US Treasury note rose to almost 1.8% due to concerns about interest rates.

site_title: Running from the stresses of everyday life
summary: Lawyer Dean Collins, managing partner and head of the Singapore office at Dechert, credits endurance running with boosting his mental clarity and performance. He began running in 2018, initially training for a half marathon, and soon discovered the benefits of running for his mental well-being and professional growth. Collins now runs 4 times a week and incorporates strength training and yoga into his routine, using data and apps to track his performance and set goals. His passion for running has also led him to sign up for marathons, including the Big Sur Marathon and the London Marathon, with a charity he supports.

site_title: The blurred lines between visionaries and fraudsters
summary: A US jury has found Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos, guilty on 4 of 11 charges, with the remaining 7 charges remaining undecided. The verdict, which was expected to be a referendum on corporate greed, may not have the larger message initially thought. The article suggests that the line between visionaries and fraudsters is blurred, and that many entrepreneurs have characteristics of both. The outcome of the trial highlights the complexity of the issue, with the jury seeming to agree with some but not all of the prosecution's claims. The article concludes that the verdict reflects the nuances of the law and the specific charges, rather than a larger message about corporate behavior.

site_title: 777 new Covid-19 cases; weekly infection growth rate rises to 1.69
summary: Singapore reported 777 new Covid-19 cases on January 7, with a weekly infection growth rate of 1.69, an increase from 1.5 the previous day. This marks the 14th consecutive day of rising cases. The growth rate indicates that the number of new weekly Covid-19 cases is still increasing.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after soft jobs data
summary: Wall Street opened flat on Friday following weaker-than-expected job growth data. The Dow Jones rose 0.04%, the S&P 500 gained 0.03%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.10%. A rise in wages fueled concerns about higher inflation.

site_title: The democratic threat to democracy
summary: Today's liberal democracies face a growing threat from illiberal majoritarianism, where autocratic leaders claim to represent the general will of the majority without regard for minority rights. This form of autocracy relies on electoral victories for legitimacy, as seen in the cases of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and former US President Donald Trump. In contrast to revolutionary movements, illiberal democrats depend on competitive elections to maintain their power, and their narratives often rely on exclusionary tactics to create a "majority." This shift poses a significant challenge to liberal democracies, including the US, where elements of the Republican Party are pursuing strategies to restrict voting rights for minority groups.

site_title: What is BFC Bank and why is iFast buying it?
summary: iFast Corporation is acquiring an 85% stake in BFC Bank for £40 million (S$73.4 million), with £22.6 million for acquisition, £15 million as a capital injection, and £2.4 million for transaction costs. The acquisition aims to expand iFast's wealth management platform. The deal is part of iFast's strategy to strengthen its presence in the financial services sector.

site_title: Resolve to think bigger in 2022
summary: People make the same New Year's resolutions year after year, failing to achieve them due to a lack of deeper change. The problem lies in the "triumph of hope over expectation," where willpower is not enough to overcome ingrained habits. To truly change, individuals must face and dissect why their resolutions failed in the past, leading to unexpected outcomes beyond just willpower.

site_title: DBS retains 'buy' on IHH with S$2.32 target despite US lawsuit
summary: DBS Group Research maintains a 'buy' rating on IHH Healthcare despite a US lawsuit seeking over $6.5 billion in damages. The analysts believe IHH has strong grounds to seek dismissal for the claims. The estimated potential liability remains uncertain due to the involvement of multiple defendants and non-party defendants. DBS sets a target price of S$2.32 for IHH.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 ends third week higher on gains in banks, mining stocks
summary: The FTSE 100 in Europe ended its first week of the year higher, with a 0.5% gain, driven by gains in banking and mining stocks. Barclays and HSBC Holdings led the gains, while Anglo American and BHP Group benefited from strong metal prices. The mixed US jobs data and its impact on Federal Reserve policy also influenced investor sentiment.

site_title: Food for the business brain
summary:
Key takeaways from the article include: 

Singaporean executives and business leaders recommend podcasts and video summaries for on-the-go information and learning. A recommended book, "China's Leaders: From Mao to Now" by David Shambaugh, provides in-depth coverage of key Chinese leaders and their impact on China. Leadership development can boost Singapore's global competitiveness, and authentic leadership is crucial in uncertain times. Companies are advised to reconsider having an executive chairman and to prioritize CEO salaries and retirement planning.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.75 points to 1,543.11 on Friday, driven by gains. The index saw 600 gainers for every 338 losers, with a total trading volume of 4.141 billion lots worth RM1.904 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the first week of the new year sharply higher, defying concerns of a fresh outbreak and rising US interest rates. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.82% to 23,493.38, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. Tech firms benefited from bargain-buying, leaving the Hang Seng Index up 0.41% for the week.

site_title: UK house prices post biggest annual gain since 2007
summary: UK house prices posted the biggest annual gain since 2007, rising 9.8% year on year to a record £276,091 in December. This represents a £24,500 increase in value over the past 12 months, the largest gain in cash terms since 2003.

site_title: Germany to restrict restaurant access to rein in Omicron's surge
summary: Germany is set to restrict access to restaurants and cafes to curb the spread of the Omicron coronavirus strain. Vaccinated or recovered individuals will still need to provide a negative test to enter establishments. This measure aims to reduce contact without resorting to lockdowns. The decision was made in response to the surge in infections, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz and regional leaders agreeing on the new rules in a video call.

site_title: UK mortgage lenders expect housing market to slow this year
summary: UK mortgage lenders predict the housing market will slow in 2022 due to affordability concerns. Rising taxes, interest rates, and utility bills are expected to put pressure on consumers, following the strongest growth in almost two decades during the pandemic. The Bank of England may tighten monetary policy to combat inflation, while tax increases in April will further impact the market. This slowdown may add to the economic headwinds in 2022.

site_title: Japan and US vow more defence cooperation to counter Chinese threat
summary: The US and Japan pledged increased defense cooperation to counter China's growing threat, citing concerns over China's efforts to undermine the rules-based order in the region. The two allies expressed concerns about human rights in China's Xinjiang and Hong Kong regions and emphasized the importance of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait. They also vowed to work together to deter and respond to destabilizing activities in the region, including China's military buildup and hypersonic missile tests.

site_title: US employment growth misses expectations; unemployment rate falls to 3.9%
summary: US employment growth fell short of expectations in December, with 199,000 jobs added, missing forecasts of 400,000. The unemployment rate dropped to 3.9% from 4.2% in November, indicating tightening labor market conditions. Economists had predicted a higher payrolls increase and lower unemployment rate. The Labor Department revised household survey data, which affects the jobless rate, for the last five years. Despite moderate job gains, the disruptions caused by rising Covid-19 infections may impact economic activity in the near term.

site_title: Only 3,200 homes are left for sale on Toronto's market after record year
summary: Toronto's real estate market has ended 2021 with a record 121,000 home sales, a 28% increase from the previous year, and a record average selling price of nearly C$1.1 million. With only 3,200 homes left for sale, the market has experienced a frenzy fueled by low interest rates. This surge in sales has raised concerns about addressing housing costs, which are becoming increasingly unaffordable for many in the city.

site_title: Airbus faces US$339m class action suit in the Netherlands, lawyers say
summary: Airbus faces a US$339 million class action lawsuit in the Netherlands, filed by institutional investors who claim they suffered damages due to the company's withholding of information about corruption. The lawsuit, filed by the Foundation for Investor Loss Compensation, alleges that Airbus overpriced shares and accuses accountants KMPG and Ernst & Young of complicity. Airbus has agreed to a US$4 billion fine for bribery and corruption in 2020 and maintains it has "solid grounds to defend itself" against the allegations.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: iFast Corporation is set to acquire an 85% stake in UK-incorporated BFC Bank for £40m. A Singapore SPAC, backed by Temasek, plans to list on Jan 21. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is revising its Singapore travel advisory following a Covid data flap. Malaysian workers will seek a judicial review of the British government's decision to approve Supermax as a supplier to the NHS due to allegations of forced labor. The STI rose 0.66% on Friday, buoyed by banking stocks.

site_title: China's economy is in for more pain as virus cases persist
summary: China's economy is expected to face more economic pain due to persistent Covid-19 cases. The zero-tolerance policy on Covid-19 will likely curb consumer spending and disrupt production and shipping. Retail sales growth could weaken to 3.7% in 2022, down from an estimated 13% in 2021, according to economists Chang Shu and Eric Zhu. The situation could worsen if the Omicron variant gains a foothold in the country, which is more contagious and has limited effectiveness against China's vaccines.

site_title: Apple's Tim Cook earned over 1,400 times the average worker in 2021
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook's 2021 pay was $99.9 million, 1,447 times that of the average employee, with a median salary of $68,254. This is a significant increase from 2020, when Cook's pay was 256 times the median employee's salary. The pay ratio is attributed to stock awards, which contributed to Cook's substantial earnings.

images.alt_text: Apple boss Tim Cook's pay in 2021 was 1,447 times that of the average employee at the tech giant, a filing on Thursday showed, fuelled by stock awards that helped him earn a total of nearly US$100 million.

site_title: Thailand announces more coronavirus curbs after jump in cases
summary: Thailand extends its quarantine waiver program suspension and introduces new restrictions due to a surge in Omicron cases, with new applications not being approved until further notice. Existing applicants can still enter the country without quarantine until January 15. The country will also lift an entry ban on eight African countries and allow quarantine-free entry via suspended sandbox schemes starting January 11. Additionally, Thailand will halt alcohol consumption in restaurants after 9 pm in eight provinces and ban it nationwide to curb local virus transmissions.

site_title: 296 patients qualified for vaccine injury payouts as of Dec 31: MOH
summary: As of Dec 31, 296 patients in Singapore qualified for government financial aid under the Vaccine Injury Financial Assistance Programme (VIFAP) due to serious side effects related to Covid-19 vaccines. This is an increase from 144 as of last August, with a total payout of S$1,262,000.
