The highest Tier 1 payout of S$225,000 has been extended to two applicants, and the number of applicants remains unchanged since the last update in August.

site_title: Bitcoin hits lowest since September in drop of 40% from record
summary: Bitcoin plummeted to its lowest level since September, dropping 40% from its record near US$69,000, as it fell below US$42,000. The decline was attributed to minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting, which signaled potential rate hikes and a balance-sheet rundown. Other major cryptocurrencies, including Ether, Binance Coin, and XRP, also experienced significant drops. Analysts believe the volatility is linked to central banks tightening monetary policy and the unrest in Kazakhstan affecting crypto-mining operations.

site_title: McDonald's runs out of hash browns in some Taiwan stores
summary: McDonald's Taiwan reported a shortage of imported hash browns due to "unstable global shipping supply" and suspended sales in some stores. The shortage is attributed to the coronavirus pandemic affecting global supply chains. The company aims to resume selling hash browns in the second half of January after restocking. This is not the first time McDonald's has faced supply chain issues, as Japanese stores previously rationed French fries due to import delays. The shortage is part of a broader global trend of supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.

site_title: 7 in 10 Singapore SMEs need more support in upskilling employees: Survey
summary: In a survey conducted by NTUC LearningHub, 7 in 10 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore require more support in upskilling their employees, citing budget constraints and lack of resources as major challenges. Only 19% of SMEs plan to improve training methods, while 40% of larger companies do the same. The survey also found that 43% of employers face lack of support from employees when implementing workforce training programs, and 38% of employees rate their company's learning and development programs as either fair, bad, or very bad.

site_title: Mahathir hospitalised for elective medical procedure
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 96, has been hospitalized for an elective medical procedure at the National Heart Institute. This is his second hospitalization at the institute in as many months. Mahathir has a history of heart problems, including multiple heart attacks and bypass surgery. He served as prime minister twice, for a total of 24 years, and was leader of a reformist coalition in 2018. The current administration's collapse in 2020 was due to infighting.

site_title: Cambodia PM meets Myanmar junta chief as visit sparks protests
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen met with Myanmar's military ruler Min Aung Hlaing on Friday, sparking protests in the country over fears his trip will legitimize the junta. Hun Sen's visit, aimed at promoting a peace plan sponsored by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), has been criticized by opponents of military rule, who claim he is backing the junta. Protests broke out in various parts of Myanmar, with demonstrators chanting "Hun Sen don't come to Myanmar" and burning posters of the prime minister.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.07% on Friday, January 7, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 23,318.92. This follows a late rally the previous day. Traders await US jobs data for an update on the economic recovery. Meanwhile, other markets, such as the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index, also saw gains.

site_title: Nordic Group confirms offer for Starburst at S$0.238 per share
summary: Nordic Group has confirmed a firm offer to acquire Starburst Holdings at S$0.238 per share in cash, following shareholder approval. The offer represents a 4.16% premium to Starburst's 1-month VWAP and a 9.07% premium to its 3-month VWAP. Nordic aims to leverage Starburst's engineering expertise to build economies of scale and cost efficiencies, with potential for cross-selling of services. The deal requires Nordic to control at least half the company, with executive chairman Edward Lim and managing director Yap Tin Foo already committing 69.7% of shares.

site_title: Hong Kong's growth forecasts at risk as Omicron spreads
summary: Hong Kong's economic growth forecasts are at risk due to the spread of Omicron-variant virus cases, which may dampen economic activity, particularly in the service sector. New virus control measures, including cancelled flights and dining bans, have been introduced, and economists have reduced forecasts for gross domestic product growth, with some expecting 2% or less this year. Analysts at IHS Markit, Bloomberg Economics, and Fitch Ratings have flagged downside risks to their expectations, citing the potential for further economic contraction. The measures are expected to have a marginal impact on Bank of America's forecast.

site_title: Europe: Equity markets subdued at open
summary: Europe's stock markets opened on a subdued note on Friday, awaiting critical US jobs data and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans. London's FTSE 100 index fell marginally, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined. Investors remain apprehensive due to the Fed's hawkish stance, with mixed Asian bourses following. The release of US payrolls data and the Fed's aggressive rate-tightening path have rattled global traders, leading to a decrease in market sentiment.

site_title: China developer Shimao Group seeks ABS extensions; shares, bonds sell off
summary: Chinese developer Shimao Group faces financial stress as it seeks extensions on maturities for two asset-backed securities, totaling $183.50 million. The company proposes a repayment plan, but ABS holders may reject it without credit enhancements, potentially triggering cross-default clauses. This comes after Shimao defaulted on a loan payment of $645 million, causing its shares and bonds to plummet. The company is in talks with China Credit Trust to resolve the outstanding payment, but investors remain concerned about liquidity stress in the property sector.

site_title: Australia: Financials, energy stocks lead rebound
summary: Australian shares rebounded 1.3% on Friday, led by financials and energy stocks, after a tech-driven sell-off on Thursday. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,453.3. Financial stocks rose 1.9% and energy stocks jumped 2.2% amid supply worries in Kazakhstan and Libya. The tech sector rose 1.1% despite a poor Nasdaq performance. James Hardie Industries slumped 4.1% after ousting its CEO for breaching code of conduct.

site_title: Nippon Paint to offer 203b yen in overseas share sale
summary: Nippon Paint plans to sell up to 203 billion yen (S$2.4 billion) of its shares in an overseas sale, aiming to improve liquidity and alleviate concerns over strategic holdings. Several shareholders, including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, MUFG Bank, and Sompo Japan Insurance, have agreed to reduce their holdings. The move follows calls from investors to free up capital in Japanese companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% at the open on Friday, driven by gains in banking stocks, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,202.31. The market was influenced by the Federal Reserve's shift towards tighter monetary policy, which weighed on European and US stocks. Other heavily traded securities included Thai Beverage, International Cement Group, and Singtel, which advanced 1.5%, dipped 3.9%, and rose 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB initiates 'add' on Hyphens Pharma with S$0.36 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Hyphens Pharma with an "add" call and a target price of S$0.36, citing the pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare company's Novem acquisition as a growth driver. Analyst Tay Wee Kuang expects the acquisition to contribute to a 22.9% growth forecast for FY2022 and notes the company's strong cash position and resilient business model. The target price represents a potential upside of 18% from the current trading price, with analysts expecting stable, sustainable growth moving forward.

site_title: 'I am not a virus,' insists Indian man named Kovid
summary: Indian travel start-up founder Kovid Kapoor, 31, has gained social media attention after declaring "I am not a virus" on his Twitter profile, referencing the COVID-19 pandemic. Kapoor recently traveled outside India for the first time since the pandemic, sparking amusement among his followers, who have liked and retweeted his post 40,000 times. He expressed excitement for his future foreign trips, saying "Future foreign trips are going to be fun!" Kapoor's name has become a topic of conversation, with many amused by the coincidence of his name and the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Kapoor said he has been "Kovid positive since 1990" and posted a picture holding a bottle of Corona beer.

site_title: Singapore SPAC Vertex Technology set for local listing on Jan 21
summary: Singapore-based special-purpose acquisition company Vertex Technology Acquisition (VTAC), backed by state investor Temasek's Vertex Venture, is set to list on January 21. VTAC aims to raise at least S$170m by selling units at S$5 apiece, focusing on cybersecurity, fintech, and other sectors. The listing is part of the company's initial public offering (IPO) process.

site_title: Chinese police rap Walmart for cybersecurity loopholes
summary: Chinese authorities have accused Walmart of violating cybersecurity laws after discovering 19 vulnerabilities in its network system in Shenzhen, China. The retail giant was ordered to make rectifications without mentioning any fines or details of the vulnerabilities. This comes after Walmart faced criticism for allegedly removing products sourced from Xinjiang from its apps and stores, sparking a wave of membership cancellations at its Sam's Club in China. The incident marks a fresh set of troubles for Walmart in China, which has already faced criticism for its handling of Xinjiang-related issues.

site_title: Oil prices jump on supply worries amid Kazakhstan unrest
summary: Oil prices surged on Friday, rising 0.6% to $82.47 a barrel for Brent crude and 0.6% to $79.96 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. The increase reflects market jitters over unrest in Kazakhstan and Libya, where output has dropped due to pipeline maintenance work. Supply concerns, combined with a 6% gain in the first week of the year, have pushed prices to their highest since late-November, despite fears over the Omicron variant's impact on demand.

site_title: Sanofi partners with AI firm Exscientia to develop up to 15 new drugs
summary: Sanofi partners with AI firm Exscientia to develop up to 15 new drugs, worth up to $5.2 billion, in a deal that will focus on oncology and immunology treatments. Exscientia will lead discovery and design of small molecule drugs, while Sanofi will handle clinical development. This partnership aims to improve research accuracy and reduce timelines, with Exscientia's AI technology potentially shortening the 5,000 molecule synthesis process to 500.

site_title: SPH Reit records 98.8% occupancy in Q1, with 5.5-year WALE
summary: SPH Reit reported a 98.8% occupancy rate as of end-November, up from 97.9% a year ago, with a 5.5-year weighted average lease expiry (WALE). The real estate investment trust (Reit) cited its strategically located assets and "captive catchments" as contributing factors. Occupancy in Singapore's portfolio increased to 99.8%, while tenant sales rose 6% year-on-year in Australia. The Reit's capital management is healthy, with low debt costs and undrawn revolving credit facility lines. Despite concerns over the Omicron variant, the manager remains "cautiously optimistic" about the future.

site_title: Shell pursues US$7b buyback 'at pace' despite LNG troubles
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to pursue its US$7 billion share buyback program despite its liquefied natural gas (LNG) production being impacted by unplanned outages and a slowdown in global economic activity due to the Omicron Covid-19 variant. The company's LNG production and liquefaction volumes were below a peak in 2019, but its LNG trading results are expected to be "significantly higher" in the fourth quarter. Shell also announced it will move its head office to London and change its name to Shell Plc as part of a plan to simplify its structure and shift its tax residence.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close marginally lower
summary: Tokyo shares closed marginally lower on Friday, January 7, 2022, as investors awaited US job data. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index declined 0.03% to 28,478.56, while the Topix index fell 0.07% to 1,995.68.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log sharpest daily gain in 5 weeks
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.18% to 2,954.89, logging the sharpest daily gain in 5 weeks. Foreign investors bought 634.9 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won weakened to its lowest in a year and a half. The benchmark Kospi index has fallen 0.76% this year but lost 2.5% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS retains 'buy' on IHH with S$2.32 target despite US lawsuit
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained a "buy" rating on IHH Healthcare with a target price of S$2.32 despite a US lawsuit seeking over US$6.5 billion in damages. The lawsuit alleges IHH conspired to frustrate a proposed share acquisition transaction between Fortis Healthcare and Emqore Envesecure Private Capital Trust. DBS analysts believe IHH has strong grounds to seek dismissal and a temporary near-term overhang on the company's share price will be resolved if the lawsuit is dismissed swiftly.

site_title: Indonesia minister says 'emergency over' on coal supply crunch: CNBC Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's power emergency triggered by a coal supply crunch is over, according to Coordinating Minister Luhut Pandjaitan. The government had suspended coal exports starting January 1 due to low inventory levels, but the emergency has been lifted. Discussions on a permanent solution will continue on Friday, with a review of the domestic market obligation formula and a potential new formula to be discussed. The current 25% production requirement for local market sales will be evaluated, with a decision expected on the same day.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH maintains 'buy' on Sea with US$370.76 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains a "buy" rating on Sea with a target price of US$370.76, despite a recent 17% drop in stock price. Analyst Clement Ho cites the company's strong fundamentals, including its reduction in cash burn and continued market share gains in e-commerce. Ho also notes that Tencent's stake sale is unrelated to Sea's strong fundamentals and that the recent price correction is "healthy." The target price represents a 100.7% increase from the stock's previous close and is based on Sea's stronger sales growth profile compared to its e-commerce peers.

site_title: STI up 0.66%, buoyed by banking stocks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.66% to 3,205.26 points, driven by gains in banking stocks, which accounted for over 40% of the index. However, 5 of 7 Reits underperformed due to rising interest rates. Other Asian markets, such as the Hang Seng Index, Australia's ASX 200, and South Korea's Kospi, also saw gains. The Shanghai Composite Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 declined.

site_title: Fed's 'maximum employment' is here; not everyone has benefited
summary: The US Federal Reserve has declared its "maximum employment" goal nearly complete, citing a tight job market with rapid progress expected. Officials have been reluctant to define the term, but recent minutes show they believe the economy is poised to meet its goal. However, the job recovery has been uneven, with significant gaps among women, the less educated, and in certain regions. The Fed's emphasis on jobs was driven by concerns about inflation, but the recent surge in inflation has led to a reevaluation of its approach. The Fed is now poised to hike interest rates, potentially slowing economic growth and hiring.

site_title: South Korea's Lotte Chemical to form petchem project in Indonesia worth US$3.9b
summary: South Korea's Lotte Chemical plans to invest US$3.9 billion in a large-scale petrochemical complex in Indonesia, with commercial production targeting 2025 and annual revenue of 2.4 trillion won. The project aims to capitalize on Indonesia's growing demand for petrochemicals, with the country expected to become a major player in the global aluminium industry. Lotte Chemical's move is seen as a strategic expansion into the Southeast Asian market, marking the company's entry into Indonesia's burgeoning petrochemical sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, January 7, rebounding from sharp falls on speculations about a US monetary policy shift. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.8% to 28,704.63, while the Topix index advanced 0.6% to 2,008.37. The gains came despite US President Trump's new threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: China urges banks to boost property lending on default fears
summary: China's regulators have urged banks to boost real estate lending in the first quarter amid concerns over a liquidity crisis in the industry. The move comes as authorities dial back a multi-year crackdown on the sector, seeking to engineer a soft landing. The easing of debt restrictions for developers and a relaxation of funding for mergers and acquisitions are seen as efforts to stabilize the market. However, smaller firms are still likely to struggle to raise cash, and the offshore dollar bond market remains shut for refinancing.

images.alt_text: China called on banks to boost real estate lending in the first quarter and eased a key debt restriction for developers, a sign that authorities are becoming increasingly concerned about the industry's liquidity crisis.

site_title: Beauty is only skin deep in China 'micro-procedure' craze
summary: In China, a growing trend of "micro-procedures" is on the rise, with cosmetic treatments like laser facials, fillers, and thread lifts becoming increasingly popular among young consumers. The industry is expected to reach $46 billion this year, driven by rising disposable incomes and social media pressure. However, the government has cracked down on the industry, banning industry advertising practices that contribute to "appearance anxiety" and levying fines on unlicensed providers. Experts argue that micro-procedures are a less-invasive alternative to traditional surgery, but the rise of unregulated providers poses concerns.

site_title: Even mainland traders are dumping China mega caps
summary: Mainland Chinese investors have dumped Hong Kong stocks, including technology giants Tencent and Meituan, for the first time since 2018, with net selling of 19 billion yuan in the second half of last year. This has led to a 50% drop in the Hang Seng Tech Index and a 5% decline in the Nasdaq 100 Index. Mainland investors now view these stocks as the least favourite, with only Kuaishou Technology being a favourite in the second half. The selling has also spilled over to US-listed tech stocks, with American depositary receipts of Bilibili slumping 64% in the past year.

site_title: Kazakh president says order mostly restored in the country
summary: Kazakhstan's president, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, says constitutional order has been largely restored in the country after Russia sent troops to quell a nationwide uprising. The uprising, sparked by a fuel price hike, has resulted in dozens of deaths and widespread destruction. Russian paratroopers, part of a collective security force, have been deployed to help restore order. Despite the situation being largely under control, fresh gunshots were heard in Almaty's central square on Friday morning, and the internet remains shut off.

images.alt_text: Demonstrations that began as a response to a fuel price hike have swelled into a broad movement against the government and ex-leader Nursultan Nazarbayev.

site_title: Europe: Stocks plummet from record highs on hawkish Federal Reserve
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.3% from record highs on Thursday, driven by hawkish signals from the US Federal Reserve's December meeting, which raised interest rate expectations and battered technology shares. Despite a slowdown in German inflation, investors remain cautious due to inflation fears and rising interest rates. Banks and insurance stocks were the sole gainers, while the European Central Bank is poised to raise interest rates as early as October.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound as financials gain, James Hardie sinks
summary: Australia's shares rebounded 1.5% on Friday, driven by gains in banking and financials, while tech stocks rose 1.3% after Thursday's 6.4% drop. James Hardie's shares fell 10.8% after ousting CEO Jack Truong for code of conduct breaches. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,468.3, its highest level in 16 months.

site_title: Trump slams Biden speech on Capitol riot as 'political theatre'
summary: US President Joe Biden marked the one-year anniversary of the Capitol riot with a speech, accusing former President Donald Trump of a "web of lies" and a threat to democracy. Trump responded by calling Biden's speech "political theatre" and repeating his claims that the 2020 election was "rigged." Trump also accused Biden of trying to divide America and claimed the election was fraudulent, despite being rejected by multiple states, the Justice Department, and courts.

site_title: J&J says its single dose protects against breakthrough Covid-19 for up to 6 months
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced a real-world study showing its single-shot Covid-19 vaccine protects against breakthrough infections and hospitalizations for up to six months. The study, conducted from January 1 to September 7, 2021, found protection wanes only after four months, compared to two months for two-dose vaccines. The company also reported no waning of protection for ICU admissions. The study covered 168 million people and has not been peer-reviewed.

site_title: Carousell said to be in US$1.5b SPAC talks with L Catterton
summary: Carousell, an online classifieds marketplace operator, is in talks with L Catterton Asia Acquisition, a US-listed SPAC, to go public through a potential $1.5 billion merger. The deal could include a private investment in public equity (PIPE) worth a few hundred million dollars. Carousell, founded in 2012, has expanded to 8 markets across South-east Asia and counts prominent investors such as Telenor Group and Sequoia Capital India. The SPAC, backed by L Catterton and luxury goods firm LVMH, aims to carry out due diligence on Carousell over the coming weeks.

site_title: New York Times to buy sports news site The Athletic
summary: The New York Times is set to acquire sports news website The Athletic for $550 million, aiming to expand its global sports journalism presence. Founded in 2016, The Athletic has grown rapidly with 1.2 million subscribers, but has struggled to reach profitability. The acquisition is part of The New York Times' diversification drive, with the goal of reaching 10 million subscribers. The Athletic will become an independent subsidiary, with its founders staying on as co-presidents.

site_title: Malaysia workers seek judicial review of Supermax deal to supply UK health service
summary: Malaysian glove maker Supermax will seek a judicial review of the UK's decision to award it a framework agreement to supply personal protective equipment to the National Health Service (NHS) due to concerns over forced labor allegations. The decision comes after US Customs and Border Protection banned imports from Supermax and Canada put on hold its contract due to similar concerns. Supermax has announced a new foreign worker management policy and enhanced human resources policies in response to the allegations. A judicial review is expected to be filed at London's High Court.

site_title: E3 video game expo to not be held in person amid Covid-19 risks
summary: The Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) will not be held in person in 2022 due to ongoing health risks surrounding Covid-19, according to the Entertainment Software Association (ESA). This decision comes as the US experiences a surge in Covid-19 cases, with a record 1 million infections reported in 24 hours and a 540,000 new cases per 7-day average. The move follows other cancelled or postponed in-person events, including CES, the Grammy Awards, and the Sundance Film Festival.

images.alt_text: The Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3), a globally renowned event for video games, technology and computers, will not be held in person this year amid fears around Covid-19, its operator said on Thursday.

site_title: Kazakhstan unrest upends Bitcoin mining
summary: Violent protests in Kazakhstan led to internet shutdowns, disrupting major cryptocurrency mining operations in the country. The unrest, sparked by fuel price surges, raises risks and costs for mining groups, potentially leading them to move away. Kazakhstan, which has become a popular alternative to China for cryptocurrency mining due to cheap power, now faces uncertainty. The country's energy grid is taxed by the mining activity, and the government's growing wariness of crypto mining could further exacerbate the issue. The disruptions have also led to a decline in Bitcoin's price.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q4 profit jumps on server chip demand, foundry margins
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 52% year-over-year increase in fourth-quarter operating profit, reaching 13.8 trillion won (S$15.6 billion), its highest in 4 years. Strong demand for server memory chips and higher margins in chip contract manufacturing drove the growth. Revenue likely rose 23% to 76 trillion won, despite a drop in memory chip prices. The company attributed the missed estimate to costs such as employee bonuses and marketing expenses. Samsung is set to release detailed earnings later this month.

site_title: Mozilla Foundation backtracks on accepting crypto after backlash
summary: Mozilla Foundation has temporarily stopped accepting cryptocurrency donations to its BitPay platform following a backlash from users, including co-founder Jamie Zawinski, who criticized the decision as "planet-incinerating Ponzi grifters" due to environmental concerns. The move comes after similar backlash from other companies, such as Kickstarter and Discord, over their plans related to cryptocurrencies. Mozilla had initially solicited cryptocurrency donations in a Twitter appeal, but has since reevaluated its stance on climate and sustainability.

site_title: Tesla's cameras-only autonomous system stirs controversy
summary: Tesla's reliance on cameras and artificial intelligence for its autonomous driving system has sparked controversy, with many experts questioning its effectiveness. A demonstration at CES showed a Tesla car failing to stop in time when a child's silhouette was placed in its path, while a car with lidar technology stopped safely. Experts argue that combining cameras with other systems, such as lidars and radars, is more reliable, and that Tesla's approach may have plateaued. Regulators may favor systems built around redundancy, citing the current limitations of camera-only autonomous systems.

site_title: OCBC to continue with physical tokens as it weighs fraud risks to customers
summary: OCBC is halting its plan to phase out physical hardware tokens for two-factor authentication on its online banking platform due to a sharp rise in online fraud involving the bank. The move comes after nearly 470 people lost S$8.5 million in SMS phishing scams impersonating the bank since December. OCBC will continue to enable customers to use hardware tokens and is working with the police on the incident. This decision reverses the bank's previous plan to phase out physical tokens by March 2022.

site_title: UK identifies rare case of avian flu in a human
summary: UK health officials have identified a rare case of avian flu in a human, the first time the virus has been transmitted from birds to people in the country. The infected individual, in south-west England, acquired the infection from close contact with infected birds kept at home. The individual is self-isolating and there is no evidence of onward spread. The risk to the wider public remains "very low," but officials caution against touching sick or dead birds. This case highlights concerns about the spread of the virus, particularly with wild birds migrating from Europe during winter months.

site_title: Australia's most populous state to reinstate some Covid-19 curbs: report
summary: Australia's New South Wales state will reinstate COVID-19 restrictions, including shutting nightclubs and cancelling non-urgent surgeries, due to record coronavirus infections. The measures, expected to be approved by the state government, will include capacity limits for cafes and restaurants, and bans on singing and dancing at pubs. The move comes as the state struggles with a surge in cases, with nearly 1,609 people admitted to hospitals with COVID-19 in just over a week. The restrictions will be branded as safety measures rather than a lockdown.

site_title: GameStop plans to launch an NFT marketplace
summary: GameStop plans to launch an NFT marketplace by the end of the year, sending its shares soaring in extended trading. The company is in talks with crypto and blockchain companies about which tokens to use and is discussing funds to invest in NFT content creators and gaming companies. A team of over 20 people has been assembled to focus on crypto-related efforts. This move follows GameStop's efforts to shift focus from brick-and-mortar shops to digital sales. The company's shares jumped 29% in extended trading, following a 700% increase last year.

site_title: Gold edges higher as WHO categorises Omicron as not 'mild'
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,791.73 per ounce, hovering near a 2-week low, after the WHO categorised the Omicron variant as not "mild". This move, combined with higher US interest rates, capped gold's gains. The metal is sensitive to rising yields, which increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Gold's decline was expected, with a 2% weekly fall, as traders anticipate a 70% chance of a 25-basis-point rate hike at the March Fed meeting.

images.alt_text: Gold inched up on Friday (Jan 7), hovering close to a 2-week low hit in the previous session, after the chief of the World Health Organization (WHO) said the Omicron variant cannot be considered "mild", while stronger yields capped bullion's gains.

site_title: Art makes a roaring return
summary: Singapore Art Week 2022 features 130 art shows across the island, with 600 artists from around the world participating. Despite the pandemic, the event celebrates its 10th year with a diverse lineup of international and local artists. The week includes various events, such as the Light To Night Festival, Horizons virtual program, and SEA Focus art fair, which explores themes like intergenerational connections, technology, and blockchain. Local artists have benefited from travel restrictions, while others feel it's crucial to connect with the global art world.

site_title: US to revise Singapore travel advisory after Covid data flap
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is revising its travel advisory for Singapore after a data flap regarding the country's Covid-19 testing data. The CDC had previously reclassified its advisory due to a lack of testing findings, but Singapore has since shared its virus statistics, showing a low and stable incidence of Covid-19. The CDC is working with Singapore's Ministry of Health to update its Travel Health Notice, following a statement from Health Minister Ong Ye Kung that Singapore's situation is "very well understood".

site_title: iFast to acquire 85% stake in UK-incorporated BFC Bank for £40m
summary: iFast Corporation, a wealth management platform, is acquiring an 85% stake in UK-incorporated BFC Bank for £40m (S$73.4m). The acquisition aims to enhance iFast's fintech ecosystem, grow its customer base, and meet its target of S$100 billion in assets under administration by 2028. Despite initial startup losses, iFast expects robust growth in profitability from its ePension division in Hong Kong and plans to expand globally, starting with the UK. The deal will be funded by internal resources, bank borrowings, and fundraising.

site_title: Stocks to watch: First Reit, SLB Development, Lian Beng
summary: First Reit recommended unitholders to vote in favor of a proposed acquisition of 12 Japan nursing homes and a S$30.6 million settlement for cancelled works. SLB Development anticipates a "significant" year-on-year increase in net profit for H1 2022 due to substantial unit sales. Lian Beng Group expects its overall performance for the half-year to be lower than the previous year due to pandemic challenges. Trading halts were called for iFast, Advanced Holdings, Nordic Group, and Starburst Holdings pending announcements.

site_title: Omicron pushes UK services PMI to 10-month low: IHS Markit
summary: The UK services sector experienced its largest loss of momentum in 10 months in December, with the IHS Markit/CIPS services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 53.6 from 58.5 in November. The Omicron variant led to cancellations of bookings in the hospitality industry, resulting in a slump in consumer spending on travel, leisure, and entertainment. Economists predict a further decline in GDP in January, with some forecasting a 0.6% fall, as supply bottlenecks worsen and inflation rises.

site_title: Drinks on the house
summary: A couple, Lendl Chong and Karen Tan, have converted their 893 sq ft apartment in Jalan Besar into a unique space for entertaining, with a fully-equipped bar on the second floor. The bar features a T-tower font for dispensing fresh beer brewed by Chong, who also takes beer brewing classes. The apartment's compact design has required creative solutions, such as converting the former kitchen into the master bedroom and utilizing the staircase landing with a mirror and sofa. The bar is the main attraction, with three fridges and fancy equipment, and is often used for late-night gatherings within the household visitor limit.

site_title: Guardiola tests positive amid Man City Covid outbreak but FA Cup ties unaffected
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola has tested positive for Covid-19 amid a major outbreak at the Premier League leaders, with 21 players and staff isolating. Despite this, all 32 FA Cup third-round ties, including City's match against Swindon, are set to proceed. Guardiola's assistant, Rodolfo Borrell, will take charge of the team, while Burnley manager Sean Dyche has also been sidelined by the virus. The outbreak is attributed to the Omicron variant, which has resulted in record case numbers across Britain.

site_title: Rise in takeaways a boon for Singapore's F&B industry
summary: Singapore's food and beverage industry has seen a rise in takeaways, with over 50% of customers opting for this option, despite lower dine-in numbers. This trend is financially beneficial for the industry, with higher profit margins for takeaway orders. However, customer satisfaction with takeaway orders is lower than with delivery orders, particularly in areas such as menu ease of understanding and ordering processes. To improve takeaway business, restaurant operators should focus on simplifying their menu, ordering process, and reducing waiting times.

site_title: China is not trapping Africa in debt: foreign minister
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi rejected suggestions that Beijing is luring African countries into debt traps with massive loans, calling the idea a "narrative" pushed by opponents to poverty reduction. Wang said China's lending is "mutually benefiting" and not a strategy to extract concessions. China is Africa's largest trading partner, with over $200 billion in direct trade in 2019, and has funded costly infrastructure projects in Kenya, including a $5 billion railway loan. Observers have raised concerns about Kenya's reliance on Chinese funding, warning of soaring debt levels.

images.alt_text: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Thursday rejected suggestions that Beijing was luring African countries into debt traps by offering them massive loans, dismissing the idea as a "narrative" pushed by opponents to poverty reduction.

site_title: NTUC Income to corporatise in an attempt to sharpen its competitive edge
summary: NTUC Income, a Singaporean insurer, plans to corporatize in an effort to sharpen its competitive edge. The move will not affect current policyholders or business operations, and employees can expect more career growth opportunities. The insurer aims to expand its regional presence and become more tech-enabled to appeal to a younger client base. This strategic move may also prepare the company for a potential sale, as its current status as a social enterprise may limit its appeal. The corporatization is part of NTUC Income's ambitious growth trajectory.

site_title: Artisanal wagyu comes to Singapore
summary: A new wagyu importer, Mitsu Boshi, has been granted exclusive rights to supply prized Matsusaka beef in Singapore, a rare export from Japan. Founded by veteran meat businessman Mark Foo, the company aims to bring high-quality Matsusaka beef to Singapore through an online shop and a dine-in concept set to launch in May or June. Matsusaka beef is considered one of the top three wagyu brands, alongside Kobe and Omi, and is known for its rich flavor and smooth texture. The company's online shop has already gained popularity among enthusiasts willing to pay top dollar for premium beef.

site_title: A rare complication
summary: Vacheron Constantin has introduced the Traditionnelle Complete Calendar Openface, a rare triple calendar complication watch. The watch features a 41mm 18K white gold case, apertures for day and month, and a central hand for date display. The model also includes a moonphase, which requires only one correction every 122 years. The watch's movement features an anthracite finish and a sleek, open-worked sapphire-crystal dial. The Traditionnelle Complete Calendar Openface is priced at US$47,300 and is a signature timepiece for the luxury watch brand, which has been producing high-quality timepieces for 267 years.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as market weighs Federal Reserve shift
summary: US stocks declined modestly on Thursday as markets digested mixed economic data and concerns over tightening Federal Reserve monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 0.1% each. The 10-year US Treasury yield pushed higher towards 2% amid expectations of higher interest rates and faster bond reductions. Investors await Friday's monthly government jobs report, which is expected to show a 440,000 job gain and a 4.1% unemployment rate.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished modestly lower on Thursday after a choppy session as markets digested mixed economic data and amid concerns over tightening Federal Reserve monetary policy.

site_title: Oil extends rally on Kazakhstan unrest and Libyan outages
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, extending their rally, due to escalating unrest in Kazakhstan and supply outages in Libya. Brent crude futures rose to $81.99 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained to $79.46. Russia sent paratroopers to Kazakhstan to quell the uprising, but oil production remains unaffected. Libya's oil output is at 729,000 barrels per day, down from a high of 1.3 million barrels per day last year. Despite Opec+ sticking to its output target, analysts say the market is bullish, with prices expected to average $88 a barrel in 2022.

site_title: China says stable economy is 'crucial' political issue in 2022
summary: China's executive vice-minister Han Wenxiu emphasizes the importance of a stable economy ahead of the Communist Party's twice-a-decade meeting in 2022. He urges policymakers to implement supportive policies while being cautious of contraction, accelerating fiscal spending and prioritizing infrastructure development. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address economic concerns.

site_title: 9 noteworthy cars for 2022
summary: The 2022 car market is expected to accelerate the electric revolution in Singapore, with several notable models set to launch. Audi's e-tron S, BMW's 2 Series Coupe and i7, Ferrari's 296 GTB, Mercedes-EQ EQS, Range Rover, Porsche 718 Cayman GT4 RS, and Kia EV6 are among the exciting electric and hybrid vehicles to look out for this year. These cars showcase the increasing use of battery power in performance vehicles and the shift away from combustion engines, with many manufacturers aiming to electrify their lineups in the coming years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SLB Development anticipates a significant year-over-year increase in net profit for H1 2022 due to substantial sales of units in its projects. Its parent company, Lian Beng Group, expects lower performance for the half-year due to ongoing construction challenges. Meanwhile, KS Energy has entered an agreement to transfer its listing status to logistics firm Jacobson Global Logistics for S$3 million. First Reit's independent directors recommend unitholders vote in favor of acquiring 12 nursing homes in Japan and a S$30.6 million settlement.

site_title: Investors brace for quantitative tightening as Fed sends hawkish message
summary: The US Federal Reserve has sent a hawkish message, sparking investors to brace for quantitative tightening. Minutes from the December meeting revealed officials discussed shrinking the central bank's asset holdings and raising interest rates to combat inflation, with a faster pace of balance sheet reduction expected. This move is expected to have a significant impact on the markets, with investors adjusting their expectations for interest rates and economic growth.

site_title: Dollar steadies as boost from Fed hike expectation fades
summary: The US dollar stabilized after reaching a 14-month high due to the fading of expectations from the Federal Reserve's December policy meeting minutes, which hinted at a potential rate hike as early as March. The minutes showed officials discussing reducing the Fed's asset holdings and raising interest rates sooner to combat inflation. This boost in expectations had previously driven the dollar's climb.

site_title: A record 4.5 million Americans quit their jobs in November
summary: The US labor market experienced a record 4.5 million job quits in November, with the quits rate reaching 3%, its highest level since 2000. Openings remained elevated, falling to 10.6 million from 11.1 million in October. This suggests a struggle for employers to retain talent, but also indicates some progress in filling vacancies.

site_title: Bonus hike of 30% to 50% for investment bankers seen likely
summary: Singapore's debt capital market (DCM) underwriting fees surged 87.6% to US$182.6 million in 2021, with primary bond offerings from Singapore-domiciled issuers reaching a record US$45 billion this year. DBS topped the DCM league table, accounting for 16% of market share.

site_title: DWS, Hines poised to buy ramp-up industrial building for S$93.8m
summary: DWS Group and Hines are set to buy a 9-storey industrial building in Bukit Batok for S$93.8 million, with a price of S$248 per square foot on net lettable area. The property, known as Bukit Batok Connection, is being sold by the Soilbuild Business Space Reit, which was privatized last year. This deal is part of the growing trend of industrial property investments in Singapore.

site_title: German industrial orders bounce back on strong foreign demand
summary: German industrial orders rebounded 3.7% in November, driven by strong foreign demand, exceeding analyst expectations. Orders from the eurozone rose 13.1% and those from non-eurozone countries increased 5%. Despite delivery bottlenecks, the upturn in foreign business is encouraging, and economic institutes expect the German economy to stagnate in the first half of 2022. The government's green energy plans and digitization efforts are expected to boost business prospects for industrial machinery manufacturers in the medium term.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase moderately
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose 7,000 to 207,000 for the week ended Jan 1, with economists forecasting 197,000 applications. The increase is attributed to disruptions from soaring Covid-19 infections, which may impact the labor market. Despite this, the labor market is tightening, with claims declining from a record high in early April 2020. The Federal Reserve views the labor market as "very tight," potentially leading to interest rate hikes and asset reductions to tame inflation.

site_title: Third-party logistics game getting trickier
summary: Third-party logistics firms face increasing competition and pressure to expand their services beyond just delivery. Amid the COVID-19 pandemic surge in demand, these companies must adapt to meet merchants' evolving needs, including offering more than just delivery services. To stay ahead, some logistics players have had to upgrade their capabilities to move up the value chain, indicating a shift towards a more comprehensive and service-centric approach.

site_title: Brokers' Take: Steep valuation discount of Singapore property plays 'too good to ignore', says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research recommends accumulating on the price weakness of Singapore's property market, citing a steep valuation discount of 0.55 times price to net asset value, a multi-year low. Analysts believe the market has already priced in cooling measures, with developers' price to NAV multiples below trough levels seen in past recessions. Strong pre-sale trends are expected to shield developers from potential risks, and the sector is likely to trade in line with the Straits Times Index.

site_title: The corporate culture conundrum: board leadership and the trust compact
summary: A corporate culture conundrum exists, with scandals like Archegos Capital Management's collapse highlighting the impact of organisational culture on risk profiles. Despite founder Bill Hwang's insider trading ban, the hedge fund accumulated leveraged positions, leading to a $4.7 billion loss for Credit Suisse. The incident led to CEO and Chief Risk Officer departures, executive board bonus forfeitures, and Chairman Urs Rohner waiving chairmanship fees. This incident underscores the importance of effective board leadership and a trust compact in maintaining ethical conduct and mitigating risk.

site_title: Pound dips on US dollar strength; UK service PMIs hit 10-month low
summary: The pound dipped 0.1% against the US dollar and 0.2% against the euro due to the US dollar's strength, as investors weighed the impact of easing Omicron fears on the UK economy. The services PMI index fell to a 10-month low, showing a loss of momentum in Britain's services sector. Analysts differ on the outlook, with one predicting a possible decline in the euro-sterling exchange rate and another warning of risks to the UK economy.

site_title: US trade deficit widens as imports surge to a record
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a record $80.2 billion in November, driven by a surge in imports to $304.4 billion and exports of $224.2 billion. The increase was attributed to retailers stocking up for holiday shoppers and rising demand for foreign oil. Despite a stronger US dollar, which eased import costs, supply chains remain challenging and lean inventories make it difficult for US producers to meet demand. This is the largest trade deficit since records began in 1947.

site_title: US attorney general vows to pursue Jan 6 inquiry 'at any level'
summary: US Attorney General Merrick Garland vowed to pursue accountability for those responsible for the January 6 Capitol riot, including former President Donald Trump. Garland stated he would defend democratic institutions from attack and threats of violence. The Justice Department will hold all perpetrators "at any level" accountable, regardless of their involvement. Garland's comments come amid criticism from Democrats and some Republicans for not holding Trump accountable for his role in inspiring the riot.

site_title: The pandemic might not boost inequality
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic initially seemed to exacerbate inequality, particularly among unskilled workers and minorities, with job losses concentrated in sectors with high proportions of female workers. However, a two-year analysis reveals that government support, including direct financial assistance and short-term schemes, largely offset the impact of job losses on people's income in most developed countries. This suggests that the pandemic may not have increased inequality as expected, and that targeted government support can mitigate its effects.

site_title: US: Wall St falls as tech stocks weaken on hawkish Fed minutes; cyclicals rise
summary: US stocks fell in choppy trading on Thursday as minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting showed a hawkish tone, pushing down tech stocks and boosting economy-sensitive sectors. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. Technology and consumer discretionary sectors fell over 1% each, while value-oriented energy, financials, and industrials rose. The S&P 500 closed lower, with the Nasdaq also falling.

site_title: Vertex, Tikehau blank-cheque vehicles lodge prospectuses
summary: Two blank-cheque vehicles, Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation (VTAC) and Pegasus Asia, have lodged prospectuses to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). VTAC, backed by Temasek, is offering 11.8 million units at S$5 per unit, while Pegasus Asia is offering 25.6 million units at the same price. Both companies aim to be the first SPAC listing on SGX, which could boost the exchange's IPO activities. The listing of SPACs in Singapore could provide a boost to SGX, following a framework introduced last September.

site_title: 813 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; weekly infection growth rate rises to 1.5
summary: Singapore reported 813 new Covid-19 cases, with a weekly infection growth rate of 1.5, up from 1.28 the previous day. The cases include 390 imported, 404 community, and 19 in migrant worker dorms. The total number of cases in Singapore is now 283,214. One new death was reported, bringing the total to 835. As of Thursday, 91% of Singapore's eligible population have completed their full vaccination regimen, and 44% have received their vaccine booster shots.

site_title: Farm-to-table wagyu
summary: A lack of transparency in the supply chain of Wagyu beef is a common issue, with many restaurants unable to provide information about the farmer or rearing process. According to Shuo Koh, director of Responsible Food, the supply chain involves multiple stakeholders, making it difficult to track the origin of the beef. This lack of transparency can make it challenging for consumers to make informed choices about the products they buy.

site_title: Indonesia revokes thousands of mining, coal permits
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo revoked 2,078 mining and coal permits and 193 forestry permits due to companies' failure to provide work plans or misuse of permits. The move aims to rein in the country's vast resources sector, which includes 17 billion tonnes of coal reserves and Asia's largest tropical forest area. The government also threatened to revoke power producers' licenses if they don't meet domestic electricity generator supply obligations. The revocation comes amid a coal crisis sparked by the ban on overseas shipments.

site_title: US: Stocks stage rebound as bonds remain elevated
summary: US stocks rebounded 0.3% on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 indices gaining 0.3% and 0.4% respectively, after investors took pause on tightening monetary policy concerns. Treasury yields rose, while the US dollar and yen fluctuated. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was little changed. The rebound came despite concerns over US-China trade tensions and split views on the Federal Reserve's policy direction.

site_title: German inflation slows, bolstering ECB case for surge to ease
summary: German inflation slowed to 5.7% in December, down from 6% the previous month, supporting the European Central Bank's case for easing interest rates. This slowdown, driven by easing energy costs, follows signs that price pressures in the euro area are abating. Economists predict further easing of inflation in the first half of 2023, with some forecasting it to stay above 2% until 2024.

site_title: SLB expects 'significant' rise in H1 profit; parent Lian Beng still weighed by construction challenges
summary: SLB Development, a property player, expects a "significant" year-on-year increase in net profit for H1 2022 due to substantial sales of units in its projects. The company's key projects include industrial building Inspace and residential developments Affinity @ Serangoon and Riverfront Residences. Despite parent company Lian Beng still facing construction challenges, SLB's forecast is largely driven by the recognition of contributions from construction progressed. The exact profit increase is not specified, but the company's announcement suggests a positive outlook for the half-yearly period.

site_title: Biden's shots-for-millions rule hinges on supreme court showdown
summary: The US Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on President Joe Biden's vaccination rules, which require 80 million workers to get vaccinated or regularly test, and shots for workers in facilities receiving government healthcare funds. Business groups and Republican-led states claim the rules would cost billions and violate state sovereignty. The rules aim to increase the country's vaccination rate amid the Omicron variant surge, with the CDC stating only 62% of the country is fully vaccinated and 35% have received a booster shot. The outcome will determine the fate of Biden's plan to combat the pandemic.

site_title: TPG executives to pocket potential US$1.4b tax windfall after IPO
summary: TPG executives will receive an estimated $1.44 billion in tax benefits from the firm's initial public offering (IPO), which they will share with founders David Bonderman and Jim Coulter. Under a tax receivable agreement, TPG will pay 85% of the tax savings to its top dealmakers, with the remaining 15% valued at $1.4 billion. This payout is expected to significantly impact TPG's cash position and could result in a material negative effect. The arrangement has been criticized for stripping public shareholders of value, and experts warn that investors may not fully understand the implications of the tax benefits.

site_title: Google, Facebook fined for cookie breaches
summary: France's data privacy watchdog CNIL fined Google 150 million euros and Facebook 60 million euros for making it difficult for internet users to refuse online trackers, known as cookies. The companies must provide simpler tools for users to refuse cookies and guarantee their consent. The fines, which can increase to 100,000 euros per day of delay, are part of a 3-month compliance period. Both companies have committed to further changes to protect users' rights to privacy and trust.

site_title: Malaysia's top anti-graft official to cooperate with regulator after share trading allegations
summary: Malaysia's top anti-graft official, Azam Baki, will cooperate with the country's securities regulator after being asked to explain allegations that he owned millions of shares in public listed companies in 2015 and 2016. Azam stated that his share trading account was used by his brother, and he had no interest or benefit in the shares purchased. An advisory board found no criminal conduct or conflict of interest on Azam's part, but the Securities Commission will verify statements and gather evidence.

site_title: First Reit independent directors recommend green-lighting Japan nursing home purchase
summary: First Reit's independent directors recommend that unitholders vote in favor of acquiring 12 nursing homes in Japan from OUE Lippo Healthcare for S$30.6 million and a separate S$30.6 million settlement for cancelled works in Indonesia. The acquisition and settlement are on normal commercial terms, according to independent financial advisor Stirling Coleman Capital. The independent directors and audit and risk committee have recommended unitholders vote for the four resolutions related to the Japan expansion and the settlement. The proposed unit issue price of S$0.305 per unit is considered fair and reasonable.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase moderately
summary: US jobless claims rose 7,000 to 207,000 for the week ended Jan 1, exceeding economists' forecast of 197,000. The increase is attributed to disruptions from soaring Covid-19 infections, with some businesses temporarily closing and forcing workers to file for unemployment. Despite this, the labor market is tightening, with claims declining from a record high in early April 2020. The Federal Reserve views the labor market as "very tight," potentially leading to interest rate hikes to tame inflation.

site_title: Teochew highs and lows at San Shu Gong
summary: San Shu Gong, a Teochew restaurant in Geylang, Singapore, offers a mixed dining experience with strong dishes amidst some mediocre ones. The eatery caters to a high-end crowd who enjoy upscale, all-you-can-drink dining in an air-conditioned environment. The restaurant's unique atmosphere and generous drinks policy make it a popular choice for those who want to indulge in Teochew cuisine without breaking the bank. Despite its flaws, San Shu Gong remains a popular spot for those seeking an elevated dining experience.

site_title: Personal data of OG department store customers leaked
summary: OG department store in Singapore has reported a data breach, exposing personal data of affected customers including names, mobile numbers, and dates of birth. The breach occurred when an external third-party membership portal service provider's database was compromised. OG notified members on Tuesday and is conducting preliminary investigations. The data breach affects OG members in basic or gold tiers, but no other details on the scope or cause of the breach have been disclosed.

site_title: Why Brexit is only getting started 1 year on
summary: One year after the UK-EU trade deal, the process of Brexit is far from complete, with key gaps still to be filled and tensions between the two sides running high. The deal, struck in just 8 months, has triggered 12 months of turmoil, including disputes over fishing licenses, vaccine exports, and the introduction of new trade barriers. Public opinion is increasingly negative, with over 60% of voters believing Brexit has gone badly. The UK's departure from the EU has also led to a shift towards greater federalism in the EU, with potential implications for the UK's unity and territorial integrity.

images.alt_text: Brexit has exacerbated tensions over the UK's unity, including putting Northern Ireland at the forefront of UK politics in a way it had not been for a generation.

site_title: KS Energy enters agreement to transfer listing status to Singapore logistics company
summary: KS Energy, a judicially managed mainboard-listed company, has entered an agreement to transfer its listing status to Singapore logistics company Jacobson Global Logistics for S$3 million. The deal aims to provide potentially better returns for shareholders, as liquidating KS Energy's assets may not yield significant value. This is the second attempt by a judicially managed company to transfer its listing status, with previous attempts by Technics Oil and Gas and China Great Land Holdings resulting in termination or delisting. KS Energy will issue further details to shareholders and creditors in due course.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares drop 2.8% as Fed hints at tightening
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 2.8% on Thursday as investors anticipated the US Federal Reserve's potential early tightening of monetary policy. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 844.29 points to 28,487.87, while the Topix index fell 42.26 points to 1,997.01. This rekindled speculation, despite other markets showing resilience, such as the STI's 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 0.72% to 23,072.86, driven by tech firms benefiting from bargain-buying. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, albeit smaller. The gains came after a late rally, with investors showing resilience despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China property tax trial likely delayed during real estate slump
summary: China's planned property tax trials may be delayed due to the country's real estate slump, with analysts citing a lack of a detailed implementation plan and opposition from homeowners and developers. The trials were initially set to begin by the end of 2021, but experts now expect a market uptick before the government proceeds. Despite this, officials remain determined to launch the trials, with some analysts predicting a possible recovery in the market by the first half of this year, which could lead to a delay in the tax trials.

site_title: Tencent-backed Tuhu to move planned US IPO to Hong Kong
summary: Tuhu, a Chinese online car-services platform backed by Goldman Sachs and Tencent Holdings, is shifting its proposed US IPO to Hong Kong, citing data security concerns and better risk disclosures in the Asian financial hub. The startup could raise US$300-400 million this year. Tuhu joins other Chinese companies, such as Lalamove and Meicai, that have rerouted their IPOs to Hong Kong. The move comes after Beijing cracked down on overseas listings.

site_title: Digital asset tech company Sygnum crosses S$1b valuation with S$120m in Series B funds
summary: Sygnum, a digital asset technology company, has raised S$120 million in an oversubscribed Series B funding round, valuing the company at over S$1 billion. The funding boost comes after a 10-fold increase in consolidated gross revenues in 2021 and a growth in assets under administration to over S$3 billion. The company plans to use the funds to develop new institutional-grade services and expand into new global markets, with a focus on Web 3.0 technologies. Sygnum's co-founders and management team continue to hold majority ownership of the company.

site_title: Vietnam car maker VinFast to build US battery factory as it goes all-electric
summary: Vietnam's VinFast plans to build a US battery factory to support its transition to all-electric vehicle production by the end of 2022. The company aims to become the first car company to cease making petrol-powered cars and transition to all-electric vehicle production. VinFast will initially source batteries from suppliers before starting its own production in the US, where it hopes to attract consumers away from Tesla and General Motors. The company plans to initially produce 100,000 battery packs per year with a US$174 million investment.

site_title: Shimao defaults on trust loan, R&F bonds sink
summary: Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, has defaulted on a trust product with 645 million yuan (S$137.6 million) of overdue payment. China Credit Trust demanded early repayment after Shimao failed to meet instalment requirements. Shimao's dollar bonds fell at least 10 cents on the dollar. Meanwhile, Guangzhou R&F Properties' bonds slumped after the developer warned it may struggle to repay a note maturing next week due to liquidity issues.

site_title: Japan's beloved 'Super Dry' beer to get first-ever recipe change
summary: Asahi Group will make its first-ever recipe change to Super Dry beer, a flagship Japanese brew, to improve drinkability and aroma while maintaining crispness. The change, set to launch next month, follows 2 years of reduced alcohol sales and changing consumer tastes due to the pandemic. The revamped formula includes a new design and logo, and comes as Japan's breweries struggle with declining beer sales. The move aims to boost the brand's global ambitions, with CEO Atsushi Katsuki targeting Super Dry to break into the top 10 global brews by 2030.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street drop on Fed rate hike plans
summary: Asia markets fell on Thursday following a Wall Street drop due to expectations of the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Fed minutes showed officials are ready to act, with plans to increase the federal funds rate sooner or at a faster pace than anticipated. This move has rattled markets, particularly tech firms, which are more susceptible to higher borrowing costs, leading to losses in Tokyo, Sydney, and other Asian cities.

site_title: Tikehau's Pegasus Asia lodges prospectus for S$150m SPAC
summary: Pegasus Asia, a Special Purpose Acquisition Company (SPAC) backed by European asset manager Tikehau Capital and its partner Financiere Agache, has lodged a preliminary prospectus with the Monetary Authority of Singapore for a S$150 million listing. The offering includes 25.6 million units at S$5 per unit, with 24.6 million units available for international placement and 1 million units for a public offer in Singapore. The SPAC plans to focus on tech-enabled sectors in Asia-Pacific and has 2 years to complete its business combination with a target company.

site_title: Pan-United to provide sustainable concrete solutions to Vietnam's Novaland
summary: Pan-United Corporation has signed a 2-year cooperation agreement with Novaland Group to provide sustainable concrete solutions. The agreement includes the construction of two on-site batching plants in Vietnam's Dong Nai province, which will supply 700,000 cubic meters of ready-mix concrete to Novaland's Aqua City development. FiCO Pan-United Concrete Joint Stock Company will use carbon-capture technologies to develop high-quality, low-carbon concrete for the project, aiming to contribute to Vietnam's goal of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: Vertex Technology lodges preliminary prospectus for S$200m SPAC
summary: Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation (VTAC), a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) backed by Vertex Ventures, has lodged a preliminary prospectus with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for a S$200m SPAC listing. The offering will include 11.8 million units, with 11.2 million offered to international investors and 600,000 to the public in Singapore. Cornerstone investors have also subscribed for 22.2 million units, with a market capitalization of S$200m expected post-listing.

site_title: Crypto security is biggest concern for institutional investors
summary: Institutional investors are hesitant to invest in cryptocurrencies due to security concerns, with 79% citing asset custody as a key consideration. Volatility, market capitalization, and regulatory environments also play a role. However, respondents are optimistic about the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) gaining more authority to regulate cryptocurrencies, with 76% expecting this to happen this year, and 73% believing it will positively impact crypto prices. This increased regulation could alleviate concerns and potentially boost investment in the space.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.59 points to 1,533.36. Losers outnumbered gainers 618 to 320, and volume reached 2.866 billion lots worth RM1.903 billion.

site_title: Investors brace for quantitative tightening as Fed sends hawkish message
summary: The US Federal Reserve has sent a hawkish message, signaling a potential quantitative tightening and faster interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Minutes from the December meeting revealed officials discussed shrinking the central bank's asset holdings and raising rates sooner than expected. This has bolstered bets on higher yields, weighing on growth and technology shares, and led to a sell-off in these sectors. Investors expect the Fed to reduce its balance sheet and may consider outright balance-sheet reductions to combat inflation, potentially leading to a more aggressive rate hike path.

site_title: STI spared Asia's sell-off with 0.66 % gains to 3,184.30 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.66% higher at 3,184.30 points on Thursday, despite Asian markets closing lower due to the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on interest rates. Banking stocks rose, with UOB, DBS, and OCBC gaining 0.76%, 1.75%, and 0.86% respectively. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) were the main decliners, with 6 out of 7 finishing in the red.

site_title: NTUC Income to corporatise in bid to raise its competitiveness and fuel growth
summary: NTUC Income Insurance Cooperative plans to corporatise, shifting from a cooperative to a corporate entity, to increase competitiveness and raise capital for growth initiatives. The move aims to sharpen Income's competitive edge in the mature domestic market and gain access to strategic growth options. Existing institutional and ordinary members will receive equivalent shares in the new company, and the cooperative will be liquidated. The corporatisation is expected to be completed in the second half of the year, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Baht falls most in a month as Thailand raises Covid alert level
summary: The Thai baht fell 1% to 33.523 per US dollar, its largest decline in a month, after the government raised the Covid-19 alert level to the second-highest category. The move aims to discourage dining, consuming alcohol, and traveling abroad. The currency has lost over 10% in the last 12 months due to the pandemic's impact on the tourism-dependent economy. Analysts predict the baht may regain strength in the first quarter as a potential trade and current-account surplus takes effect, with forecasts of a 34 per US dollar value by the first quarter.

site_title: Myanmar's economy at risk from a likely prolonged civil conflict: Fitch Solutions
summary: Myanmar's economy is at risk from a likely prolonged civil conflict, with Fitch Solutions predicting a protracted conflict that may last years. The country is under a military coup since 2021, and the State Administration Council faces an increasingly organized rival government, the National Unity Government. Internationally, Fitch Solutions expects a more determined effort from ASEAN and the West to support the NUG, with the US passing a defense act that legitimizes the NUG and denies resources to the junta. This may lead to economic hardship, reduced support for the junta, and increased conflict, ultimately prolonging the civil war.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: NTUC Income plans to corporatize to boost competitiveness. The number of HDB flats sold for over $1 million rose to 38 in December 2021, surpassing the previous record. Singapore's unemployment rate declined in November. Investment bankers expect a 30-50% bonus hike due to record M&A activity in Singapore. Japan's Super Dry beer will undergo its first recipe change. The STI gained 0.66% to 3,184.30 points, sparing Asia's sell-off.

site_title: Omicron spreads in India's big cities but hospitalisations still low
summary: India reports 90,928 new Covid-19 cases, mostly from major cities like Delhi, Mumbai, and Kolkata, with the Omicron variant overtaking Delta. Despite the surge, hospitalisations remain low, with most infected showing mild symptoms and recovering quickly at home. The federal health ministry has identified these cities as areas of concern, and state officials worry about the spread to rural areas. The situation is being closely monitored, with health authorities discussing measures to prevent the spread, particularly in the context of upcoming elections.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 5-week low as hawkish Fed lifts US yields, dollar
summary: South Korean shares ended at a 5-week low due to elevated US yields and a firmer dollar, as the Federal Reserve signaled a sooner-than-expected start to rate hikes. The benchmark Kospi closed down 1.13% at 2,920.53, with chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix falling 0.65% and 0.40% respectively. The Korean won weakened to its lowest level in 17 months, and institutional investors sold 5.86 trillion won worth of Kospi shares. Foreigners, however, were net buyers of 182.5 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Aggrieved Laguna noteholders to launch class-action suit against Peter Kwee this month
summary: Over 200 aggrieved debenture holders of Laguna National golf club are launching a class-action suit against the club and its owner Peter Kwee. The suit, valued at S$1.1 million, aims to recover tens of millions of dollars in unpaid debts from the club. Noteholders claim that Kwee had enough funds to redeem the debentures but instead used them to revamp the golf course and build a hotel. The suit will be launched "no later than end January 2022" and will scrutinize Laguna National's books over the last 20 years to uncover any discrepancies.

site_title: Yen at its weakest in 50 years in real terms: JP Morgan
summary: The yen has reached its weakest level in 50 years, with its real effective rate falling to 66.3, according to JP Morgan analysts. The currency's nominal exchange rate against the US dollar has tumbled to a 5-year low of 116.3550, and it's expected to drop further, reducing Japanese consumers' spending power and increasing the risk of capital flight. Analysts predict the yen could reach 119 per dollar if the current correlation between US interest rates and the yen holds, and warn of the risk of unexpectedly high inflation in Japan.

site_title: Japan, Australia sign defence treaty with eyes on China
summary: Japan and Australia signed a landmark defence treaty to strengthen their ties and contribute to regional stability, amid growing concerns over China's military expansion. The treaty, part of the "Quad" grouping, aims to enhance inter-operability and cooperation between their forces. China has cast the move as an attempt to stymie its resurgence, while Japan's defence spending continues to increase. The agreement underscores the momentum of the Quad and follows recent announcements by the US, Britain, and Australia on a new alliance, AUKUS.

site_title: Bishan HDB resale flat hits new record price of S$1.36m; million-dollar deals jump 3 times in 2021
summary: In December 2021, the number of Housing Board (HDB) resale flats sold for at least S$1 million reached a record high of 38, with a 5-room DBSS unit at Bishan's Natura Loft fetching the highest price of S$1.36 million. For the year 2021, there were 261 million-dollar HDB resale transactions, tripling the 82 flats resold in 2020. Despite rising volumes, million-dollar flats still account for a small proportion of total transactions.

site_title: Bitcoin, Ether near multi-month lows following hawkish Federal Reserve minutes
summary: Bitcoin fell below US$43,000, testing multi-month lows, after the Federal Reserve's minutes showed a leaning towards more aggressive policy action. The cryptocurrency lost 1.7% on Thursday, with Ether down 5.2% on Wednesday, touching its lowest level since October. The decline is correlated with traditional asset classes, as institutions trade both crypto and other assets. The Fed's actions have reduced investor appetite for riskier assets, and a break below US$42,000 would make Bitcoin the weakest since September.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank maintains US$379 target for Sea despite 17.3% tumble on Tencent stake sale
summary: Maybank Research maintains its "buy" call and US$379 target price for Sea despite the stock's 17.3% tumble on Tencent's stake sale. Analyst Lai Gene Lih believes the sale is unrelated to fundamentals and that Sea's long-term growth prospects remain unchanged. Lai points to Sea's robust balance sheet, Shopee's top e-commerce position, and potential from Garena Free Fire Max as reasons for his bullish stance.

site_title: Malaysian retailer Senheng targets doubling market share by 2025
summary: Malaysian retailer Senheng New Retail aims to double its market share to 30% by 2025, from 13% in 2020. The company plans to raise RM267.5 million at an offer price of RM1.07 per share, valuing it at RM1.6 billion. Senheng's profit rose 21% to RM34 million in the 9 months ended September, driven by higher sales from its bigger stores. The company plans to upgrade or open 61 stores through 2024, using more than half of the IPO proceeds.

site_title: Tencent's WeChat app keeps growing despite Beijing crackdown
summary: Tencent's WeChat app has defied a government crackdown in China, growing 12.5% in daily active users to 450 million in 2021, and adding 200 million monthly users to its native search function. Despite Beijing's efforts to dismantle closed ecosystems like WeChat, the app has continued to evolve with new features such as download-free lite apps and short-video feeds. WeChat has also started accepting China's digital yuan in its payments service, and its mini-programs have seen significant growth, with over 700 million people accessing Covid-19 services and transactions in Covid-hit sectors doubling.

site_title: Lack of chips to further hit UK car market in 2022: industry group
summary: The UK car market is expected to be further impacted by the global semiconductor chip shortage, which hurt sales in 2021. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) predicts that the shortage will continue to affect the market in 2022 and 2023, with around one in six new cars sold being electric or hybrid vehicles. The SMMT's chief executive, Mike Hawes, stated that demand is still strong but the chip shortage will undermine the market, leading to higher vehicle prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 4.54 points or 0.29%, at 1,543.41. Volume was 239.26 million lots worth RM120.28 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 290 to 106.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower extending US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on January 6, 2022, following a two-day rally, with investors disheartened by US stock falls. The Nikkei 225 index declined 0.65% and the Topix index dropped 0.51%.

site_title: UK to ease English Covid-19 travel curbs as infections hit all-time high
summary: The UK government announced changes to Covid-19 travel rules for England, scrapping pre-departure tests and quarantine on arrival until a negative lateral flow test. This move comes as the country faces a surge in cases due to the Omicron variant. Prime Minister Boris Johnson cited the limited impact of travel curbs on case growth while also easing testing rules for asymptomatic individuals. The changes, effective from Friday, aim to balance the need to control the virus with the economic impact on the travel industry.
