The rally was fueled by concerns that the Omicron variant might be less severe than initially feared. This marks the second consecutive session at a record high.

site_title: US CDC backs previous advice for 5-day isolation; no test needed
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has backed its previous guidance of a 5-day isolation period for Covid-19, allowing individuals to take a rapid antigen test if they want and can access one. The agency cited a review of 113 studies showing most transmission occurs early in the course of infection, between 2-3 days before and 8 days after symptom onset. Individuals who test negative after 5 days should still wear masks and be cautious around others.

site_title: The success of destructive vaccine politics
summary: The US failed to effectively distribute Covid-19 vaccines due to the power of politically motivated lies. Key lies repeated by Republican politicians and right-wing media include the claim that Covid is no big deal, vaccination is ineffective, and vaccination is a personal choice. These claims undermined the vaccination campaign and hindered the Biden administration's efforts to end the pandemic. Despite the persistence of Covid, the anti-vaccine strategy has worked politically for Republicans, who have successfully blamed Biden for failing to end the pandemic.

site_title: US snowstorm strands drivers for 24 hours or more
summary: A severe snowstorm in the US has stranded drivers on a major highway outside Washington for 24 hours or more, with some reporting being stuck for 27 hours. The icy conditions on I-95 in Virginia led to a massive traffic jam, with drivers running out of gas and experiencing extreme cold. US Senator Tim Kaine and journalist Jim DeFede were among those stranded, with DeFede describing the highway as an "icy parking lot" with no signs of rescue. The Virginia department of transport reported that only 19 vehicles remained stranded, and plow trains were expected to clear the road soon.

site_title: Investment opportunities in the metaverse
summary: The metaverse, a digital world envisioned by Neal Stephenson in his 1992 novel Snow Crash, is poised to become a reality. With technological advancements, social media, remote work, and video gaming driving its growth, the metaverse will soon rival the physical world. The term "metaverse" combines "meta" (beyond) and "verse" (universe), signifying a vast digital universe where people will live, work, and play.

site_title: The golden thread running through sustainability
summary: Sound corporate governance is a crucial aspect of sustainability policies, often overlooked in favor of environmental and social considerations. The term "ESG" (environmental, social, and governance) was first coined in a 2004 UN study, aiming to connect financial markets to a changing world. Effective governance is essential for addressing environmental and social challenges, and its neglect can have severe consequences. Strong corporate governance structures and accountability mechanisms are necessary to ensure sustainable practices and responsible business operations.

site_title: 3 corporate bond sectors hold promise for 2022
summary: Market forecasters predict a bumpy road for bonds in 2022 due to high interest rate expectations. However, three sectors are expected to hold promise: short-term bonds, high-yielding bank instruments, and high-quality Chinese corporate debt. Rising interest rates are a signal of economic growth, and companies are seeing healthy cash flows. Investors should focus on active portfolio management strategies and consider diversification opportunities in these sectors, which may provide positive returns despite the expected rate hikes.

site_title: Blow for Macron's party as opposition holds up Covid bill
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's centrist party suffered a blow as opposition parties joined forces to block a Covid-19 health pass bill, requiring a full vaccination course for events and travel. The bill's implementation was halted after the right-wing Republicans teamed up with far-right and far-left parties to stop the debate. The National Assembly's lower house rejected the bill, leaving Macron's party red-faced. This setback comes at a time when Macron's government is facing growing opposition and criticism over its handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell, Brainard to get Senate hearings next week; Biden promises diversity
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will appear before the Senate Banking Committee on January 11 to consider his renomination for a second four-year term. President Biden is also set to hold hearings for Fed Governor Lael Brainard's nomination as vice chair and potential picks for three other Fed Board seats, prioritizing diversity. If confirmed, the Fed Board would be more diverse than ever, with at least one Black economist and a Black female member. Biden's selections aim to address the Fed's historical lack of diversity.

site_title: New year, new art
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund is hosting an online auction of artworks by talented children aged 13-19, with proceeds going to support underprivileged and troubled homes. The inaugural 13-19 Art Prize concluded with 23 paintings and 11 digital artworks selected as prizewinners, showcasing a range of visions from fantasy-based images to pandemic-era evocations. The artworks will be auctioned online until January 17, with all net proceeds supporting The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: Trump says he is cancelling his Jan 6 news conference
summary: Former US President Donald Trump announced the cancellation of a news conference scheduled for January 6, the one-year anniversary of the US Capitol riot. The event would have marked the anniversary of the storming of the Capitol by Trump's supporters. Trump's decision comes as the nation marks a significant milestone in the aftermath of the 2021 insurrection.

site_title: Another year of bull markets?
summary: The article examines the possibility of a bull market in US stocks in 2022, citing concerns from US and UK index charts. The S&P 500 index's behavior, including a change in trend line and short-term trading bands, indicates trend weakness. The article suggests that the prolonged break in the uptrend line and the setting of downside targets at the trading band's value, rather than the trend line, are early indications of trend weakness. The FTSE 100 is also expected to experience limited upside, with a significant resistance level at 7700.

site_title: Tencent plans to sell a stake in Singapore's Sea for up to US$3b
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to sell up to 14.5 million shares of Sea, a 2.6% stake, at US$208-212 each, aiming to raise up to US$3.1 billion. The offer price is a 6.9% discount to Sea's recent close. The move is part of Tencent's efforts to divest and fund new initiatives, philanthropic efforts, and social responsibility programs. The sale will reduce Tencent's stake in Sea to 18.7%.

site_title: Tesla showroom in China's Xinjiang region blasted by rights groups
summary: US human rights and trade groups have criticized Tesla for opening a showroom in China's Xinjiang region, where detention camps have been criticized for human rights abuses. The Council on American-Islamic Relations called Tesla's move "supporting genocide." Similar criticism came from US Senator Marco Rubio and the Alliance for American Manufacturing. The move has drawn attention to tensions in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.15 points to 1,541.90. Volume reached 3.518 billion lots worth RM1.931 billion. The market saw 524 gainers and 383 losers.

site_title: Singapore PMI ends 2021 on higher note amid overall improving sentiment in Asia
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector ended 2021 with a hopeful note, as the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose 0.1 point to 50.7 in December, marking 18 consecutive months of expansion. This follows a brief dip in the previous month. The improvement in sentiment echoes rising optimism in Asia.

site_title: Fintech startup Brankas raises US$20m Series B funds led by Insignia
summary: Brankas, a Singapore-based fintech startup, has raised US$20 million in Series B funding led by Insignia Ventures Partners. The round was joined by existing backers and new investors, including Visa, to deepen its payments, data, and API product offerings in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. Brankas, founded in 2016, specializes in enabling access to financial and identity data, and has worked with non-bank players to offer open finance solutions. The company now has over 100 staff in 17 countries and plans to double its headcount, with new partnerships in Vietnam and Bangladesh.

site_title: Look, no one manning the bridge: autonomous ships have arrived
summary: Autonomous ships, also known as maritime autonomous ship systems (MASS), have begun to arrive in the industry, with several companies and organizations developing and testing these systems. These ships can be controlled remotely from shore-based centers, reducing the need for crew and potentially lowering carbon emissions. Companies such as Sea Machines Robotics and Ocean Infinity have already demonstrated successful autonomous voyages, with Sea Machines' 1,000+ nautical miles voyage marking a significant milestone. However, there are still significant regulatory and human resource challenges to be addressed before MASS can become widespread.

site_title: Biden doubles US purchase of Pfizer Covid therapeutic pills
summary: President Joe Biden announced a doubling of US government purchases of Pfizer Covid therapeutic pills, increasing the stockpile to 20 million from 10 million pills. The new order aims to reduce hospitalizations and deaths from Covid-19.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished Tuesday slightly higher, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.06% to 23,289.84. The gains were driven by a record on Wall Street, but investors remained cautious due to concerns over Omicron and inflation. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also experienced declines, with the latter losing 0.10%.

site_title: Sembcorp signs 12-year agreement to supply power to Indian state Andhra Pradesh
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a 12-year power purchase agreement to supply 625 megawatts of power to power distribution companies in Andhra Pradesh, India. The power will be generated from Sembcorp Energy's 2.6 gigawatt supercritical power generation facility in Nellore, India. The agreement is expected to commence in 2023 and will ensure optimal utilisation of conventional generation capacity, with 77% of Sembcorp Energy's thermal plant capacity underpinned by long-term power purchase agreements.

images.alt_text: The power supply will be generated from Sembcorp Energy's 2.6 gigawatt supercritical power generation facility in Nellore, India.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow hit record highs
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 hit record highs on Tuesday as concerns over the Omicron variant decreased, with travel stocks experiencing a bounce. Ford gained on positive forecasts for electric pickup production. The Dow Jones was up 182.88 points or 0.50% at 36,767.94, while the S&P 500 rose 13.36 points or 0.28% to 4,809.92.

site_title: STI climbs 1.5% on Wall Street gains; DBS rises to 52-week high
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.5% to 3,181.13 points on Tuesday, driven by Wall Street gains. DBS bank reached a 52-week high of S$33.71 after a 2.81% gain. Decliners included Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT), which fell 5.21% after announcing a merger. The market saw a mixed performance in Asia, with some indices rising and others falling.

site_title: Impact being assessed after fire at Koda's Vietnam factory building
summary: A fire occurred at Koda's factory building in Vietnam's Long An province on Monday, January 3. No casualties were reported, and the company has arranged for affected orders to be produced in other buildings. The affected building, equipment, and inventories are insured, with insurance adjusters assessing the impact. Koda's shares closed flat at S$0.72 on Tuesday. The company has 11 factory buildings in the province, and the incident is being assessed for its impact.

site_title: US manufacturing gauge falls while price pressures ease
summary: US manufacturing gauge fell to 58.7 in December, the lowest level since January 2021, due to declines in delivery times and prices. Despite this, underlying components showed strength, with demand indicators remaining firm. Capacity constraints are loosening, and the sector is expected to continue expanding at a healthy pace. Fifteen industries reported growth, led by apparel, furniture, and textiles, with the government jobs report expected to show 35,000 manufacturing jobs added in December.

site_title: Beijing seals off its Olympic 'bubble'
summary: Beijing has sealed off its Winter Olympic "bubble," a zero-tolerance Covid-19 strategy that restricts thousands of staff, volunteers, and athletes from direct physical access to the outside world. The closed loop, which began on Tuesday, requires daily testing and face masks for everyone inside, with vaccinated individuals allowed to enter without quarantine. The system, set to operate until late March, aims to limit the pandemic's impact on the February 4-20 Winter Olympics and subsequent Paralympics.

site_title: Britons warned of hospital crisis over Omicron surge
summary: The UK is facing a potential hospital crisis due to a surge in Omicron infections, with over 50,000 NHS staff absent from work. Staff shortages are causing strain on the National Health Service, with at least six hospital trusts declaring critical incidents. While hospital admissions have not reached peak levels, the NHS is struggling with staff forced to self-isolate. The government is considering easing restrictions on self-isolation for health staff to alleviate pressure on hospitals.

site_title: Opec+ agrees to 400,000 barrel-a-day increase as market looks tighter
summary: Opec+ has agreed to a 400,000 barrel-a-day production increase in February, aiming to revive halted output and meet growing global demand. The decision follows improved market outlook, with fuel consumption recovering from 2020's collapse and crude inventories dwindling. The alliance, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, expects a smaller supply surplus this quarter than initially predicted, with production to exceed demand by 1.4 million barrels a day in the first three months of the year.

site_title: Your Blackberry dies today; end of an era for iconic handset
summary: BlackBerry has announced that devices running its original operating system and services will no longer be supported after January 4, 2022, effectively ending the era of the iconic handheld device. The move marks the end of a line that remains popular for its reliability and security. BlackBerry stopped making its own smartphones in 2016 and licensed its brand to TCL Communication, which will continue to support its Android-powered devices until August. The end of support will render devices unable to receive updates, limiting functionality.

site_title: BMW claims victory over Mercedes in global luxury-sales race
summary: BMW has claimed victory over Mercedes-Benz in the global luxury-car sales race for the first time since 2015, according to a statement from BMW's head of sales Pieter Nota. The Munich-based automaker delivered 1.7 million BMW-branded vehicles in the first nine months of 2021, exceeding Mercedes-Benz by over 112,000 vehicles. BMW attributes its success to its product lineup and operational performance, while Mercedes-Benz warned of continued semiconductor shortages affecting the industry. BMW will report full-year sales numbers on January 12.

site_title: India's Reliance Jio planning up to US$671m bond sale
summary: Reliance Jio, India's top telecom operator, is planning a record-breaking rupee bond sale of up to US$670.65 million, with a 50 billion rupee note maturing in five years at a 6.20% coupon rate. The company aims to use the proceeds to meet financial liabilities. As the country's largest mobile phone carrier, Jio has 426.6 million wireless subscribers and is set to launch 5G services in India, following its successful bid in the latest airwaves spectrum auctions.

site_title: Gardenia Malaysia shuts one factory for undetermined period amid severe flooding
summary: Gardenia Malaysia has shut down one of its bakery factories due to severe flooding, affecting about 10% of its total supply for FY2022. The factory's inventory and property damage are being assessed, with a total net book value of RM55 million. The company has notified insurers and plans to seek recovery under applicable policies, ramping up production at unaffected factories to mitigate supply disruption. The extent of the impact cannot be quantified at present, and the factory's closure will remain in place until the affected production lines are replaced or repaired.

site_title: Prudential Singapore boosts support for SMEs in their digitalisation efforts
summary: LIFE insurer Prudential Singapore has launched a digital commerce playbook and collaborated with Ngee Ann Polytechnic and ST Engineering to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in their digitalisation efforts. The playbook, launched in September 2021, provides practical help on using digital technologies tailored to each business's needs. The initiatives also offer training on cybersecurity awareness and provide access to co-working spaces at competitive rates, aiming to empower SMEs to accelerate their digital transformation and stay relevant in the current pandemic.

images.alt_text: Husks Green is a SME that benefitted from Prudential Singapore's collaboration with Ngee Ann Poly where students were assigned to various SMEs to support them in digital commerce. Managing director of Husks Green, Mr Phang Siang Yang (right), his colleague Ee Swee Moi (left) and Ngee Ann Polytechnic intern Mr Marcus Soo (middle), are taking photos of Husk Green's products to be used on the company's social media pages.

site_title: China's US$708b race for cash adds pressure for easing
summary: China's financial markets face pressure in January due to a surge in seasonal demand for cash, with estimated liquidity needs reaching $708 billion. A maturing debt wall and Lunar New Year-related expenses will test the central bank's ability to maintain stable liquidity conditions. Analysts predict the People's Bank of China may ease monetary policies, but warn that further easing could fuel asset bubbles and undermine efforts to control inflation. The central bank has already reduced reserve requirements, but some experts fear a liquidity crunch could occur if liquidity support is insufficient.

site_title: China to order cybersecurity reviews for some firms seeking overseas listings
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration will enforce new rules requiring platform companies with over 1 million users to undergo a security review before listing abroad, starting Feb 15. The rules also govern the use of algorithm recommendation technology, requiring companies to give users the right to switch off the service. The moves aim to tighten Beijing's grip over its technology sector, potentially impacting companies like ByteDance and Alibaba. The rules do not specify whether they will apply to companies seeking listings in Hong Kong, but lawyers suggest they may not be required for companies already listed in the city.

site_title: David Bowie's estate sells songwriting rights to Warner
summary: David Bowie's estate has sold the publishing rights to his entire body of work to Warner Chappell Music for an estimated $250 million. The deal includes hundreds of songs spanning Bowie's six-decade career, such as "Space Oddity" and "Heroes." This sale follows a trend of massive music rights acquisitions by corporations, driven by the stability of streaming growth and low interest rates. Warner Chappell will now house Bowie's work as both a songwriter and recording artist, marking a significant milestone in the music industry.

site_title: US sets global record of over 1 million daily Covid-19 cases
summary: The US has set a global record for daily Covid-19 cases, with 1,080,211 new cases reported on Monday, according to Johns Hopkins University data. The Omicron variant, which accounts for 59% of national cases, is spreading rapidly, and the nation's death toll has fallen by 10% week-over-week. Officials are struggling to balance public health protection with economic concerns, and the US has approved a Covid-19 booster shot for children as young as 12.

images.alt_text: The United States recorded more than one million Covid-19 cases on Monday, according to data from Johns Hopkins University, as the Omicron variant spread at a blistering pace.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas, Sabah state launch masterplan for gas development
summary: Malaysia's state oil firm Petronas and Sabah state have launched the Sabah Gas Masterplan, a plan to develop the state's natural gas resources. The plan includes the construction of a 2 million tonnes per annum liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant, with the state government taking a more prominent role in gas marketing and distribution. The project aims to provide opportunities for Sabah to expand its LNG distribution and attract investors based on market needs, with 120 mmscfd volume of gas to be made available for key industries.

site_title: EY calls for loss carry-back relief cap to be raised tenfold to S$1m in Budget 2022 wishlist
summary: EY is calling for several measures in Singapore's Budget 2022, including a raised loss carry-back relief cap of S$1 million to provide cash flow relief to companies, particularly small and medium enterprises. The firm also suggests a 1-time pandemic relief for dormant or inactive companies, a research and development tax credit, and expanded qualifying activities for the Financial Sector Incentive. Additionally, EY recommends age relief for older individuals, a slew of other reliefs for spouses and caregivers, and government co-funding for pilot programmes on packaging waste reduction and research into Singapore's net-zero ambitions.

site_title: Asti amends internal processes after controversy over S$1.4m payment to retrenched CEO
summary: ASTI Holdings will implement internal processes to ensure accurate remuneration disclosures after a public controversy over a S$1.4 million payment to retrenched CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee. The company's board acknowledged the error, which occurred due to an inadvertent oversight by HR, and will have its chief financial officer review key management compensation. The company also plans to update its Corporate Governance Report and have key management personnel review compensation information to ensure accuracy. This follows a public backlash after NUS Business School professor Mak Yuen Teen raised questions about the circumstances behind the payout.

site_title: Dollar surges against yen as investors bet on Fed hike
summary: The US dollar surged against the yen, reaching new 5-year highs, as investors bet on a Federal Reserve rate hike due to the potential limited economic impact of the Omicron variant. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 96.398, while the dollar was up 0.7% against the yen, its highest since January 2017. Global markets continued their upbeat moves, with the euro down 0.2% versus the dollar. Investors have priced in a first US rate increase by May and two more by the end of 2022.

site_title: Peter Kwee's new Nassim project aims at super wealthy, with an eye on S$6,000 psf
summary: Ultra-luxury 4-unit complex Nassim Quattro, developed by Peter Kwee's son Kevin Kwee, has been put on the market with target asking prices of around S$6,000 per square foot (psf). The 49 Nassim Road project, a freehold development, sits on about 45,000 sq ft of elevated land and features 4 duplexes with private lifts, swimming pools, and car park lots. The units can be combined to form larger residences, and the developer expects mainly foreigners, permanent residents, and locals to show interest, with a few Singaporeans also expressing interest.

site_title: Wall Street's hopes for return to office dashed again by Covid
summary: Wall Street's efforts to return employees to the office have been derailed by the highly transmissible Omicron variant of Covid-19, with top banks such as Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs urging remote work until at least mid-January. Many firms have previously pushed for in-office work, but the latest surge in cases has forced them to reconsider. Executives warn that it may take until at least January 31 for a safe return to the office, with some firms even banning indoor events and requiring vaccination boosters.

images.alt_text: A record 10 million people were diagnosed with Covid-19 in the 7 days through Sunday, almost twice the pandemic's previous weekly high, though weekly deaths continued to drop.

site_title: Centurion's newly formed exco will boost its decision-making process: experts
summary: Centurion Corporation, a Singapore-based developer of purpose-built worker and student accommodations, has formed an executive committee (exco) to boost its decision-making process. The exco, comprising David Loh and other board members, will assist the board with oversight responsibilities, evaluate major strategic initiatives, and recommend proposals to achieve long-term value creation. Experts say the exco can be useful in complex or transformational exercises, but caution against it becoming "a board within a board" that interferes with management decision-making. Centurion's exco terms of reference ensure that key decisions rest with the board.

site_title: Azalea closes Altrium private equity fund II at US$805m
summary: Azalea Investment Management closed its Altrium II private equity fund at US$805 million, exceeding its initial target. The fund, launched in 2019, allows accredited investors to participate in a diversified portfolio of PE funds across the US, Europe, and Asia. Strong interest from new investors and existing backers, as well as low minimum commitment and efficient capital management, contributed to the fund's success. The closure of Altrium II marks a continuation of Azalea's mandate to broaden investors' access to private equity, with plans to launch more quality PE products in 2022.

site_title: 842 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, weekly infection growth rate rises to 1.09
summary: Singapore reported 842 new Covid-19 cases as of January 4, with a weekly infection growth rate of 1.09, the highest since November 12. The country has seen a rise in cases over the past week, with 334 community cases and 438 confirmed Omicron cases detected. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung warned of an imminent Omicron wave, while the ICU utilisation rate increased to 43.8%. With 91% of the eligible population fully vaccinated, the authorities are closely monitoring the situation and assessing risk levels for Covid-19 measures.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened with a strong start to 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 1.0% to 7,460.59 points, Frankfurt's DAX index climbing 0.3% to 16,065.39 points, and Paris' CAC 40 gaining 0.6% to 7,261.39 points. The gains follow strong starts to the year for Tokyo and Wall Street.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: S-Reits underperformed in 2021 due to pandemic-related restrictions and inflation fears. The payment performance of Singapore firms improved slightly in Q4, with all sectors showing a decline in slow payments. The public raised over S$70,000 for badminton champion Loh Kean Yew, and flight capacity to and from Singapore remains stable through March 2022. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.5% on Wall Street gains, with DBS reaching a 52-week high. Meanwhile, S-Reits are pivoting to the 'new economy', and Nutryfarm announced changes to its board.

site_title: Japan's Kishida lays out new contigency plan against Omicron risk
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced a new contingency plan to address the Omicron risk, aiming to deliver Pfizer's oral treatment nationwide in February. The government will prepare to shift focus to domestic measures to prevent a surge in community transmissions, and will consider extending border controls if a spike in infections leads to hospital bed shortages. Kishida also plans to forgo overseas visits to focus on anti-pandemic measures, as the country confirmed its first Omicron case that couldn't be traced to overseas travelers, with over 993 cases reported.

site_title: Collective sale market faces rougher terrain in 2022
summary: The collective sale market in Singapore is expected to face a rougher terrain in 2022 due to the recent property cooling measures. Despite diminishing unsold supply, over-priced sites are unlikely to find buyers amid heightened risk. In 2021, a dozen projects worth S$2.19 billion were transacted, with developers becoming more cautious. Analysts expect a five percent decline in the government's supply of private homes in H1 2022, which may moderate rising land prices. Developers are expected to focus on GLS sites and smaller, reasonably-priced en bloc sites, with some opting for joint ventures and partnerships to alleviate risk.

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil sector under pressure amid operational disruptions, yield losses from floods
summary: Malaysia's palm oil sector is under pressure due to operational disruptions and yield losses from floods in several states, including Kelantan, Trengganu, and Pahang. The floods, caused by continuous heavy rain, have disrupted estate operations and road access to mills, but yield losses are manageable due to high CPO prices. Analysts predict that CPO prices may stay elevated in the first quarter of 2022, with some forecasting a record high before the end of Q1. The impact on supply is likely to be temporary, with some analysts expecting a short-term negative impact on productivity.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher in new year trade
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on their first trading day of 2022, with the Nikkei 225 increasing 1.77% to 29,301.79 and the Topix index adding 1.90% to 2,030.22. This follows a similar trend in US shares, which also advanced on their first trading day of the year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat as stronger dollar offsets New Year optimism
summary: South Korean shares closed flat on Tuesday, January 4, 2022, as a stronger US dollar offset New Year optimism, limiting foreign investor activity. The benchmark Kospi index rose 0.02% to 2,989.24, despite a 0.37% gain on Monday. Institutional investors continued to sell shares after the ex-dividend date, while the stronger dollar limited foreign buying. The US dollar strengthened due to expectations of interest rate hikes, offsetting gains from Wall Street, which was driven by strong performances from Apple and Tesla.

site_title: China's anti-graft crackdown has ensnared over 20 finance officials so far
summary: China's anti-graft crackdown has targeted over 20 finance officials, including those from top regulators and state-owned banks, since October 12. The officials have been probed or penalized for alleged "serious" violations of party discipline and state law. Chinese President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has punished over 1.5 million officials, is also part of a broader crackdown on the private sector, including major technology and property firms. The campaign has raised concerns about slowing economic growth and the nation's $54 trillion financial system.

site_title: Philippines' stock exchange cancels trading on technical glitch
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) halted trading on January 4, 2022, due to a technical glitch affecting 43 of 125 registered brokerage firms. The halt was triggered by the bourse's rule that requires a third of firms to access the system to continue trading. The Philippines' broader index fell 1.4% on January 3, weighed down by rising Covid-19 cases. The PSE is working to resolve the issue, but no timeline has been provided.

site_title: Brokers' take: SAC Capital initiates 'buy' on Marco Polo Marine with S$0.032 target price
summary: SAC Capital has initiated a "buy" call on Marco Polo Marine with a target price of S$0.032, citing opportunities in the Taiwan wind farm market and revenue growth from higher charter and utilization rates. The analyst expects MPM to increase its vessels chartered to Taiwan from 2 to 4 by end-2022, giving it an edge in scoring wind farm projects. However, the company is expected to experience slower growth in the first half of 2022 due to a monsoon season.

site_title: Crowdfund for badminton world champion Loh Kean Yew draws over S$108,000 in 2 days, more donations pouring in
summary: Singaporean badminton world champion Loh Kean Yew has received over S$158,000 in donations, exceeding initial targets, after a crowdfunding campaign set up by Wei Chan and four business leaders. The campaign, launched after Loh did not receive prize money from his BWF World Championships win, has raised S$108,000 from public donations in two days, with a S$50,000 donation from a former national badminton player also included. The funds will support Loh in his sporting endeavors.

site_title: Gold gains as preventive curbs increase on spike in Omicron cases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,806.20 per ounce amid curbs to contain Omicron coronavirus cases, while US Treasury yields supported by inflation fears limited gains. Omicron appears more contagious but less virulent than Delta, leading to preventive measures and work-from-home policies. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields rose to a 1-month high, raising the opportunity cost of holding non-interest paying gold. Silver, platinum, and palladium also gained.

site_title: Taiwan just bought 20,000 bottles of rum China didn't want
summary: Taiwan's State-owned Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor (TTL) purchased 20,400 bottles of Lithuanian rum after China denied permission for its import. The move is seen as a show of support for Lithuania amid diplomatic tensions between the two nations. China has been angry with Lithuania since Taiwan opened a representative office in Vilnius in November, violating Beijing's one-China principle. TTL's purchase is a dollar diplomacy move aimed at countering China's efforts, with the company calling for a toast to Lithuania's support for Taiwan.

site_title: China's sticking to its border policies will keep the heat up on tourism-dependent economies, says Fitch
summary: China's continued adherence to its "zero-Covid" policy will likely keep pressure on tourism-dependent economies, particularly Thailand, which was a key source market for China before the pandemic. Fitch Ratings expects a slow recovery in international tourism in Asia-Pacific in 2022 due to the Omicron variant and local outbreaks. Analysts say China's dynamic zero-Covid strategy, which focuses on early detection and mass testing, may not be easily abandoned, despite mounting criticism and economic pressure.

site_title: Taiwan central bank split on using rates to rein in housing market
summary: Taiwan's Deputy Governor Chen Nan-kuang has expressed the need for interest rate adjustments to rein in the country's rapidly rising housing market. In contrast, Governor Yang Chin-long has suggested using selective credit controls instead. Chen argues that loose monetary policy is a major contributor to house price inflation and that interest rates should be used as a tool to stabilize the financial environment. The central bank has kept borrowing costs unchanged, but some economists predict rate hikes this year.

site_title: Novo Tellus gets nod for SPAC listing on SGX: sources
summary: Novo Tellus Capital Partners, a Singapore-based buyout firm, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange to list its SPAC, Novo Tellus Acquisition Corp, with a planned initial public offering of S$150-200 million. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to boost listing volumes, which have been low in recent years. The approval comes after regulators rolled out a framework in September, with other firms, such as Vertex Venture Holdings and Tikehau Capital SCA, also receiving similar approvals.

site_title: Chip shortage may turn into oversupply in 2024 for Asian foundries: Morningstar
summary: A chip shortage may ease in the second half of 2022 and turn into an oversupply in 2024 for Asian foundries, according to a Morningstar sector report. The shortage will be addressed by automotive-related backlog, while emerging trends like the metaverse, electric vehicles, and artificial intelligence will lead to an oversupply. Morningstar expects Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) to outperform the market due to its resilience, high exposure to high-value verticals, and relatively small exposure to commoditized legacy manufacturing processes.

site_title: Beijing meets state air quality standards for first time in 2021
summary: Beijing met state air quality standards for the first time in 2021, with average PM2.5 readings reaching 33 micrograms per cubic meter, a 13% decrease from the previous year. The city's efforts to cut coal consumption, reduce transportation emissions, and relocate heavy industry have contributed to the improvement. Beijing's air quality has improved significantly over the past decade, with residents enjoying nearly 4 months more of clear skies in 2021 compared to 2013. The city's progress is attributed to a concerted effort by all regions and departments to achieve comprehensive improvements.

site_title: Capacity, demand for flights to and from Singapore hold up through March 2022
summary: Singapore's flight capacity and demand to and from the city remain steady despite the emergence of the Omicron variant, according to data from Alton Aviation Consultancy. From December 2021 to March 2022, no material change was observed in flight capacity, with seat capacity on quarantine-free Vaccinated Travel Lane flights expected to increase from under 480,000 to over 570,000. Airlines have filed for capacity increases on over 15 routes, but a stabilizing Covid situation is crucial to maintaining seat capacity.

site_title: Vietnam mulls 347t dong stimulus for Covid-battered economy
summary: Vietnam's government is proposing a 347 trillion dong (S$20.6 billion) stimulus package to boost its economy, which has been severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. The plan includes 176 trillion dong in infrastructure projects and 110 trillion dong in assistance to enterprises and workers. The measure aims to reduce bank loan interest rates and delay loan payments to help businesses, with the goal of increasing economic growth and accelerating the recovery of the travel and tourist industries. The proposal is a reduced version of an earlier plan weighing 800 trillion dong in stimulus measures.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB says Kimly trades at attractive discount, reiterates 'add'
summary: CGS-CIMB has reiterated its "add" call on Kimly, a coffee shop and food court operator, with an unchanged target price of S$0.56. Kimly is trading at an attractive discount to its F&B peer Koufu, which is set to be privatized at S$0.77. The research team believes Kimly's shares will benefit from the structural trend of hybrid work arrangements and growing demand for online food delivery, with a potential upside of 34.9% from the current price.

site_title: Indonesia warns coal supply crunch not over as China prices rally
summary: Indonesia has warned that its coal supply situation remains critical ahead of a review of its export ban, which has led to a surge in coal prices in China, the world's largest consumer of the fuel. The ban, enacted to avoid power outages in Indonesia, has disrupted energy security for major economies like China, India, Japan, and South Korea. Indonesia's coal reserves are being supplemented by domestic miners and other suppliers, but analysts warn that re-routing coal shipments could lead to higher demand from Australia, a major supplier to Asia.

site_title: China Evergrande 2021 sales plunge 39%, shares set to resume
summary: China Evergrande Group reported a 39% decline in contracted sales for 2021 to 443 billion yuan (S$94.3 billion). The company's shares resumed trading on Tuesday after being suspended, trading at HK$1.59. Evergrande confirmed it will demolish 39 buildings on the resort island of Hainan as ordered by local authorities. The decision does not affect other plots of land in the Ocean Flower Island project. The company will actively communicate with the authority to resolve the issue.

site_title: Payment performance of local firms improves slightly in Q4: SCCB
summary: Singapore's payment performance of local firms improved slightly in Q4, with all sectors recording a decline in slow payments on a quarter-on-quarter basis. Slow payments fell to 44.3% in Q4, while prompt payments rose to 40.8%. The construction sector accounted for the highest proportion of payment delays, but saw a slight dip. The SCCB expects a continued trend of gradual improvements in payment performance in 2022. Overall, the annual average proportion of prompt payments is 41.2%, up from 40.7% in 2020.

site_title: Biden, Trump to address split-screen nation on Jan 6 anniversary
summary: President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump will address the nation on the one-year anniversary of the January 6 attack on Congress, with Biden warning of threats to US democracy and Trump promoting conspiracy theories about the 2020 election. Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris will speak from inside the Capitol, while Trump will hold a press conference from his Florida property. The divide between the two leaders reflects the ongoing political polarization in the US, with Trump's base continuing to believe in unsubstantiated claims of election fraud.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders eye virus, inflation, rates
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, with Tokyo and Sydney jumping over 1% as investors eyed easing concerns about Omicron and economic recovery optimism. However, Hong Kong and Shanghai dipped due to tech firm woes and fears about China's property sector. The Dow and S&P 500 started the year with new all-time highs, while the Nasdaq rallied thanks to tech giants like Apple and Tesla. Investors await the release of Federal Reserve minutes for insight into its plans amid surging inflation, with some predicting interest rate hikes.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH upgrades CDL Hospitality Trusts to 'buy', positive on global Covid recovery
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded CDL Hospitality Trusts to "buy" due to its positive outlook on the global Covid recovery. Analyst Jonathan Koh expects the UK to recover in the second quarter of 2022, driven by domestic and intra-regional travel, with Hilton Cambridge City Centre and The Lowry Hotel benefiting. Globally, Koh also anticipates continued recovery, with Singapore reopening its international borders and Germany seeing a decline in new Covid-19 infections. However, Koh notes that CDLHT's Singapore hotels may face a bumpy transition out of serving as isolation facilities.

site_title: S-Reits pivot to 'new economy' in tough 2021; look forward to brighter year ahead
summary: S-Reits in Singapore underperformed the benchmark Straits Times Index in 2021, with a total return of 5.2% compared to 13.6%. The sector's underperformance was driven by market expectations of US Federal Reserve rate hikes amid supply chain disruptions and rising demand. However, S-Reits have pivoted to in-demand "new economy" sectors such as data centers and e-commerce logistics, with asset acquisitions totaling over S$12.7 billion in 2021. Several new economy-focused Reits have also proposed mergers, including the proposed merger of ESR-Reit J91U with Ara Logos Logistics Trust, expected to be completed in early 2022.

site_title: Australia Covid-19 cases surge, hospitalisations hit pandemic high in most populous state
summary: Australia has reported a pandemic high in Covid-19 cases, with 47,799 infections on Tuesday, surpassing its previous high of 37,212. Hospitalisations in New South Wales rose to 1,344, a new record, with four new deaths registered. Despite the surge, vaccination levels of nearly 92% have helped keep the death rate lower than previous outbreaks. Australia is also battling a shortage of rapid antigen tests, and authorities have ruled out covering the cost for at-home testing.

site_title: Bukalapak, Salim Group to buy into Indonesia's Allo Bank rights issue
summary: Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak.com and conglomerate Salim Group will subscribe to Allo Bank's 4.8 trillion rupiah rights issue, valuing the digital lender at S$454.3 million. Allo Bank plans to sell 10 billion shares at 478 rupiah each, with tycoon Chairul Tanjung's Mega Corpora increasing its investment by 1.3 trillion rupiah. Bukalapak.com will buy 1.2 trillion rupiah of shares, while Salim Group's Indolife Investama Perkasa will buy 623 billion rupiah worth of shares. The move is part of Allo Bank's expansion into digital banking in Indonesia.

site_title: Philippines widens Covid-19 restrictions outside capital
summary: The Philippines has expanded COVID-19 restrictions outside the capital, Manila, to include over 11 million people in surrounding provinces due to a surge in cases. The restrictions, set to last until mid-January, include limiting unvaccinated residents to home, reducing capacity at restaurants, parks, and beauty salons, and suspending in-person classes and contact sports. The country has recorded over 2.8 million infections and more than 51,000 deaths, with daily infections at a two-month high in January. The government has deemed the entire country at "high risk" following a spike in cases.

site_title: Walmart temporarily shut nearly 60 US stores for Covid-19 cleaning in December
summary: Walmart temporarily shut nearly 60 US stores in December due to the Omicron variant, adopting a policy to present a safe and clean in-store environment. The stores in hotspots like Texas and New Jersey were closed for cleaning, following a similar approach taken two years ago to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Centurion, Golden Energy, Geo Energy, ComfortDelGro, CDW
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Four companies saw significant developments on January 4: Centurion Corp established an executive committee to oversee business decisions, Golden Energy and Resources and Geo Energy Resources faced temporary coal export bans in Indonesia, ComfortDelGro announced CEO Ang Wei Neng's resignation, and CDW secured a deal to produce a digital video-editing console. Shares of Centurion, Gear, and Geo Energy closed flat or declined, while CDW's shares rose 12%. ComfortDelGro's shares fell 0.7% after the resignation announcement. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Australia housing boom fades as Melbourne, Sydney pull back
summary: Australia's housing boom appears to be over, with growth expected to fall to 5% this year after a 22.1% rise in 2021. The housing market cooled further in December, with Melbourne reporting its first price decline since October 2020 and Sydney recording its slowest month since then. The upper-end housing market, which fueled the boom, is now leading the slowdown. Affordability constraints and tighter credit conditions are expected to drag down demand, according to CoreLogic's research director Tim Lawless, predicting a "sharp slowdown" in the market this year.

site_title: Centurion sets up exco to assist board with oversight duties
summary: Centurion Corporation has established an executive committee (exco) to assist its board with oversight responsibilities, effective January 1. The exco, headed by joint chairman David Loh Kim Kang, will have a say in business decisions and strategic initiatives. This move aims to enhance the board's oversight duties.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, January 4, 2022, following a record-breaking performance on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.54% to 23,400.62, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. Despite gains, concerns over Omicron, inflation, and supply chain problems remained.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Tuesday at 1,549.36, up 0.02% from the previous day. The index saw 162 gains and 86 losses, with a trading volume of 132.50 million lots worth RM58.65 million.

site_title: China to require certain firms to undergo cybersecurity reviews before pursuing overseas listings
summary: China will implement new rules requiring platform companies with over 1 million users to undergo cybersecurity reviews before listing abroad, starting Feb 15. The Cyberspace Administration of China also plans to regulate the use of algorithm recommendation technology, requiring users to be able to switch it off. The moves aim to strengthen oversight over China's technology sector and potentially impact companies such as TikTok and Alibaba Group.

site_title: London's fintech boom opens the door for dirty money
summary: London's fintech industry, particularly electronic money institutions (EMIs), has grown rapidly, with an estimated £1.4 billion in transactions daily. However, critics warn that the loosely regulated sector is vulnerable to dirty money and money laundering. Over 200 EMIs have been licensed by the UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) since 2018, with some firms linked to money laundering scandals, alleged financial wrongdoing, and high-risk clients. The FCA has taken action, rejecting 50 applications and conducting eight formal reviews, but concerns remain about oversight weaknesses and the potential for greater risk-taking.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on new year trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on January 4, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 rising 1.01% to 29,082.72 and the Topix index adding 0.88% to 2,010.52. This followed gains in US shares on their first trading day of the year.

site_title: Knight Frank hires Chia Mein Mein to helm en bloc, land sales
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has appointed Chia Mein Mein as its new head of capital markets (land and collective sale). Chia, with over 25 years of experience, will drive the land sale and collective sale business, despite the government's recent cooling measures, which may impact the collective sale segment. Chia has advised on transactions exceeding S$2.6 billion and previously worked at Delasa, Colliers International, and the Housing and Development Board.

site_title: Japan's factory activity growth softens in December: PMI
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity grew for the 11th consecutive month in December, but at a slower pace than the previous month, according to the au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI). The index fell to 54.3, easing from the previous month's 54.5. Despite a gradual recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, foreign orders for Japanese manufactured goods saw a softer growth rate due to a rise in coronavirus infections, particularly in South Korea.

site_title: Apple becomes first US company to reach US$3t valuation
summary: Apple has become the first US company to reach a market value of over $3 trillion, surpassing the $2 trillion milestone in August 2020. The tech giant briefly hit the record level on Monday, before slipping back to $182.88 per share. This achievement demonstrates the tech industry's surge during the pandemic, driven by demand for personal electronics and digital services.

site_title: Verizon, AT&T to delay 5G deployment, averting aviation standoff
summary: US carriers Verizon and AT&T agreed to a 2-week delay in deploying C-Band wireless spectrum, averting an aviation safety standoff that threatened to disrupt flights starting January 5. The delay, to January 19, comes after the White House, airlines, and aviation unions pressured the carriers to address concerns about potential interference with aircraft electronics. The agreement allows regulators, airlines, and wireless carriers to work on minimizing potential impact on flight operations over the next two weeks.

site_title: China will continue to 'modernise' nuclear arsenal: foreign ministry
summary: China reaffirmed its commitment to modernizing its nuclear arsenal, despite global efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. The country's foreign ministry stated that it will continue to upgrade its nuclear capabilities for reliability and safety reasons. China also called on the US and Russia to reduce their nuclear stockpiles, citing the US and Russia as holding 90% of the world's nuclear warheads. The move comes amid heightened tensions between China and the US over issues like Taiwan and trade.

site_title: Oil settles higher on 2022 demand optimism
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday on optimism about 2022 demand recovery, despite Opec+ expected to agree to another output increase. The Omicron variant has dampened demand, but hopes for a stronger recovery outweigh concerns. Oil prices settled higher despite Opec+'s anticipated output hike, which aims to trim oil demand for the next four years. The market is also watching the impact of rising Covid-19 infections on demand.

site_title: Australia: Shares kick off 2022 higher on Wall Street boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday, driven by gains in energy and mining stocks, following a strong overnight session on Wall Street. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7,510, building on a near 2% gain over the past two weeks. Energy stocks, including Santos and Whitehaven Coal, surged, while financials and miners also rose. The gains were despite concerns over soaring Covid-19 infections and a record 37,000 new cases in Australia, with investors focusing on the Omicron variant's mild impact.

site_title: Investors wary of record wave of emerging-market IPOs
summary: A record 1,162 emerging-market companies made initial public offerings in 2021, raising $228 billion, a 31% increase from 2020. Despite the surge in new listings, the benchmark gauge of developing-economy stocks ended 2021 with its worst year since 2018, due to headwinds such as virus variants and higher interest rates. Many newly issued stocks have risen in price, but losses in communication-industry listings and political risk in Latin America have dragged down performance. Investors are cautious about emerging-market equities in 2022, with some predicting lingering weakness until at least the second half of the year.

site_title: US flight cancellations top 2,800 as Covid-19, snow pummel airlines
summary: Over 2,830 US flights were canceled on the first day of 2022 due to Covid-19 and winter storms, with 8,200 flights grounded since January 1. The cancellations were highest at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport, with 75% of flights canceled, followed by Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport and Washington Dulles International. Illness among airline workers linked to the Omicron variant has contributed to the cancellations, with airlines citing high numbers of sick calls.

site_title: Turkish inflation hits 19-year high in December
summary: Turkey's annual inflation rate reached a 19-year high of 36.1% in December, according to official data, surpassing November's rate of 21.3%. This surge is attributed to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's unconventional economic policies, which sparked a currency crisis. This marks the highest inflation rate since 2002, posing pressure on policymakers and further exacerbating economic concerns in the country.

images.alt_text: Erdogan rails against high rates as the "mother and father of all evil", going against economic orthodoxy to claim they cause high inflation.

site_title: Indonesia's economic recovery could be Jakarta bourse's next big theme: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) predicts Indonesia's economy will recover, with GDP growth projected to reach 3.5% in 2021 and 5% in 2022. The brokerage attributes this to falling Covid-19 infection rates and over 40% vaccination of the population. This growth is expected to boost the Jakarta Composite Index (JCI) to 7,400 by end-2022, driven by higher corporate earnings growth and increased traffic for retailers and toll roads. UOBKH recommends investing in laggard and undervalued names, including Unilever Indonesia, Telkom Indonesia, and Kalbe Farma.

site_title: Yen see turning point after biggest annual drop since 2014
summary: The Japanese yen is nearing an end to its biggest annual decline since 2014, with some analysts suggesting it may be turning a corner. Historically, the yen has strengthened at the start of Federal Reserve rate hikes, potentially ending an extended period of weakness. In 2021, the yen fell over 10% against the dollar as traders anticipated interest rate increases from the US central bank and the Bank of Japan. A recent trend of the yen strengthening at the start of Fed hikes may signal the end of its decline.

site_title: CIMB to hire BNP Paribas veteran as regional M&A head
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has hired Ng Cho Weng, a BNP Paribas veteran, as its head of mergers, acquisitions and sponsors for South-east Asia. Ng, a managing director at BNP's Singapore unit, will join CIMB next month and be based in Kuala Lumpur. This move is part of CIMB's efforts to strengthen its M&A capabilities in the region.

site_title: Fed's moves pumped up stocks. In 2022, it may pull the plug
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in 2022 to combat inflation, ending government stimulus programs. This shift in policy will alter investor behavior, potentially deflating the stock market. Analysts predict a decrease in market buoyancy, reversing the market's ability to ignore pandemic realities. As a result, investors, businesses, and consumers will behave differently, taking air out of the market.

site_title: China's Dec factory activity returns to growth, beats forecasts: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity grew at its fastest pace in six months in December, with the Caixin PMI rising to 50.9, its highest level since June. Factory output increased at the fastest pace in a year, driven by easing price pressures, while new export orders fell and employment contracted. The growth adds uncertainty to China's economic recovery, which has been weighed down by a slowing manufacturing sector, debt problems, and Covid-19 outbreaks. Analysts expect a further slowdown in fourth-quarter GDP.

images.alt_text: China's factory activity grew at its fastest pace in six months in December, driven by production hikes and easing price pressures, but a weaker job market and business confidence added uncertainty, a private survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Future Retail seeks to quash Amazon arbitration action
summary: Future Retail has asked a New Delhi court to declare arbitration proceedings with Amazon.com in Singapore as illegal, citing an antitrust agency suspension of a 2019 deal. Amazon used its US$200 million investment in debt-laden Future to block the retailer's sale of assets to a rival, alleging breach of contracts. The court will review the arbitration proceedings, which Amazon initiated to assert its rights over Future. This move follows Amazon's successful use of the 2019 deal to block the asset sale. The outcome could impact the future of Future Retail and its dealings with Amazon.

site_title: Biden unveils plan to boost competition in US meat industry
summary: US President Joe Biden has unveiled a plan to boost competition in the US meat industry, allocating $1 billion in funding to support independent meat processors and ranchers. The initiative aims to address the lack of meaningful competition in the industry, where a handful of big companies control 55-85% of the market. The plan includes new rules to strengthen enforcement of the Packers and Stockyards Act and clarifying "Product of USA" meat labels. The move is seen as a step to address rising concerns over meat prices and the power of top meatpackers, but some industry leaders have expressed skepticism about the plan's effectiveness.

images.alt_text: The United States will issue new rules and US$1 billion in funding this year to support independent meat processors and ranchers as part of a plan to address a lack of "meaningful competition" in the meat sector, President Joe Biden said on Monday.

site_title: 10 stocks to watch in 2022
summary: The Companies & Markets team at The Business Times has compiled a list of 10 stocks to watch in 2022, citing improved market conditions and a decrease in Covid-19 concerns. The list includes Singtel, Sinarmas Land, Cordlife, and Q&M Dental Group, among others. Some of these stocks are held by the authors in their personal portfolios. The list is based on the team's analysis of market trends and operations, and is intended to provide investors with potential opportunities in the coming year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks kick off 2022 at record highs
summary: European stocks closed at all-time highs on January 3, 2022, as investors remained optimistic about a steady economic recovery despite the surge in Covid-19 cases due to the Omicron variant. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% to a record close of 489.99 points, following a 22.4% surge in 2021. This marked the second-best yearly performance since 2009, driven by economic stimulus measures, earnings growth, and vaccine rollouts.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS initiates 'buy' on Grab, cites opening of Asean economies as potential catalyst
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated a "buy" call on Grab, setting a 12-month target price of US$9, citing the opening of Asean economies and potential inclusion in the MSCI Singapore Index as catalysts. Analyst Sachin Mittal expects Grab's dominance in mobility and food delivery, as well as its growing fintech segment, to drive growth. However, rising competition and macro weakness could lead to a bear target price of US$6. The analyst projects a group EBITDA of US$420 million for FY2022 and US$200 million for FY2023.

site_title: BlackBerry loses bid to dismiss BlackBerry 10 lawsuit in New York, fall trial possible
summary: A US judge rejected BlackBerry's bid to dismiss a long-running class-action lawsuit claiming the company defrauded shareholders by inflating the success of its BlackBerry 10 smartphones. The case, which has been ongoing for over eight years, could go to trial this fall. The lawsuit claims BlackBerry misrepresented the success and profitability of its BlackBerry 10 smartphones, which ultimately failed to gain traction in the market.

site_title: New York subpoenas Trump, children in fraud probe
summary: New York State Attorney General Letitia James has subpoenaed former President Donald Trump, his son Don Jr, and daughter Ivanka as part of a years-long civil investigation into the family's business dealings. The subpoenas seek their testimony, following a reported request for Trump to testify in person on January 7. The investigation is ongoing, with no specific charges or conclusions mentioned.

site_title: US jury finds Theranos founder Holmes guilty in fraud trial
summary: A US jury found Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes guilty of conspiring to defraud investors, convicting her on 4 of 11 counts. Holmes, 37, was acquitted on 4 counts and unable to reach a decision on 3. She was accused of swindling investors by claiming Theranos' machines could run tests with a few drops of blood. The verdict sheds light on the company's failed endeavour to revolutionize lab testing, which relied on conventional machines. Holmes' conviction comes after a trial that featured testimony from former employees and investors who claimed she made misleading claims.

site_title: California's residential market pricey? In 2021, it got even pricier
summary: California's residential market saw significant price increases in 2021, with the median sale price of a single-family home rising 12.3% to $798,440, more than double the national median price of $353,900. This mirrors national trends, with outlying suburbs and smaller metro areas experiencing double-digit increases. Urban markets like San Francisco saw more modest gains, reflecting a shift towards more affordable areas. The state's home prices outpaced national trends, highlighting the region's persistently high housing costs.

site_title: Nutryfarm announces changes to board
summary: Nutryfarm International announced changes to its board, with non-executive director Xu Hai Min stepping down on December 30, 2021, to focus on other business interests. Xu will also step down from roles as legal representative of subsidiaries. The company appointed two new non-executive independent directors, Low Chin Parn Eric and Lim Swee Hua David, and redesignated two independent directors to new roles. Independent directors Neo Chee Beng and Jimmy Ng Poh Khoon will remain with the company until the completion of an independent review requested by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Can the Reit IPO market rev up to help investors build retirement savings?
summary: Singapore's Reit IPO market has experienced a resurgence with the successful listings of Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) and Digital Core Reit (DC Reit) in 2021. These Reits, which focus on overseas assets, traded flat and up 32% respectively at end-2021, contrasting with overseas-centric Reits that traded below their IPO prices. The addition of these Reits to the market is expected to increase investment options for investors, particularly those looking to build retirement savings. This development may revitalize the Reit IPO market and provide more choice for investors.

site_title: US authorises Pfizer booster for kids as young as 12
summary: US health authorities approved Pfizer's Covid-19 booster shot for children as young as 12, reducing the wait time between initial vaccination and an extra dose from six months to five. The decision aims to combat the Omicron variant, which has driven a resurgence in cases. A separate approval was given for a Pfizer-BioNTech booster dose for immunocompromised children aged 5-11, including those who have received organ transplants.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% in early trade on Tuesday, following Wall Street gains. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed to 3,154.85, driven by gains from property developer OKH Global and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The move follows fresh records on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 advanced 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.2%. The Indonesian Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources also announced a temporary ban on coal export sales, which may impact Geo Energy Resources RE4.

site_title: Reducing road emissions requires all hands on deck
summary: A growing number of countries and businesses are working towards reducing road emissions, with a focus on achieving zero-emission vehicles by 2040. The UK, Norway, and Singapore have set ambitious targets, with Singapore aiming to phase out petrol- and diesel-powered cars by 2040. However, electrification alone is not enough, and alternative solutions such as renewable liquid fuels are needed to achieve significant reductions in transport-related emissions. Collaboration between governments, businesses, and research institutes is key to driving innovation and reducing emissions, with Singapore and other countries exploring various solutions, including hydrogen and renewable fuels.

site_title: Asia, Europe manufacturing grows as Omicron keeps spreading
summary: Asia and European factory activity expanded in December, driven by resilient demand and easing supply-chain bottlenecks as the Omicron strain spreads. Key highlights include a rise in North Asia's industrial production, with Taiwan and South Korea posting the sharpest jumps. In the euro area, manufacturing activity slipped to 58, with Italy showing growth and France the weakest. Asia is bracing for the potential impact of Omicron on its manufacturing outlook and economic recovery, following disruptions caused by the previous wave of lockdowns.

site_title: Russia, China, Britain, US and France say no one can win nuclear war
summary: China, Russia, Britain, the US, and France have agreed that no one can win a nuclear war and that it should never be started. The five nuclear powers, who are permanent members of the UN Security Council, consider it their primary responsibility to avoid war and reduce strategic risks. They also reaffirmed their determination for nuclear arms control and disarmament, aiming to work with all countries to create an atmosphere of security. The agreement comes amid heightened tensions between Moscow and Western nations over Russia's military build-up near Ukraine.

site_title: This may be the year Boris Johnson's luck runs out
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's luck may be running out as he faces multiple challenges in 2022, including the Covid-19 pandemic, rising inflation, and investigations into party breaches and a loan to his Downing Street residence. Despite his opponents' frustration with his failures, Johnson has managed to maintain his standing, but his ability to regain it is uncertain. Experts warn that a series of unpredictable events could either boost or hinder his chances, leaving his future in politics hanging in the balance.

site_title: Stocks of firms that diversified into hot sectors, crude oil plays among best performers for 2021
summary: The Singapore stock market performed better than its regional counterparts in 2021, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 9.8% despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The top performers included companies that diversified into new businesses, such as digital security company Disa, which rose 600%, and luxury watch retailers like The Hour Glass, which increased 155%. Oil-linked stocks also benefited from higher crude oil prices, with Rex International and Marco Polo Marine rising 107.5% and 107.7%, respectively. However, pandemic plays like personal protective equipment makers sank to the bottom of the pack. Analysts predict a challenging year for Singapore stocks in 2022 due to global growth concerns and inflationary pressures.

site_title: Looking back at market surprises in 2021
summary: Markets experienced notable surprises in 2021, including a 50,000% realized return in NFT artwork in just three weeks. Global stock returns reached record highs, with the S&P 500 hitting a new high. Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification, while retail investors are anticipated to drive massive growth in ETFs in the region. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarization is emerging as a trend, with shifting safe havens in the market. These factors are contributing to the ongoing market rise.

site_title: Indonesia 2021 budget deficit smaller than target as revenues rise
summary: Indonesia's 2021 budget deficit was 4.65% of GDP, lower than the initial 5.7% estimate, thanks to a commodity boom and growing domestic demand. Revenues surpassed their target for the first time in 13 years, with a 21.6% growth on a yearly basis. The government collected 2,003.1 trillion rupiah, exceeding its target. For 2022, the budget deficit outlook is 4.85% of GDP, with some tax hikes expected to narrow the deficit further.

site_title: Volatile Turkish lira seesaws after inflation surges
summary: Turkey's lira surged 3% on Monday after inflation data showed a 19-year high of 36.08%, surpassing expectations. The currency had weakened 5% earlier in the day, but rebounded after oscillating between 12.77 and 13.92. The central bank's recent interest rate cuts despite inflation concerns have investors on edge. The lira has lost 44% of its value against the US dollar in 2021 and weakened 19% in the past week, prompting calls from President Erdogan to keep savings in lira and shift gold into banks.

site_title: Budget 2022: a chance to brace for global minimum tax
summary: Singapore faces challenges in attracting investments amid the implementation of the OECD's Global Anti-Base Erosion (GloBE) rules, which aim to ensure multinational enterprises pay a minimum of 15% effective tax rate. To counter this, the government should consider introducing flexibility into the tax incentive regime, offering grants and other benefits alongside tax incentives, revising and enhancing the Research and Development (R&D) tax incentive, and preserving hub activities by revising tax incentives. These measures will help Singapore maintain its attractiveness for investments and stay ahead of competitors.

site_title: Spider-Man: No Way Home continues box office domination
summary: Spider-Man: No Way Home continues its box office dominance, collecting US$52.7 million over the New Year's holiday frame in the US and Canada, boosting its total to US$609 million. The movie has already collected over US$1 billion worldwide, outperforming other recent releases like Shang-Chi and Sing 2. With no real competition until the release of Scream on January 14, Spider-Man: No Way Home is expected to continue raking in the dough.

site_title: Digital banks seen debuting strongly in 2022, but 'long and difficult' path to profitability
summary: Singapore's digital banks, including Grab-Singtel's GXS Bank and Sea's digital full-bank, are set to launch in 2022, aiming to capture underserved segments in the well-banked market. Despite initial hype, industry watchers expect these new banks to struggle to turn a profit, taking over 5 years, as incumbents bring their A-game and macro uncertainties prevail. The newcomers will rely on existing ecosystems to win customers, and their success will depend on leveraging parent platforms for data-sharing and network.

images.alt_text: A Grab spokesperson says that its new digital bank will provide customers with core banking services such as savings as well as other products like loans and wealth management; the Grab-Singtel joint venture, known as GXS Bank, has hired around 200 new staff.

site_title: Best World to buy back up to 10% of shares, no assurance of delisting
summary: Best World International, a beauty product distributor, will buy back up to 54.4 million shares (10% of its issued share capital) at S$1.36 apiece as part of an off-market offer. The move comes after trading was suspended in 2019 due to concerns over its business model in China. The buyback offer is open to all investors except a group of shareholders who collectively control 51.56% of the company. There is no assurance that Best World will be able to raise external financing for a potential delisting.

site_title: Jackson Chia to replace Ang Wei Neng as chief of ComfortDelGro's taxi business
summary: ComfortDelGro announced that Ang Wei Neng will resign as chief executive of its taxi business on April 1, to be replaced by Jackson Chia. Chia, currently group chief sustainability officer and CEO of ComfortDelGro's private mobility unit, will take over the role concurrently with his existing portfolio. Ang, a Member of Parliament, was appointed to helm the taxi business in 2017. The change follows Ang's decision to pursue another career path.

site_title: US: S&P 500 nears record high in bright start to year
summary: The S&P 500 opened near record levels on Monday, extending a recovery from the pandemic shock into the new year. The Dow Jones fell 16.71 points, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 87.53 points. Shares in Tesla jumped after the electric carmaker posted bumper delivery numbers. The S&P 500 rose 11.96 points, and the Nasdaq Composite reached a fresh record.

site_title: Opec sees tighter first quarter as it considers output hike
summary: OPEC reduced its global oil market surplus estimate for the first quarter to 1.4 million barrels a day, a 25% decrease from its previous forecast. This move may encourage the OPEC+ coalition to proceed with a modest production increase, expected to be around 400,000 barrels a day. The revised estimate is attributed to a weaker supply outlook from rival producers and a more robust demand outlook for 2022, with an average full-year surplus of 1.4 million barrels a day.

site_title: Airlines warn of flight delays amid a defer-5G clash
summary: Airlines warn of potential flight delays amid a US government request to delay new 5G service that aviation interests claim may interfere with aircraft electronics. AT&T and Verizon Communications rejected the request, but may offer a 6-month pause near some airports. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and airlines predict substantial impacts on flight schedules, with up to 350,000 commercial flights impacted annually at a cost of $2.1 billion.

site_title: Alibaba drops amid signal some investors may be poised to sell
summary: Alibaba Group Holding shares fell 3.3% amid concerns that investors may be selling stakes after swapping US holdings for Hong Kong-listed shares. A sharp rise in Alibaba American Depositary Receipts being converted into Hong Kong shares may signal a potential decline in investor sentiment. The move comes as Chinese companies face stricter disclosure requirements in the US and a regulatory crackdown at home, contributing to a 49% share price decline last year. Previous conversions have been followed by share price declines, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to pay US$60m to resolve data security lawsuit
summary: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay US$60 million to settle a lawsuit by customers who claimed the bank exposed their personal data due to its failure to properly retire outdated IT systems. The settlement, which requires US District Judge Analisa Torres' approval, provides at least two years of fraud insurance coverage and up to US$10,000 in reimbursement for out-of-pocket losses. Morgan Stanley denied wrongdoing, but has made "substantial" upgrades to its data security practices.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 finish first session of 2022 at records
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Monday, January 3, 2022, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.7% at 36,585.06 and the S&P 500 jumping 0.6% to 4,796.56. Apple briefly reached a $3 trillion valuation, despite expectations of higher interest rates. The Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.2% to 15,832.80, marking a bullish start to 2022.

images.alt_text: Major Wall Street indices closed at fresh records on Monday and Apple briefly reached a US$3 trillion valuation in a bullish open to 2022, despite expectations for higher interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia seeks to rename company as Capital A
summary: AirAsia Group has proposed changing its company name to Capital A Berhad, subject to shareholders' approval. The proposed name change was approved by the Companies Commission of Malaysia.
