This move is part of the airline's efforts to rebrand and expand its business. No specific timeline for the name change has been announced.

site_title: Airbus exceeds target of 600 jet deliveries in 2021, sources say
summary: Airbus has provisionally exceeded its 2021 delivery target of 600 jets, according to industry sources. Final totals are pending an audit, but deliveries went down to the wire, with several handovers completed on December 31. A surge in A350 deliveries helped meet the target, but supply chain issues and the ongoing coronavirus crisis limited deliveries of some medium-haul jets. This surpasses Airbus' previous target of at least 566 deliveries, which was raised in July after better-than-expected half-year results.

site_title: Merits of Mapletree merger must be seen through longer-term lens
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) proposed a S$4.2 billion merger, creating the seventh largest Reit in Asia with a theoretical market capitalization of S$10.5 billion. The merged entity, named Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), will have assets under management of S$17.1 billion. MCT unitholders will receive S$1.1949 for each unit, while MNACT unitholders can choose between receiving new MCT units or cash. The merger is expected to be 8.9% accretive to distribution per unit and 6.5% accretive to NAV on a pro forma basis.

site_title: Philippine peso goes from emerging market Asia's best to worst currency in a week
summary: The Philippine peso, once the best-performing currency in emerging Asia, fell to the worst in just one week, dropping around 2% due to a seasonal boost from remittances ending. Strategists predict further losses, citing a dovish central bank and rising current-account deficit. Barclays expects the currency to fall to 51.50 by the end of June, while Nomura sees 51.7 by the end of March, with a history of sliding in January in five of the past six years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start year with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the year with losses, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.53% to 23,274.75. Embattled tech firms and property companies were major contributors to the decline, following news that Evergrande had suspended trading in its shares ahead of an announcement. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday, and US markets closed at fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Kim Jong-un's decade in power is a game changer for Asia and beyond
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has solidified his power and influence over the past decade, despite the challenges posed by international sanctions and the COVID-19 pandemic. His nuclear-armed ballistic missile force has increased, providing him with leverage to extract concessions in future disputes. Kim has also emerged as a key international actor, outsmarting former US President Donald Trump in several meetings. The US and South Korea face a policy headache in navigating the growing nuclear danger posed by Pyongyang, with differing interpretations of "denuclearisation" on the peninsula. The Biden administration must resolve the sequencing of steps to move the process forward, while also addressing the fragility of the situation and potential risks of conflict.

summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 1.26% to 1,547.77, with 186 losers outweighing 155 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong: where East and West no longer meet
summary: The Chinese government is using the recent Hong Kong legislative elections to promote its own system of democracy and counter criticism from the West. The elections, held under a new, Beijing-designed system, saw pro-establishment candidates win 89 of 90 seats, with a record low turnout of 30.2%. China has issued two white papers, one extolling its own system and claiming it has developed a "whole-process people's democracy", and the other linking the Hong Kong elections to its mainland democracy development. The move is seen as a response to Beijing's worsening relationship with the West and a threat to liberty in Hong Kong.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to pay US$60m to resolve data security lawsuit
summary: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay US$60 million to settle a lawsuit by 15 million customers who claimed the bank exposed their personal data due to inadequate data security practices. The settlement requires approval by US District Judge Analisa Torres and provides customers with at least two years of fraud insurance coverage and reimbursement of up to US$10,000 in out-of-pocket losses. Morgan Stanley denied wrongdoing and made "substantial" upgrades to its data security practices, following a US$60 million civil fine in 2020.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 18.48 points lower at 1,549.05 on Monday, with 485 gainers outnumbering 436 losers. The decline occurred despite a boost in stocks in Europe and the US, where mining and healthcare companies were driven up by sector-specific gains. In other news, Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and a Dutch firm announced plans to privatise Grand Venture Technology at $0.94 per share.

site_title: Golden Energy unit does not foresee impact from Indonesia's coal export restrictions
summary: Golden Energy Mines, a unit of Golden Energy and Resources, does not foresee an impact from Indonesia's temporary coal export ban from January 1 to January 31. The ban was implemented due to critically low inventories at domestic power plants, but the company's production quota for 2022 is unaffected. GEMS has complied with Indonesia's domestic market obligation regulation, exceeding the 25% domestic sales requirement last year. The company's shares closed 1.72% higher on Monday.

site_title: Tesla beats supply chain woes to report record deliveries
summary: Tesla reported record quarterly deliveries of 308,600 vehicles, exceeding analyst estimates, in the fourth quarter of 2021. This marks the sixth consecutive quarter of record deliveries for the company. Despite global chip shortages and regulatory pressure, Tesla ramped up production in China, boosting deliveries by 87% from 2020 to 936,172 vehicles. CEO Elon Musk expressed optimism that the company will maintain an annual growth rate of over 50% for "quite a while." Analysts predict Tesla's deliveries will grow to 1.3 million vehicles this year, despite production challenges.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS reinitiates 'buy' on CapitaLand Investment with S$4 target
summary: DBS Group Research has reinitiated coverage on CapitaLand Investment (CLI) with a "buy" call and a target price of S$4, representing a 17% upside from its current price. The research team highlights CLI's positive performance since its demerger, with the stock's share price climbing 18% from its listing day and trading at 1.2 times price to net asset value. DBS expects CLI's revenues to grow 10% in FY2022, driven by robust growth in fees from funds under management, and a 3-year net profit CAGR of 12% from FY2021 to FY2024.

site_title: Airlines warn of flight delays as AT&T, Verizon balk at 5G delay
summary: Airlines have warned of potential flight delays due to the rollout of 5G service by AT&T and Verizon, which could interfere with aircraft electronics. Despite a request from the US government to postpone the rollout, the wireless carriers have refused, saying it would harm millions of mobile customers. The airlines estimate 350,000 flights could be impacted annually, with costs totaling $2.1 billion. The Federal Aviation Administration and Department of Transportation are reviewing the response and considering restrictions on 5G service near airports to mitigate potential disruptions.

site_title: India's shadow lenders build super apps as competition heats
summary: India's shadow lenders are building super apps to offer various financial products on a single digital platform, competing with fintech firms. Shriram City Union Finance and Bajaj Finance, two major non-bank finance companies, are taking this step after a crisis that saw several finance companies fold up. The sector aims to play catch up, with Shriram Group planning to merge Shriram City Union Finance with Shriram Transport Finance to create the largest shadow lender in the country. The move aims to cross-sell products and tap into growing consumer demand for financial services.

site_title: STI closed 0.34% higher on first trading day of the year
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.57 points or 0.34% to 3,134.25 points on its first trading day of the year, defying rising Omicron cases. Analysts attribute the uptick to the gradual reopening of Singapore's economy, despite market volatility. Four stocks closed in the red, including Mapletree Commercial Trust, which fell 4% after its merger announcement. The market awaits clarity on business activities and Omicron's impact.

site_title: Chinese property stocks sink after demolition order for Evergrande group
summary: Chinese property stocks plummeted 1.7% after Evergrande Group was ordered to demolish 39 buildings in Hainan province due to an illegally obtained building permit. The move raised concerns about policy makers' willingness to ease their crackdown on indebted property companies. Evergrande halted trading, and shares of other developers also dropped 2.8% in Hong Kong. The industry faces a $197 billion funding gap, with contracted sales falling 26% in December. Despite this, Chinese high-yield dollar bonds rose, suggesting investors remain optimistic about the sector.

site_title: Next space race - US and China take their rivalry beyond Earth
summary: The US and China are engaging in a new space race, with both countries planning to establish a human-robotic presence on the moon. The US aims to send a space capsule into orbit around the moon by March or April, with plans to land the first woman and first non-white American on the lunar surface by 2025. China plans to set up an unmanned research base station on the moon by 2027, and is concerned about the US's Artemis Accords, which allow governments to protect their facilities with safety zones. The rivalry is expected to have significant political implications, with both countries seeking to claim ownership of lunar territory.

site_title: Opec names Kuwait oil executive as secretary-general
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has appointed Kuwaiti oil executive Haitham al-Ghais as its new secretary-general, effective August 1, 2022, for a three-year term. He succeeds Nigeria's Mohammed Barkindo, who led the organization since 2016 and oversaw a drastic oil output cut in 2020 due to the pandemic. Al-Ghais' appointment is seen as a continuation of the gradual reopening of Opec's oil production, which has helped prices recover since last year.

site_title: China Evergrande shares halted, set to release 'inside information'
summary: China Evergrande Group shares have been halted from trading pending the release of "inside information". The embattled property developer is struggling to repay over $300 billion in liabilities, including $20 billion in international market bonds. Evergrande missed new coupon payments worth $255 million, but has a 30-day grace period. The firm has set up a risk management committee and will engage with creditors. Additionally, a city government in Hainan ordered the developer to demolish 39 residential buildings within 10 days due to illegal construction.

site_title: Ronaldo statue kicks up a fuss in India's Goa
summary: A statue of Cristiano Ronaldo in Calangute, Goa, India, has sparked protests due to its perceived insensitivity towards local sports stars. Locals, including former Indian international player Micky Fernandes, claim the statue is a hangover from Portugal's colonial rule, which administered Goa until 1961. The statue's unveiling was meant to inspire young people to excel in football, but Fernandes and others argue that a local footballer should be honored instead. The incident highlights ongoing tensions between Goa's Portuguese heritage and its Indian identity.

site_title: Maybank group CEO to step down, leadership search underway
summary: Maybank Group President and CEO Abdul Farid Alias, 52, will step down at the end of August after serving since 2013. A search for his successor is underway, assessing internal and external candidates. Farid has indicated he won't seek renewal of his contract, citing a desire to pursue his own interests after completing his third term. He will continue to oversee the bank's management and operations until a new leader assumes the position.

site_title: Singapore's December market cap up 1.3%, led by gains from local banks
summary: Singapore's total market capitalisation rose 1.3% in December to S$858.1 billion, driven by gains from local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB, which are expected to benefit from rising interest rates and economic recovery. Blue-chip stocks, including Straits Times Index constituents, also recorded stronger gains. The Straits Times Index ended 9.8% higher in 2021, with a total return of 13.6%. Market activity remained resilient despite Covid-19 concerns, with investment analysts expecting banking stocks to perform well in 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks kick off 2022 at record highs
summary: European stocks reached record highs on January 3, 2022, driven by hopes for a steady economic recovery despite the Omicron coronavirus variant. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.6% to 490.76 points, surpassing its November record high. The benchmark saw a 22.4% jump in 2021, fueled by economic stimulus, earnings growth, and vaccine rollouts. Key sectors, including automakers and airlines, also saw gains, with Lufthansa jumping 5% after a Citi upgrade.

site_title: RM200b worth of investment approvals in Malaysia expected in 2022: UOB
summary: Malaysia is expected to receive RM200 billion (S$64.8 billion) in investment approvals in 2022, according to UOB economists. This is a result of the country's robust growth prospects, regional recovery, and potential positive trade and investment diversion effects from the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. Despite tighter global monetary conditions and lingering Covid-19 uncertainties, Malaysia's National Economic Recovery Plan and tax incentives have attracted foreign investments.

site_title: Indonesia's inflation at 18-month high in December
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate surged to 1.87% in December, the highest in 18 months, driven by rising food and plane ticket prices. This exceeded expectations of 1.80% and marks a reversal from the 1.75% rate in November. Bank Indonesia aims to keep inflation within 2-4% for 2021-2022, with the core inflation rate rising to 1.56%.

site_title: AT&T, Verizon CEOs reject US request for 5G deployment delay
summary: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg requested a two-week delay in the deployment of 5G wireless service around airports due to aviation safety concerns. However, AT&T and Verizon CEOs John Stankey and Hans Vestberg rejected the request, stating they would not deploy 5G around airports for six months but would not limit the use of C-Band spectrum. The wireless companies deemed the proposal "an irresponsible abdication of the operating control required to deploy world-class communications networks."

site_title: Geo Energy Resources hits snag as Indonesia bans coal exports for January
summary: Geo Energy Resources' operations have been impacted by Indonesia's temporary ban on coal exports for January, due to concerns over low inventories at domestic power plants. The ban aims to prevent widespread blackouts. Despite this, the company stated that the export ban won't affect its production quota and plans, as it met domestic market obligations last year. The Indonesian Ministry is currently reviewing the ban, and Geo Energy Resources will monitor the situation, making further announcements as necessary.

site_title: Tesla Q4 deliveries beat estimates despite supply chain woes
summary: Tesla Inc. reported record quarterly deliveries of 308,600 vehicles in Q4 2021, exceeding analyst estimates of 263,026. This marks the sixth consecutive quarter of record deliveries for the company, led by CEO Elon Musk. Despite global chip shortages, Tesla ramped up production in China, where it ships models to Europe and some Asian countries. Annual deliveries rose 87% to 936,172 vehicles, with the company aiming for 50% annual growth. Tesla's market capitalization surpassed $1 trillion in October and shares gained 50% last year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks begin 2022 with mild gains on trade data boost
summary: South Korean shares closed higher on their first trading day of 2022, with the Kospi index rising 11.12 points, or 0.37%, to 2,988.77, driven by solid trade and PMI data. December exports data expanded 18.3% year-over-year to a record $60.7 billion, while factory activity expanded at its fastest pace in 3 months. Foreign investors bought net 270.4 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won weakened. The benchmark 10-year yield rose 6.6 basis points to 2.321%.

site_title: CDW wins contract from Razer-backed Loupedeck, reports recovery in 2021
summary: CDW Holding, a Japanese-managed precision components specialist, has secured a contract with Loupedeck, a Finnish tech start-up backed by Razer, to produce Loupedeck Live, a digital input video-editing console. The deal marks a recovery in orders from major customers in CDW's equipment manufacturing business, with shipment volumes nearly tripling in 2021 compared to 2020. CDW's OEM subsidiary in Hong Kong is credited for overcoming global semiconductor challenges and setting up operations in Thailand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP rose 7.2% in 2021, driven by strong Q4 growth, which may pose upside risks to 2022 forecasts. Private home prices and HDB resale prices increased 5% and 3.2% respectively in Q4 2021. The MAS and CAD are investigating Samtrade FX, an online trading platform, for potential offences. CDW won a contract from Razer-backed Loupedeck, while Kingsmead Properties' deal with mm2 Asia's cinema business fell through due to Omicron uncertainty. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.34% higher on its first trading day of the year.

site_title: MAS, CAD investigating online trading platform Samtrade FX; 3 arrested
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) are investigating online trading platform Samtrade FX for potential offences under local securities laws. Three men aged 31-36 have been arrested in connection with the probe, which was launched on December 28, 2021. Samtrade FX is being looked into for carrying out irregular trading activities without a required capital markets services (CMS) licence. The platform's Singapore entities are also under investigation, with the parent company already on the MAS Investor Alert List since July 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin 2022 on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began 2022 on a positive note, rising 0.48% to 23,510.54, despite concerns over the Omicron virus variant. This follows a healthy finish to 2021. Mainland Chinese markets remain closed due to a holiday. The Hang Seng Index saw a 112.87-point increase.

site_title: Omicron wave imminent as cases climb to 17% of Covid-19 infections in Singapore: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that the Omicron variant now accounts for 17% of Covid-19 cases, signaling an imminent Omicron wave. With around 1,200 active cases, 20 people in intensive care, and low deaths, the recent Delta variant wave has subsided. Vaccination efforts continue, with 87% of the population having received two doses and 41% having received booster shots. Ong urged the public to remain vigilant and exercise civic responsibility as new vaccines are expected to arrive this month.

site_title: India's Dec jobless rate rises to 7.9%: CMIE
summary: India's December unemployment rate rose to 7.9%, up from 7.0% in June, according to data from the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE). The increase is attributed to the rise in coronavirus cases and restrictions in many states. This marks a higher unemployment rate in the country since the June figure.

site_title: Indian factories end 2021 on strong note despite dip in momentum
summary: India's manufacturing sector ended 2021 on a strong note, with growth in new orders and output remaining sharp despite losing momentum in December. The Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 55.5 in December, above the 50 mark that separates growth from contraction for a sixth month. Elevated price pressures remain a concern, potentially leading to earlier monetary policy tightening by the Reserve Bank of India. Employment slipped into contractionary territory, but firms maintained solid output and kept selling prices unchanged to boost sales.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MCT, MNACT, mm2 Asia, China Everbright, Hanwell, Koh Brothers Eco
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market include a proposed merger between Mapletree Commercial Trust and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, a sale and purchase agreement lapse for mm2 Asia, and China Everbright Water securing a waste water treatment project. Other notable announcements include Hanwell's acquisition of CKH Food Trading and 123 Mart, and Koh Brothers Eco Engineering's preliminary offer document for an initial public offering.

site_title: Hong Kong airport targets raising US$4b in bond deal: sources
summary: Hong Kong's Airport Authority plans to raise up to $4 billion in a multi-tranche dollar bond offering, mandated to 22 banks, according to sources. The move comes as the airport faces increased flight bans due to pandemic restrictions. A 5-year green bond is proposed, issued under the authority's Sustainable Finance Framework, following a HK$4.4 billion loss in the 2020-2021 financial year. Investor demand for the deal will be assessed starting Tuesday, marking a test of investor sentiment.

site_title: Australian PM Morrison feels 'totally fine' days after Covid-19 exposure
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison reported feeling "totally fine" after being exposed to a positive Covid-19 case at a press conference. Despite being advised by the New South Wales state health department to be on alert, Morrison said he hasn't taken a test and is not symptomatic. The country is experiencing a surge in virus numbers, with 20,795 new cases reported in New South Wales on Monday, and hospitalizations reaching a new high.

site_title: South Korea factory activity quickens but output, export orders shrink: PMI
summary: South Korea's factory activity expanded at the fastest pace in three months in December, with the IHS Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 51.9. However, production and export orders shrank due to supply chain constraints, including semiconductor chip shortages and weak demand. New orders grew at a faster pace, driven by domestic demand, but export orders fell for the first time since September 2020. Economists remain cautious, citing the need for significant improvements in global supply chains for manufacturing to recover.

site_title: Singapore's GDP up 7.2% in 2021; strong Q4 growth brings upside risks to 2022 forecasts
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 7.2% in 2021, exceeding the official forecast of 7% and the fastest full-year growth since 2010. The strong Q4 growth of 5.9% is driven by a rebound from 2020's record 5.4% contraction and supported by manufacturing and services sectors. Economists expect a solid economic recovery in 2022, with upside risks, as high vaccination rates and favorable export and manufacturing sectors are expected to support further reopening.

site_title: Asia: Markets get 2022 off to mixed start in thinned trade
summary: Asian markets began the year with a mixed start, driven by improved regional economic data and concerns over the Omicron variant, inflation, and central bank stimulus removal. Factory activity picked up in countries such as South Korea, Taiwan, and the Philippines, while Singapore's economy expanded 7.2% in 2021. However, Hong Kong's tech sector dragged down gains, and news of China Evergrande's trading suspension weighed on sentiment. Oil prices edged up ahead of Opec's meeting to discuss output plans.

site_title: Sudan's Hamdok quits as prime minister after failing to restore civilian government
summary: Sudanese Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok has resigned after failing to restore a civilian government six weeks after returning to his post. Hamdok cited the need for a roundtable discussion to produce a new agreement for Sudan's transition to democracy. Protests against the military takeover continue, with at least two people killed and a death toll of 56 since the October coup. Hamdok's resignation throws Sudan's political future into uncertainty, three years after an uprising led to the overthrow of long-time leader Omar al-Bashir.

site_title: South Korea's Moon vows fresh push for peace in final months as president
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in vowed to make another push for peace in his final months as president, despite North Korea's Kim Jong Un showing little interest in reciprocating. Moon reiterated his goal of institutionalizing sustainable peace and an end-of-war declaration to ease North Korean suspicions. He expressed hope to continue talks, despite opposition candidate Yoon Suk-yeol advocating a tougher line against Pyongyang. Moon's efforts have made little progress since signing landmark agreements with Kim in 2018, and his role as an intermediary between Washington and Pyongyang has diminished.

site_title: Hot stock: mm2 Asia up 9.8% after deal to sell cinema business falls through
summary: Shares of mm2 Asia rose 9.8% after its deal to sell its cinema business to Kingsmead Properties fell through. The company had agreed to sell its cinema business for $84.8 million, but Kingsmead Properties instead chose to exchange its deposit into newly issued shares. This comes after mm2 paused its spin-off and IPO of its cinema business due to compliance issues. The company had also considered merging its cinema business with Golden Village cinemas.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed on Monday for holidays
summary: Financial markets in Australia, China, Japan, New Zealand, and Thailand are closed on Monday for public holidays. The article also discusses various stock market news, including a mandatory offer for PSC shares, stocks to watch, and the impact of US-EU trade talks on the market. Additionally, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Troubled Evergrande suspends share trading again
summary: Evergrande, a Chinese property giant, has suspended trading of its shares for the second time, citing no reason. The firm is struggling to repay $300 billion in liabilities, having become ensnared in Beijing's deleveraging crackdown on China's bloated property sector. Evergrande was previously labelled as being in default by international ratings firms, and its shares have plummeted following missed payments. The company has repeatedly attempted to deliver unfinished projects and pay off debts, but its struggles continue, with the provincial government of Guangdong overseeing its debt restructuring process.

site_title: RCEP could lift Thailand's agri-based sectors: Maybank Securities report
summary: Thailand's agri-based sectors could benefit from the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) due to significant tariff reductions, according to a Maybank Securities report. Companies such as Tipco Foods, Malee Group, and Wice Logistics are expected to benefit from lower tariffs on exports to South Korea, Japan, and China. Analysts predict that RCEP will simplify logistics procedures, making it easier for companies like Kerry Express to move cargoes across borders. However, concerns remain about potential flooding of cheap manufactured and agricultural goods from China, which could pose difficulties for domestic businesses.

site_title: Private home prices climb 5%, HDB resale prices up 3.2% in Q4 2021: flash data
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 5% in Q4 2021, with landed homes increasing 3.7% and non-landed homes 5.4%. This is the fastest annual growth since 2010. HDB resale prices also surged 3.2% in Q4, with resale flat prices climbing 12.5% for the full year. Analysts expect private residential property prices to decline in 2022 due to new cooling measures, but HDB resale prices may continue to grow at a slower pace.

site_title: Willy Shee replaces Lew Syn Pau as lead independent director at Golden Agri-Resources
summary: Golden Agri-Resources announced changes to its board, with Willy Shee replacing Lew Syn Pau as lead independent director, effective January 1. Shee, a former chairman of Asia at CBRE, will serve alongside Soh Hang Kwang, a former vice-chairman at Rabobank. Both Shee and Soh will also join the audit committee, nominating committee, and remuneration committee. The changes come after Lew Syn Pau and Foo Meng Kee resigned as non-executive independent directors on December 31, after serving over 9 years.

site_title: Arrests, clashes in Netherlands Covid-19 protest
summary: Thousands of protesters in Amsterdam defied authorities to oppose coronavirus restrictions, leading to clashes and 30 arrests. The protest, despite being banned, saw protesters chant "This is Holland! Power to the people!" Four police officers were injured, and 30 protesters were arrested for various offenses. The restrictions, announced by Prime Minister Mark Rutte on December 18, include lockdowns and limited outdoor gatherings until January 14.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open after GDP data; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% on Monday, following the release of GDP data showing a 5.9% growth in the fourth quarter of 2021, bringing full-year growth to 7.2%. The STI gained 4.93 points to 3,128.61 as 59.6 million securities worth S$25.4 million changed hands. Local banks also rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC advancing 0.3%, 0.1%, and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: Goldman Sachs asks US employees to work from home until Jan 18
summary: Goldman Sachs is asking its eligible US employees to work from home until January 18, amid the spread of the Omicron variant. The company will maintain its offices with Covid-19 safety protocols, including vaccine and booster requirements, bi-weekly testing, and mandatory masks. This move follows other financial firms in altering their return-to-office plans due to the uncertainty. Goldman Sachs had previously required vaccinations for staff and visitors, and weekly Covid-19 tests.

site_title: Mapletree merger not win-win for MCT unitholders
summary: A proposed merger between Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) has raised concerns among MCT unit holders. Despite MCT's steady growth, MNACT has underperformed, with a 1.9% annual distribution increase compared to MCT's 4.8%. MNACT also has higher gearing and underperformed MCT's listed units. The merger is being presented as a win-win, but critics argue it is a premium deal for MCT holders to acquire an underperforming trust.

site_title: Oil starts new year on positive note, pandemic worries curb gains
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, January 3, 2022, as the market started 2022 on a positive note, despite concerns over the rapidly spreading Covid-19 pandemic limiting gains. Brent crude increased 67 cents to $78.45 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 77 cents to $75.98 a barrel. Oil analysts have lowered their price forecasts for 2022 due to the Omicron variant and supply glut, with Brent crude expected to average $73.57 a barrel and US crude averaging $71.38 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Monday as the market kicked off 2022 on a positive note, although concerns over demand waning due to rapidly spreading Covid-19 pandemic limited gains.

site_title: A year after Capitol riot, Americans fear for their democracy: polls
summary: A year after the US Capitol riot, Americans are deeply concerned about the health of their democracy, with two-thirds believing it's threatened and a third saying violence against the government can sometimes be justified. Pride in democracy has dropped from 90% to 54%. President Biden has promised to overcome the seemingly irreconcilable views dividing American society. Trump supporters continue to believe he's not the legitimately elected president, and 60% hold him responsible for the Capitol invasion.

site_title: Biden told Ukraine leader US will 'respond decisively' if Russia invades: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden assured Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky that the US will "respond decisively" if Russia invades Ukraine. In a phone call, Biden reaffirmed the US commitment to Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. This comes after Biden warned Russian President Vladimir Putin of severe consequences if Moscow invades Ukraine. The US and its European allies accuse Russia of threatening Ukraine with a new invasion, with 100,000 Russian troops massed near the border.

site_title: Hot stocks: MCT down 3%, MNACT rises as much as 3.6% on proposed merger
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) have proposed a merger, expected to create one of Asia's largest Reits. MNACT's units surged 3.6% to a 21-month high, while MCT's units dropped 3% to a 14-month low. The combined entity, Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), will have a theoretical market capitalization of S$10.5 billion and is expected to be accretive to distribution per unit and net asset value for both MCT and MNACT unitholders. Analysts predict benefits from increased assets under management, diversified growth, and improved cost of capital, but also note potential risks and dilution.

site_title: US air travel still messy, with another 2,400 flights scrapped
summary: US air travel continued to face disruptions on January 2, 2022, with over 2,400 flights canceled due to bad weather or staffing issues related to the Omicron coronavirus variant. Southwest Airlines canceled 400 flights on Sunday, with more predicted for Monday as a winter storm moves eastward. The cancellations have caused frustration among travelers, with many experiencing long wait times and difficulty rescheduling flights. The US is not alone in experiencing travel disruptions, with 4,079 flights canceled globally over the weekend.

site_title: Hong Kong independent news outlet shuts down to 'ensure safety'
summary: Hong Kong's independent news outlet CitizenNews announced it will shut down to ensure safety, three days after the national security police raided another independent online news outlet. CitizenNews, founded in 2017, had absorbed journalists from other outlets amid tightening control over Hong Kong's local press. The outlet cited a deteriorating media environment and the need to protect its staff, following the raid on StandNews and the forced shutdown of pro-democracy Apple Daily. CitizenNews' co-founders are former presidents of the Hong Kong Journalists' Association, one of the last professional groups to remain standing.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 319.5m yuan wastewater treatment project in Shandong
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a 319.5 million yuan wastewater treatment project in Shandong, China, with a concession period of 30 years. The project, valued at S$67.8 million, will treat municipal wastewater for 50,000 cubic meters per day and expand the company's presence in Shandong Province. This deal boosts China Everbright Water's aggregate water treatment capacity to over 1.5 million cubic meters per day, and the company plans to raise investment funds via internal resources and external financing.

site_title: Singapore's GDP grew 7.2% in 2021, on the back of 5.9% Q4 growth
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 7.2% in 2021, exceeding the official forecast of 7% due to strong manufacturing sector growth, driven by electronics and precision engineering. The Q4 growth rate was 5.9%, higher than economists' expectations of 5.1%. The manufacturing sector expanded 12.8% in 2021, while the construction sector grew 2% in Q4. The services sector, led by the information and communications, finance and insurance, and professional services groups, grew 4.6% overall. Economists revise their 2022 GDP growth forecast to 5.5% due to the stronger-than-expected 2021 growth.

site_title: Twitter blocks US Republican lawmaker account over Covid-19 claims
summary: US Republican congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene's personal Twitter account was permanently suspended for violating the platform's Covid-19 misinformation policy. Greene, a supporter of Donald Trump, had made false claims about the 2020 election and the pandemic. Twitter had previously sanctioned her account, but this was the first permanent suspension. Greene claimed Twitter is an enemy to America and vowed to show America that it's not needed. The move follows Twitter's strike system, which imposes escalating sanctions for repeated violations.

site_title: Euro marks 20 eventful years
summary: The euro marked 20 years since its introduction, overcoming initial doubts and concerns to be used by 340 million people in 19 countries. European leaders praised the currency, with Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen calling it a "true symbol for the strength of Europe" and ECB President Christine Lagarde describing it as a "beacon of stability and solidity".

site_title: Opec+ report sees short-lived, mild impact from Omicron variant
summary: Opec+ expects the Omicron coronavirus variant to have a mild and short-lived impact on the oil market, keeping the door open for a further increase in output. The Joint Technical Committee report notes a steady economic outlook in both advanced and emerging economies. Opec+ is set to discuss increasing output targets by 400,000 barrels per day in February, following a meeting on Monday to appoint a new secretary general. Oil demand forecasts for 2021 and 2022 remain unchanged, with 5.7 million and 4.2 million barrels per day expected, respectively.

site_title: British bank Santander UK makes US$175 million in mistaken payments
summary: Santander UK mistakenly paid approximately $175 million to 75,000 customers on Christmas Day, including those from rival banks. The bank is seeking assistance from other financial institutions to recover the lost funds. The incident highlights the potential risks of mistaken payments in the banking industry.

site_title: mm2 Asia's deal with Kingsmead Properties for sale of cinema business falls through
summary: mm2 Asia's deal to sell its cinema business to Kingsmead Properties has fallen through due to uncertainty surrounding the Omicron variant. Kingsmead Properties exercised its exchange right, exchanging its S$6 million deposit for 75 million new mm2 shares at a share price of S$0.08 per share. The proposed sale was to be completed by Dec 31, but the Omicron variant's impact on investor appetite has led to the deal's collapse. mm2 Asia remains optimistic about the recovery of its cinema business, with its founder and executive chairman welcoming Kingsmead Properties as a strategic shareholder.

site_title: Chinese superfan spends thousands on Olympic souvenir obsession
summary: Chinese superfan Zhang Wenquan has amassed an estimated 5,000 Olympic souvenirs, spending at least 400,000 yuan (S$84,800) on them, with a collection displayed in local schools and universities ahead of the 2022 Winter Games in Beijing. Zhang, a 35-year-old construction firm worker, developed his passion for collecting souvenirs after working as an official volunteer at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, where China won 48 gold medals. He continues to scour the internet for rare items and has even received donations from Olympic volunteers, with his collection now becoming a local attraction.

site_title: Utilities stocks test new resistance high
summary: Utilities stocks reached a new resistance high, with the SPDR Utilities ETF (XLU) experiencing a strong comeback after a Covid-19 sell-off in 2020. A double rising wedge pattern suggests a potential longer-term correction, as the sector is heavily dependent on interest rate policies. Despite this, funds may flow into finance, technology, and industrial sectors due to inflationary pressure.

site_title: Floods hit seven states in Malaysia, thousands evacuated
summary: Malaysia is experiencing severe flooding in seven states, affecting over 125,000 people, with thousands evacuated and 8,727 taking shelter at relief centers. Fifty people have died, and two remain missing. The floods, which started on Dec 17, have strained emergency services, and the government has allocated RM1.4 billion in cash aid and relief. The country is seeking US$3 million from the UN Green Climate Fund to adapt to climate change.

site_title: Singtel appoints 2 new non executive, independent directors
summary: Singtel has appointed two new non-executive and independent directors, Yong Hsin Yue and John Arthur, effective January 1. Yong, a 50-year-old Singaporean, has a direct interest in the company and previously served as managing director of Kuok (Singapore) and general manager of Wilmar International. Her appointment brings the company's total number of independent directors to four.

site_title: Tech industry group calls for better access to talent, public procurement chances for SMEs
summary: Singapore's Tech industry group, SGTech, has submitted 15 recommendations to the Ministry of Finance for Budget 2022, focusing on alleviating the industry's talent crunch and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The proposals include facilitating access to foreign talent, recognizing more qualifications, and setting up a digital transformation centre for SMEs. SGTech also recommends increasing government procurement opportunities for SMEs and providing stronger support for trade associations and chambers.

site_title: How Discord, born from an obscure game, became a social hub for young people
summary: Discord, initially created as a multiplayer game, became a social hub for young people after its chatting feature was turned into the sole product. In 2015, founder Jason Citron laid off game developers and rebranded the game, which initially had only 6 users. Despite initial uncertainty, Discord gained popularity, eventually becoming a leading platform for online communities and gaming. Today, it boasts millions of users worldwide, revolutionizing the way people connect and communicate online.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: A step by step guide to estate planning (Ep 110)
summary: BT Money Hacks, a podcast, released an episode on estate planning, providing a step-by-step guide for individuals. The episode aims to help viewers navigate the process of creating a comprehensive estate plan. Key takeaways include understanding wills, trusts, and probate, as well as tax implications and planning for dependents. By following these steps, individuals can ensure their assets are distributed according to their wishes and minimize potential tax liabilities.

site_title: AEM's non-exec, non-independent director redesignated to lead ID as stake gets 'diluted to below 5%'
summary: AEM Holdings announced the redesignation of non-executive and non-independent director James Toh to lead independent director, effective January 1, due to his stake in the company being diluted below 5% following the allotment of 26.8 million shares to Venezio Investments. Toh's new role comes after his stake in the company decreased, affecting his independence and influence.

site_title: Dubai seeks to offset Covid-19 impact with budget of 60b dirhams
summary: Dubai has unveiled a budget of 60 billion dirhams to offset the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and drive economic growth. The spending plan allocates 42% for infrastructure and transportation, and 30% for social development, with revenue expected to come mainly from fees and taxes. The move comes as Dubai continues to host the Expo 2020 exhibition and has seen a sharp improvement in business conditions, driven by a rebound in new orders and tourism.

site_title: Gold muted as weaker dollar counters rate hike bets
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,797.94 per ounce as a weaker dollar countered concerns about potential interest rate hikes. The dollar index moved away from multi-month peaks, reducing bets on faster rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. Analysts at Goldman Sachs and Bank of America Merrill Lynch still expect multiple rate hikes this year, but the weaker dollar has reduced the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, supporting gold prices.

site_title: The 4 'L's of Singapore politics in 2021: livestreaming, lies, lousy schools and long runway
summary: Singapore's 2021 politics were marked by uncertainty, with the leadership transition of Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and the appointment of Lawrence Wong as Finance Minister. The event led to a Cabinet reshuffle and raised questions about the future leadership of the ruling People's Action Party (PAP). Livestreaming of Parliament proceedings also became a new feature, with MPs engaging in verbal sparring and controversies such as Raeesah Khan's lie in Parliament. The incident damaged the opposition Workers' Party (WP), and the outcome of the situation remains uncertain.

site_title: What should you do when contrarians disrupt?
summary: Contrarians who think differently can add value to an organization, even if their ideas seem unrelated to the current discussion. When a quiet employee suddenly speaks, their ideas often fall on deaf ears, leading to awkward silences and the conversation resuming as if nothing was said. This phenomenon, known as groupthink, can stifle innovation and creativity. Embracing contrarian views and actively seeking out diverse perspectives can help organizations stay adaptable and thrive in uncertain times. By doing so, companies can foster a more inclusive and innovative culture.

site_title: EU drafts plan to label gas and nuclear investments as green
summary: The European Union is drafting plans to label some natural gas and nuclear energy projects as "green" investments, amid a year-long battle over climate-friendliness. The European Commission aims to propose rules in January on whether gas and nuclear projects will be included in the EU's "sustainable finance taxonomy". This move is seen as a compromise between EU governments, which have been divided on the issue. The labeling plan is expected to be announced in January, with the goal of providing clarity on what constitutes a green investment in the EU.

site_title: State firm buys China South City stake in developer bailout
summary: A Chinese state-run enterprise, Shenzhen SEZ Construction and Development Group Co, has agreed to purchase a 29% stake in struggling developer China South City Holdings Ltd for HK$1.91 billion (S$328 million). This move is part of Beijing's efforts to limit the fallout from a widening debt crisis in the country's real estate industry. The purchase is expected to provide financial support to the developer and stabilize the market.

site_title: This was the year of the super billionaire, with US$1 trillion in gains
summary: In 2021, the world's 500 richest individuals saw their collective wealth surge by over $1 trillion, driven by soaring equity markets and rising asset values. However, some billionaires faced significant losses, including Bill Hwang, who lost $20 billion in days. The year was marked by extreme scrutiny, with Elon Musk's wealth reaching levels comparable to John D. Rockefeller's and Bill Gates facing divorce allegations under a Jeffrey Epstein cloud. Despite the challenges, 2021 proved a good time to be a multibillionaire.

site_title: China developers confront a US$197b challenge in January
summary: China's property developers face a US$197 billion challenge in January, with maturing bonds, coupons, and deferred wages to pay. The fund holds a heavier weighting in 12 fossil-fuel stocks than the S&P 500, and charges investors higher fees on average than non-sustainably labeled counterparts. site_title: 3 monster years for the S&P 500 set a towering bar for January

Despite this, some companies downgraded their growth expectations, including Grab and Sats, while others saw pay hikes, such as Citigroup's target of a 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Rio's low-key New Year generates 50% less trash
summary: Rio de Janeiro's sanitation service collected 320 tonnes of trash on New Year's Eve, 50% less than the annual average from 2018-2020. The city's low-key celebrations, due to the pandemic and rainy weather, resulted in significantly less waste, with 167 tonnes collected in Copacabana. This marked a significant improvement over pre-pandemic levels, with nearly 5,000 trash collectors completing the clean-up by 9am.

site_title: DBS, UOB to continue offering physical tokens on request
summary: DBS and UOB have announced they will continue to offer physical security tokens to customers on request, following OCBC's decision to halt its hardware token phase-out amid rising online fraud. DBS had previously phased out physical tokens in April 2021, while UOB stopped issuing them automatically in 2018. Digital tokens, integrated within mobile banking apps, are considered equally secure and provide an added layer of security via two-factor authentication. Both banks urge customers to remain vigilant and protect their credentials and devices from scams.

site_title: Making culture great again
summary: Low Sze Wee, a 52-year-old Singaporean, transitioned from a law career to a prominent role in the arts, becoming the CEO of the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre (SCCC) in 2018. He initially worked as a weekend docent at the Singapore Art Museum, where he discovered his passion for art research and sharing his love for art. Low has spent over two decades in the arts, curating exhibitions and promoting the unique Singapore Chinese identity. He emphasizes the importance of unity in diversity and the impact of cultural interaction on Singapore's multicultural society.

site_title: Smart connections with Louis Vuitton
summary: Louis Vuitton's latest smartwatch, the Tambour Horizon Light Up, boasts a custom-designed operating system and a range of innovative features, including a built-in heart-rate monitor and 24 LED lights that create a mesmerizing glow-in-the-dark animation. The watch can pair with both iOS and Android devices, offering users a highly customizable experience with interchangeable watch faces and a seamless integration with the Louis Vuitton Connect app. Available in three models, the Tambour Horizon Light Up is priced at S$4,300 (excluding strap).

summary: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CGSI) downgraded Grab's stock rating to 'hold', citing expected earnings growth to slow in the second half of the year. Despite this, CGSI remains optimistic about the company's long-term prospects. The downgrade comes as Grab continues to navigate the competitive ride-hailing market and faces increasing competition from other players. The bank expects Grab's earnings to grow, but at a slower pace than previously anticipated. The decision reflects a cautious approach to the company's prospects, but CGSI maintains a neutral stance on Grab's stock.

site_title: Unique stays with the best views in Australia
summary: Australia is reopening its borders to Singaporeans, allowing for epic adventures across iconic views and gourmet experiences. Top picks include unique stays in the Blue Mountains, Orange, South Coast, Victoria, and the Australian Capital Territory. Highlights include the Secret Treehouse in Blue Mountains, Borrodell Vineyard in Orange, Clifftop Solitude villa in Victoria, and Mount Majura Vineyard in Canberra. Visitors can enjoy gourmet meals, wine tastings, and immersive experiences such as stargazing, truffle hunting, and exploring the Great Ocean Road. With various regions opening up on subsequent dates, now is the time to plan a soul-stirring journey across Australia.

summary: The Credit Guarantee Scheme India (CGSI) has downgraded its rating on Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowdown in earnings growth in the second half of the year. The downgrade comes after Grab reported strong earnings growth in the first half, but the CGSI anticipates a decline in revenue and profitability in the latter half. Despite this, the CGSI maintains a 'hold' rating, indicating a stable outlook for the company. The downgrade highlights the challenges faced by Grab in maintaining its growth momentum in the Indian market. No specific timeline or target price was mentioned.

site_title: Born into the circle of life
summary: Chef Zor Tan, 35, is set to open his highly-anticipated restaurant Born in Singapore, marking a new chapter in his culinary journey. Tan, who rose to Michelin stardom under Andre Chiang, has a 12-year journey of hard work and dedication, from starting in the lowest ranks at Jaan to earning two Michelin stars with Chiang's Sichuan Moon in Macau. Born, named to represent creative rebirth and the circle of life, will merge French and Chinese cuisine, reflecting Tan's heritage. With an estimated S$3 million investment, Tan aims to guide young chefs and share his vision.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on tech drag
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.21% to 36,722.60, amid a rise in US Treasury yields and a drag on technology-heavy growth stocks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the Nasdaq dropping 0.48% to 15,547.16. The decline was attributed to a rise in US Treasury yields, which hit technology stocks.
